ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Officers, election or appointment, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-45; terms of officers generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-46. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-54. - Request for outside employment. 
    Employees of the city shall not accept employment or do any work for an employer other than the city during the time the employee is employed by the city without first obtaining from the head of the department for which he works a clearance that the proposed work will not interfere with the employee's efficiency in the discharge of his duties with the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-1; Code 1995, § 2-46) 
Sec. 2-55. - Investigation of request; determination. 
(a)  Heads of departments of the city shall investigate requests of employees within their department who seek permission to work for employers other than the city. If upon investigation they find that the proposed work will not interfere with the efficiency of the employee's discharge of his duties with the city, they shall give a written authorization to such employee. 
(b)  If the head of a department determines that such proposed work will interfere with the efficiency of the employee in the discharge of his duties with the city, or the head of a department determines at any time that work that has been cleared for the employee does in fact interfere with the efficiency of the employee in the discharge of his duties with the city, he shall advise the employee. After such notice, no city employee shall accept or do such work for an employer other than the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-2; Code 1995, § 2-47) 
Sec. 2-56. - Dismissal. 
    Any employee who accepts or does work for an employer other than the city without first clearing with his department head, or who is notified by his department head to discontinue work for an employer other than the city and fails to do so, may be dismissed as an employee of the city by the head of the department. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3; Code 1995, § 2-48) 
Sec. 2-57. - Compensation for lost time. 
    No money shall be paid to any official or employee of the city for any time lost by such official or employee from the actual discharge of his duties as such official or employee, except as may be provided by the rules and regulations of the county personnel board, or by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 2-5; Code 1995, § 2-49) 
Sec. 2-58. - Strikes or slowdowns. 
    Any strike of employees of the city, or any concerted stoppage or slowdown of work by employees of the city, is prohibited. No employee of the city shall participate in any strike or concerted stoppage or slowdown of work against the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-6; Code 1995, § 2-50) 
Sec. 2-59. - Discharge of employees for striking. 
    Any person who violates section 2-58 shall be immediately discharged from his employment with the city as of the date of such violation and shall not be re-employed by the city for a period of one year thereafter. Any employee of the city who has attained permanent status within the meaning of the applicable civil service law and who violates this section shall be discharged in accordance with the provisions of such law. 
(Code 1973, § 2-7; Code 1995, § 2-51) 
Sec. 2-60. - Picketing. 
    No person, group of persons, association, corporation or union shall picket, or cause, aid, abet or participate in, picketing of the city, or of the city hall or other buildings or place in or at which work or affairs of the city are customarily carried on or conducted, for the purpose of: 
(1)  Achieving or gaining any objective of any strike or concerted stoppage or slowdown of work prohibited by section 2-58; 
(2)  Coercing the city to grant or accede to any demand or request in respect of grievances or of wages or of employment or of hours or conditions or terms of employment of any employee or former employee of the city; 
(3)  Causing or inducing any person to cease work for the city or to refrain from working for the city; 
(4)  Notifying the public of a labor dispute or that the city or its city council or any officer thereof is unfair; or 
(5)  Anything in relation to any employee or former employee or prospective employee of the city or in relation to terms of employment with the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-8; Code 1995, § 2-52) 
Secs. 2-61-2-78. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CLERK AND TREASURER[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Clerk generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-100 et seq.; treasurer generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-120 et seq.; bond required, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-43-104, 11-43-120. 

Sec. 2-79. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section II of Ord. No. 3499, adopted July 16, 2013, repealed § 2-79 which pertained to offices of clerk and treasurer consolidated, and derived from the 1973 Code, § 2-23; and the 1995 Code, § 2-66. 
Sec. 2-80. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section II of Ord. No. 3499, adopted July 16, 2013, repealed § 2-80 which pertained to duties, and derived from the 1973 Code, § 2-24; and the 1995 Code, § 2-67. 
Sec. 2-81. - Designation of banking institutions. 
    The mayor shall, by letter to either the clerk and treasurer or the utilities manager, as may be proper, designate which banking institutions shall be used as the depository for any of the accounts of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-28; Code 1995, § 2-69) 
Sec. 2-82. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section II of Ord. No. 3499, adopted July 16, 2013, repealed § 2-82 which pertained to issuance of licenses, and derived from the 1973 Code, § 2-30; and the 1995 Code, § 2-70. 
Sec. 2-83. - Bond required; conditions. 
(a)  The clerk and treasurer shall give bond, with some guaranty or surety company as surety, in the amount of $10,000.00 for the faithful performance of his duties and against any fraudulent or dishonest act upon his part, and any wrongful abstraction or wilful misapplication done or participated in by him. 
(b)  The bond of the clerk and treasurer shall be conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties and against any fraudulent or dishonest act upon his part and any wrongful abstraction or wilful misapplication done or participated in by him. Neither the clerk and treasurer nor the surety on his bond shall be liable for any act or omission specifically authorized or directed by the city council in the result of which act or omission the clerk and treasurer has no personal pecuniary interest. Neither the clerk and treasurer nor the surety on his bond shall be liable for any loss of funds by reason of the failure of any depository in which he is authorized to deposit such funds by the provisions of this Code or any other ordinance of the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 2-26; Code 1995, § 2-71) 
Sec. 2-84. - Powers vested in two separate officials. 
    Offices of city clerk and city treasurer are vested in and imposed upon two separate officials with distinct powers and duties. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
DIVISION 2A. - CITY CLERK 

Sec. 2-85. - Powers and duties, generally. 
    The city clerk shall exercise the powers conferred and discharge the duties imposed upon the clerk by the laws of the State of Alabama and ordinances of the City of Bessemer, and is the administrative head of the municipal court clerk's office of the city under the direct supervision and control of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
Sec. 2-86. - Attendance at city council meetings; keeping of minutes; seal; absence of clerk. 
    The city clerk shall attend all meetings of the city council and shall record in a minute book all acts and proceedings of the city council, including a record of all votes or abstentions therefrom, when roll is called. The city clerk shall transcribe and maintain custody of all rules, ordinances, and resolutions adopted or passed by the city council. The clerk shall also have custody of the city seal. During the absence of the clerk the council may appoint some person to perform its duties. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
State Law reference- Clerk attending meetings, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-100. 
Sec. 2-87. - Ordinances and resolutions to be filed. 
    The city clerk shall file consecutively all ordinances and resolutions filed by the city council, in addition to recording in said minute book all ordinances and resolutions adopted by the city council. The date of their passage and approval shall appear therein and they shall be numbered. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
State Law reference- Recordation of ordinances, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-8. 
Sec. 2-88. - Custody of city records, etc; removal of such records, etc. 
    The clerk shall carefully preserve in his or her office all important books, papers, records, deeds, official bonds and documents of all kinds belonging to the city, but he or she may permit their temporary removal by authorized officers or agents of the city upon obtaining a receipt in accordance with laws of the State of Alabama and applicable city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
Sec. 2-89. - Custody and distribution of copies of City Code. 
    The clerk shall be the custodian of the City Code and all printed copies and he or she shall make distribution and sale of these copies in accordance with the regulations prescribed by the city council at [a] price to be determined by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
Sec. 2-90. - Loss, destruction, etc. of official records. 
    It shall be a misdemeanor for the clerk to destroy or negligently lose or permit to be destroyed, mutilated, altered or lost any official records of the city such as official bonds, ordinances or resolutions, contracts, etc. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
Sec. 2-91. - Claims and demands; issuance of warrants. 
    The clerk shall submit all claims, requisitions and demands against the city to the council at its next regular meeting for its approval, unless already provided by ordinance or resolution, and upon its being approved by the council and the passage of ordinances carrying it into effect when necessary, said clerk shall issue warrant on the city treasurer or director of finance for the amount of such claim, requisition or demand. Before issuing any warrant upon the treasurer, the clerk shall audit the claim, certify to its correctness and keep a record thereof, which record shall also show to what department or departments it is chargeable. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-101. 
Sec. 2-92. - Clerk to pay over city funds daily. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk to pay over daily to the director of finance or city treasurer, except Sundays, national holidays, all money coming into his or her hands. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
Sec. 2-93. - Additional duties; bond. 
    The clerk, in addition to these enumerated duties, shall perform any and all duties that may be required of him by ordinance or resolution. He shall give bond, with sureties, to be approved by the mayor, in such sum as the council may prescribe. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
Sec. 2-94. - Clerk to attest municipal contracts and affix seal; exceptions. 
    All written contracts or municipal obligations, including temporary loans and excluding purchases for ordinary current municipal needs, shall be attested by the clerk, to which he shall also affix the seal of the city. This section shall not apply to bond issues or attached interest coupons. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
Sec. 2-95. - Record of municipal obligations, contracts, etc. 
    It shall be the clerk's duty to keep a record of all municipal obligations, contracts and evidences of debt, names of all persons interested, dates of execution and of maturity, amounts involved and any other information pertaining thereto of general interest. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
Sec. 2-96. - Inventory of city property; listing evaluation of property. 
    It shall be the duty of the director of finance to prepare and keep on file for the information of city officials and the public a complete and up to date inventory of all the tangible property of the city, real and personal, including realty, houses, buildings, livestock, vehicles, tools, implements, machinery, scrapers, street cleaners, books, furniture, cells, fire equipment, hose, engines, hook and ladders, trucks, electrical apparatus, etc. In securing such inventory, the director of finance shall have the right to call upon any officer, agent or employee of the city for any desired information at the discretion of the mayor. The inventory shall also show the approximate value of each item. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
DIVISION 2B. - CITY TREASURER (DIRECTOR OF FINANCE) 

Sec. 2-97. - Designation. 
    The treasurer shall be designated as the director of finance. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
Sec. 2-98. - Powers and duties, generally. 
    The director of finance shall be the custodian of the funds of the municipality, keeping an accurate record of the funds of the several departments, and shall keep books showing accurately the financial condition of the city, and as follows: 
(1)  He shall pay out money only upon warrants drawn by the officers authorized by the applicable provisions of this title to draw warrants upon the treasurer, and when paid shall keep safely the warrants so drawn. Such warrants, approved by the mayor or such other person as the council may designate, except as otherwise provided in this section, shall be drawn by the clerk on the treasurer, the warrant showing to what department the same is to be charged. 
(2)  He shall keep a convenient set of books in which there shall be kept a separate account with each collecting officer of the city. He shall keep a separate account with each department for which a separate appropriation shall have been made, crediting the amount of the appropriation and charging warrants drawn against the same. 
(3)  He shall keep such other accounts as may be necessary to show the financial condition of the municipality and of each department thereof at all times. 
(4)  He shall not allow the amount appropriated for any item of expense to be drawn on for any other purpose. 
(5)  He shall not allow any warrant to be drawn unless sufficient funds actually be in the treasury to the credit of the fund upon which such warrant is drawn unless specifically authorized by an ordinance or by the mayor and is carefully itemized and shall have been examined, audited and approved. 
(6)  He shall keep a record of all warrants presented for payment which are unpaid for want of funds and shall pay them when funds are available in the order of their presentation. 
(7)  He shall collect and account for all monies due to the municipality or any department thereof and all monies owed shall be directly paid to the director of finance for depository into the treasury except as provided in this Code. 
(8)  He shall make report once a month or oftener if required by the council of the financial condition of the account of each department authorized to draw on the treasurer and shall make a quarterly statement, under oath, of the financial condition of the city or town to the council. 
(9)  He is the administrative head of the revenue department of the city under the direct supervision and control of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
Sec. 2-99. - Issuance of; form; and content of licenses. 
    The director of finance shall issue all licenses. Each license issued by the director of finance shall have designated therein by him the name of the person to whom it is issued, the name of the trade, business, profession or occupation to be followed, and shall authorize the licensee to engage in such business, trade, profession or occupation, and shall prescribe or designate the place which shall not be changed except by consent of the city council, which consent may be endorsed by the director of finance upon the license. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
Sec. 2-100. - Payment of city money generally. 
    All city vouchers or requisitions for the payment of city money shall be drawn by the director of finance, and on such vouchers he shall designate upon what fund it is drawn or against which department it is charged as set out in the annual budget. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § II, 7-16-2013) 
Secs. 2-101-2-109. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITY ATTORNEY 

Sec. 2-110. - Duties. 
    The city attorney shall discharge the duties imposed and exercise the powers conferred upon him by state statute, the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-10; Code 1995, § 2-81) 
Sec. 2-111. - Legal adviser. 
    The city attorney shall be the legal adviser, on all necessary questions, of the mayor, the city council and other city officers and employees in respect to city business, their official duties and all matters pertaining to the city's welfare and its rights and powers, insofar as they may be affected by the official acts of such officers. 
(Code 1973, § 2-11; Code 1995, § 2-82) 
Sec. 2-112. - Attendance at meetings; legislation. 
(a)  The city attorney shall attend such regular, special, or called meetings as he may be requested by the mayor to attend. When so attending, he shall advise the city council, or any member thereof, upon any legal matters pertaining to the officers or the interests of the city. 
(b)  He shall prepare such ordinances and resolutions as may be required of him and, when requested, advise the city council as to the legality, reasonableness and constitutionality of legislation pending before the city council or of enactments already adopted. 
(Code 1973, § 2-12; Code 1995, § 2-83) 
Sec. 2-113. - Written opinions required. 
    The city attorney shall, when requested, furnish written opinions or advice to any city official in respect to his official duties, insofar as the city may be affected. 
(Code 1973, § 2-13; Code 1995, § 2-84) 
Sec. 2-114. - Drafts of contracts and documents. 
    When directed by the city council, the city attorney shall prepare needed contracts, conveyances, documents, etc., for use by the city or its officers. He shall pass upon the legal sufficiency of all bonds of city officers, contracts and bonds of persons having dealings with the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-14; Code 1995, § 2-85) 
Sec. 2-115. - Prosecutions in municipal court. 
    When requested by the mayor, the city attorney shall attend the municipal court and prosecute cases pending in such court. 
(Code 1973, § 2-15; Code 1995, § 2-86) 
Sec. 2-116. - Prosecution of appeals. 
    The city attorney shall prosecute all cases appealed from the municipal court. 
(Code 1973, § 2-16; Code 1995, § 2-87) 
Sec. 2-117. - Recommendations to city council. 
    The city attorney shall make, from time to time, such suggestions or recommendations to the city council as may seem advisable and proper in reference to the enforcement, revision or modification of the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-18; Code 1995, § 2-88) 
Sec. 2-118. - Represents city in all suits in which city is party; compensation in addition to monthly retainer. 
    In all suits or proceedings, wherever pending, to which the city shall be a party, the city attorney, or an attorney selected by him with the consent of the city council, shall appear for and represent the city. For such representation the attorney representing the city shall be entitled to reasonable compensation as approved by the council. In such suits or proceedings, if the city attorney represents the city, the compensation paid to him shall be in addition to the monthly retainer paid to such attorney. 
(Code 1995, § 2-89; Ord. No. 1942, § 1, 6-22-1976; Ord. No. 2065, § 1, 10-2-1979) 
Sec. 2-119. - Limitation of authority-Settling suits. 
    In any suit brought against the city for personal injuries or property damage, the city attorney shall have the authority to consent to judgment therein against the city without any approval other than his own in an amount not exceeding $4,000.00. With his approval and that of the mayor and one other councilmember he may settle in an amount not exceeding $7,500.00. With the approval of the mayor and all members of the council he may settle in any amount. 
(Code 1995, § 2-90; Ord. No. 1995, § 1, 11-15-1977) 
Sec. 2-120. - Same-Making compromises. 
    With no approval other than his own, the city attorney may compromise for any amount not exceeding $4,000.00 any claim against the city for personal injury or property damage which has not yet been put to suit. With the approval of the mayor and any other councilmember, the city attorney may compromise such claims in any amount not to exceed $7,500.00. 
(Code 1995, § 2-91; Ord. No. 1995, § 2, 11-15-1977) 
Sec. 2-121. - Release required for suits or compromises. 
    The city attorney shall take a proper release of the city in either case. 
(Code 1973, § 2-17; Code 1995, § 2-92; Ord. No. 1942, § 1, 6-22-1976; Ord. No. 2065, § 1, 10-2-1979) 
Secs. 2-122-2-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY ENGINEER 

Sec. 2-141. - Creation of office. 
    There is created the position of the city engineer. The city engineer shall be designated as the head of the engineering department of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-19; Code 1995, § 2-106) 
Sec. 2-142. - Duties. 
    The city engineer shall: 
(1)  Administer and operate the engineering department of the city. 
(2)  Advise the city council and the heads of other departments of the city on any engineering problem or any engineering matter affecting the interest of the city. 
(3)  Recommend, consult with and advise the planning and zoning commission on the development of a master plan for the orderly development of future public improvements and facilities. 
(4)  Cause to be prepared and recommend to the city council for approval all maps, drawings, profiles, specifications and engineering data for all public improvements of the city. 
(5)  Draft engineering data and specifications for public improvement ordinances, and prepare estimates of cost, notices to contractors for bids, construction contract technical data and assessment rolls and other cost data relative to the levy of public improvement assessments. 
(6)  Supervise construction work undertaken by the street department and certify to the city council when work authorized by the city under contract has been completed in accordance with plans and specifications. 
(7)  Prepare maps relative to annexations of the city, and such other maps as may be required to show the location of sewers, boundaries of the city and other data needed in the administration of the affairs of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-20; Code 1995, § 2-107) 
Sec. 2-143. - Qualifications. 
    An application for the position of city engineer shall present evidence: 
(1)  Of a BS degree in engineering from an accredited engineering college or university; 
(2)  That the applicant has been licensed and registered as an engineer in this state; and 
(3)  Any additional qualifications as may be prescribed in the notice for examinations issued by the county personnel board. 
(Code 1973, § 2-21; Code 1995, § 2-108) 
Sec. 2-144. - Appointment. 
    The position of city engineer shall be appointed by the mayor. 
(Code 1973, § 2-22; Code 1995, § 2-109) 
Secs. 2-145-2-171. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, COMMITTEES AND AUTHORITIES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-172-2-195. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Creation, composition, and powers of municipal planning commission, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-52-2-11-52-7; zoning commission generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-79. 

Sec. 2-196. - Creation. 
    There is created a planning and zoning commission with powers and duties as set by law that is designated and referred to as "The Planning and Zoning Commission of Bessemer, Alabama." 
(Code 1973, § 2-32; Code 1995, § 2-141) 
Sec. 2-197. - Composition; qualifications; appointment; terms of office; compensation; removal of members; vacancies. 
(a)  The commission shall consist of nine members: The mayor, one of the administrative officials of the city selected by the mayor, a member of the council to be selected by it as a member ex officio and six persons who shall be appointed by the mayor. If the mayor designates a person to sit in his place on the city planning commission, such person appointed shall serve during the term of the mayor, unless his original appointment shall be limited to a term certain of not less than 12 months at the time of appointment. 
(b)  All members of the commission shall serve without compensation, and the appointed members shall hold no other municipal office, except that one of such appointed members may be a member of the zoning board of adjustment or appeals. 
(c)  The term of the ex officio member shall correspond to the councilmember's official tenure. The term of each appointed member shall be six years or until his successor takes office. 
(d)  Members other than the member selected by the council may, after a public hearing, be removed by the mayor for inefficiency, neglect of duty or malfeasance in office. The council may, for like cause, remove the member selected by it. The mayor or council, as the case may be, shall file a written statement of reasons for such removal. 
(e)  Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the expiration of term shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor in the case of members selected or appointed by him, by the council in the case of the councilmember or other members selected by the council. 
(Code 1973, §§ 2-33-2-36; Code 1995, § 2-142) 
Sec. 2-198. - Organization; meetings. 
(a)  The planning and zoning commission shall meet and elect a chairman from amongst the appointed members and create and fill such other of its offices as it may determine. The term of the chairman shall be one year, with eligibility for reelection. 
(b)  The commission shall hold at least one regular meeting in each month. It shall adopt rules for transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations. Such record shall be a public record. 
(Code 1973, § 2-37; Code 1995, § 2-143) 
Sec. 2-199. - Master plan; contents; adoption of parts; amendments. 
(a)  The planning and zoning commission shall make and adopt a master plan for the physical development of the city, including any areas outside of its boundaries which, in the planning and zoning commission's judgment, bear relation to the planning of the city. 
(b)  The master plan, with the accompanying maps, plats, charts and descriptive matter shall show the commission's recommendations for the development of such territory, including, among other things: 
(1)  The general location, character and extent of streets, viaducts, subways, bridges, waterways, waterfronts, boulevards, parkways, playgrounds, squares, parks, aviation fields, and other public ways, grounds and open spaces. 
(2)  The general location of public buildings and other public property. 
(3)  The general location and extent of public utilities and terminals, whether publicly or privately owned or operated, for water, light, sanitation, transportation, communication, power and other purposes. 
(4)  The removal, relocation, widening, narrowing, vacating, abandonment, change of use or extension of any of the ways, grounds, open spaces, buildings, property, utilities or terminals already described in this section. 
(5)  A zoning plan for the control of the height, area, bulk, location and use of buildings and premises. 
(c)  As the work of making the whole master plan progresses, the commission may from time to time adopt and publish a part of the plan, any such part to cover one or more major sections or divisions of the city or one or more of the other functional matters to be included in the plan. 
(d)  The commission may from time to time amend, extend or add to the plan. 
(Code 1973, § 2-39; Code 1995, § 2-144) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-8. 
Sec. 2-200. - Survey and studies for master plan; purposes. 
(a)  In the preparation of the master plan, the planning and zoning commission shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of present conditions and future growth of the city and with due regard to its relation to neighboring territory. 
(b)  The master plan shall be made with the general purpose of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated, adjusted and harmonious development of the city and its environs which will, in accordance with present and future needs, best promote health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, including, among other things, adequate provision for traffic, the promotion of safety from fire and other dangers, adequate provisions for light and air, the promotion of the healthful and convenient distribution of population, the promotion of good civic design and arrangement, wise and efficient expenditure of public funds and the adequate provision of public utilities and other public requirements. 
(Code 1973, § 2-40; Code 1995, § 2-145) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-9. 
Sec. 2-201. - Powers and functions. 
(a)  The planning and zoning commission shall have power to promote public interest in and understanding of the master plan and, to that end, may publish and distribute copies of the plan or of any report and may employ such other means of publicity and education as it may determine. Members of the commission, when duly authorized by the commission, may attend city planning conferences or meetings of city planning institutes or hearings upon pending city planning legislation. The commission may, by resolution spread upon its minutes, pay the reasonable traveling expenses incident to such attendance. 
(b)  The commission shall, from time to time, recommend to the appropriate public officials programs for public structures and improvements and for the financing thereof. It shall be part of its duties to consult and advise with public officials and agencies, public utility companies, civic, educational, professional and other organizations, and with citizens with relation to the protecting or carrying out of the plan. The commission shall have the right to accept and use gifts for the exercise of its functions. All public officials shall, upon request, furnish to the commission, within a reasonable time, such available information as it may require for its work. 
(c)  The commission, its members, officers and employees, in the performance of their functions, may enter upon any land and make examinations and surveys and place and maintain necessary monuments and marks thereon. 
(d)  In general, the commission shall have such powers as may be necessary to enable it to fulfill its functions, promote city planning or carry out the purposes of this division. 
(e)  The planning and zoning commission shall have all powers granted to the zoning commission as prescribed by law. 
(Code 1973, § 2-42; Code 1995, § 2-146) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-6. 
Sec. 2-202. - Territorial jurisdiction of commission over subdivisions; approval of maps or plats. 
(a)  The territorial jurisdiction of the city planning commission over the subdivision of land shall include all land located in the city and all land lying within five miles of the corporate limits of the city and not located in any other municipality, except that in the case of any such nonmunicipal land also lying within five miles of another municipality having a planning commission, then the jurisdiction of each municipal planning commission shall terminate at a boundary line equidistant from the respective corporate limits of the municipalities. 
(b)  No map or plat of any subdivision shall be recorded, and no property shall be sold referenced to such map or plat, until and unless it has been first submitted to and approved by the planning commission. 
(Code 1973, §§ 2-43-2-46; Code 1995, § 2-147) 
State Law reference- Territorial jurisdiction generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-30. 
Sec. 2-203. - Adoption, publication and certification of subdivision regulations by commission; arrangement of streets, other ways; subdivision plat. 
(a)  The planning commission shall adopt regulations governing the subdivision of land within its jurisdiction. Such regulations may provide for the proper arrangement of streets in relation to other existing or planned streets and to the master plan, for adequate and convenient open spaces for traffic, utilities, access of firefighting apparatus, recreation, light and air and for the avoidance of congestion of population, including the minimum width and area of lots. Such regulations may include provisions as to the extent to which streets and other ways shall be graded and improved and to which water and sewer and other utility mains, piping or other facilities shall be installed as a condition precedent to the approval of the plat. The regulations or practice of the commission may provide for tentative approval of the plat previous to such installation, but any such tentative approval shall be revocable and shall not be entered on the plat. In lieu of the completion of such improvements and utilities prior to the final approval of the plat, the commission may accept a bond with surety to secure to the city the actual construction and installation of such improvements or utilities at a time and according to specifications fixed by or in accordance with the regulations of the commission. The city may enforce such bond by all appropriate legal and equitable remedies. 
(b)  All such regulations shall be published as provided by law for the publication of ordinances, and, before adoption, a public hearing shall be held thereon. A copy thereof shall be certified by the commission to the probate judge of the county in which the city and territory are located. 
(Code 1973, §§ 2-43-2-46; Code 1995, § 2-148) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-31. 
Secs. 2-204-2-229. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BUILDING CODE BOARD OF APPEALS 

Sec. 2-230. - Established. 
(a)  Purpose. The city hereby establishes a building code board of appeals to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the building official relative to the application and interpretation of the International Residential Code as adopted by the city. 
(1)  Appointment. Members shall be appointed to the building code board of appeals by the city council based on the individual's experience and training to pass on matters pertaining building construction. 
(2)  Composition. The building code board of appeals shall be comprised of three regular members, one alternate member and the city building official as an ex officio member. 
(3)  Term. Members of the building code board of appeals shall be appointed and serve for staggered terms of four years, three years, and two years. The ex officio member shall serve for the duration of their position as the city building official. The alternate member shall be appointed and serve for a four year term. 
(b)  Rules of procedure. The building code board of appeals shall adopt rules of procedures for conducting its business, and shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the appellate with a duplicate copy to the building official. 
(Res. No. 116-08, 2-19-2008) 
Secs. 2-231-2-253. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TREE COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-254. - Established. 
    There is established a tree commission and the mayor, with the concurrence of the council, shall appoint to the tree commission two members of the council, and the mayor shall serve as an ex officio member. The councilmember's term shall expire on the date that a newly elected council shall take office. In addition, the mayor shall appoint, with the concurrence of the council, six additional persons in the city. Following the initial appointments, two members shall be appointed annually to serve for a period of three years, and until their successors are appointed and qualified. Persons with special expertise may be added as needed who shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor. 
(Code 1995, § 2-161; Ord. No. 2612, § I, 2-1-1994) 
Sec. 2-255. - Meetings. 
    The commission shall provide in its minutes for regular periodic meetings. Meetings may also be called by the mayor, by either of the two councilmembers, or by any two of the commission members, after giving not less than three days' notice of the date, time and place of the special meeting. 
(Code 1995, § 2-162; Ord. No. 2612, § II, 2-1-1994) 
Sec. 2-256. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The tree commission shall: 
(1)  Make recommendations to the mayor and council on the needs of the city in connection with its tree planting program; 
(2)  Recommend the type and kind of trees to be planted upon city streets, parks and other public places within the city; 
(3)  Assist the mayor and council in providing information regarding the protection, maintenance, removal, and planting of trees on public property, and, where requested by the owner, on private property; 
(4)  Assist in making a master street plan by recommending the use and species of trees; 
(5)  Recommend to the mayor and council which trees are considered unwanted trees, and identify and recommend removal of dead, dying, diseased or insect infected trees; and 
(6)  Make studies and report back to the mayor and council with recommendations on matters concerning trees in the city. 
(Code 1995, § 2-163; Ord. No. 2612, § III, 2-1-1994) 
Secs. 2-257-2-275. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - BESSEMER AIRPORT AUTHORITY BOARD OF DIRECTORS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal and regional airport authorities, Code of Ala. 1975, § 4-3-1 et seq.; "Each member elected by the governing body of one of the authorizing subdivisions shall be a resident of the authorizing subdivision by whose governing body he was elected," Code of Ala. 1975, § 4-3-5. 

Sec. 2-276. - Created. 
    There is hereby created by the city council an airport board, a public body, which shall be known as the "Bessemer Airport Authority," sometimes referred to herein as the "airport authority." 
Sec. 2-277. - Jurisdiction. 
    The airport authority shall have jurisdiction and control over the Bessemer Airport, the municipal airport of the city. 
Sec. 2-278. - Membership. 
    The airport authority shall be governed by a board of directors consisting of five members. The members of the board of directors shall be nominated by the mayor and appointed by the city council. The board members shall be so appointed and designated to serve for terms as established by the city council. Vacancies occurring otherwise than by the expiration of the term shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the original appointment. Each airport authority board member shall hold office until a successor has been appointed. 
Sec. 2-279. - Qualifications. 
    At least three members of the Bessemer Airport Authority Board of Directors shall be bona fide residents and qualified electors of the City of Bessemer, Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 3335, § 1, 6-19-2007; Ord. No. 3493, § 1, 4-16-2013) 
Sec. 2-280. - Organization; powers; duties. 
    The airport authority shall be organized according to and vested with all of the powers and duties enumerated under state law. 
Secs. 2-281-2-308. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - EDUCATIONAL BUILDING AUTHORITY[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Educational building authorities generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 16-17-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-309. - Established. 
(a)  The name of the authority is and shall be the "Educational Building Authority of the City of Bessemer." 
(b)  The location of the principal office of the authority shall be at city hall. 
(c)  The authority shall have all powers conferred on corporations of like nature under state law, and any amendment thereof heretofore or hereafter made, and all other powers conferred upon corporation generally by the laws of Alabama, as heretofore or hereafter amended 
(d)  The authority shall be a nonprofit corporation and no part of the net earnings thereof shall inure to the benefit of any private person or entity of any nature whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 3306, §§ 1-6, 6-20-2006)

DIVISION 7. - BESSEMER BEAUTIFICATION BOARD[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3540, §§ 1-6, adopted Sept. 15, 2015, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as div. 7, §§ 2-321-2-326 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 2-321. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created the Bessemer Beautification Board. This board shall act in an advisory capacity to the mayor and council in regard to matters set out in this section. The board shall not have the right to sue or be sued or to have or to hold property, and all money or property accruing to it shall be vested in and be the money or property of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3540, § 1, 9-15-2015) 
Sec. 2-322. - Purpose. 
(a)  The beautification board shall study, investigate, develop and propose plans for improving the health, sanitation, safety and cleanliness of the city by beautifying the streets, highways, alleys, parks and other city property. 
(b)  The board shall recommend those plans as it deems proper to agencies of the city for the beautification of the city and otherwise promote public interest in the general improvement of the appearance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3540, § 2, 9-15-2015) 
Sec. 2-323. - Composition. 
(a)  The beautification board shall consist of any number of members as from time to time are appointed by the mayor; provided, that the membership shall not be less than seven nor more than 25 persons. 
(b)  Each member shall be appointed for a term of four years to begin immediately, or until the tenure of the mayor expires, whichever first appears. Each member shall be over 19 years of age or older. 
(c)  Appointments to fill a vacancy can be made for the unexpired term at any time by the mayor. A vacancy may occur through death, resignation, expiration of term, or four unexcused absences to regularly scheduled meetings upon which notice was forwarded to all board members within a reasonable time. 
(d)  The mayor, or his/her designee, a representative of the city council and a representative of the parks department shall be ex-officio non-voting members of the board. 
(Ord. No. 3540, § 3, 9-15-2015) 
Sec. 2-324. - Quorum and calling of meetings and keeping of minutes. 
(a)  A quorum shall consist of half of the board members serving at any time, plus one. 
(b)  The board shall hold regular meetings at city hall or a designated city facility once each month on a date determined by the board. Special meetings may be called by the chairperson upon five days' written notice to the members, which notice shall be sufficient if mailed, postage prepaid, addressed to each member, six days prior to such special meetings. Special meetings may also be held at any time upon written waiver of notice executed by each member of the board. 
(c)  The board is required to keep minutes of its meetings. Minutes will be deposited with the city clerk with duplicate copy maintained by the secretary. Upon certification of meeting minutes by a quorum at the next regularly scheduled meeting, the chairperson and secretary shall affix their signature and certify the same to the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 3540, § 4, 9-15-2015) 
Sec. 2-325. - Election of officers. 
(a)  A chairperson, vice-chairperson, and secretary shall be elected by the members of the board at the first regular meeting at which a quorum is present at the first meeting in September each year for a term of office to begin October 1 of such year and terminate on September 30 of the following year, except for the initial officers, which shall be elected at the first meeting at which a quorum is present after the establishment of the board. 
(b)  The chairperson or vice-chairperson, if chairperson is absent, shall officiate all meetings. Should the chairperson and vice-chairperson both become vacant or be absent from a regularly scheduled meeting, a quorum can appoint a member present to officiate for that meeting only. 
(c)  No officer shall serve in the same office for more than two consecutive terms. 
(d)  Any officer may be removed by unanimous consent of all members if an issue of moral turpitude or other conduct renders said officer unable to perform said duties. 
(Ord. No. 3540, § 5, 9-15-2015) 
Sec. 2-326. - No compensation of board members. 
(a)  The members of the beautification board and the officers thereof shall receive no compensation whatever for their services thereon, nor shall they receive compensation of per diem for attending meetings. 
(b)  The board shall have no authority to act for or to oblige the city or any official or agency thereof in any matters whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 3540, § 6, 9-15-2015) 
Secs. 2-327-2-336. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Competitive bids required for certain contracts, Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-50. 

Sec. 2-337. - Revenue department. 
    The revenue department of the clerk and treasurer's office shall have the following responsibilities: 
(1)  Enforce the city business license ordinance. 
(2)  Collect and account for all monies due the city, the responsibility for which is not vested in another agency or entity. 
(Code 1973, § 2-31; Code 1995, § 2-186)

ARTICLE VI. - MUNICIPAL-OWNED VEHICLES[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3549, § 1, adopted July 19, 2016, repealed art. VI in its entirety, and §§ 2-8 of said ordinance enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Former art. VI, §§ 2-471-2-478 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 3385, §§ 1-6, adopted July 15, 2008. 

Sec. 2-471. - Use of municipal vehicles policy statement. 
    Municipally owned vehicles are intended to promote the efficient and effective conduct of official municipal business, and therefore, are to be used exclusively to further this purpose. 
(Ord. No. 3549, § 2, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 2-472. - Personal use. 
    City-owned vehicles are for official use only. Personal use of city-owned vehicles is prohibited, except as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 3549, § 3, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 2-473. - Application. 
    The rules and regulations set forth in this article shall be applicable to the use of city-owned passenger vehicles, patrol cars, and trucks by all city officers, employees and volunteers, including elected and appointed officials and employees. For purposes of this article, "city-owned vehicles" shall include any motor vehicle owned by or under the control of the city and provided for the use of any city official, employee, agent or volunteer in the performance of official duties. 
(Ord. No. 3549, § 4, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 2-474. - Use of municipal vehicles generally. 
(a)  Municipally-owned vehicles are to be operated only by city officials and employees (a) on official business of the City of Bessemer and (b) as authorized to do so by the mayor as hereinafter provided. This paragraph does not authorize or expand the use of municipally owned vehicles in sections 2-474, 2-476 and 2-477 of this article. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, utilization of municipal vehicles generally shall be by the authorization of the mayor as hereinafter provided. 
(c)  Municipally-owned vehicles shall not be utilized to transport persons other than city employees except in the line and scope of duty and in connection with city business. Releases shall be obtained from persons who are not city employees to ride in municipal vehicles whenever possible, prior to allowing the same. 
(d)  All municipal vehicles shall be identified as official city vehicles by appropriate markings with the exception of certain law enforcement vehicles as directed by the mayor or request of the chief of police. 
(e)  Drivers shall be prohibited from carrying passengers in city vehicles who are not related to city business. The City Council or the Mayor of the City of Bessemer may grant approval, in writing, to carry specified passenger(s) or to use a city vehicle in appropriate circumstances and on a case-by-case basis without amendment to this article. 
(f)  Drivers shall observe all traffic laws at all times. 
(g)  Drivers shall operate vehicles not only in compliance with law, but in compliance with safe driving practices including but not limited to obeying speed limits and using seat belts. 
(h)  Fines and penalties imposed by a court for a violation while on city business shall be the personal responsibility of the driver. 
(i)  Parking citations issued to a city vehicle shall be the responsibility of the driver who parked the vehicle. 
(j)  Drivers shall operate city vehicles in an ordinary, reasonable manner consistent with the intended use of the vehicle. Except for vehicles engaged in law enforcement work, they shall not be used in activities which may endanger the vehicle. 
(k)  The use of any tobacco product by any driver of a city vehicle is prohibited. 
(l)  The use of alcohol by any driver of a city vehicle is prohibited. 
(m)  The use of a cell phone while driving a vehicle is prohibited, unless it is an emergency or law enforcement vehicle and during an emergency. A hands-free device may be used at any time. 
(n)  The costs of repairing damages to city vehicles resulting from gross negligence, abuse or willful misconduct by the driver having custody of the vehicle shall be recoverable from the driver. 
(Ord. No. 3549, § 5, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 2-475. - Parking and overnight retention of municipal vehicles. 
(a)  General. When not in use on city business, city vehicles shall at all times be kept at the following designated locations on city property: 
(1)  All vehicles assigned to the Bessemer Police Department shall be parked and kept at Bessemer Police Department. 
(2)  All vehicles assigned to the Bessemer Fire Department shall be kept and parked at Bessemer Fire Station nearest to the job assignment of the employee assigned to the vehicle. 
(3)  All vehicles assigned to personnel at city hall and all other vehicles not specifically mentioned herein shall be kept and parked at Bessemer Utilities. 
(b)  No person shall operate or have overnight retention of city vehicles except as otherwise provided in this article. 
(c)  The governing body of the City of Bessemer, hereby grants overnight retention of municipal vehicles, subject to the provisions of this article, as follows: 
(1)  The Mayor of the City of Bessemer, Alabama; 
(2)  The Bessemer Police Department: 
a.  The chief of police; and 
b.  Such persons employed in the Bessemer Police Department as the chief of police deems necessary for the good and efficient operation of the police department. 
(3)  The Bessemer Fire Department: 
a.  The fire chief; and 
b.  Such persons employed in the Bessemer Fire Department as the fire chief deems necessary for the good and efficient operation of the fire department. 
(d)  Parking overnight retention. Municipal vehicles on overnight retention and when not in use or on city business shall be safely and securely parked at the residence of the driver under whose charge the municipal vehicle has been let. 
(Ord. No. 3549, § 6, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 2-476. - Criteria for overnight retention; other personnel. 
(a)  The City Council or Mayor of the City of Bessemer may authorize other personnel to retain municipal vehicles overnight, under the following criteria: 
(1)  The driver must respond to emergencies which require immediate attention during off-duty hours for the protection of persons or property specifically requiring the presence of the employee in a supervisory or technical capacity. Such emergencies shall require immediate travel to the emergency scene. An average of at least three emergency calls per month requiring travel shall be documented. This subsection shall not apply to emergency responders utilizing fire apparatus; and 
(2)  The driver's duties are such that the checkout of a city vehicle from a city facility at the start or end of a normal workday would be both impractical and uneconomical due to lost time and increased city transportation costs. In such cases, it shall be determined that the employee's productive working hours would be reduced by travel time if the vehicle were not parked at the residence. 
(b)  Temporary overnight retention. Temporary overnight retention shall be permitted: 
(1)  When a driver is working on a special assignment requiring continuous availability of a city vehicle. Such authorization shall only extend over the span of the special assignment. 
(2)  When a driver requires the use of a city vehicle to attend city business and/or a training session in or out of the city, and such assignment is to the benefit of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3549, § 6, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 2-477. - [Driver's travel log; reservations; fuel card; city logo; place of parking and overnight retention.] 
(a)  Vehicles assigned to the city council. There shall be kept in each vehicle assigned to the city council a driver's travel log to be completed by each driver each time the vehicle is used. The log shall specify the following: 
(1)  The name of the driver using the vehicle; 
(2)  The date and time the use begins; 
(3)  The destination and business purpose for the use; 
(4)  The beginning odometer reading; 
(5)  The ending odometer reading; and 
(6)  The date and time the use ends and the vehicle is returned. 
(b)  Submission of travel log. The driver shall be responsible for submitting the driver's travel log to the council's secretary at the end of each use. The driver's travel logs shall be kept in the records of the city council for easy review and retrieval. A driver who fails to record his or her beginning and ending mileage may be responsible for gaps, omissions or errors in recording the mileage of the preceding driver. 
A copy of the travel log from the preceding 30 days shall be placed upon the agenda of each planning session for review by the council. 
(c)  Reservation for use of vehicle-In-town. 
(1)  Reservation. A person desiring the use of a vehicle assigned to the city council for in-town use (inside of the city limits and up to ten miles beyond of the city limits of the City of Bessemer) must reserve the use of vehicle at least 24 hours or one business day, before the intended use. 
(2)  Consecutive day use. No person may reserve the use of a vehicle assigned to the city council for consecutive days unless the same is approved, in advance, by the council president, the pro tem if the president is unavailable, or the city council. 
(3)  Use of vehicle to survey the district. No person may reserve the use of a vehicle assigned to the city council to survey any council district more than twice monthly. Surveying a council district shall mean use of such vehicle to drive through a council district to assess or evaluate the condition of or projects in a district or to otherwise canvass the condition of a district or the opinions of the residents of a district. 
(4)  Return of vehicle. A vehicle used under this section shall be returned to its place of parking and retention not later than 4:30 p.m., and the keys and log provided to the council secretary or, in his/her absence, to the office of the city clerk. In extenuating circumstances, with the prior approval of the council president or the pro tem if the president is unavailable, the vehicle may be returned by 9:00 a.m., of the following day. 
(d)  Reservation for use of vehicle-Out-of-town. 
(1)  Reservation. A person desiring the use of a vehicle assigned to the city council for out-of-town use (more than ten miles beyond the city limits of the City of Bessemer) must reserve the use of the vehicle at least seven days prior to the intended use. In extenuating circumstances, the seven-day requirement may be waived by council president, the pro tem if the president is unavailable, or the city council. 
(2)  Reservation information. The person reserving a vehicle for out-of-town use shall state: 
a.  The destination and business purpose for the use; 
b.  Number of days the vehicle is expected to be used; and 
c.  The date the vehicle is expected to be returned. 
(3)  Return of vehicle. A vehicle used under this section shall be returned to its place of parking and retention not later than 4:30 p.m., on the day the user arrives back in town and the keys and log shall be provided to the council secretary or, in his/her absence, to the office of the city clerk. In extenuating circumstances, with the prior approval of the council president or the pro tem if the president is unavailable, the vehicle may be returned by 9:00 a.m., of the following day. 
(e)  Fuel card. A person refueling a vehicle assigned to the city council with a city issued fuel card shall provide a copy of all fuel receipts from the use of said card to the director of finance with a copy attached to the travel log. All vehicles must be refueled at the end of each use prior to parking the vehicle in its designated location. 
(f)  City logo. Each vehicle assigned to the city council shall bear the city's logo on the front doors, below the side-view mirrors. 
(g)  Place of parking and overnight retention. All vehicles assigned to the Bessemer City Council shall be parked and kept in the city's parking lot adjacent to city hall. 
(Ord. No. 3549, § 7, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 2-478. - Unauthorized use. 
    Every use of a municipal vehicle in violation of the provisions of this article shall be deemed unauthorized. 
(Ord. No. 3549, § 8, 7-19-2016) 
Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Intoxicating beverages generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-1-1 et seq.; power of municipalities to adopt ordinances to promote temperance and to suppress intemperance, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-112. 

Sec. 6-1. - State statutes adopted by reference. 
(a)  All provisions, except those which by their nature are not applicable, of Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-1-1 et seq. are adopted by reference as if fully set out in this chapter. 
(b)  All definitions and rules of construction of the state statutes adopted by reference shall apply, insofar as applicable, in this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 6-1) 
Sec. 6-2. - Illegal drinking place defined; sales from; visitation of; buying from; violation. 
(a)  Illegal drinking place means any place where liquor, wine, malt or brewed beverages are sold without a license duly issued therefor by the state alcoholic beverage control board. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell liquor, wine, malt, or brewed beverages at any place not duly licensed by the state alcoholic beverage control board. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to visit or resort to an illegal drinking place for the purpose of buying any liquor, wine, malt, or brewed beverage. 
(d)  Proof that a person is present in or at an illegal drinking place at the time any liquor, wine, malt or brewed beverages are sold therein shall be prima facie evidence that such person was visiting or resorting to such place for the purpose of buying liquor, wine, malt, or brewed beverages. 
(e)  Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be guilty of an offense against the city and shall be punished as provided by law. 
(Code 1995, § 6-2; Ord. No. 2204, 5-3-1983) 
State Law reference- Abatement of unlawful drinking places generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-4-70 et seq. 
Sec. 6-3. - State license required; revocation by state. 
(a)  No license shall be issued to any applicant for the sale of any intoxicating beverages under the provisions of this chapter until the applicant has obtained a license from the state alcoholic beverage control board for the sale of such beverage. The city shall issue a license for the same type of license issued by such board. 
(b)  If the license issued by the state alcoholic beverage control board is revoked for any cause whatsoever, the city license shall also be revoked upon receipt of notice from such board. 
(Code 1973, § 3-8; Code 1995, § 6-3) 
Sec. 6-4. - Licenses required. 
(a)  For individuals. No person within the city limits shall sell, or have in his possession with the intent or purpose to sell, or offer to sell, any liquor, wine, malt or brewed beverage, unless such person has, prior thereto, made application for and received a proper license from the city for the sale of such liquor, wine, malt or brewed beverage. 
(b)  For businesses. No person operating a business within the city limits shall sell or have in his possession with the intent or purpose to sell or serve or give away or otherwise distribute at or in such place of business any liquor, wines, malt or brewed beverages, unless such person has, prior thereto, made application for and received a proper license from the city for the sale of such liquor, wines, malt or brewed beverages. 
(c)  Sales in public places. No person shall sell, serve, distribute or give away, or offer to sell, serve, distribute or give away any liquor, wines, malt or brewed beverages at any public place within the city limits unless such person has, prior thereto, obtained a proper license from the city for the sale or distribution of such liquor, wines, malt or brewed beverages at such public place. 
(Code 1973, § 3-2; Code 1995, § 6-4) 
State Law reference- Authority to license and collect fees or taxes for sale of alcoholic beverages, Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-3A-21(15)(c). 
Sec. 6-5. - Written statement required by licensees; contents. 
(a)  Every distributor or seller of intoxicating beverages shall before engaging in business within the city limits file with the clerk and treasurer a written statement, under oath, containing full data regarding the business he intends to carry on. 
(b)  The written statement shall include: 
(1)  His place of business; 
(2)  Whether or not such wholesale distributor or seller is a natural person, a corporation, a partnership or association; 
(3)  If not a natural person, the names of the persons composing the partnership, corporation or association and their residences, or the names and residences of the persons who hold the capital stock of the corporation; and 
(4)  Such other information as the city council may require. 
(Code 1973, § 3-3; Code 1995, § 6-5) 
Sec. 6-6. - Application for license; investigation; determination. 
(a)  Every application for a license for the sale of intoxicating beverages to be sold for consumption on the licensed premises, and a license has not been issued for the preceding year, shall be submitted to the city clerk and treasurer. 
(b)  The police chief shall make an investigation of the police record and the character of the applicant. He shall make a survey of the residents within a one-block radius, if within the fire zone, or three-block radius, if outside the fire zone, as to whether there is objection to the location of the place of business at the proposed location. The chief of police shall report his findings of fact to the city council, together with his recommendation as to whether the application should be granted or denied. The city council, after consideration of the facts and the recommendation of the chief of police, shall determine whether in the interest of the peace, good order and welfare of the community the application for license shall be granted or refused. 
(c)  The fire limits of the city shall include the area designated as the corporate city limits. 
(Code 1973, §§ 3-5, 6-2; Code 1995, §§ 6-6, 50-2) 
Sec. 6-7. - Transfer of licenses; fee. 
(a)  Licenses issued pursuant to this section may not be assigned. Upon written application, and subject to the approval by the state alcoholic beverage control board, the city is authorized to transfer any license from one person to another, or from one place to another within its jurisdiction, or both. No transfer shall be made to a person who would not have been eligible to receive the license originally, nor for the transaction of business at a place for which the license could not originally have been issued lawfully. 
(b)  No license shall be transferred in any event more than one time during the term of the license. 
(c)  A fee shall be paid by the applicant upon the filing of an application to transfer any alcoholic beverage license. This fee shall not be refunded even if the application is denied. The amount of the fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 6-7; Ord. No. 2233, § 1(3-6), 9-21-1984; Ord. No. 2291, § 1, 12-17-1985) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-3A-23(j). 
Sec. 6-8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3468, adopted Aug. 16, 2011, repealed § 6-8 which pertained to distribution or sale within police jurisdiction, and derived from the 1973 Code, § 3-9; and the 1995 Code, § 6-8. 
Sec. 6-9. - License for specified business location only. 
(a)  Every person subject to any of the provisions of this chapter shall designate the place at which such business is to be carried on. The license issued shall designate such place, and such license shall authorize the carrying on of business only at such place. For each place at which such business is carried on, a separate license shall be required. 
(b)  Any person dealing in two or more articles or engaging in two or more businesses licensed under this chapter shall pay for and take out a license for each line of business. 
(Code 1973, § 3-12; Code 1995, § 6-9) 
Sec. 6-10. - Presence of beverages on premises; presumption of sales. 
    The possession by any person of any liquor, wines, malt or brewed beverages at or on any business or business premises within the city limits shall be prima facie evidence that such liquor, wines, malt or brewed beverages are being possessed on such premises by such person for the purpose of sale. 
(Code 1973, § 3-14; Code 1995, § 6-10) 
Sec. 6-11. - Consumption of beverages on business premises limited to licensed beverages. 
    No person operating a place of business within the city limits shall allow any person to drink any intoxicating beverage on such business premises other than the beverage for which the business has been duly licensed. 
(Code 1973, § 3-15; Code 1995, § 6-11) 
Sec. 6-12. - Refund of license fees. 
    If any license for the sale of liquor, wines, malt or brewed beverages, having been issued by the city, is revoked then, in such case, the city shall not be required to refund any portion of the moneys paid by the licensee for such license. 
(Code 1973, § 3-20; Code 1995, § 6-12) 
Sec. 6-13. - Consumption of intoxicating beverage in public; licensed premises. 
(a)  No person shall consume or drink any intoxicating beverage in any public place other than on the premises where purchased and for which a license has been procured by the proprietor thereof for the sale of that particular type of beverage. 
(b)  No proprietor, owner, manager, or person in charge of any business shall allow any person to drink any intoxicating beverage on his premises, other than the beverage for which the business has been duly licensed and which was actually purchased in such place of business. 
(Code 1973, § 3-22; Code 1995, § 6-13) 
Sec. 6-14. - Tax levied on beer; amount. 
(a)  In addition to all other taxes now imposed by law, every person who sells, stores or delivers beer or ale in the city shall pay a license tax to the city. A license tax is fixed and levied for the sale, storage or delivery of beer or ale in the city limits. 
(b)  The license tax shall be in an amount equal to $0.02 for each bottle, can or other container thereof containing 12 fluid ounces or less and a like amount for each additional 12 fluid ounces, or fractional part thereof, contained therein, so sold, stored or delivered. 
(Code 1973, § 3-28; Code 1995, § 6-14) 
Sec. 6-15. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3468, adopted Aug. 16, 2011, repealed § 6-15 which pertained to tax levied in police jurisdiction; amount, and derived from the 1973 Code, § 3-29; and the 1995 Code, § 6-15. 
Sec. 6-16. - License for sale of off-premises wine-Application. 
    Any business may apply for a license for the sale of off-premises wine by making application to the clerk and treasurer and giving such information as may be necessary. The chief of police shall make an investigation and report his findings and recommendations to the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 3-32; Code 1995, § 6-16) 
Sec. 6-17. - Same-Conditions. 
    Any person granted an off-premises wine license shall be subject to the conditions of this chapter and to the following additional conditions: 
(1)  Any conflict shall be resolved in favor of the more restrictive. 
(2)  The license must be conspicuously displayed under a transparent substance upon the licensed premises. 
(Code 1973, § 3-33; Code 1995, § 6-17) 
Sec. 6-18. - Persons receiving, storing, selling or handling alcoholic beverages preserving, auditing and inspecting records. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every person, club, or association of persons receiving, storing, selling or handling alcoholic beverages enumerated in this chapter in any manner whatsoever, to keep and preserve all invoices, books, papers, cancelled checks or other memoranda touching the purchase, sale, exchange or receipt of any and all such alcoholic beverages for a period of three years. 
(b)  All such invoices, books, papers, cancelled checks or other memoranda shall be subject to audit and inspection by any duly authorized representative of the city at any and all times. 
(c)  Any person, club or association of persons who fails or refuses to keep and preserve the records as required by this section or who, upon request by a duly authorized agent of the city, fails or refuses to allow an audit or inspection of records, as provided in this section, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-8. 
(Code 1973, § 3-10; Code 1995, § 6-19)

ARTICLE II. - BILLIARDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Billiard rooms generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-6-1 et seq. 

Sec. 10-19. - Definitions. 
    The definitions set forth in Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-6-1 (Billiard rooms-Definitions), shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this article. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-6-1, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-6-1. 
(Code 1973, § 4-1; Code 1995, § 10-26) 
Sec. 10-20. - Issuance of license prohibited. 
    This chapter shall not be construed as authorizing the issuance of any license by the city for the operation of any public billiard room, where the operation of such billiard room is prohibited by other laws of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 4-2; Code 1995, § 10-27) 
Sec. 10-21. - Sale of alcoholic beverages; license issuance. 
(a)  No person shall sell, offer for sale, or possess or keep for the purpose of sale, any alcoholic beverage in any pool room, pool hall, billiard hall or like place of business in the city. 
(b)  The clerk and treasurer shall not issue a license for the sale of whiskey, beer or wine or other alcoholic beverages to be sold, stored or offered for sale in violation of the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 4-7; Code 1995, § 10-32) 
Sec. 10-22. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not be construed to include billiard tables or billiard rooms operated by industrial concerns for the exclusive use of its employees, Young Men's Christian Associations, religious orders, charitable institutions, state, county or city institutions, fraternal orders, or bona fide clubs using such tables for employees or members only. 
(Code 1973, § 4-11; Code 1995, § 10-36) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-6-15. 
Secs. 10-23-10-47. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BINGO[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license and regulate bingo games, Amd. No. 386, Ala. Const.; prohibition of gaming and gambling houses generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-111. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3463, §§ 1-16, adopted May 3, 2011, repealed the former art. III, §§ 10-48-10-54, 10-82-10-87, and enacted a new art. III as set out herein. The former art. III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2108, §§ 2-15, adopted Oct. 7, 1980; and the 1995 Code, §§ 10-56-10-62, 10-76-10-81. 

Sec. 10-48. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the City of Bessemer Bingo Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 1, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 10-49. - Definitions. 
    As used herein the following words shall have the following meanings as described here, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Any and all games of bingo shall mean any game of chance known as bingo, including any game permitted by federal law or which the National Indian Gaming Commission has classified, in a letter opinion, as a Class II bingo game (whether or not electronic, computer, or other technological aids are used in connection therewith), which incorporate the following elements: (i) the game must be played on a grid of five horizontal rows intersecting by five continuous squares contained within the grid; (ii) each square in a grid must be designated by a number or other symbol contained in a collection of numbers or symbols used for playing the game; (iii) numbers or symbols are selected by a procedure or mechanism entirely or predominantly governed by chance, and as such number or symbols, if they present on one or more of the squares on any grid in play, are covered or otherwise marked on such grid; (iv) the winner or winners of a particular game are the players of those grids for which a previously designated pattern or arrangement is first covered or marked; (v) two or more players must compete against one another for prizes; (vi) monetary wagers may be collected for the players of bingo for the opportunity to participate in the game, and such wagers may vary in amount to reflect the value of the prize of winning a particular game, whether the wager is for participation in the whole game or a particular phase thereof, and other factors reflecting the interplay of the amount wagered, the size of the prize and the probability of winning; and (vii) the prizes for winning the game of bingo must be in accordance with state law. To the extent that the foregoing elements are present in the game of bingo, it can be played with different kinds of equipment varying from one end of the spectrum, where traditional cards displaying the playing grids are used with tokens to cover the designated square on the grids, to the technologically advanced end of the spectrum where electronic devices perform the operation of the game using computers or micro processors and interact with the human players by means of an electronic console. When the game of bingo is played on electronic devices which determine and signal the winner, such devices, shall be electronically linked to ensure that multiple players are competing against each other. The prizes or evidence thereof for winning bingo games may be disbursed by the electronic devices or consoles used in playing such games at the time each game is won or on different schedules that reflect a record of wins and losses involving multiple games. The entertaining capabilities of electronic devices and consoles used in playing bingo may be enhanced by spinning reels or other video or mechanical displays, but such displays and the apparatus used to perform them may not affect the play or outcome of the game. In the event that any controversy concerning whether or not a certain activity, or type of activity, constitutes the game of "bingo" as herein defined, and for which a license may be issued, the decision of the chief of police shall control and be final. Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary, the definition of "bingo" or "bingo games" must include the following description as follows: 
(1)  Each player uses one or more cards with spaces arranged in five columns and five rows, with an alphanumeric or similar designation assigned to each space. 
(2)  Alphanumeric or similar designations are randomly drawn and announced one by one. 
(3)  In order to play, each player must pay attention to the values announced; if one of the values matches a value on the player's card, the player must physically act by marking his or her card accordingly. 
(4)  A player can fail to pay proper attention or to properly mark his or her card, and thereby miss an opportunity to be declared a winner. 
(5)  A player must recognize that his or her card has a "bingo," i.e., a predetermined pattern of matching values, and in turn announce to the other players and the announcer that this is the case before any other player does so. 
(6)  The game of bingo contemplates a group activity in which multiple players compete against each other to be the first to properly mark a card with the predetermined winning pattern and announce the fact. 
    Additionally, "bingo" and "bingo games" shall be defined as said definition may be subsequently amended by the Alabama Supreme Court and/or pursuant to an Amendment to the Constitution of the State of Alabama. 
    Bingo expenses shall mean all expenses incurred in connection with the holding, operating and conducting of bingo games in accordance with the Constitution of Alabama 1901, including but not limited to, the following expenses; rental of bingo machines, payment for the maintenance and repair of bingo machines, payment of prizes, rental for the location, utilities, janitorial services, security services, banking services, permit fees, taxes and license fees, insurance premiums, professional services, maintenance and any payments required by this article. Any expenses authorized by the Alabama Constitution shall be permitted under this article. 
    Bingo facility shall mean a facility in which bingo games are operated by a nonprofit organization as provided in this article. As long as a nonprofit organization is operating the bingo games, the bingo facility may be owned by an individual, partnership, profit corporation or for profit organization. 
    Bingo machine shall mean any electronic or mechanical equipment, machine or device, or computer or other technological hardware or device, (i) which is installed, or is to be installed, at a Class B qualified location and (ii) which is used, or can be used, to play bingo as herein defined.
