Bingo machines include any machine, device or hardware that assists a player or the playing of bingo games, broadens the participation levels in a common game, and includes all of the ancillary bingo supplies. Examples of bingo machines include but are not limited to, dispensers, readers, electronic player stations, player terminals, central computer servers containing random number generators and other processing capabilities for remote player terminals, electronic consoles capable of providing game results in different display modes, telephones and telephone circuits, televisions, cables, and other telecommunication circuits, and satellites and related transmitting and receiving equipment. Bingo machines shall not be deemed to be for any other purpose a "gambling device" or "slot machine" within the meaning of the Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 13A-12-20(5) and (10) or other provision of law, whether now in effect or hereafter enacted. Traditional bingo played utilizing paper cards and any devices to assist in the playing of traditional bingo utilizing paper cards shall be exempt under this definition. 
    Bingo machine vendor shall mean any person that leases or otherwise provides "bingo machines" to a Class B bingo licensee. 
    Bingo sessions shall mean a consecutive period of time up to 24 consecutive hours during which bingo is played Monday through Saturday. A holder of a Class A or a Class B bingo license shall not be limited in the number of bingo sessions it operates during any 24-hour period. No bingo facility shall operate between the hours of 3:00 a.m. and 2:59 p.m. on any Sunday. 
    Chief of police shall mean the Chief of Police for the City of Bessemer, Alabama, or in his absence, the next most senior captain, who is charged with certain duties concerning investigation, regulation, and enforcement of the requirements of this article as set forth therein. 
    Class A bingo license shall mean a license issued to an applicant who desires to operate only paper card bingo games at a Class A qualified location as defined herein. 
    Class B bingo license shall mean a license issued to an applicant who desires to operate any and all games of bingo at a Class B qualified location. 
    Class A qualified location for the holder of a Class A bingo license shall mean a location (i) which has been previously licensed under the provisions of Ordinance No. 2108 as amended, or (ii) any other location which (a) is located within the following zoning classifications of the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Bessemer, Alabama, to-wit: O-1, C-1, SC-1, C-2, C-3, C-4, C-5, C-6, PRD or any other zoning classification of the zoning ordinance which specifically provides for the playing of bingo as a permitted use or a use permitted upon review, (b) which has been inspected by the fire department, the police department and the department of buildings and inspections for compliance with applicable federal, state and local laws and (c) approved by the city council for the conduct of paper card bingo. 
    Class B qualified location for the holder of the Class B bingo license shall mean a location which: 
(1)  Is located within one of the following geographic areas within the city limits of Bessemer: 
a.  Any real property with a boundary situated within 600 feet of the centerline of 9th Avenue; or 
b.  Any real property situated between Alabama Adventure Parkway on the North, 9th Avenue SW on the East, Academy Drive on the South, and Powder Plant Road on the West; 
(2)  Has one of the following zoning classifications set forth in the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Bessemer, Alabama, to-wit: O-1, C-1, SC-1, C-2, C-3, C-4, C-5, C-6, PRD or any other zoning classification of the zoning ordinance as hereafter amended which specifically provides for the playing of bingo as a permitted use or a use permitted upon review; 
(3)  Has been inspected by the fire department, the police department and the department of buildings and inspections for compliance with applicable federal, state and local laws; 
(4)  Has submitted to the revenue department a certificate of insurance which provides for liability insurance in an amount not less than $1,000,000.00; 
(5)  Has demonstrated to the department of buildings and inspections that the location has adequate square footage of floor space within that portion of the building that is open to the general public for the placement of at least 300 bingo machines; 
(6)  Has demonstrated to the fire department, the police department and the department of buildings and inspections that the location has adequate parking for patrons and employees; 
(7)  Has demonstrated to the police department an ability to provide onsite security as reasonably prescribed by the chief of police, including but not limited to at least one APOST certified officer on the premises during all hours of operation; 
(8)  Has demonstrated to the fire department an ability to provide onsite first aid as reasonably prescribed by the fire chief; 
(9)  Has demonstrated to the revenue department such accounting procedures, controls and security monitoring as are reasonably necessary to preserve and promote the integrity of the operation of bingo games and the protection of the nonprofit organization and the patrons of the bingo games; 
(10)  Has demonstrated to the department of buildings and inspections satisfactory evidence that the location is fully compliant with the Americans with Disabilities Act; 
(11)  Has a minimum of 300 bingo machines on site and available for play at all times; and 
(12)  Has been approved by the city council for the conduct of Class B bingo games. 
    License holder shall mean any holder of a Class A bingo license or Class B bingo license. 
    Location shall mean a building, hall, room, premises, grounds and/or outdoor area that comply with all federal, state and local laws and applicable building and fire codes. 
    Net proceeds from bingo shall mean gross receipts from holding, operating and conducting of bingo games in accordance with the Constitution of Alabama 1901 less winnings and/or prizes awarded less bingo expenses. 
    Nonprofit organization shall mean any bona fide charitable, education, religious, fraternal, civic or service organization or other entity which has been classified by the Internal Revenue Service as a tax-exempt organization and which operates without profit to its members (if any). 
    Paper card bingo shall mean any game of chance known as bingo to the extent that it is played with traditional bingo cards displaying playing grids that are used with tokens to cover the designated squares on the cards and which incorporate the following elements: (i) the game must be played on a grid of five horizontal rows intersecting by five continuous squares contained within the grid; (ii) each square in a grid must be designated by a number or other symbol contained in a collection of numbers or symbols used for playing the game; (iii) numbers or symbols are selected by a procedure or mechanism entirely or predominantly governed by chance, and as such number or symbols, if they present on one or more of the squares on any grid in play, are covered or otherwise marked on such grid; (iv) the winner or winners of a particular game are the players of those grids for which a previously designated pattern or arrangement is first covered or marked; (v) two or more players must compete against one another for prizes; (vi) monetary wagers may be collected for the players of bingo for the opportunity to participate in the game, and such wagers may vary in amount to reflect the value of the prize of winning a particular game, whether the wager is for participation in the whole game or a particular phase thereof, and other factors reflecting the interplay of the amount wagered, the size of the prize and the probability of winning; and (vii) the prizes for winning the game of bingo must be in accordance with state law. Paper card bingo must be played without the incorporation of any electronic device. 
    Person shall mean any human being, corporation, partnership, limited liability company, business organization, association or legal entity of any kind whatsoever. 
    Revenue director shall mean the person appointed by the mayor to be the department head of the revenue department, who is charged with certain duties concerning the issuance of licenses and revocation of licenses prescribed by this article. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 2, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 10-50. - Authorization for the operation of bingo games. 
    The city hereby authorizes the licensing and operation of bingo games within the City of Bessemer subject to the authority, rules, and regulations set forth in the Constitution of Alabama (1901), Amendment No. 386 to the Constitution of Alabama (1901), Amendment No. 600 to the Constitution of Alabama (1901), and the provisions of this article, as amended from time to time. 
    If any provision in this article is deemed less restrictive than the Constitution of Alabama (1901), Amendment [No.] 386, and amended by Amendment [No.] 600, by a court of competent jurisdiction, then the provisions of the article shall be read to comply with the Constitution of Alabama, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 3, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 10-51. - Bingo license required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a bingo game within the city limits unless the City of Bessemer first issues a license authorizing the playing of bingo. The licenses described herein shall be in a form designated by the Mayor of the City of Bessemer which is consistent with the terms of this article. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to lease or otherwise provide bingo machines to any Class B bingo licensee unless the City of Bessemer first issues a license to said person. 
(c)  The following types of business licenses are hereby created for the operation of bingo games in the city: 
(1)  Class A bingo license; 
(2)  Class B bingo license; and 
(3)  Bingo machine vendor license. 
(d)  A holder of a Class A or Class B bingo license may hold only one license, and that license shall be valid for only one location in the City of Bessemer, Alabama. A license is not assignable or transferable without the express written consent of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 4, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 10-52. - Application for license; submission; form content; application fees and bingo machine fees. 
(a)  Any nonprofit organization desiring to obtain a license to operate bingo games hereunder shall make application to the revenue director and pay such application fee as is required by this article. Each such application shall be updated within 30 days of the close of each calendar year on a form prescribed by the city. 
(b)  For each calendar year, an annual base fee of $250.00 shall be required for a Class A bingo license and $15,000.00 shall be required for a Class B bingo license. Payment shall be due at the time of original application and at the time for renewal each year following as provided by this article. The holder of any bingo license pursuant to this article shall not be entitled to a half-year license; payment of the entire calendar year fee must be made in full prior to the issuance of a bingo license. 
(c)  In addition to all other fees set forth in this section, each holder of a Class B bingo license shall pay the following fees: 
(1)  Through December 31, 2011, $100.00 per bingo machine per month paid monthly in advance. 
(2)  On and after January 1, 2012, $150.00 per bingo machine per month paid monthly in advance. 
(3)  All bingo machine fees for the first month of holding a bingo license must be paid at the time of the original application, and payment must be made for a month in full, regardless of when during the month the bingo license is issued. The bingo machine fees for all subsequent months of holding a bingo license must be paid within the first ten days of each month. 
(4)  If additional bingo machines are utilized at any time after the license holder has paid its original or renewal fees in a given tax year, the license holder must make a supplemental payment for each additional bingo machine prior to the time that any new machine is placed in service. 
(5)  Each license holder of a Class B bingo license must pay for a minimum of 500 bingo machines per month paid in advance, regardless of whether said bingo machines are actually in operation. 
(d)  Any bingo machine vendor desiring to lease or otherwise provide bingo machines to a Class B bingo licensee shall make application to the revenue director and pay such application fee as required by this article. Each such application shall be updated within 30 days of the close of each calendar year on a form prescribed by the city. 
(e)  For each calendar year an annual base fee of $20,000.00 for the first location to which bingo machines are provided to a Class B bingo location shall be required for a bingo machine vendor license and $1,000.00 for each additional Class B bingo location to which bingo machines are provided. Payment shall be due at the time of original application and at the time for renewal each year following as provided by this article. The holder of any bingo license pursuant to this article shall not be entitled to a half-year license; payment of the entire calendar year fee must be made in full prior to the issuance of a bingo license. 
(f)  No license shall be issued under this section to any applicant qualified hereunder unless and until the applicant fully provides the information required hereunder, such being provided in a form and in sufficient detail to satisfy the City of Bessemer of its validity and sufficiency. The City of Bessemer may require any reasonable confirming documentation as to any information required hereunder and shall have reasonable time to check and confirm by any available method the accuracy or validity of any information provided hereunder. 
(1)  Any annual anniversary update under this section shall fully provide the information required hereunder, such being provided in a form and in sufficient detail to satisfy the City of Bessemer of its validity and sufficiency. The City of Bessemer may require any reasonable confirming documentation as to any information required hereunder and shall have reasonable time to check and confirm by any available method the accuracy or validity of any information provided hereunder. 
(2)  The city reserves the right to revoke any license issued under this section should there be a material change in the information provided on any update required under this section which would have caused the city to reject the initial application. 
(g)  No Class A or Class B bingo license shall be issued until such time as the location listed in the application meets the definition of a Class A or Class B qualified bingo location as defined in section 10-49 of this article. 
(h)  No license shall be issued for any individual electronic player station or device if the City of Bessemer finds that said individual electronic player station or device is a "gambling device" as defined by the statutes and Courts of the State of Alabama. Should said application be incomplete or contain material inaccuracies, same shall be grounds for denial of the license. In addition, the chief of police shall investigate as to the possible criminal record of the applicant. Should it be determined that any of said parties have, within two years prior to the date of application, been convicted of any felony and/or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, the application may be denied. 
(i)  Each application for a Class A or Class B bingo license or renewal thereof shall be on such form as is prescribed or approved by the mayor and shall, at a minimum, contain the following information and exhibits: 
(1)  The date of incorporation or other evidence of inception showing existence by the nonprofit organization for at least 24 months immediately prior to the issuance of the license. 
(2)  A certified copy of the charter, certificate of incorporation, by-laws, or other evidence of legal existence of the nonprofit organization or operator. 
(3)  Where applicable, a copy of the letter ruling or tax-exempt determination letter from the Internal Revenue Service, or other proof deemed acceptable by the City of Bessemer verifying the tax-exempt status of the nonprofit organization named in the application of the parent organization of which the same is a qualified branch, chapter, lodge or post. 
(4)  The names and residence addresses of each of the members, officers, directors, or the other authorized representatives of the nonprofit organization who are responsible for the operation of bingo games by the nonprofit organization. 
(5)  The exact physical location at which the applicant will conduct the bingo games and proof that such location is either owned or leased by the nonprofit organization which is conducting bingo games. If such location is not owned by such nonprofit organization, the application shall include the names and addresses of the owners or owners of the leasehold interest thereof and a copy of all agreements with the said owners and/or owners of the leasehold interest thereof regarding the rental or use of the premises for the operation of bingo games. 
(6)  The application shall also be accompanied by a drawing showing the floor plan of the proposed business and all exits. Applications for licenses shall also show the proposed location of each individual electronic player station or device, and its floor space requirement as required under the Building Code of the City of Bessemer. 
(7)  A statement listing all convictions, if any, for criminal offenses, other than traffic offenses, of each of the persons identified pursuant to subsections (i)(4) and (5) above. 
(8)  A statement that the persons identified pursuant to subsections (i)(4) and (5) above are persons of good moral character. 
(9)  Such additional information as is reasonably required by the City of Bessemer to ensure compliance with this article and other applicable city, county, state and federal ordinances, laws and regulations. 
(j)  Each applicant for a Class B license or renewal thereof shall be on such form as is prescribed or approved by the mayor, and shall, at a minimum, contain the following information and exhibits: 
(1)  The number and type of individual electronic player stations or devices intended to be operated; 
(2)  The owner, description, model and serial number of each individual electronic player stations or device; and 
(3)  The full name, address and date of birth of each and every owner of such business. 
(k)  Each application or renewal for a bingo machine vendor license or renewal thereof shall be on such form as is prescribed or approved by the mayor, and shall, at a minimum, contain the following information and exhibits: 
(1)  The date of the incorporation, organization or other evidence of inception. 
(2)  A certified copy of the following if a corporation: the charter, certificate of incorporation, by-laws, a certificate of good standing issued by the state in which the corporation is incorporated and if the corporation is a foreign corporation, a certificate of authority issued by the Secretary of State of Alabama that the foreign corporation is qualified to do business in Alabama. 
(3)  A certified copy of the following if a limited liability company: the articles of organization, the operating agreement, a certificate of good standing issued by the state in which the corporation is incorporated and if the company is a foreign company, a certificate of authority issued by the Secretary of State of Alabama that the foreign company is qualified to do business in Alabama. 
(4)  The Federal Taxpayer Identification number of the person. 
(5)  The names and residence addresses of each of the managing members, officers, directors, or the other authorized representatives of the entity who will be the designated agents of the entity for the leasing or otherwise providing of bingo machine to the Class B bingo licensee. 
(6)  The exact physical location at which the applicant will lease or otherwise provide bingo machine and proof that such location is either owned or leased by a holder of a current Class B bingo licensee which is conducting bingo games. 
(7)  A statement listing all convictions, if any, for criminal offenses, other than traffic offenses, of each of the persons identified pursuant to subsection (k)(5) above. 
(8)  A statement that the persons identified pursuant to subsection (k)(5) above are persons of good moral character. 
(9)  Such additional information as is reasonably required by the City of Bessemer to ensure compliance with this article and other applicable city, county, state and federal ordinances, laws and regulations. 
(10)  The number and type of individual electronic player stations or devices intended to be operated; and 
(11)  The owner, description, model and serial number of each individual electronic player station or device and the exact location physical location of each device within the City of Bessemer. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 5, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 10-53. - Issuance of license. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a fully completed and documented application for a Class A or Class B bingo license meeting all the requirements set out herein, the chief of police shall make such investigation as he may deem necessary and proper of the qualifications of each applicant as required herein and the truth and veracity of the information contained or attached to the application. After making such investigation and after being satisfied that all qualifications and requirements as set out herein have been fulfilled and that the location meets the requirements of either a Class A qualified location or a Class B qualified location, the chief of police shall make recommendations to the city council as to whether the requested license should be issued. As part of said investigation, any person named in section 10-52 herein may be required to consent to a background and criminal history investigation. 
(b)  Upon approval of the city council by a majority vote of its members, the revenue director shall issue such license to said applicant upon the terms and conditions herein set forth. 
(c)  A Class A bingo license shall be issued to an applicant who desires to operate paper card bingo only at a Class A qualified location. 
(d)  A Class B bingo license shall be issued to an applicant who desires to operate any and all games of bingo at a Class B qualified location. 
(e)  The revenue director shall issue a sticker or decal for each individual electronic player station or device located at the location of a bingo licensee annually at the time of the issuance of the bingo license. A fee of $100.00 shall be charged for each sticker/decal annually. Any sticker or decal may be transferred by the City of Bessemer to another electronic player station or device which replaces an electronic player station or device for which the sticker or decal was previously issued; a $35.00 administrative fee shall be paid for each such transfer. Any license holder found in violation of this requirement shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Bessemer. Each bingo machine without a sticker/decal shall be a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 6, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 10-54. - Amendments. 
(a)  An applicant may amend an application filed hereunder to correct or complete the information contained therein or to change said information to comply with a change in circumstances at any time prior to the denial thereof by the City of Bessemer or the issuance of a license thereon, provided that said amendment is made in or on a form satisfactory to the City of Bessemer and the applicant pays a substitution or amendment fee of $200.00 per amendment. 
(b)  A license, once issued, may be amended only upon submission of a new, completed application satisfactory to the City of Bessemer and payment of a new application fee by the license holder. If such amendment is approved, a new license evidencing the amendment will be issued in place of the license being amended. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 7, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 10-55. - Contents and display of licenses. 
(a)  Each bingo license shall contain the name and address of the license holder, the location at which the license holder is permitted to conduct bingo games, the days of the week on which the license holder is permitted to conduct bingo games, and the date on which the license was issued and upon which it expires. 
(b)  Each bingo machine vendor license shall contain the name and address of the license holder, the location at which the license holder is permitted to lease or otherwise provide bingo machine, and the date on which the license was issued and upon which it expires. 
(c)  All license holders, including bingo machine vendors, shall display any required license conspicuously at the location where bingo is being conducted at all times during the conduct of a bingo game. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 8, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 10-56. - Fee procedures. 
(a)  All monies collected by the City of Bessemer hereunder shall be paid to the City of Bessemer and shall be deposited into the general fund. To the extent allowed by law, in the public interest, the said account shall be subject to audit by the State of Alabama Examiners of Public Accounts. 
(b)  The City of Bessemer as authorized by this article shall have the power to make regulations respecting the reporting, collection, and enforcement of the fees levied pursuant to this article. The levy, collection and enforcement of the fee shall be administered by the city, or other legal entity as established by ordinance of the City of Bessemer. 
(c)  Failure to remit any fee required under this article by the due date shall result in a penalty of 25 percent of the total levies due under this article which is due and payable on the second business day thereafter. 
(d)  At any time after the fifth business day wherein a license holder fails or refuses to remit fees and/or penalties, the City of Bessemer shall order said business closed until all fees and penalties are paid in full. 
(e)  At any time after the issuance of a license, each license holder shall be subject to periodic inspection of the location by a designated representative from the City of Bessemer to determine and maintain an exact accounting of the number of electronic bingo machines. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 9, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 10-57. - Effect of license. 
    The license holder, by accepting a license under the authority of this article, understands and acknowledges that the various courts of this state have issued different and varying opinions as to the legality of certain bingo operations. The fact that a license has been issued under the authority of this article shall not be evidence at any judicial proceeding that the city has taken the position that the operation of licensed activities is permitted under the laws of the State of Alabama. In the event that a court of competent jurisdiction determines that a particular bingo game is not permitted, the license holder agrees by acceptance of the bingo license that neither the license holder nor any other person or entity shall be entitled to a refund of any license fees or taxes collected by the City of Bessemer under this article. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 10, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 10-58. - Sales taxation. 
    Any operator of a bingo location shall be subject to all city tax as the current tax law requires. Further, each bingo machine vendor is subject to Bessemer City Tax. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 11, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 10-59. - General regulations and prizes. 
(a)  No person under the age of 19 shall be permitted to play any game or games of bingo, nor shall any person under the age of 19 be permitted to conduct or assist in the conduct of any game of bingo. 
(b)  No bingo licenses shall be issued to any nonprofit organization, unless such organization shall have been in existence in Jefferson County, Alabama, for at least 24 months immediately prior to the issuance of the license. 
(c)  Bingo games shall be operated only on the premises owned or leased by the nonprofit organization operating the bingo game. If the premises are leased, the rate of rental shall not be based on a percentage of receipts or profits resulting for the operation of bingo games. 
(d)  No nonprofit organization shall enter into any contract with any individual, firm, association or corporation to have said individual or entity operate bingo games or concessions on behalf of the nonprofit organization, nor shall said nonprofit organization pay consulting fees to any individual or entity for any services performed in relation to the operation or conduct of a bingo game, but this provision shall be interpreted to allow any items and matters allowed by Alabama Constitution of the State of Alabama. 
(e)  A nonprofit organization shall not lend its name to allow its identity to be used by any other person or entity in the operation or advertising of a bingo game in which said nonprofit organization is not directly and solely operating said bingo game. 
(f)  Prizes given by any nonprofit organization for the playing of bingo games in the City of Bessemer, Alabama, shall be unlimited but, in no event, shall any prize exceed the amount displayed on any machine prior to the playing of any game and no prize shall be paid for a game in which there is a machine malfunction. 
(g)  No person or organization, by whatever name or composition thereof, shall take any salary, expense money, or fees as remuneration for services rendered in the operation of any bingo game. (Amendment 386; Proposed by Act 80-431, submitted at the Sept. 2, 1980, election, and proclaimed ratified Sept. 17, 1980, Proclamation Register No. 3, p. 180; as amended by Amendment 600; Proposed by Act 96-420, submitted at the November 5, 1996 election, and proclaimed ratified Dec. 5, 1996, Proclamation Register No. 8, p. 220), but this provision shall be interpreted to allow any items and matters allowed by Alabama Constitutional Amendment 386, amended by Alabama Constitutional Amendment 600. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 12, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 10-60. - Records and accounting. 
    Each holder of a bingo license shall keep and maintain the following records and accounts pertaining to each bingo session conducted by it for at least six years from the date of such session: 
(1)  An itemized list of all gross receipts for each bingo session, which shall include all receipts derived from the sale of bingo cards, entrance fees, donations, or for any other source whatsoever pertaining to the operation of such session. 
(2)  An itemized list of all bingo expenses, costs and disbursements, other than prizes paid or given as a result of the operation of any bingo session, together with the name and address of each person to whom said bingo expenses, disbursements or consideration was paid or given, a receipt invoice for all items purchased and for all services rendered; and such other records as will adequately reflect the amount and nature of such expenses, costs and disbursements. 
(3)  All records, receipts, accounts and or lists required to be kept and maintained hereunder shall be open to inspection by the City of Bessemer during reasonable business hours. All locations at which bingo games are being held by a license holder, or at which a license holder intends to conduct bingo games, shall be open to the City of Bessemer during all times at which bingo games are being conducted and during all other reasonable business hours. 
(4)  On or before April 15 in each year, each license holder shall file with the city a financial statement of receipts and expenses relating to the operation of bingo games in the previous calendar year. Said report shall be in addition to any and all other reports required by law. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 13, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 10-61. - Suspension or revocation of license; appeal. 
    The chief of police or revenue director may suspend or revoke any license issued pursuant to this article if the license holder or any officer, director, agent, member or employee of the license holder violates this article or rule promulgated hereunder. Appeal to the city council from an adverse ruling shall be available to the license holder if filed with the city clerk within 14 days of the suspension or revocation. Alternatively, the city council may, sua sponte , suspend or revoke any permit issued pursuant to this article if the license holder or any officer, director, agent, member or employee of the license holder violates this article or rule promulgated hereunder. Appeal of any adverse decision rendered by the city council may be made to the Circuit Court of Jefferson County, Alabama, Bessemer Division, within 14 days of the adverse decision. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 14, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 10-62. - Effect of revocation. 
    A license holder whose license is revoked as herein set out shall return such license to the City of Bessemer on or before the effective date of such revocation and whether returned or not such license shall be inactive on the effective date and shall become void 15 days after the effective date of revocation. A license holder who loses the right to use a license in consequence of a violation of any rule or regulation promulgated herein shall be ineligible to apply for or have issued to it another license hereunder for a period of 24 months after the effective date of such revocation. Nor shall any license be issued to any person which is directed or controlled by persons listed in the application for license filed pursuant to section 10-52, in regard to the revoked license or to any organization which the membership is substantially the same as any organization whose license has been revoked hereunder, for a period of 24 months after the effective date of such revocation. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 15, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 10-63. - Violation, offense. 
    Any person, association, corporation, or organization who or which shall violate any of the provisions of this article relating to the conduct of bingo in the City of Bessemer or any terms of any license issued under this article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Bessemer. In addition, said person, association, corporation or organization shall forfeit any license issued under this article and shall be ineligible to serve as an officer of a licensee or to participate in conducting bingo for a period of two years. 
(Ord. No. 3463, § 16, 5-3-2011) 
Secs. 10-64-10-117. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICES AND CENTERS 

Sec. 10-118. - Scope. 
    This article shall be applicable to the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 10-119. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Amusement center, game room and arcade, hereinafter referred to by the term "amusement center," means: 
(1)  Any place of business where the gross receipts from mechanical amusement devices, as hereinafter defined, constitutes 25 percent or more of the gross receipts of the business; 
(2)  Any place of business which advertises as an amusement center, game room, arcade, or similar type business where mechanical amusement devices are available to the public for use; or 
(3)  Any place of business which has less than 10,000 square feet of floorspace available to the general public for use and has more than six mechanical amusement devices available to the public for use or operation. 
    Mechanical amusement device , hereinafter referred to by the abbreviation "MAD," means an instrument, machine, or contrivance which may be operated or set in motion upon the insertion of a coin, bill, slug, token, plat, disc, money, or any other insertion device, which may be operated by the public for use as a game, entertainment, or amusement, of any kind or description whatever. Specifically excluded from the purview of this article are devices which only furnish music and which are commonly referred to as "jukeboxes," scales for the express purpose of giving weights, medical devices, such as, those providing blood pressure information, pool and billiard tables and bowling lanes. 
    Revenue director refers to the Director of Licenses, Department of Revenue, Bessemer, Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 10-120. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not be applicable to: 
(1)  Any person having set up in his private residence one or more MAD's when employed for his own private use or for the use of his family; 
(2)  Clubs where MAD's are used exclusively by club members and for which no charge for playing is made and prizes or awards are forbidden. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 10-121. - License required. 
(a)  No amusement center shall be established, maintained or conducted in the city by any owner or operator without first obtaining a license to operate such place in the city. 
(b)  The revenue director shall issue a sticker or decal for each MAD located at an amusement center annually at the time of the issuance of the license for the amusement center. 
(c)  Each MAD located at any amusement center must have the sticker or decal obtained from the revenue director affixed to the MAD in a clearly visible location. 
(d)  Failure to display the current license for the amusement center or to have a current decal or sticker affixed to each MAD may result in closure of the amusement center and/or confiscation of the MAD and/or a 50 percent penalty of the cost of the license, sticker or decal. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 10-122. - Restrictions on location of amusement centers and arcades. 
(a)  No amusement center license, as hereinafter set forth, shall be issued by the revenue director to any such proposed operation which shall be located less than 1,000 feet from the property line of any property on which there is located an elementary, junior high school, high school, or vocational school; or which shall be located less than 300 feet from the property line of any property on which there is located a church. 
(b)  The revenue director shall not issue an amusement center license until the city zoning board of adjustment has made a determination in compliance with the requirements of the city zoning ordinance that the use is compatible with the permitted district use and is consistent with the provisions of the zoning ordinance of the city, as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000; Ord. No. 3240, § 1, 5-4-2004) 
Sec. 10-123. - Application for license, fee, term. 
(a)  Applications for an amusement center license and MAD sticker or decal shall be made to the city revenue department on a form provided by the revenue department, and shall be in accordance with the provisions of this section. The application for license, sticker or decal shall be verified and state, among other things: 
(1)  The number and type of machines or devices intended to be operated; 
(2)  The proposed locations for such machines or devices; 
(3)  The proposed business address, the full name of the business; 
(4)  The owner, description, model and serial number of each MAD; and 
(5)  The full name, present address and date of birth of each and every owner of such business. 
(b)  The application for an amusement center license shall be accompanied by an annual license fee which shall be established, from time to time, by the city council, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(c)  The amount of the license fee for each MAD shall be based upon the following factors, whether: 
(1)  The MAD dispenses no rewards except free play, or if it dispenses or the player is awarded coupons, certificates, or tickets valued in the amount of one cent (1/100 one dollar) or less per play; or 
(2)  The MAD dispenses or the player is awarded coupons, certificates, or tickets valued in an amount greater than one cent (1/100 one dollar) per play. 
The amount of each MAD license fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(d)  The application for an amusement center shall also be accompanied by a drawing showing the floor plan of the proposed business, all exits, the proposed location of each MAD, and its floorspace requirement as required under the building code of the city. 
(e)  An application for a MAD license shall be accompanied by a drawing showing the proposed location of each MAD. 
(f)  No license shall be issued until such time as the fire department has determined that the proposed location of each MAD will not interfere with egress from the building in case of fire, and that all fire regulations and life safety codes have been satisfied. 
(g)  No such licenses shall be issued until such time as the building department has determined that all electrical, pneumatic and hydraulic connections to each MAD comply with the this Code, and that all building and zoning regulations have been satisfied. 
(h)  No license shall be issued until such time as the police department has verified the accuracy of the information set forth in the application. No license shall be issued for any MAD if the police department finds that said MAD is a gambling device as defined by the statutes and courts of the state. Should said application be incomplete or contain material inaccuracies, same shall be grounds for denial of the license. In addition, the police department shall investigate as to the possible criminal record of the applicant or the officers and directors, if the applicant is a corporation. Should it be determined that any of said parties have, within two years prior to the date of the application, been convicted of any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude or involving the operation of an amusement center, or of any felony, said conviction shall be grounds for denial of a license. 
(i)  If, after the issuance of any license, the licensee desires to operate additional MAD's or to relocate those MAD's already in place, the applicant shall submit an amended application, in a form similar to the original application, showing, the additions, changes or modifications desired. Any drawings, or other information filed with the original license application and not affected by the additions, changes or modifications requested may be incorporated by reference in the amended application. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000; Ord. No. 3240, § 2, 5-4-2004; Ord. No. 3272, § 1, 11-2-2004) 
Sec. 10-124. - Basis for denial. 
    The revenue director shall deny an application for the following reasons: 
(1)  Misstatements or misleading statements of material facts in the application shall be a basis for denial. 
(2)  The proposed operation would not comply with one or more applicable city ordinances or state statutes. 
(3)  Failure to receive location approval of the city board of zoning adjustment or failure to receive approval of the fire department, building department or police department as required by the provisions of this article. 
(4)  Failure to pay the required application fee. 
If the director does not issue a license, the reasons for his not doing so shall be given in writing and shall accompany the notice of nonissuance. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 10-125. - Term. 
    The term of any license granted shall begin January of the license year and shall terminate at midnight on December 31 of that year. In the event that a license is obtained after January 1, the cost of the license shall not be prorated and shall terminate on December 31, regardless of the date of issuance of the license. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 10-126. - Notice. 
    Each applicant shall be notified by registered mail or by hand delivery of the issuance or nonissuance of an original license by the director at any address listed in the application for license. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 10-127. - Appeal. 
    An applicant who's application has been denied for any reason, other than failure to receive location approval by the board of zoning adjustment, shall have the right to appeal the decision of the revenue director to the city council for a hearing. Any such notice of appeal shall be filed with the clerk of the city within 14 days of the date of the decision of the revenue director and the city council shall hear said appeal within 30 days of the date of the appeal. The decision of the city council shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 10-128. - Display of license. 
    The license issued herein by the revenue director shall be prominently displayed within the premises of the amusement center. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 10-129. - Renewal procedure. 
(a)  Within 30 days of the expiration of the license, a licensee may apply to the director for renewal thereof, on such applications as shall be provided by the director. 
(b)  Renewal applications shall contain the name, address and license number of the licensee's operation, and further, licensee shall indicate any changes from the information furnished to the director at the time of the original application. 
(c)  An application for renewal of an amusement center license shall be accompanied by a renewal application fee, no part of which shall be refundable. The amount of the renewal application fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(d)  An application for renewal of a MAD license shall be accompanied by a renewal application fee, no part of which shall be refundable. The amount of the renewal application fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000; Ord. No. 3240, § 3, 5-4-2004) 
Sec. 10-130. - Suspension or revocation procedure. 
(a)  When the revenue director finds one or more of the following have occurred: 
(1)  Making of a misstatement or misleading statement of material fact in the application, not discovered until after the issuance of such license; 
(2)  A violation of any statutes or ordinances pertaining to consumption or possession of alcoholic beverages by a minor, or any statutes or ordinances pertaining to a possession of controlled substances or narcotics, has occurred on the premises of an amusement center; or 
(3)  The operation of the amusement center or any MAD located in the amusement center does not comply with one or more applicable city ordinances or state statutes. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the revenue director to notify the licensee of his determination and advise the licensee at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing that at a fixed time and place specified in the notice, he will apply to the city council for a suspension or revocation of the license. At the time and place so specified in the notice, the licensee may appear before the city council in person and by counsel, one or both, and show cause, if any there be, why said license should not be suspended or revoked. Any determination made by the city council shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 10-131. - Miscellaneous regulations; conduct prohibited. 
(a)  No person under the age of 13 years shall be permitted on the premises of any amusement center without parental supervision. 
(b)  No consumption of alcoholic beverages or nonintoxicating beer shall be permitted on the premises of an amusement center. 
(c)  No alcoholic beverages or nonintoxicating beer shall be permitted on the premises of an amusement center. 
(d)  No firearms shall be permitted on the premises of an amusement center. 
(e)  No narcotics or controlled substances under the laws of the United States or the state shall be permitted on the premises of an amusement center or arcade. 
(f)  At least one supervisor of at least 19 years of age, employed by the operator, shall be on duty at all times and be present on the premises of an amusement center. 
(g)  An amusement center may not operate between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(h)  No person can reward a player of a coin-operated amusement machine with non-cash merchandise, prizes, toys, gifts, certificates or novelties that have a wholesale value of more than $5.00. 
(i)  No person or player can redeem non-cash merchandise, prizes, gifts, toys, gift certificates or novelties for cash. 
(j)  No issuer of a gift certificate that has been awarded to a player at an amusement center or arcade can give cash or part cash and merchandise for the gift certificate. Only merchandise can be given for the gift certificate. 
(k)  A licensee who elects to give a gift certificate as an award must stamp on the gift certificate the name of the amusement center signed by the licensee. 
(l)  A person cannot give but one award per game to a player of a MAD and the wholesale prize cannot exceed $5.00. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 10-132. - Penalties. 
    Any person who shall be convicted of a violation of any provision of this article may be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 10-133. - Cavaet. 
(a)  The fact that a license for an amusement center or for a MAD has been issued by the revenue director of the city shall not be evidence at any judicial proceeding that the city has taken the position that the operation of the amusement center is permitted under the laws of the state or that any MAD is a legal machine or device. Further, by accepting the license, the licensee understands and agrees that the city shall not be stopped from arguing in a court of law that the licensed amusement center is an illegal gambling operation or that a particular licensed MAD is a gambling device as defined by the statutes of the state. The licensee, by accepting any license issued pursuant to this article, understands and acknowledges that the various courts of this state have issued different and varying opinions as to the legality of certain MAD's and the issuance of gift certificates in relation thereto. In the event that a court of this state determines that a licensed amusement center is an illegal gambling operation or that a particular licensed MAD is a gambling device, the licensee agrees by acceptance of the license that neither the licensee of the amusement center or the owner or licensee of the MAD shall be entitled to a refund of the license issued by the revenue director. 
(b)  The city is opposed to illegal gambling operations within its corporate limits and will prosecute to the fullest extent of the law any violation of the gambling laws of the state or the municipal ordinances of this city. 
(Ord. No. 3116, 8-15-2000) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 3304, adopted on May 16, 2006, placed a moratorium on the issuance of any licenses or permits for any mechanical amusement devices (MAD) to include those individual arcade games and sweepstakes readers as authorized in decisions by Judge Dan C. King, III and Judge Scott Vowell until such time as the City of Bessemer has had an opportunity to modify its zoning ordinance so as to regulate and create zoning areas for these type devices. Nothing in the ordinance prohibited the issuance of a license or permit to existing amusement centers or mechanical amusement devices previously licensed by the City of Bessemer. The ordinance also directed that the director of the department of revenue shall not issue a license or permit for any new mechanical amusement devices until such time that the city council has made a decision relative to zoning or otherwise authorized issuance thereof. 
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Animals generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 3-1-1 et seq.; general authority relative to animals, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 3-5-14, 11-47-110. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means any and all types of animals, both domesticated and wild, male and female, except man. 
    At large means off the premises of the owner and not under control of a human being either by leash, cord, chain or otherwise. 
    Collar means any band, chain, harness or suitable device worn around the neck of a dog to which a license may be affixed. 
    Dog means any member of the canine species, male or female, which has attained the age of three months or more. 
    Fowl means any and all fowl, domesticated and wild, male and female. 
    Keep means possessing, controlling, exercising or allowing to run at large. 
(b)  The definitions set forth in Code of Ala. 1975, § 3-7A-1 (Rabies-Definitions), shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this chapter. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in Code of Ala. 1975, § 3-7A-1, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in Code of Ala. 1975, § 3-7A-1. 
(Code 1973, § 5-1; Code 1995, § 14-1) 
Sec. 14-2. - Citation for violation of chapter provisions. 
    Any officer noting a violation of this chapter may issue a citation designating the date, time, location and offense and the name of the officer who issues the citation. The citation shall contain the location, the violation charged and the description of the animal causing such violation. 
(Code 1995, § 14-2; Ord. No. 1895, § 1, 5-6-1975) 
Sec. 14-3. - Payment of penalty; warrant upon failure. 
    The owner of the animal in question may, within five days after the issuance of the citation, pay the penalty prescribed in section 14-4 for the offense as noted on the citation. If the citation has not been paid within five days from the date of the citation, a warrant for the arrest of the owner shall be issued and the persons arrested shall be brought before the municipal court for trial as in other cases. 
(Code 1995, § 14-3; Ord. No. 1895, § 2, 5-6-1975) 
Sec. 14-4. - Penalty amounts. 
    The minimum penalty or fine for violations of this chapter shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and will be available for public examination in a fine schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 14-4; Ord. No. 1895, § 3, 5-6-1975) 
Sec. 14-5. - Enforcement of chapter. 
    The rabies control officer and the officers of the police department shall enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 5-2; Code 1995, § 14-5) 
Sec. 14-6. - Applicability of state laws to custody of animals. 
    No person owning or having in his custody any animal shall violate any laws, rules or regulations of the state applicable thereto. Such laws, rules and regulations are adopted by reference and incorporated herein as if fully set out. Where the provisions of rules and regulations are less restrictive than the provisions of this chapter, the latter shall govern. 
(Code 1973, § 5-3; Code 1995, § 14-6) 
Sec. 14-7. - Keeping animals. 
(a)  No person shall keep or maintain any animal in the city in such manner so as to become a public nuisance or disturb the peace, comfort or health of any person residing within the city. 
(b)  The keeping of all animals within the city shall be subject to all pertinent regulations of the state health department and the county health department. 
(Code 1973, § 5-33; Code 1995, § 14-7) 
Sec. 14-8. - Unnecessary noises by animals. 
    No person shall keep any animal which by causing frequent or long continued noise shall disturb the comfort or repose of any person in the vicinity. Such action is declared to be a public nuisance and detrimental to public health and welfare. 
(Code 1973, § 5-54; Code 1995, § 14-8) 
Sec. 14-9. - Keeping of-Swine. 
    No person shall keep or maintain any swine upon any premises within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 5-35; Code 1995, § 14-9) 
Sec. 14-10. - Same-Vicious animals. 
    No person shall keep any vicious animal, whether owned by him or not, on his premises within the city. 
(Code 1973, § 5-36; Code 1995, § 14-10) 
Sec. 14-11. - Same-Reptiles and wild animals. 
    No person shall keep or maintain any poisonous reptile or wild animal without first having registered such animal or reptile with the chief of police and the county department of health. The chief of police may prescribe regulations to ensure the safe penning or caging of such animals. 
(Code 1973, § 5-37; Code 1995, § 14-11) 
Sec. 14-12. - Issuance of permit. 
    The rabies control officer shall issue permits to keep the animals described in section 14-11 when, in his judgment, they are not detrimental to public health or likely to create a nuisance. 
(Code 1973, § 5-38; Code 1995, § 14-12) 
Sec. 14-13. - Complaint of unsanitary conditions; hearing. 
    Whenever a complaint is made to the city council that the animals mentioned in section 14-15 are creating an unsanitary or obnoxious condition, the city council shall give notice of a hearing to be held at which the party complained against and the complainants shall be present. If, upon hearing the matter, the city council deems the condition unsanitary, it shall revoke the license of the party complained against. 
(Code 1973, § 5-43; Code 1995, § 14-13) 
Sec. 14-14. - Keeping of fowl or animals. 
    No person shall keep within the city any fowl, chickens or rabbits within 30 feet of a dwelling house or 12 feet of a lot line without a permit from the county health department. 
(Code 1973, § 5-34; Code 1995, § 14-14) 
Sec. 14-15. - Animals or poultry-License to raise. 
(a)  Any person engaged in raising or breeding poultry, pigeons, rabbits, hares or guinea pigs for commercial purposes or otherwise shall obtain a license. 
(b)  Each application shall state the number and kind of poultry or animals to be raised and the location of the premises to be used for that purpose. 
(Code 1973, § 5-39; Code 1995, § 14-15) 
Sec. 14-16. - Same-Sanitary conditions for raising. 
    All persons raising poultry or animals within the city, whether for commercial purposes or otherwise, shall be required to keep the poultry or animals at all times in a clean and sanitary condition and free from obnoxious odors. 
(Code 1973, § 5-41; Code 1995, § 14-16) 
Sec. 14-17. - Turning cattle from enclosed premises. 
    No person shall turn from his enclosed premises any cattle, horses, goats or hogs unless such animals are turned over to the care of some person at the time such cattle, horses, goats or hogs are turned out of the premises of the owner. 
(Code 1973, § 5-42; Code 1995, § 14-17) 
Sec. 14-18. - Exhibition of animals breeding in public. 
    No person shall exhibit a stallion, jackass, bull or other animal kept for breeding purposes in any public place, while breeding. 
(Code 1973, § 5-44; Code 1995, § 14-18) 
Sec. 14-19. - Dead animals-Covering of carcasses for human consumption during transport. 
    The body or part of any animal to be used for human food shall not be transported through any streets, unless it is covered so as to protect it from insects, animals, dust and dirt. 
(Code 1973, § 5-45; Code 1995, § 14-19) 
Sec. 14-20. - Same-Removal; costs. 
(a)  No person shall permit any dead horse, cow, sheep or other animal carcass to remain within the city longer than a reasonable time for removing or burying the same, which shall be done in accordance with any of the county health department rules and regulations. 
(b)  The charge for removal by the city of any dead horse or cow shall be as established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 5-46; Code 1995, § 14-20) 
Sec. 14-21. - Same-Burial. 
    When a dead animal is found in the city, the owner shall promptly and properly bury the animal when notified to do so by the county health department. Where the owner is unknown or neglects or refuses, the health officer shall bury the animal. Refusal or neglect by the owner is punishable as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1973, § 5-47; Code 1995, § 14-21) 
Sec. 14-22. - Same-Mutilation. 
    No person shall skin, cut, or in any manner, mutilate the body of any deceased animal within the city when the animal is to be taken away or disposed of by the city. 
(Code 1973, § 5-48; Code 1995, § 14-22) 
Sec. 14-23. - Minimum area limitation for keeping animals. 
(a)  No animal shall be kept on any lot or parcel of land within the city consisting of less than 10,000 square feet in area. 
(b)  The provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to the keeping of: 
(1)  Small household pets to include, but not limited to, dogs and cats; or 
(2)  Animals for commercial purposes where such use is established as a lawful use under the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1973, § 5-56; Code 1995, § 14-23) 
Sec. 14-24. - Cruelty to animals; exception. 
(a)  No person shall override, overdrive, overload, drive when overloaded, torture, torment, deprive of necessary sustenance, cruelly beat, mutilate or cruelly kill, or cause or procure to be overridden, overdriven, driven when overloaded, tortured, tormented, deprived of necessary sustenance, cruelly beaten, mutilated or cruelly killed, any animal. No person having the charge or custody of such animal, either as owner or otherwise, shall inflict unnecessary cruelty upon the animal, or fail to provide the animal with proper food, drink or protection from the weather, or cruelly drive the animal when unfit for labor. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed as prohibiting the dehorning of cattle. 
(Code 1973, § 5-49; Code 1995, § 14-24) 
State Law reference- Cruelty to animals generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-14. 
Sec. 14-25. - Fastening animals to trees; impoundment. 
(a)  No person shall at any time fasten any horse or other animal to any hydrant, shade tree, or to any box or case around such tree, or to any public ornamental tree on any street or public ground. 
(b)  Any police officers or other authorized persons may impound the animal so fastened until any penalty as may be provided and any expenses reasonably incurred in keeping and caring for the animal are paid. If the fine and charges are not paid within seven days, the animal shall be deemed a stray and treated as provided for in article III of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 5-52; Code 1995, § 14-25) 
Sec. 14-26. - Injuring or poisoning animals. 
(a)  No person who accidentally or otherwise strikes an animal with an auto and injures it shall leave the scene without rendering aid and assistance in the care of such animal. 
(b)  No person shall willfully or negligently poison any animal. 
(Code 1973, § 5-50; Code 1995, § 14-26) 
Sec. 14-27. - Diseased animals. 
    Every person owning or having any animal under his charge within the city which he knows or suspects has been affected by any communicable disease, in particular by glanders or anthrax, shall isolate the animal from other animals and shall report the existence or suspected existence of such disease to the county health department. 
(Code 1973, § 5-51; Code 1995, § 14-27) 
Sec. 14-28. - Animals running at large. 
    No owner or custodian shall permit any cattle, horse, mule, sheep, goat, geese, ducks, chickens or any other animal to run at large within the city. Tying such animal for grazing in any street or other public place shall be deemed running at large within the meaning of this section. To permit running at large is declared to be a nuisance and dangerous to public health and safety. 
(Code 1973, § 5-57; Code 1995, § 14-28) 
Sec. 14-29. - Dangerous animals running at large; exception. 
(a)  No person shall permit any bear, or other noxious or dangerous animal to run at large, or lead such animal, muzzled or unmuzzled, with chain or rope, or other appliance on any street, public place, or public way of the city. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to a lawfully conducted circus or carnival parade or theatrical performance. 
(Code 1973, § 5-58; Code 1995, § 14-29) 
Sec. 14-30. - Animal running at large by accident. 
    No animal running at large by accident with a person in immediate pursuit of it shall be deemed a stray within the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 5-59; Code 1995, § 14-30) 
Sec. 14-31. - Pets in eight-story residential buildings. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any pet owner to house pets in any residential structure, located within the municipal limits of the city, consisting of eight stories or more. 
(b)  Any person who violates any section of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Any person who violates any section of this article shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-8. 
(c)  Animals that are used to assist handicapped persons (e.g., guide dogs for persons with vision impairments, hearing dogs for persons with hearing impairments and emotional support animals for persons with chronic mental illness) are exempt. 
(Ord. No. 3156, 6-9-2001) 
Secs. 14-32-14-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS 

Sec. 14-51. - License tag-Required. 
    No person shall possess, keep or harbor within the corporate limits of the city after the month of February in any year any dog that does not have attached to it a dog license tag for such year issued by the clerk and treasurer. 
(Code 1973, § 5-4; Code 1995, § 14-51) 
Sec. 14-52. - Same-Preparation; contents; issuance. 
(a)  The clerk and treasurer shall prepare, or cause to be prepared, an adequate number of dog license tags for issuance for each calendar year. 
(b)  A dog license tag shall consist of a metal disk having inscribed thereon the number of the calendar year for which issued and also the words, "City of Bessemer Dog License." The dog license tags shall be numbered serially. 
(c)  One tag shall be issued by the clerk and treasurer for the appropriate calendar year for each dog for which application for such tag is made, when the requirements of section 14-53 are complied with. 
(Code 1973, § 5-5; Code 1995, § 14-52) 
Sec. 14-53. - Same-Fee; vaccination certificate. 
(a)  Before any dog license tag shall be issued for any dog, the applicant therefor shall pay the clerk and treasurer a tag issuance fee. He shall deliver to the clerk and treasurer the certificate of some person authorized in section 14-114 to vaccinate dogs showing the name, color, breed, sex, weight and age of the dog for which a dog license tag is sought, and that the dog described in the certificate has been vaccinated by such authorized person in accordance with sections 14-113 and 14-114 and showing, also, the date of vaccination, the name of the manufacturer of the vaccine administered, the manufacturer's lot number of the vaccine administered, the number of cubic centimeters of vaccine administered and the method of administration of the vaccine. 
(b)  Where five or more dogs all belonging to the same person are in the same kennel, humane society or pet shop a maximum annual fee for the issuance of dog license tags for such dogs shall be charged. 
(c)  The clerk and treasurer shall not issue any license tag for any dog for any calendar year other than the calendar year in which such certificate shows the dog was vaccinated. 
(d)  The amounts of the fees listed in this section shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 5-6; Code 1995, § 14-53) 
Sec. 14-54. - Same-Delinquent license fee. 
    All licenses required by section 14-51 which have not been paid within the month of February of each year shall be delinquent. A delinquent fee shall be added to the amount of such license. The amount of the fees shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 5-7; Code 1995, § 14-54) 
Sec. 14-55. - Same-Nontransferable. 
    No person shall permit or allow any dog in his charge or control within the corporate limits of the city to wear a dog license tag issued for a different dog. 
(Code 1973, § 5-8; Code 1995, § 14-54) 
Sec. 14-56. - Noisy dogs. 
    No person shall confine, harbor or keep at any place or any premises, within the corporate limits of the city, any dog which habitually, continuously or intermittently makes or emits sounds or noises of such volume as to be a public nuisance by reason of being obnoxious or annoying to the ordinary persons in that neighborhood. 
(Code 1973, § 5-9; Code 1995, § 14-56) 
Sec. 14-57. - Vicious dogs; confinement. 
    No owner or any other person in charge of any vicious dog shall harbor or keep at any place or on any premises within the corporate limits of the city a vicious dog unless the dog is securely confined or bound in such a manner as to prevent it from biting or attacking any person or other animal. 
(Code 1973, § 5-10; Code 1995, § 14-57) 
Sec. 14-58. - Running at large-Prohibited. 
    No owner or custodian of any dog shall knowingly allow such dog to run at large within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 5-11; Code 1995, § 14-58) 
Sec. 14-59. - Same-Exception. 
(a)  No owner or person in charge of a dog shall cause or permit such dog to run or be at large on or about any lot or premises, within the corporate limits of the city, unless the dog is securely and effectively confined to such lot or premises by a wall, fence or other enclosure. 
(b)  Whenever a dog is permitted to run at large within a wall, fence or other enclosure, as provided under this section, it shall be the duty of the owner or person in charge of such dog to give public notice or warning. The warning shall be conspicuously posted at every unlocked entrance to such enclosure, that such dog is at large within the enclosure. 
(Code 1973, § 5-12; Code 1995, § 14-59) 
Sec. 14-60. - Leash required. 
    No owner or person in charge of a dog shall cause or permit such dog to run or be upon a street, sidewalk, thoroughfare or public place, within the corporate limits of the city, unless the dog is attached to a leash in the hands of the owner or person in charge. 
(Code 1973, § 5-13; Code 1995, § 14-60) 
Secs. 14-61-14-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - IMPOUNDMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to impound animals running at large, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-110. 

Sec. 14-81. - Animals at large. 
    Any animal let or permitted to run at large in violation of provisions of this article shall be impounded at the owner's expense until the penalty for the violation is paid. 
(Code 1973, § 5-60; Code 1995, § 14-81) 
Sec. 14-82. - Interference with officer impounding. 
    No person shall willfully prevent or obstruct the impounding of any animal in violation of any of the provisions of this article or shall take any animal out of any pound without the consent of the rabies control officer, or shall knowingly impound or attempt to impound any animal not legally liable to impoundment. 
(Code 1973, § 5-24; Code 1995, § 14-82) 
Sec. 14-83. - Power to impound dogs. 
    Any officer or agent authorized or empowered to perform any duty under this article is authorized to go upon any premises and seize for impounding any dog which he may lawfully seize when such officer is in immediate pursuit of such dog, except upon the premises of the owner of the dog if the owner is present and forbids the entry of the officer or agent. A warrant shall then issue according to law at the request of such officer or agent. 
(Code 1973, § 5-15; Code 1995, § 14-83) 
Sec. 14-84. - Impounding dogs. 
    The rabies control officer may seize and take into custody and impound or cause to be taken into custody and impounded and thereafter destroyed or disposed of as provided in this article: 
(1)  Any dog off the premises of the owner which official or his agent have reason to believe is a stray dog; 
(2)  Any dog off the premises of the owner without a current registration tag on his collar; 
(3)  Any female dog in season off the premises of the owner; and 
(4)  Any dog which is permitted to run at large within the city contrary to section 14-58. 
(Code 1973, § 5-17; Code 1995, § 14-84) 
Sec. 14-85. - Officer may impound animal at large. 
    Any police officer or other officer designated by the city is authorized to capture and impound any animal found at large in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1973, § 5-61; Code 1995, § 14-85) 
Sec. 14-86. - Property owner may impound animal. 
    Any person who finds an animal or fowl on his property to his injury or annoyance may: 
(1)  Remove such animal or fowl to an animal shelter, public or private; or 
(2)  Retain possession of such animal or fowl and, as soon as possible, notify the humane society or other appropriate existing agency of this custody, giving a description of the animal and the owner's name, if known. 
(Code 1973, § 5-53; Code 1995, § 14-86) 
Sec. 14-87. - Impounding by residents. 
    Any resident of the city may take up any animal found running at large and deliver it to a police officer or other authorized person for impounding, or he may impound the animal in the city pound. 
(Code 1973, § 5-16; Code 1995, § 14-87) 
Sec. 14-88. - Qualifications for redeemer. 
    The owner of an impounded dog or animal may redeem it as provided for in section 14-92. However, at the expiration of the impoundment period, any other person may claim the dog or animal, provided such person pays the fees set out in section 14-92. 
(Code 1973, § 5-19; Code 1995, § 14-90) 
Sec. 14-89. - Disposition of unredeemed animals; sale. 
(a)  When a dog or animal has been impounded in accordance with this article and has not been redeemed by his owner, the poundkeeper or agent of the humane society or any person authorized under this article to do so may cause the dog or animal to be sold or destroyed in a humane manner. 
(b)  Any dog or animal which has remained in the pound over 14 days and which has not been redeemed by the owner, may be sold by the city to the highest bidder for cash, provided that: 
(1)  No dog or cat may be sold for less than $3.00, plus the cost of maintenance and rabies inoculation; or 
(2)  No animal may be sold for less than $10.00, plus the cost of maintenance. 
(Code 1973, § 5-20; Code 1995, § 14-91) 
Sec. 14-90. - Collection of fine where sale proceeds are insufficient. 
    When the proceeds of the sale are insufficient to satisfy the costs, fees and penalties incurred, the balance of the debt owing may be collected by the city through due process of law. 
(Code 1973, § 5-22; Code 1995, § 14-93) 
Sec. 14-91. - Record of impounded animals. 
(a)  Any officer or agent authorized to impound an animal under the provisions of this article, who impounds an animal, shall make a record of the breed, color and sex of the animal and whether or not it is licensed. 
(b)  If the animal is licensed, the officer shall enter the name and address of the owner and number of the license tag. The officer shall also enter in the record the disposition made of such animal. 
(Code 1973, § 5-23; Code 1995, § 14-94) 
Sec. 14-92. - Redemption prior to sale; fees. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the poundkeeper or any agent authorized or empowered to perform any duty under this article, to take up and impound any animal running at large, found loose, or grazing or feeding in violation of this section. Such animal picked up by animal control will be kept for a period of two weeks. If after such time the animal is not claimed, animal control retains the right to sell said animal for a price of not more than $250.00 or release animal into the care of a charitable organization so designated by the city. 
(b)  If, before the day of sale, any animal so taken up and impounded is applied for by the owner or person entitled to its custody, it shall be released to the owner by the poundkeeper or any agent authorized or empowered to perform any duty under this article, on the payment of the actual cost of impounding, feeding and maintaining such animal. 
(c)  The proceeds of all sales of any such animal taken up and impounded as aforesaid shall be paid into the revenue department, but if any surplus of proceeds of sale remain after paying the charges and expenses thereof and all expenses for impounding, feeding and maintaining such animal, such surplus shall be paid to the owner of the animal from the sale of which the proceeds were derived, upon satisfactory proof of the ownership being made. 
(d)  An impoundment fee for all animals placed in the animal shelter operated by the city shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(e)  Additional fees. The owner of any animal impounded by the city will also be liable for the cost of maintenance, care, feed, or any other costs incurred in housing such animal. Such cost will be ascertained and determined by the poundkeeper or any agent authorized or empowered to perform any duty under this article. 
(Code 1973, § 5-21; Code 1995, § 14-92; Ord. No. 3219, 5-27-2003) 
Secs. 14-93-14-112. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RABIES CONTROL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Rabies generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 3-7A-1 et seq. 

Sec. 14-113. - Vaccination of dogs required. 
    No person shall possess, keep or harbor within the corporate limits of the city after the month of February of any year any dog which has not been vaccinated within such year as provided in section 14-53. 
(Code 1973, § 5-26; Code 1995, § 14-116) 
Sec. 14-114. - Inoculation; sufficiency.
