    In order to be sufficient under this article, the vaccination of a dog shall be accomplished by a physician, surgeon or veterinarian duly licensed as such by the state board of veterinary medical examiners, or by a rabies inspector or deputy rabies inspector appointed pursuant to the state law, by means of injection beneath the skin of such dog of at least five cubic centimeters of canine anti-rabies vaccine, manufactured by a person licensed for such manufacture by the United States Public Health Service for each 20 pounds, or fraction of 20 pounds, of the weight of the dog up to 80 pounds of such weight. 
(Code 1973, § 5-27; Code 1995, § 14-117) 
Sec. 14-115. - Knowledge or suspicion of rabies; confinement. 
    No person shall keep, harbor or maintain on or about any place or premises within the corporate limits of the city a dog, cat or other animal that is known to have or reasonably suspected of having rabies, unless the animal is securely confined in such a manner as to effectually prevent contact with or injury to other animals or persons. Any such animal not so confined shall either be destroyed or removed to the city pound or other appropriate place by a person designated for that purpose by the city and there securely confined. 
(Code 1973, § 5-28; Code 1995, § 14-118) 
Sec. 14-116. - Period of confinement of animal after person bitten. 
    No person shall keep, harbor or maintain on or about any place or premises within the corporate limits of the city a dog, cat or other animal which has bitten or otherwise injured a human being in such a manner as to permit or favor the transmission or suspected transmission of the virus of rabies to such human being, unless such dog, cat or other animal is securely confined in such a manner as to prevent its disappearance or escape for not less than 14 days or such minimum period of time following such bite or injury as may be reasonably necessary for the purpose of determining whether such dog, cat or other animal is afflicted with rabies, either by physical examination or observation done by or on behalf of the county board of health. 
(Code 1973, § 5-29; Code 1995, § 14-119) 
Sec. 14-117. - Period of confinement of animal after animal bitten. 
    No person shall keep, harbor or maintain on or about any place or premises within the corporate limits of the city a dog, cat or other animal whatsoever which has been or is reasonably suspected of having been bitten, or otherwise injured by or having been in contact with another animal afflicted with or suspected of being afflicted with rabies in such a manner as to permit or favor transmission of such disease unless such dog, cat or other animal so bitten, injured or in contact shall be securely confined for not less than six months thereafter. 
(Code 1973, § 5-30; Code 1995, § 14-120) 
Sec. 14-118. - Impounding rabid animals; inoculation. 
    When a dog, cat or other animal is found in or about any street, public thoroughfare, public place, lot or premises or portions of premises within the corporate limits of the city, except in accordance with the provisions of this article, it shall be the duty of any police officer or other person employed for that purpose to take such animal into custody and remove or cause the animal to be removed to the city pound and placed in charge of the rabies control officer to be held and properly disposed of before any such dog, cat or other animal is released, it shall be appropriately inoculated at the expense of the owner for the purpose of immunizing it against rabies. 
(Code 1973, § 5-31; Code 1995, § 14-121) 
Sec. 14-119. - Removal of animal to pound; destruction. 
(a)  The health officer shall have the right at any time to move, or cause to be moved, to the city pound, or other place designated by him, for observation or examination, any dog, cat or other animal which is reasonably suspected to be afflicted with rabies, or which has bitten or otherwise injured a human being in such a manner as would permit or favor the transmission of the virus of rabies in the event such animal should be afflicted with rabies, or which has been, or is reasonably suspected to have been bitten or injured, or in contact with another having or suspected of having rabies. 
(b)  No person shall hinder, obstruct or interfere with the health officer, or his authorized agent or deputy, in the exercise of the authority conferred upon him in this chapter. It shall be the duty of the health officer to destroy, or cause to be destroyed, any animal found to be afflicted with rabies. 
(Code 1973, § 5-32; Code 1995, § 14-122) 
Sec. 14-120. - Disposition of impounded dogs suffering from rabies or other infectious disease; rabies tests. 
(a)  Any impounded dog which appears to be suffering from rabies or affected with hydrophobia, mange or other infectious or dangerous disease or which has attacked any person shall be kept at the pound until such time and under such conditions as required by the rabies control officer. The rabies control officer shall notify the county health department when he has good reason to believe that such dog is in his possession. 
(b)  Whenever in the judgment of the rabies control officer or the city health department it becomes necessary to test a dog or the remains of a dog suspected of being rabid, the dog shall be sent to a veterinarian and/or state laboratory for rabies-hydrophobia testing and disposition. The fees, costs and expenses of such tests shall be paid by the owner of the dog except as otherwise provided by law. 
(Code 1973, § 5-25; Code 1995, § 14-123) 
Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt building laws and inspect buildings, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-59; authority to adopt technical codes by reference, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-8; state building construction standards, Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-9-160 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Liability of city officials. 
    No officer, agent, or employee of the city shall render himself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this chapter. He shall be defended by the city attorney until the final determination of the proceedings therein. 
(Code 1973, § 6-56; Code 1995, § 18-1) 
Sec. 18-2. - Technical codes; on file. 
    At least three copies of the technical codes adopted by reference shall be on file in the office of the clerk and treasurer for public inspection and use. 
(Code 1973, § 6-1(b); Code 1995, § 18-2) 
Sec. 18-3. - Payment of permit and inspection fees. 
    All fees for permits and inspections required under this chapter shall be paid at the office of revenue department. 
(Code 1995, § 18-3; Ord. No. 2551, § VI, 9-17-1991) 
Sec. 18-4. - Unused permits; refunds. 
(a)  The city clerk and treasurer is authorized to make refunds of amounts paid for permits issued under this chapter at any time within 90 days after the issuance of the permits, provided the building inspection officer certifies in writing to the city clerk and treasurer as follows: The permit for which the refund is requested has not been utilized to begin any work, and no such work is planned. Any refund made under the provisions of this section shall be subject to an administrative charge, which amount shall be deducted from the refund applied for. 
(b)  The amount of the administrative charge shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 18-4; Ord. No. 2551, § VII, 9-17-1991) 
Sec. 18-5. - Fees for additional work. 
    If during the performance of the work or installation or alteration permitted by a permit granted under this chapter, additional installations or alterations are required, it shall be unlawful for the person who secured the original permit to fail to immediately remit to the city clerk and treasurer an amount that is equal to the additional fees for permits and inspections incurred by the additional installations or alterations. Any fees not immediately remitted for installation or alteration of work not permitted on the original permit shall be subject to a fee double the specific fees provided by law to be paid for a timely permit. 
(Code 1995, § 18-5; Ord. No. 2551, § VIII, 9-17-1991) 
Sec. 18-6. - Permit-Double permit fees. 
(a)  When work for which a permit is required by this chapter is commenced prior to the obtaining of a permit, the permit applicant shall be required to pay a penalty, as provided by section 18-9, plus a double permit fee. The payment of the required fee shall not relieve any person from fully complying with all of the requirements of all applicable regulations and codes of this chapter, nor shall it relieve them from being subject to any of the penalties therein. The double fee requirement shall be applicable to all divisions of the building and zoning department, as noted in this section. 
(b)  The amounts of the permit fee and penalty shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 10-13; Code 1995, § 18-6; Ord. No. 2551, § IX, 9-17-1991) 
Sec. 18-7. - Same-Issuance; separate permits. 
(a)  If the building inspection officer is satisfied that the work described in an application for a permit and that the drawings and specifications which may be filed therewith conform to the requirements of this chapter, then a permit shall be issued to the applicant. 
(b)  No building permit shall be issued by the city for any structure within the corporate limits of the city or its police or fire jurisdiction until such time as said permits have been reviewed by the fire chief or his agent for the fire department of the city, single-family dwellings excepted. 
(c)  A separate permit must be obtained for the work on each structure or for each separate piece of work of any description including alterations, additions and general repairs, except for minor repairs. 
(Code 1995, § 18-7; Ord. No. 2551, § X, 9-17-1991; Ord. No. 3024, 6-2-1998) 
Sec. 18-8. - Same-Commencement of work; time extensions. 
    The building inspection officer shall act upon an application for a permit with drawings and/or specifications, as filed, or as amended, without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. A permit issued shall be construed to proceed with the work and shall not be construed as authority to violate, cancel, alter or set aside any of the provisions of this chapter, nor shall such issuance of a permit prevent the building inspection officer from thereafter requiring correction of errors in construction or of violations of this chapter. Any permit issued shall become invalid unless the work authorized by it shall have been commenced within 90 days after its issuance, or if the work authorized by such permit is suspended, cancelled, or abandoned for a period of 90 days after the time the work is commenced, provided that, for cause, one or more extensions of time for periods not exceeding 90 days each, may be allowed in writing by the building inspection officer. 
(Code 1995, § 18-8; Ord. No. 2551, § XI, 9-17-1991) 
Sec. 18-9. - Citations for violations of chapter. 
(a)  The building inspection officer or any city police officer shall serve upon the owner of property or each person engaged in the activities regulated under this chapter, which activities are being conducted in violation of this chapter, a citation to appear in the municipal court at a time and date specified thereon to answer the charge of such violation of this chapter; provided, however, that prior to 12:00 noon on the date this matter is to be set before the municipal court, such person charged in such citation, if he has not previously settled or been convicted of three or more such violations within 12 months of the date of such citation, may dispose of the citation by settlement involving payment to the clerk of the municipal court a fine for the offenses charged, plus any and all charges otherwise payable to the city pursuant to the terms and conditions of this chapter. If the offense charged is the third such offense by the owner or person charged within 12 months from the date of such citations, settlement cannot be voluntarily made to the clerk of the municipal court as referred to in this section. If the settlement of the charges set out in the citation is not made prior to 12:00 noon of the date the case is set for trial in the municipal court, and if the party charged fails to appear and answer such charge in the municipal court at the time and place set out in such citation, or if the citation is not otherwise disposed of by such court, a warrant shall be issued charging such party with the violation set out in the citation, which warrant shall be obtained, served and tried as provided by law for the arrest and trial of the offenses involving violations of the ordinances of the city. If a person receiving a citation as provided in this section has, within the prescribed 12 months from the date such citation settled or been convicted of three or more such violations, he shall not be permitted to settle the instant alleged offense, but shall be required to stand trial in the municipal court. 
(b)  Once the warrant has been issued and tried before the municipal court, a person found guilty of such violations shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided according to the provisions of section 1-8, which shall include the payment of any fines levied by the municipal court, plus any court costs as provided and issued by the municipal court. 
(c)  The violation of a provision of this chapter as such provision is presently existing or as hereinafter modified or amended, shall be punished by the provisions of this chapter in the case of voluntary settlement, as provided in any general ordinance of the city. Each day such offense continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  All citations shall be signed by the building inspection officer finding such violations and shall be sent by certified mail to the contractor responsible for the permit or to the owner of the property on which the violation is found, as such owner's name and address appears in the records of the county tax assessor's office. 
(e)  The amount of any fine prescribed in this section shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fine schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 18-9; Ord. No. 2551, § XII, 9-17-1991) 
Sec. 18-10. - Permit issuance fee. 
    There shall be a fee charged for the issuance of all building, plumbing, electrical, gas, house moving, and demolition permits. Such fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 18-10; Ord. No. 2014, § 1, 3-21-1978) 
Sec. 18-11. - Department of building inspection services. 
(a)  Created; chief to head department. There is created a department of building inspection services. The chief of inspection services shall be designated as the head of the department of inspection services of the city. 
(b)  Duties of chief. The duties of chief of inspection services shall be as follows: 
(1)  Organize and direct building inspections and building code enforcement services; direct housing code enforcement; act as zoning administrator and do related work as required. 
(2)  Consult with the city council on all laws and ordinances pertaining to building regulations and codes. 
(3)  Consult with and advise engineers, attorneys, contractors, property owners, and mechanics on building construction. 
(c)  Qualifications for chief. Applicants for chief of inspection services shall meet all the requirements as set out by the county personnel board and shall be appointed from the eligible list submitted by the county personnel board. 
(Code 1973, §§ 2-30.1-2-30.3; Code 1995, § 18-11) 
Sec. 18-12. - Building inspection officer; establishment. 
    There shall be a building inspection officer whose duties, powers, qualifications and compensation shall be as established by law or determined from time to time by the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 6-3; Code 1995, § 18-12) 
Sec. 18-13. - References to officials and departments in adopted technical codes. 
    Where reference is made to the duties of certain officials or departments named within the technical codes which are adopted by reference in this chapter, then that designated official of the city or of the county, who has duties corresponding to those of the named official in said technical code, shall be deemed to be the responsible official insofar as enforcing the provisions of that technical code are concerned. 
Sec. 18-14. - Permit fees. 
    Unless otherwise specified, the fees and/or charges for permits, certificates, inspections, or re-inspections as required under this chapter shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and will appear in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
Secs. 18-15-18-31. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING AND RESIDENTIAL CODE 

Sec. 18-32. - Adoption of building code. 
    The 2015 edition of the International Building Code, published by the ICC is hereby adopted by reference pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-8 and is incorporated as is set out and fully herein with the following modifications, amendments and additions to the below sections: 
(1)  105.2. Delete section 105.2 of the 2015 International Building Code and any other sections dealing with work exempt from permits. 
(2)  107.1. Delete section 107.1 in its entirety and replace with the following: 
Section 107.1 Submittal Documents. Submittal Documents consisting of construction documents, statement of special inspections, geotechnical report and other data shall be submitted in two or more sets with each permit application and in such form and detail as required by the building code official for all structures classified as Group A, E, and I, as defined by the International Codes, and all structures that contain 5000 square feet or more in area. The construction documents shall be prepared by a registered architect or engineer legally registered under the laws of this state regulating the practice of architecture or engineering and shall affix his official seal to said drawings, specifications and accompanying data. Where special conditions exist, the building official is authorized to require additional construction documents to be prepared by a registered design professional. 
(3)  111.1 Delete section 111.1 in its entirety and replace with the following: 
Section 111.1 Use and Occupancy. No building or structure shall be used or occupied, and no change in the existing occupancy classification of a building or structure or portion thereof shall be made until the building official and the fire official has issued a certificate of occupancy thereof and provided herein. Issuance of a certificate of occupancy shall not be construed as an approval of a violation of the provisions of this code or of other ordinances of the City of Bessemer. 
(Code 1995, § 18-36; Ord. No. 2549, § 1, 9-17-1991; Ord. No. 3025, § 1, 6-2-1998; Ord. No. 3283, § 3, 5-17-2005; Ord. No. 3431, § 2, 3-23-2010; Ord. No. 3531, § 1, 4-7-2015) 
Sec. 18-33. - Adoption of residential code. 
    The 2015 edition of the International Residential Code, published by the ICC is hereby adopted by reference pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-8 and is incorporated as is set out and fully herein with the following modifications, amendments and additions to the below sections: 
(1)  R105.2. Delete section R105.2 of the 2015 International Residential Code and any other sections dealing with work exempt from permits. 
(2)  R313. Delete section R313 of the 2015 International Residential Code. Automatic fire sprinkler systems for single-family homes shall not be required. 
(3)  R403. Amend that section 403.1(1) reads as follows: 
Section R403 Footings. That all footings shall have a minimum of two #4 bars placed in the middle third of the footing depth. 
(Ord. No. 3283, § 6, 5-17-2005; Ord. No. 3431, § 5, 3-23-2010; Ord. No. 3436, § 1.A, 5-4-2010; Ord. No. 3531, § 2, 4-7-2015) 
Sec. 18-34. - Building permit fees. 
    Each person engaged in excavation work, building or constructing any individual building, remodeling, adding to air conditioning, roofing, reroofing, storage tanks, fire sprinkler systems or repairing any existing building shall submit plans of each building, construction, addition, remodeling, air conditioning, roofing, reroofing, or repair to the city. For the purpose of determining the fee for the issuance of a building permit, the evaluations of the requested work shall be determined by bona fide signed contracts or other evidence of cost as submitted by the persons requesting a building permit. However, in no event shall the evaluation of the requested work be less than the average cost of construction as set out in the Building Valuation Data (BVD) chart, as revised every six months, in the most current edition of the Building Safety Journal, which is published by the International Code Council. The following charges shall be made for the issuance of building permits based on the contract or estimated cost as referred to in this section: 
(1)  The minimum building permit fee as established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code, regardless of any additional amount indicated in this section. 
(2)  In the contracts or estimated costs, as determined by the Building Valuation Data (BVD) chart in the most current edition of the Building Safety Journal as published by the International Code Council and referred to in this section, whichever is greater, if such work is $100.00 and less than $2,500.00 in value, the building permit fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(3)  Where the contracts or estimated costs, as determined by the Building Valuation Data (BVD) chart in the most current edition of the Building Safety Journal as published by the International Code Council and referred to in this section, is over $2,500.00, the building permit fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. There shall be a reinspection fee established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code, when necessitated by faulty materials, equipment or workmanship. 
(4)  The fee for occupancy on any building without a certificate of occupancy in violation of this article shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(5)  Trailers approved for construction field offices shall pay a fee when placed on a construction site before utilities can be connected. This shall be for a period of one year and another fee must be paid again at the end of one year if construction is not completed. The fees shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. The trailer office must be moved before the final inspection of the building. 
(Code 1995, § 18-37; Ord. No. 2551, § I, 9-17-1991) 
Secs. 18-35-18-58. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICAL CODE 

Sec. 18-59. - Adoption. 
    The 2011 edition of the National Electric Code compiled by the NFPA is hereby adopted by reference pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-8 and is incorporated as is set out and fully herein. 
(Code 1995, § 18-61; Ord. No. 2589, § 1, 4-6-1993; Ord. No. 3025, § 1, 6-2-1998; Ord. No. 3283, § 2, 5-17-2005; Ord. No. 3531, § 4, 4-7-2015) 
Sec. 18-60. - Electricians-Certification requirements. 
(a)  No person other than a holder of a certificate of competency or a holder of a certificate of registration as an apprentice electrician shall do any electrical installation or construction work in the city. 
(b)  No holder of a certificate of competency shall employ as an assistant in any work as described in subsection (a) of this section any person other than a holder of a certificate of competency or the holder of a certificate of registration as an apprentice electrician. 
(c)  No holder of a certificate of competency shall require a registered apprentice electrician to do any such electrical work other than under his direct supervision. 
(d)  No registered apprentice electrician shall do any such electrical work other than while under the direct supervision of the holder of a certificate of competency. 
(e)  No holder of a maintenance electrician's certificate shall make any alterations or additions to the wiring systems of the person by whom he is employed. 
(Code 1973, § 10-41; Code 1995, § 18-62) 
Sec. 18-61. - Same-Employees of contractor. 
    No electrical contractor shall employ any person on any job in the capacity of a journeyman electrician, unless such person shall have in his possession a valid journeyman's certificate of competency, issued to him as provided in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 10-40; Code 1995, § 18-63) 
Sec. 18-62. - Same-Bond; license required. 
    Before any person shall engage in the electrical business within the city limits he shall qualify as set forth in this article and post bond in the amount of $5,000.00 ensuring that all work is done in accordance with the rules and regulations of the city, which shall be filed with the city clerk and treasurer, and obtain a license. 
(Code 1995, § 18-63; Ord. No. 2163, 2-23-1982) 
Sec. 18-63. - Unauthorized connections to installations. 
    No person shall make connections from a source of electrical energy to any electric wiring, devices or equipment for the installation of which a permit is required, until a certificate of approval has been issued by the city electrician authorizing such connection and the use of such wiring, devices or equipment. 
(Code 1973, § 10-19; Code 1995, § 18-65) 
Sec. 18-64. - Sale of electrical equipment; markings; defacing markings. 
(a)  No person shall sell, offer or expose for sale at retail and/or wholesale or dispose by gift, premium or similar manner, any electrical material, apparatus, fitting, appliance, device or appurtenance, unless such electrical material, apparatus, fitting, appliance, device or appurtenance, shall conform in all respects to the provisions of this article. 
(b)  All electrical materials, apparatus, fittings, appliances, devices or appurtenances, sold, offered or exposed for sale, at retail or wholesale, or which are disposed of by gifts, premium or similar manner by any person shall bear the manufacturer's name, trademark or other identification symbol, along with markings giving operating voltage, type of current, wattage and other pertinent information as may be necessary to determine the character of the material, apparatus, fitting, appliance, device or appurtenance and the use for which it is intended. 
(c)  No person shall remove, alter, change, mar and/or deface any manufacturer's name, trademark, symbol or markings required by this section. 
(Code 1973, § 10-22; Code 1995, § 18-66) 
Sec. 18-65. - Electrical equipment; approval by underwriters. 
    No electrical material, apparatus, fitting, appliance, device or appurtenance shall be sold, offered or exposed for sale, at retail and/or wholesale or disposed of by gift, premium or other similar manner by any person, until such material, apparatus, fitting, appliance, device or appurtenance shall have been submitted to the laboratories of the National Board of Fire Underwriters and approval obtained. Only electrical materials, apparatus, fittings, appliances, devices or appurtenances appearing in the Listing of Approved Materials and Fittings of the Underwriter's Laboratories, shall be considered as having complied with this section. 
(Code 1973, § 10-23; Code 1995, § 18-67) 
Sec. 18-66. - Prohibited activities. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the business of electrical construction, installation or repair unless duly licensed by the city; provided, however, that any person who holds a valid statewide license shall be deemed qualified and, upon satisfactory proof of said license, shall be allowed to perform forthwith electrical work in any county or municipality under the terms and conditions set forth. 
(b)  No person shall permit the installation of any electrical wiring, apparatus or other appurtenances upon his premises, work, ways, machinery or plant except in strict accordance with all provisions of this article. 
(c)  No person shall maintain, operate or attempt to operate any electrical wiring, apparatus, equipment or other appurtenances, in or upon his premises, works, ways, machinery or plant, which has not been installed in strict accordance with this article. 
(Code 1973, § 10-43; Code 1995, § 18-68) 
Sec. 18-67. - Contractor's sign; requirements. 
    Each electrical contractor operating under a certificate granted in accordance with this article shall have displayed, in a conspicuous place in front of each and every place where work of an electrical nature or character is being done by him, a sign giving the name and address of the electrical contractor doing the work and the words "certified electrical contractor" in letters not less than two inches high. No such sign need be displayed in front of the place of minor repairs such as repairing or replacing flush and snap switches, fuses, lamp sockets, taping joints and repairing drop cords. 
(Code 1973, §§ 10-9(a)(1), 10-44; Code 1995, § 18-69) 
Sec. 18-68. - Meter loop or switch installation; permit and plan required. 
    Any application for a permit to install any meter loop or switch over 100 amperes capacity must be accompanied by a plan indicating the proposed size, rating, and location of the meter loop or switch, which plan must be approved by the city electrician. Such plan must show the branch circuits, the carrying capacity of each and each branch circuit shall have a carrying capacity of not less than the rating of the branch circuit and not less than the maximum load to be served. The minimum size wire shall not be smaller than no. 8 for ranges of 83/4 kw or greater rating nor smaller than no. 14 copper for other loads. 
(Code 1973, § 10-45; Code 1995, § 18-70; Ord. No. 2006, § 1, 1-10-1978) 
Sec. 18-69. - Requirements for overhead service wires. 
(a)  Service entrance assembly. The developer will, in wiring the individual buildings, cause the service entrance assembly to be so installed as to facilitate the installation by the city electric service, called "the company" in this section of overhead service wires. 
(b)  Service point. The company will designate the service point on each building. If the developer proceeds without consultation, he will be liable for relocating the service point if the company deems the location to be unsatisfactory. 
(c)  Meter base. The developer will install the proper meter base furnished by and to the specification of the company. Basically, this calls for the meter base to be securely fastened to the building at an elevation not to exceed 61/2 feet above the finished grade. 
(d)  Point of attachment. The developer must provide, at the service point designated by the company, a point of attachment of sufficient mechanical strength to support the service wires to be installed by the company. The point of attachment must provide a direct, unobstructed path to the nearest utility pole and provide for vertical clearance of the lowest conductor in the service of 18 feet over public streets, alleys or roads; 16 feet over driveways to residence garages; eight feet over accessible roofs and must be at least five feet measured horizontally from the nearest window opening. Upon application and a showing of undue hardship, this subsection's provisions may be waived if safety is maintained. 
(e)  Pipe masts. The use of a pipe mast extending above the roof is recommended when feasible. The pipe must be rigid steel conduit two inches or larger, fitted with a suitable weatherhead and anchored sufficiently to withstand the strain of the service wires. 
(f)  Inspection. The company will not proceed to install service equipment until after it has received approval of the wiring installation from the city inspection department. 
(Code 1995, § 18-71; Ord. No. 2006, § 2, 1-10-1978) 
Sec. 18-70. - Homeowner's permit examination; procedure. 
(a)  The building department official shall examine and pass upon the qualifications of every person who may apply for a homeowner's permit, to install electrical wiring in or on the premises he owns and occupies as a home. 
(b)  The examination shall cover only such subjects as pertain to the proper installation of wiring to lighting outlets, circuits, fixtures, switches, ranges and/or heaters. 
(c)  The applicant shall be required to make application for such permits on forms furnished by the city. There shall be no charge for a homeowner's examination. 
(Code 1973, § 10-30; Code 1995, § 18-72) 
Sec. 18-71. - Fraudulent use of licensee's credentials. 
    No person engaged in the business of electrical contracting in the city shall allow his name to be used by any other person, directly or indirectly, to obtain a permit for the construction of any work under his name, certificate, license or bond or make any misrepresentation or omission in his returns. 
(Code 1973, § 10-11; Code 1995, § 18-73) 
Sec. 18-72. - Enumeration of fees. 
    The electrical permit and construction fees shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and will be available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 10-12; Code 1995, § 18-86; Ord. No. 2035, § I, 12-19-1978; Ord. No. 2551, § III, 9-17-1991) 
Secs. 18-73-18-102. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MECHANICAL CODE 

Sec. 18-103. - Adoption.

Sec. 18-104. - Mechanical permit fees.

(b)  The mechanical permits shall have the same fee as building permits. For work of $100.00 up to $2,500.00 or less in value, and for work over $2,500.00, the permit fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code.

Section 605.3 Water service pipe. That no pressure rated piping as listed in Tables 605.3 and 605.4,except for Ductile Iron Pipe, shall be used in new underground piping for fire service mains within the fire jurisdiction in the City of Bessemer, both private and public, and shall be listed for fire protection service and comply with AWWA standards and NFPA 24.
