    The following is a schedule of icense classifications:

Sec. 22-23. - License fee schedules. 
    The license fee schedule shall be governed by the license code of the city adopted by Ordinance No. 2418 and as amended by Ordinance Nos. 2555, 2556, 2592, 2667 and 3036. 
(Ord. No. 3358, § 23, 12-18-2007) 
Sec. 22-24. - Exchange of information. 
(a)  The license officer may exchange tax returns, information, records, and other documents secured by the city, with other municipalities adopting similar ordinances for the exchange of taxpayer information, or with county or state authorities. The license officer may charge a reasonable fee for providing such information or documents. Any tax returns, information, records, or other documents so exchanged shall remain subject to the confidentiality provisions, restrictions, and criminal penalties for unauthorized disclosure as provided under state or city law. 
(b)  Any such exchange shall be for one or more of the following purposes: 
(1)  Collecting taxes due. 
(2)  Ascertaining the amount of taxes due from any person. 
(3)  Determining whether a person is liable for, or whether there is probable cause for believing a person might be liable for, the payment of any tax to a state, county, or city agency. 
(c)  Nothing herein shall prohibit the use of tax returns or tax information by the city in the proper administration of any matter administered by the license officer. The license officer may also divulge to a purchaser, prospective purchaser as defined pursuant to the regulations of the state department of revenue, or successor of a business or stock of goods the outstanding sales, use, or rental tax liability of the seller for which the purchaser, prospective purchaser as defined pursuant to the regulations of the state department of revenue, or successor may be liable pursuant to the Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-23-25, 40-23-82, or 40-12-224. 
(Ord. No. 3358, § 24, 12-18-2007) 
Sec. 22-25. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3468, adopted Aug. 16, 2011, repealed § 22-25 which pertained to license fees in police jurisdiction, and derived from Ord. No. 3358, § 25, adopted Dec. 18, 2007. 
Secs. 22-26-22-53. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BURGLAR ALARM SYSTEMS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Alarm system installers generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-1A-1 et seq.; municipal authority to regulate alarm installation through licenses, fees, and inspections, Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-1A-8. 

Sec. 22-54. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm equipment supplier means any person selling, leasing, installing, repairing or maintaining automatic protection devices or signaling devices. 
    Alarm system means an automatic protection device or signaling device, or both, which sends a voice alarm or other signal over regular public telephone lines or by regular frequency to the police department of the city upon detection of an unauthorized intrusion. 
    Automatic protection device means an electrically operated instrument which automatically sends a voice alarm or other signal over regular public telephone lines or by radio frequency to the police department of the city upon detection of an unauthorized intrusion. 
    False alarm means an alarm signal transmitted or made by an alarm system or automatic detection device which indicated the existence of an emergency situation and such situation is transmitted to the police department of the city when, in fact, no such emergency situation exists. 
    Signaling device means an electrically operated instrument, other than an automatic protection device, which transmits alarms upon receipt of a stimulus from a detection apparatus. 
(Code 1995, § 22-86; Ord. No. 2570, § 1, 5-26-1992) 
Sec. 22-55. - Service charge for false alarms. 
    In addition to other penalties for violations of this article, there shall be levied and charged a service charge per false alarm upon such persons whose alarm emits in excess of three false alarms within 90 days after such system has been installed for more than 60 days. The amount of the service charge shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 22-88; Ord. No. 2570, § 2, 5-26-1992) 
Sec. 22-56. - Automatic protection devices and signaling devices; installation requirements. 
(a)  Prior written approval of police or fire department. It shall be unlawful for any person to install, operate or maintain any automatic protection device which automatically transmits a message or warning to the city police department or fire department telephone lines or numbers without prior written approval of the police or fire department. 
(b)  Service organization and business license required to sell, install or repair. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in selling, leasing, installing, repairing or maintaining automatic protection devices or signaling devices in the city unless such person maintains a service organization capable of promptly and efficiently repairing, maintaining and otherwise servicing such systems or devices, and unless such person has complied with the other provisions of this article and has obtained a valid business license in the city. 
(c)  Permit from police or fire chief; fee. No alarm equipment supplier shall sell, lease or install in an institution, a public or commercial building in the city or its police jurisdiction any automatic protection device or signaling device without applying for and securing a permit from the chief of police or fire chief or his designee upon a form to be furnished by the city. A fee as provided in the city license schedule shall accompany each application for an alarm installation. This fee shall not be refundable in instances in which the permit is refused. 
(d)  Report to police or fire chief of location; patron; installer. An alarm equipment supplier, prior to installing, repairing, testing or servicing any alarm system, shall report to the chief of police or fire chief or their designee the address or location at which such installation, repair, test or servicing is to be performed, the name of the person requesting the same and the name and resident of the person who are to make such installation. 
(e)  Filing of employee list with police or fire chief. Each alarm equipment supplier now or hereafter doing business in the city shall file with the chief of police and fire chief on or before the first day of each calendar month a list setting out the name, date of birth and residence address of each person employed by such alarm equipment supplier during the immediately preceding calendar month. 
(f)  Alarm audibility time limit; in excess declared nuisance. No person shall install, operate or maintain in the city any signaling device which is designed to emit or which may be permitted to emit a sound alarm which is audible on a public street or adjacent premises for a continuous period of time of more than 15 minutes. Alarms ringing for a period in excess of 15 minutes are declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Code 1995, § 22-89; Ord. No. 2570, § 3, 5-26-1992) 
Sec. 22-57. - False alarms. 
(a)  Create safety hazard; danger of auto collision; police and firefighter diversion. The city council hereby finds that false alarms in the city constitute a hazard to the safety of police officers and firefighters of the city and the public in general. False alarms enhance the dangers of automobile collisions en route to burglary, robbery or fire alarms, substantially increase police officers' and firefighters' man-hour costs and divert police and fire resources from regularly assigned duties. 
(b)  Responsibility of operator. Each person upon whose premises or upon premises in his charge, control or possession on which there is maintained or operated an alarm system, shall be responsible for all false alarms transmitted by such alarm system. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or maintain an alarm system on any premises owned by him or in his charge, control or possession which transmits or emits in excess of three false alarms within 90 days after such system has been installed for more than 60 days. 
(c)  Report of corrective action by operator. The chief of police or fire chief may require from the appropriate person using, servicing, possessing or maintaining a faulty alarm system, proprietor alarm or audible alarm, a report in writing, within such reasonable period as is specified by the chief of police or fire chief, describing the corrective action which has been and will be taken to ensure the violation of this section will not reoccur. 
(Code 1995, § 22-90; Ord. No. 2570, § 4, 5-26-1992) 
Sec. 22-58. - Restrictions on use of alarm systems. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make or cause or commit to be made or caused, upon any premises occupied or controlled by him, any loud and unnecessary noise or sound emitted from an audible alarm system which is physically annoying to persons or which is so harsh or so prolonged in its use, time and place as to occasion physical discomfort, or which is injurious to the health, peace, comfort, privacy or tranquility of the inhabitants of the city or to any one of them. It shall be considered a violation of this article for an audible alarm system to emit a sound, otherwise herein prohibited, for a time longer than 15 consecutive minutes or for such other length of time as may be prescribed by written agreement with the city police chief. This section shall apply to audible alarm systems, whether now or hereafter installed. 
(Code 1995, § 22-91; Ord. No. 2570, § 5, 5-26-1992) 
Secs. 22-59-22-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DETECTIVES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- State and county license requirements for detective agencies, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-12-93. 

Sec. 22-90. - License application; contents; fee; bond. 
(a)  Applicants for a license as a private investigator or detective as required by section 22-6, shall file letters of application with the chief of police. 
(b)  The application shall contain: 
(1)  Personal data of the applicant as to his date of birth, place of birth, education, law enforcement experience and business experience; 
(2)  A complete and detailed record of any civil suits or criminal cases in which the applicant has been either a party or a witness; 
(3)  The applicant's present address and place of employment; and 
(4)  The name of at least three references as to the applicant's moral character. 
(c)  The applicant shall tender with his application a sum of money for the first year's license. 
(d)  The applicant shall submit with his application a surety bond in the sum of $50,000.00 with a guaranty bonding company authorized to do business in the state as surety to indemnify anyone who may be injured by the words or acts of the applicant in following the vocation, profession or business as a private investigator or detective. 
(Code 1973, § 7-107; Code 1995, § 22-111) 
Sec. 22-91. - Investigation of applicant required. 
    The chief of police shall make an investigation of each applicant for a license as a private investigator or detective, as required by section 22-6. After a full and complete investigation he shall recommend to the city council whether a license should be granted to such person. 
(Code 1973, § 7-108; Code 1995, § 22-112) 
Sec. 22-92. - Approval of city council required; filing bond. 
(a)  A license as required in section 22-90 as a private investigator or detective shall be issued only on the approval of the city council after recommendation by the chief of police. 
(b)  On the issuance of a license, the surety bond filed by the applicant shall be filed in the office of the county probate judge, city division. The cost of such recording shall be added to the license fee. 
(Code 1973, § 7-109; Code 1995, § 22-113) 
Secs. 22-93-22-114. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - GARAGE AND YARD SALES 

Sec. 22-115. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garage sale means the sale of surplus or unwanted personal property accumulated in the maintenance or operation of a home or dwelling. 
    Rummage sale means the sale of personal property belonging to a religious, charitable, civic or service organization or the sale of such personal property for the benefit of a religious, charitable, civic or service organization. 
    Yard sale means a synonym for a garage sale or rummage sale and having the same meaning and/or purpose. 
(Code 1995, § 22-136) 
Sec. 22-116. - Permit required; fee. 
    Prior to the commencement of any such garage sale, rummage sale or yard sale within the corporate limits of the city a permit must first be obtained from the license department, an application for which shall be made in writing to the license department accompanied by a fee as provided in the city license schedule and by a list of the names of all owners of the property participating in the sale. 
(Code 1995, § 22-138; Ord. No. 2208, 7-5-1983) 
Sec. 22-117. - Conduct of sales. 
(a)  Frequency. No person or organization shall conduct such a sale more than once during any six consecutive months. 
(b)  Duration. No garage, rummage or yard sale shall continue for more than three consecutive days. 
(c)  By permittee. All such sales shall be conducted by the permittee who shall be one of the owners of property offered for sale. 
(d)  Location. All garage or yard sales shall be conducted at the residence of the permittee, all rummage or yard sales shall be conducted at the sites of a religious, charitable, civic or service organization, or such other place as shall be designated in the permit. 
(Code 1995, § 22-139; Ord. No. 2208, 7-5-1983) 
Sec. 22-118. - Signs; advertisement. 
(a)  No yard sign having an area of more than six square feet shall be permitted, nor shall any illuminated or animated sign be displayed. No sign shall be displayed prior to one day before the date of the sale, and all such signs shall be removed no later than the day next following the last day of such sale. 
(b)  No advertisement of any garage or rummage or yard sale shall be permitted on public property. 
(Code 1995, § 22-140; Ord. No. 2208, 7-5-1983) 
Secs. 22-119-22-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SALES OF GASOLINE AND LUBRICATING OIL[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Weights and measures generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 8-16-1 et seq.; regulation of petroleum products generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 8-17-80 et seq.; motor fuels marketing generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 8-22-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-150. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Distributor or seller means every person who engages in selling or delivering gasoline, or who engages in selling or delivering lubricating oils to the retail trade, within the city limits, or shipping, transporting or delivering such gasoline or lubricating oils, at or from his storage point or place of business within the city limits to any point within the city limits. 
    Gasoline means gasoline, naphtha and all other motor fuels commonly used in combustion engines; but shall exclude kerosene oil. 
(Code 1973, § 7-71; Code 1995, § 22-161) 
Sec. 22-151. - License tax-Gasoline. 
    Every distributor or seller shall pay a license tax to the city in an amount provided in the city license schedule on every gallon of gasoline sold or delivered within the city limits or shipped, transported or delivered by a distributor or seller at or from his storage point or place of business within the city limits to any point within the city limits. 
(Code 1973, § 7-72; Code 1995, § 22-162) 
Sec. 22-152. - Same-Lubricating oils. 
    In addition to the license tax provided for in section 22-151, every retail distributor or seller of lubricating oils, or any substitute therefor, shall pay a license tax to the city in an amount provided in the city license schedule on every quart of such lubricating oils sold or delivered to the retail trade within the city limits. 
(Code 1973, § 7-73; Code 1995, § 22-163) 
Sec. 22-153. - Same-Within police jurisdiction. 
    The license tax of every distributor or seller of motor fuels and lubricating oils, having his place of business wholly within the police jurisdiction of the city, and having no place of business within the city limits, shall pay a license tax as provided in the city license schedule. 
(Code 1973, § 7-74; Code 1995, § 22-164) 
Sec. 22-154. - Distributors and sellers outside city; license taxes. 
    No distributor or seller having no place of business within the city limits, or the city's police jurisdiction, shall make any sales or deliveries of gasoline, or sell to the retail trade or public lubricating oil therein without first obtaining a license from the city clerk and treasurer to do so. Such seller or distributor shall be liable for and shall pay the same license tax as that fixed and specified in section 22-151. 
(Code 1973, § 7-75; Code 1995, § 22-165) 
Secs. 22-155-22-176. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GASOLINE METERS 

Sec. 22-177. - Required; sellers. 
    Every person selling gasoline at retail within the city limits shall have the gasoline measured through meters. Every gasoline pump, or other container by whatever name through which the gasoline is delivered, shall be equipped with a meter. 
(Code 1973, § 7-77; Code 1995, § 22-176) 
Sec. 22-178. - Consumers' pumps; meters required. 
    Each pump, tank or other container owned and used by any consumer of gasoline who is not a dealer shall be equipped with a meter to indicate the true measurement of gasoline discharged from such tank, pump or container. 
(Code 1973, § 7-78; Code 1995, § 22-177) 
Sec. 22-179. - Specification of meters; inspection; attachment to pumps or containers. 
(a)  The meters specified in this article shall be of a standard type to meet the specifications of the inspector of weights and measures. The meters shall be subject to inspection at all times by the inspector. Such meters shall be read at prescribed intervals by such inspector. 
(b)  The meters shall be properly attached to pumps or containers so as to show the true reading and measurement of the gasoline discharged by such vessel. They shall be so attached as to be conveniently read. 
(Code 1973, § 7-79; Code 1995, § 22-178) 
Sec. 22-180. - Tampering with meters; record of readings. 
(a)  No person shall tamper with the meters attached to gasoline pumps or containers or turn back the reading on the meter except under orders of the inspector of weights and measures. 
(b)  A correct record shall be made and kept of the readings of the meters and of any turning back of the indicators on the meters. 
(Code 1973, § 7-80; Code 1995, § 22-179) 
Sec. 22-181. - Filling station license; meters required. 
    The city clerk and treasurer shall not issue a license for the operation of any gasoline filling station unless the pumps and containers used and to be used in such station have been metered as required in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 7-81; Code 1995, § 22-180) 
Secs. 22-182-22-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GOING-OUT-OF-BUSINESS SALES[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Going-out-of-business sales generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 8-13-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-201. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fire and other altered goods sale means a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the sale will offer goods damaged or altered by fire, smoke, water or other means. 
    Going-out-of-business sale means a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that upon the disposal of the stock of goods on hand the business will cease and be discontinued at its present location, including, but not limited to, the following sales: adjuster's, adjustment, alteration, assignee's, bankrupt, benefit of administrator's, benefit of creditors', benefit of trustees, building coming down, closing, creditor's committee, creditor's end, executor's final days, forced out of business, insolvents, last days, lease expires, liquidation, loss of lease, mortgage sale, receiver's, trustee's, and quitting business. 
    Goods means any goods, wares, merchandise or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated under this article. 
    Removal-of-business sale means a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the person conducting the sale will cease and discontinue business at the place of sale upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand and will then move to and resume business at a new location in the city or will then continue business from other existing locations in the city. 
(Code 1973, § 7-49; Code 1995, § 22-202) 
Sec. 22-202. - Article supplemental to license schedule. 
    The provisions of this article are intended to augment and be in addition to the provisions of the city license schedule. Where this article imposes a greater restriction upon persons, premises, businesses, or practices than is imposed by the city license schedule then this article shall control. 
(Code 1973, § 7-51; Code 1995, § 22-201) 
Sec. 22-203. - Exemptions to article. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following persons: 
(1)  Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2)  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials. 
(3)  Duly licensed auctioneers, selling at auction. 
(4)  Any publisher of a newspaper, magazine or other publication, who publishes in good faith, any advertisement, without knowledge of its false, deceptive or misleading character, or that the provisions of this article have not been complied with. 
(Code 1973, § 7-52; Code 1995, § 22-203) 
Secs. 22-204-22-229. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 22-230. - Required. 
    A license issued by the city clerk and treasurer shall be obtained by any person before selling or offering to sell any goods at a sale to be advertised or held out by any means to be one of the following kinds: 
(1)  Going-out-of-business sale; 
(2)  Removal-of-business sale; and 
(3)  Fire and other altered stock sale. 
(Code 1973, § 7-50; Code 1995, § 22-216) 
Sec. 22-231. - Established business a requisite; exception. 
(a)  Any person who has not been the owner of a business advertised or described in the application for a license for a period of at least 12 months prior to the date of the proposed sale shall not be granted a license. 
(b)  Upon the death of a person doing business in this city his heirs, devisees or legatees shall have the right to apply at any time for a license under this article. 
(Code 1973, § 7-53; Code 1995, § 22-217) 
Sec. 22-232. - Interval between sales. 
    Any person who has held a sale, as regulated under this article, at the location stated in the application, within one year from the date of such application shall not be granted a license. 
(Code 1973, § 7-54; Code 1995, § 22-218) 
Sec. 22-233. - Restricted to one location. 
    Where a person applying for a license under this article operates more than one place of business, the license issued shall apply only to the one store or branch specified in the application. No other store or branch shall advertise or represent that it is cooperating with the licensed location, or in any way participating in the licensed sale. No licensed location shall advertise or represent that any other store or branch is cooperating with it or participating in any way in the licensed sale. 
(Code 1973, § 7-55; Code 1995, § 22-219) 
Sec. 22-234. - Application; contents. 
(a)  A person desiring to conduct a sale regulated by this article shall make a written application to the revenue department. 
(b)  The application shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The true name and address of the owner of the goods to be the object of the sale. 
(2)  The true name and address of the person from whom he purchased the goods to be sold and the price therefor, and if not purchased, the manner of such acquisition. 
(3)  A description of the place where such sale is to be held. 
(4)  The nature of the occupancy, whether by lease or sublease and the effective date of termination of such occupancy. 
(5)  The dates of the period of time in which the sale is to be conducted. 
(6)  A full and complete statement of the facts in regard to the sale, including the reason for the urgent and expeditious disposal of goods thereby and the manner in which the sale will be conducted. 
(7)  The means to be employed in advertising such sale together with the proposed content of any advertisement. 
(c)  The application shall be accompanied by an inventory as prescribed in section 22-235. 
(Code 1973, § 7-56; Code 1995, § 22-220) 
Sec. 22-235. - Inventory required with application; goods. 
(a)  The applicant shall attach to his application a complete and detailed inventory of the goods to be sold at such sale as disclosed by the applicant's records. 
(b)  All goods included in such inventory shall have been purchased by the applicant for resale on bona fide orders without cancellation privileges and shall not comprise goods purchased on consignment. 
(c)  An inventory shall not include goods ordered in contemplation of conducting a sale regulated under this article. Any unusual purchase or additions to the stock of goods of the business affected within 90 days before the filing of an application shall be deemed to be of such character. 
(Code 1973, § 7-57; Code 1995, § 22-221) 
Sec. 22-236. - Fee; renewal. 
(a)  Any applicant for a license under this article shall submit to the revenue department with his application a license fee as provided in the city license schedule. 
(b)  Any applicant for a renewal license shall submit to the revenue department with his renewal application a renewal license fee as provided in the city license schedule. 
(Code 1973, § 7-58; Code 1995, § 22-222) 
Sec. 22-237. - Term. 
    A license issued under this article shall authorize the sale described in the application for a period of not more than 45 consecutive days, Sundays and legal holidays excluded, following its issuance. 
(Code 1973, § 7-59; Code 1995, § 22-223) 
Sec. 22-238. - Renewal procedure. 
(a)  The revenue department shall renew a license for one period of time only. This period shall be in addition to the 45 days permitted in the original license and shall not exceed 36 consecutive days, Sundays and holidays excluded, when he finds: 
(1)  Facts exist justifying the license renewal. 
(2)  The licensee has filed an application for renewal. 
(3)  The licensee has submitted with the application for renewal a revised inventory showing the items listed on the original inventory remaining unsold and not listing any goods not included in the original application and inventory. 
(b)  For the purposes of subsection (a)(3) of this section, any application for a license under the provisions of this article covering any goods previously inventoried as required, shall be deemed to be an application for renewal, whether presented by the original applicant, or by any other person. 
(Code 1973, § 7-60; Code 1995, § 22-224) 
Sec. 22-239. - Nature of sale; goods. 
(a)  The license shall authorize only the one type of sale described in the application at the location named in the application. 
(b)  The license shall authorize only the sale of goods described in the inventory attached to the application. 
(Code 1973, § 7-61; Code 1995, § 22-225) 
Sec. 22-240. - Surrender. 
    Upon being issued a license under this article for a going-out-of-business sale, the licensee shall surrender to the revenue department all other business licenses he may hold at that time applicable to the location and goods covered by the application for a license under this article. 
(Code 1973, § 7-62; Code 1995, § 22-226) 
Sec. 22-241. - Transferability. 
    Any license provided for in this article shall not be assignable or transferable. 
(Code 1973, § 7-63; Code 1995, § 22-227) 
Sec. 22-242. - Licensee's duties. 
    A licensee under this article shall: 
(1)  Make no additions whatsoever, during the period of the licensed sale, to the stock of goods set forth in the inventory attached to the application for license. 
(2)  Refrain from employing any untrue, deceptive or misleading advertising. 
(3)  Conduct the licensed sale in strict conformity with any advertising or holding out incident thereto. 
(4)  Keep available at the place of sale a duplicate copy of the inventory submitted with the application and present such duplicate to inspecting officials upon request. 
(5)  Keep any noninventoried goods separated and apart from the goods listed in the filed inventory as being objects of sale and shall make such distinction clear to the public by placing tags on all inventoried goods in and about the place of sale apprising the public of the status of all such goods. 
(Code 1973, § 7-64; Code 1995, § 22-228) 
Secs. 22-243-22-262. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - GOLD AND SILVER SALES 

Sec. 22-263. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Gold and silver does not mean coins of the United States of America, or any foreign country. 
    Purchaser of gold or silver means any person who purchases gold or silver for resale at a later date. 
(Code 1995, § 22-251; Ord. No. 2085, § 1, 2-26-1980; Ord. No. 2121, § 1, 2-10-1981) 
Sec. 22-264. - Records required; contents, method of entries, defacing of entries. 
(a)  Every purchaser of gold or silver shall keep at his place of purchase a permanently bound book, with pages numbered by the manufacturer. 
(b)  He shall enter or cause to be entered in such book in ink: 
(1)  A minute description of all gold or silver bought by him in the city. 
(2)  The time when such property was received or bought. 
(3)  Particular mention of any prominent marks on any article. 
(4)  The name, sex, color, apparent age and general description and place of residence of the person from whom such property was bought. 
(5)  Wherever such gold or silver bears a number or the name of the manufacturer or other descriptive mark, the description provided for this section shall include such number, name of manufacturer, and other descriptive marks. 
(c)  The purchaser shall make the entries, or cause the entries to be made in the book at the time such gold or silver is received. The purchaser shall make the entries by making the first entry at the top of the first page of the book. Subsequent entries in the book shall be made in the order in which the gold or silver to which the respective entries pertain were bought. No purchaser shall remove, or permit to be removed, any page or part of page from such book or erase or obliterate, or permit to be erased or obliterated, any entry made upon any page of such book. 
(Code 1995, § 22-252; Ord. No. 2085, § 2, 2-26-1980) 
Sec. 22-265. - Inspection of records; exhibition of goods. 
(a)  Each purchaser during the hours of business, when requested by the chief of police or other police officer of the city, shall submit and exhibit such book provided for in section 22-264 for the inspection of chief of police or other police officer. 
(b)  Upon demand, the purchaser shall exhibit any goods or personal property which may be in the place of purchase of the purchaser, or which may have been bought and be kept by him at any place. 
(Code 1995, § 22-253; Ord. No. 2085, § 3, 2-26-1980) 
Sec. 22-266. - Purchasing from minors. 
    No purchaser shall buy or receive any gold or silver from any person under the age of 19 years. 
(Code 1995, § 22-255; Ord. No. 2085, § 5, 2-26-1980) 
Sec. 22-267. - Fifteen-day waiting period. 
    It shall be unlawful for a purchaser of gold or silver to sell, exchange, alter, destroy, melt or remove from his place of business any gold or silver, or silver objects, received, bought or exchanged by him for a period of 15 days after the report required in section 22-254. 
(Code 1995, § 22-256; Ord. No. 2121, § 2, 2-10-1981) 
Secs. 22-268-22-297. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - MASSAGE THERAPY ESTABLISHMENTS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Alabama Massage Therapy Licensure Act, Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-43-1 et seq.; municipality has power to enact local regulations regarding zoning and occupational license tax regarding massage therapists and massage therapy establishments as long as regulations are not inconsistent with the Act, Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-43-19. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-298. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following term, when used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed to it in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Massage therapy establishment means a site, premises, or business where therapeutic massage and related touch therapy modalities are practiced by a licensed massage therapist; including mobilization of the soft tissue which may include skin, fascia, tendons, ligaments, and muscles, for the purpose of establishing and maintaining good physical condition; effleurage, petrissage, tapotement, compression, vibration, stretching, heliotherapy, superficial hot and cold applications, topical applications, or other therapy which involves movement either by hand, forearm, elbow, or foot, for the purpose of therapeutic massage; the external application and use of herbal or chemical preparations and lubricants such as salts, powders, liquids, nonprescription creams, mechanical devises such as T-bars, thumpers, body support systems, heat lamps, hot and cold packs, salt glow, steam cabinet baths or hydrotherapy, as well as any massage, movement therapy, massage technology, myotherapy, massotherapy, oriental massage techniques, structural integration, or polarity therapy. The term shall not include a regularly licensed hospital, clinic or dispensary, where laser therapy, microwave, injection therapy, manipulation of the joints, or any diagnosis or treatment of an illness that normally involves the practice of medicine, chiropractic, physical therapy, podiatry, nursing, occupational therapy, veterinary, acupuncture, osteopathy, orthopedics, hypnosis, or naturopathics occurs. 
(b)  The definitions set forth in Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-43-3 (Massage Therapists-Definitions), shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this article. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-43-3, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-43-3. 
(Code 1995, § 22-276; Ord. No. 1974, § 1, 5-10-1977) 
Sec. 22-299. - Display of sign. 
    Every massage parlor shall display a legible sign not larger than permitted by the city zoning ordinance, upon which sign the words "licensed masseur" or "licensed masseuse," or both shall conspicuously appear thereon. Such sign shall contain letters no less than three inches in height and shall be displayed in such a manner that the words "licensed masseur" or "licensed masseuse" may be readily observed or read by persons upon entering the premises occupied by any massage parlor. 
(Code 1995, § 22-277; Ord. No. 1974, § 2, 5-10-1977) 
Sec. 22-300. - Compliance with specifications of license. 
(a)  No massage parlor shall operate under any name or conduct its operation under any designation not specified in its license issued by the city in accordance with this article. 
(b)  No massage shall be administered or applied by any masseur or masseuse licensed under this article except upon the premises of the regular place of business for which a license to operate a massage parlor has been duly issued by the city. 
(Code 1995, § 22-278; Ord. No. 1974, § 3, 5-10-1977) 
Sec. 22-301. - Compliance with health regulations and inspections. 
    Any massage parlor licensed under the provisions of this article shall at all times comply with all health regulations, rules and requirements as shall now or hereafter be promulgated by the county department of health. Any premises used for the purposes of a massage parlor shall, during all hours of operation, be made open and available to inspection by the county department of health for the purpose of ensuring the massage parlor's compliance with such health rules, regulations and requirements. 
(Code 1995, § 22-279; Ord. No. 1974, § 4, 5-10-1977) 
Sec. 22-302. - Cleanliness. 
(a)  No towels, wash cloths or other linen items that have not been boiled and laundered since last used shall come in contact with the body or any part thereof of any customer or patron at a massage parlor. 
(b)  Every person applying or administering massages shall cleanse his hands thoroughly by washing with soap and hot water before attending or massaging any person. 
(c)  Any person while applying or administering massages shall be clothed from the shoulders to the knees by a robe, smock or other apparel so that the person of the customer shall be protected from bodily contact with the person applying or administering the massage except for the hands and arms of such person applying or administering such massage. 
(d)  Any massage parlor licensed pursuant to this article shall be equipped with running hot and cold water and with all appliances, furnishings and materials as may be necessary to enable persons employed in and about such massage parlor to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 22-280; Ord. No. 1974, § 5, 5-10-1977) 
Sec. 22-303. - Employees having prior conviction for prostitution. 
    It shall be a violation of this article for any licensee under the provisions of this article to employ any operator, attendant, masseur, masseuse or other employee to perform or administer massages who has within the past 36 months been convicted for, or entered a plea of nolo contendere to, prostitution in any court. 
(Ord. No. 1974, § 6, 5-10-1977) 
Sec. 22-304. - Manner of administering massages. 
    No masseur, masseuse or other employee or attendant in any massage parlor shall apply or administer any massage or other treatment to any person behind locked doors nor shall he at any time massage, manipulate, fondle or otherwise touch or have physical contact with the genitals or private parts of any patron, client or other person in any massage parlor. No customer, patron, client or other person shall at any time while in any massage parlor disrobe completely or become nude or expose his genitals or buttocks while in the presence of any other person of either sex. No masseur, masseuse or employee or attendant shall at any time massage any member of the opposite sex. 
(Code 1995, § 22-281; Ord. No. 1974, § 7, 5-10-1977) 
Sec. 22-305. - Use as dormitory. 
    No massage parlor shall be used as and for a dormitory or place of sleep, nor shall any licensee under this article permit any massage parlor to be so used. 
(Code 1995, § 22-283; Ord. No. 1974, § 8, 5-10-1977) 
Secs. 22-306-22-328. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 22-329. - Business license required; contents. 
    No massage parlor shall be opened to members of the public or operated for any other purpose without the owner thereof first having obtained a business license from the city, which such business license shall contain thereon the name of each masseur, masseuse or attendant employed for such purpose by such licensed business. 
(Code 1995, § 22-296; Ord. No. 1974, § 12, 5-10-1977) 
Sec. 22-330. - Operator's license required; verification of applicant's freedom from disease. 
    No applicant for a license to conduct or operate a massage parlor nor any applicant for a masseur or masseuse license as required in this section shall be granted such license unless he shall first present for inspection to the city a written verification by a licensed physician, bearing a date not more than 20 days prior to the date of application, evidencing that such applicant is free of any contagious, infectious, or communicable disease. No masseur, masseuse or other employee or attendant applying or administering massages shall be employed in any massage parlor without first having obtained a license as provided in this article. 
(Code 1995, § 22-297; Ord. No. 1974, § 9, 5-10-1977) 
Sec. 22-331. - Qualifications of applicant. 
    Any applicant for a license under sections 22-300 through 22-333 and 22-335 shall, at the time of applying therefor, present at least two persons to the city chief of police or such other person as he shall designate who are over 21 years of age and who both have a residence and business address in the city who shall attest under oath in writing or orally, or both, as the chief of police or his designee may direct, to the good character of the applicant and to the fact that the applicant is a person qualified and skilled as a bona fide masseur or masseuse who is trained, experienced and knowledgeable in the art of kneading, massaging and striking the muscular parts of the human body and that the applicant is learned and expert in his knowledge of the human anatomy as well as the circulatory and nervous system of the human body. 
(Code 1995, § 22-298; Ord. No. 1974, § 15, 5-10-1977) 
Sec. 22-332. - License-Investigation of applicant; approval or denial; appeal. 
(a)  The chief of police, health official, and building official shall conduct an investigation of each applicant and their proposed or existing massage therapy establishment. A report of such investigation and a copy of the police record of the applicant, if any, shall be attached to the application. 
(b)  Should the chief of police or his designee, after considering the application together with the reports of the health official and building official, and the sworn statements submitted on behalf of such applicant, discover information inconsistent or contrary to the provisions of this article, then the chief of police or his designee shall disapprove such application within 15 days after the date of the filing thereof. The chief of police may, when an investigation cannot be completed within 15 days, issue a temporary permit to the applicant to expire 15 days from the date of issuance, whereupon the chief of police shall then approve or deny the application. If the application is denied, the applicant may appeal such denial in writing within ten days thereafter, which such appeal shall be filed with the city clerk and treasurer. Thereafter the city council shall at a regular or adjourned meeting of the city council hear such appeal. The applicant shall be permitted to present such relevant evidence as the applicant shall wish for consideration by the city council. Such appeal hearing shall be held not later than 21 days from the filing thereof with the city clerk and treasurer. 
(Code 1995, § 22-300; Ord. No. 1974, § 16, 5-10-1977) 
Sec. 22-333. - Same-Issuance; renewal. 
    Upon approval of an application either by the chief of police or the city council, the city clerk and treasurer shall be authorized to issue, upon payment by the applicant of the sum provided in the city license schedule a license for the current license year to such applicant, which license shall contain a license number together with the applicant's name, address, age, sex, name of employer, place of employment, signature, and a passport-type photograph of at least two inches by two inches in size, made within 30 days of the application and furnished to the chief of police by the applicant or made by the city at the request of the applicant. Any application for a reissue of a license as required in this section or for the renewal of any license required hereunder this division for a subsequent license year shall be accompanied by the written verification of a licensed physician as required by section 22-330 and by duplicate photographs as described in this section. Upon any application for a license reissue or any renewal, the applicant shall surrender the old license or shall provide the city with a written affidavit that such license is either lost or destroyed together with the details of such loss or destruction. 
(Code 1995, § 22-301; Ord. No. 1974, § 17, 5-10-1977) 
Sec. 22-334. - Same-Fees. 
    Every owner, proprietor or operator of a massage parlor which applies manual, mechanical or other massages to the human body, trunk or limbs for a fee, hire, reward or without such fee, hire or reward and applies or administers such manual, mechanical or other massages to members of the public generally or to other persons, shall pay a license fee therefor to the city based upon gross receipts as follows: 
(1)  On annual gross receipts less than $10,000.00, the sum per year as provided in the city license schedule. 
(2)  On annual gross receipts in excess of $10,000.00, the sum as provided in the city license schedule. 
(3)  In addition to the license payments in subsections (1) and (2) of this section and any other license payments provided for in this section such owner, proprietor or operator shall pay annually to the city for each individual masseur or masseuse or other attendant who shall be employed at any time during a license year by such licensee for the purpose of applying or administering massages, the sum as provided in the city license schedule. 
(Code 1995, § 22-302; Ord. No. 1974, § 13, 5-10-1977) 
Sec. 22-335. - Same-Change of place of employment; reissuance; fee. 
(a)  Upon any change of employer or place of employment of any licensee under this division, such licensee shall apply to the city clerk and treasurer of the city for a reissue of the existing license which such reissued license shall show upon its face the name and business address of the new employer of such licensee as well as applicant's address, age, sex, and signature, for which reissue the licensee shall pay to the city a fee as established by ordinance or resolution of the city council, from time to time. That fee shall be available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. Upon any such reissue, such licensee shall surrender his replaced or old license. 
(b)  No masseur or masseuse shall work for any owner, operator or proprietor whose name and business address is not identical to that shown upon such masseur's or masseuse's license issued under this division. 
(Code 1995, § 22-303; Ord. No. 1974, § 19, 5-10-1977) 
Sec. 22-336. - Same-Exhibit or display upon request. 
    Every masseur or masseuse licensed in accordance with this division, while engaged in any activity licensed in this division, shall at all times carry upon his person such license or any reissue thereof and shall exhibit the license to any client or customer upon request or to any police officer of the city or any license or health inspector or other similar official. 
(Code 1995, § 22-304; Ord. No. 1974, § 18, 5-10-1977) 
Sec. 22-337. - Alteration; amendment; defacement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person except the city clerk and treasurer to change, amend or deface any license issued under this article, except upon the expiration of the license period shown thereon. 
(Code 1995, § 22-305; Ord. No. 1974, § 10, 5-10-1977) 
Secs. 22-338-22-362. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - MUSIC VENDING MACHINES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation and licensing of music vending machines authorized generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-51-100 et seq. 

Sec. 22-363. - Unlawful operation. 
    No person shall operate, or permit to be operated, in places of business within the city limits and the city's police jurisdiction, music vending machines, phonographs or other contrivances dispensing music, unless such person has complied with section 22-364. 
(Code 1973, § 7-82; Code 1995, § 22-326) 
Sec. 22-364. - License required. 
    Any person seeking to operate music vending machines, phonographs or other contrivances dispensing music, shall, before installing such mechanisms, first obtain a license for the operation of the device. 
(Code 1973, § 7-83; Code 1995, § 22-327) 
Sec. 22-365. - Supervision of licensees. 
    Any person issued a license as required by section 22-364 shall be subject to the strict supervision of the chief of police. Such persons shall be subject to the rules and regulations governing the operation of such contrivances as may be prescribed by the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 7-84; Code 1995, § 22-328) 
Sec. 22-366. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  The city council may prescribe such rules and regulations as may be necessary to govern and control the operation of music vending machines, phonographs or other contrivances dispensing music that may be installed pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The city council shall regulate: 
(1)  The type of mechanism so used; 
(2)  The hours during which the devices shall be allowed to operate; 
(3)  The tone and volume with which the device shall be operated; and 
(4)  Any other rules and regulations necessary and not in conflict with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 7-85; Code 1995, § 22-329) 
Sec. 22-367. - Hours of operation. 
    The city council shall not prescribe any rules and regulations which would permit the operation of music vending machines, phonographs or other contrivances dispensing music between the hours of 12:01 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on Sundays, and between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on days other than Sundays. 
(Code 1973, § 7-86; Code 1995, § 22-330) 
Secs. 22-368-22-392. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- State and county license requirements for peddlers and itinerant vendors, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 40-12-139, 40-12-172 and 40-12-174. 

Sec. 22-393. - Soliciting in parking lot. 
    No person operating a parking lot within the city limits shall solicit business on the public streets of the city, or advertise or solicit business in any loud, obscene, boisterous or indecent manner or language. 
(Code 1973, § 15-137; Code 1995, § 22-351) 
Sec. 22-394. - Solicitors; security required. 
    No person shall solicit within the city limits orders, where no license is required, for goods or other articles of value, where such solicitors require a payment before such goods are delivered, without first filing with the city clerk and treasurer security to be approved by the city clerk and treasurer to ensure the delivery of the goods or other articles of value sold or for which the order was taken. This section shall not be so construed as to tax interstate commerce. 
(Code 1973, § 15-29; Code 1995, § 22-352) 
Sec. 22-395. - Use of sidewalks to display goods, wares or merchandise. 
    No person may utilize the sidewalks of the city for the purpose of displaying any goods, wares or merchandise for sale or for the purpose of advertising merchandise except as herein set out: 
(1)  Any person desiring to utilize the sidewalks for the displaying of goods, wares and merchandise for sale or advertisement shall not obstruct a minimum of six feet of sidewalk for the free passage of pedestrian on said sidewalk. Merchandise can only be displayed between the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. 
(2)  Each person displaying any goods, wares or merchandise for sale or advertisement on the sidewalks of the city shall have liability insurance in a minimum amount of $100,000.00 per person and $300,000.00 per accident, insuring the person and the city for any loss which may be incurred as a result of the person displaying said goods, wares or merchandise in the city. 
(3)  Violation of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor and subject the person so convicted to the general penalties as described in section 1-8. 
(Code 1995, § 22-353; Ord. No. 2628, §§ 1-3, 7-19-1994) 
Secs. 22-396-22-418. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - PUBLIC MARKETS[9] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Municipal authority to establish farmers markets, Code of Ala. 1975, § 2-5-17. 

Sec. 22-419. - Intent of article. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the sale of any watermelons, fruits or other produce on any of the streets within the city limits by any person having the legal right to sell such watermelons, fruits or other produce. It is the purpose of this article to regulate traffic on the streets within the city limits. 
(Code 1973, § 7-119; Code 1995, § 22-376) 
Sec. 22-420. - Established.

(Code 1973, § 7-114; Code 1995, § 22-377) 
Sec. 22-421. - Exemption of license for users of stalls. 
    No privilege license shall be required of persons who pay rent on stalls in the public markets. 
(Code 1973, § 7-115; Code 1995, § 22-378) 
Secs. 22-422-22-440. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - TREE SURGEONS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Entomology, plant pathology, horticulture, floriculture, and tree surgery generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 2-28-1 et seq. 

Sec. 22-441. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to it in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Tree surgeon means any person who, for consideration, cuts, trims or otherwise removes trees or portions of trees. 
(Code 1995, § 22-401) 
Sec. 22-442. - License required; fee. 
    Any tree surgeon operating within the corporate limits of the city shall be required to be licensed by the city. The license shall be in the amount provided in the license schedule of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 22-403; Ord. No. 2205, 5-31-1983) 
Sec. 22-443. - Permit required for each job. 
    Prior to the commencement of each and every single job by any tree surgeon within the corporate limits of the city, the tree surgeon shall be required to purchase a permit for the job from the city clerk and treasurer. The fee for each permit granted to any tree surgeon shall be as provided in the city license schedule, payable to the city clerk and treasurer. 
(Code 1995, § 22-404; Ord. No. 2205, 5-31-1983) 
Sec. 22-444. - Removal of debris. 
    Each tree surgeon doing work within the corporate limits of the city is hereby required to remove all limbs, tree trunks and other debris resulting from any work done by the tree surgeon. 
(Code 1995, § 22-405; Ord. No. 2205, 5-31-1983) 
Sec. 22-445. - Property owners and utility companies exempted. 
    Property owners doing work on their own property and utility companies are hereby exempted from this article. 
(Code 1995, § 22-406; Ord. No. 2205, 5-31-1983) 
Secs. 22-446-22-473. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - METAL RECYCLERS[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference- State and county licensing requirements for junk dealers, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-12-116. 

Sec. 22-474. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Metal recycling refers to any person, firm or entity which engages in the recycling of metal or metal products, or which purchases metal or metal products, including without limitation scrap metal or scrap metal products, for any purpose, including the recycling or reuse, whether or not in the original form, of the same. 
(Ord. No. 3332, § 1, 4-17-2007) 
Sec. 22-475. - Duties of metal recycling business. 
    Every person, firm or entity engaged in the business of metal recycling within the city, shall do each of the following with respect to transactions in which said person, firm or entity purchases metal or metal products: 
(1)  Require photographic identification of each person selling property. 
(2)  Enter upon the records of a ledger or book maintained specifically for such purpose, the following information concerning the transaction: 
a.  A clear and accurate description of the property purchased, including model and serial number if indicated on the property; 
b.  The name, residence address and date of birth of the seller; 
c.  Date and time of the purchase transaction; 
d.  Copy of photographic identification obtained and identification number of seller; 
e.  Description of the seller, including approximate height, sex and race; and 
f.  Amount of money paid for purchase. 
(3)  Permit inspection by or provide a copy of the ledger or record of items purchased to any law enforcement officer immediately upon request, and immediately permit inspection of any such items which remain in the possession of the purchaser. 
The records required by this section shall be maintained for a period of time not less than three years. 
(Ord. No. 3332, § 2, 4-17-2007) 
Sec. 22-476. - Prohibited acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or entity engaged in metal recycling or the purchase of metal products to do any of the following: 
(1)  Fail to comply with the recordkeeping requirements of this article; 
(2)  Fail to make an entry of any material matter in the record book; 
(3)  Make any false entry into said record book; or 
(4)  Refuse access to the record book to any law enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 3332, § 3, 4-17-2007) 
Sec. 22-477. - Exception. 
    The provisions of the section shall not apply to transactions consisting solely of the purchase of aluminum cans. 
(Ord. No. 3332, § 4, 4-17-2007) 
Chapter 26 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to exercise police jurisdiction over cemeteries generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-22; cemeteries and burial grounds generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-40 et seq.; dead bodies generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-19-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Removal of body from grave. 
    No person shall, from wantonness or for the purpose of dissecting or sale, remove the dead body of any human being from its place of interment. 
(Code 1973, § 2-59; Code 1995, § 30-1) 
State Law reference- Abuse of a corpse, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-13. 
Sec. 26-2. - Damaging or defacing cemetery property. 
    No person shall wilfully or maliciously injure, deface, remove or destroy any tomb, monument, gravestone or other memorial of the dead, or any fence or any enclosure about any tomb, monument, gravestone or memorial, or wilfully and wrongfully destroy, remove, cut, break or injure, any tree, shrub or plant, within any cemetery or graveyard. 
(Code 1973, § 2-60; Code 1995, § 30-2) 
State Law reference- Desecration of venerated objects generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-12. 
Sec. 26-3. - Burial and removal permits required; certificate of death; prohibited acts. 
(a)  No person, for himself, or as an officer, agent or employee of any other person, shall inter, cremate or otherwise finally dispose of a dead human body or permit the same to be done, or remove such body from the primary registration district in which the death occurred or the body was found, without the authority of a burial or removal permit issued by the local registrar of the district in which the death occurred or in which the body was found. 
(b)  No such person shall refuse or fail to furnish correctly any information in his possession, or furnish false information, affecting any certificate or record required by the health laws of the city. 
(c)  No such person shall willfully alter, other than as provided by law, or falsify any certificate of death or any record established by the health laws of the city. 
(d)  No person, being required by the health laws of the city to fill out a certificate of death and file the certificate with the local registrar, or deliver it, upon request, to any person charged with the duty of filing the same certificate, shall fail, neglect or refuse to perform such duty in the manner required by the health laws of the city. 
(e)  No person, who is a local registrar, deputy registrar or subregistrar, shall fail, neglect or refuse to perform his duty as required by the health laws of the city, and by the instructions and directions of the state registrar. 
(Code 1973, § 2-61; Code 1995, § 30-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-19-3(1-4). 
Sec. 26-4. - Graves-Price per space. 
    The price per grave space for cemetery lots at Cedar Hill Cemetery shall be determined on a per lot basis. The price per lot shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 30-4; Ord. No. 2594, § I, 10-19-1993) 
Sec. 26-5. - Same-Opening and closing; fees. 
    The cost of opening and closing graves at Cedar Hill Cemetery shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 30-5; Ord. No. 2594, § II, 10-19-1993) 
Sec. 26-6. - Same-Prices for foundations; markers; benches; monuments. 
    The price for foundations and markers, benches and monuments at Cedar Hill Cemetery shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 30-6; Ord. No. 2596, § I, 10-26-1993) 
Sec. 26-7. - Minimum dimensions of grave plot. 
    No crypt or mausoleum shall be placed on any lot or plot within Cedar Hill Cemetery which consists of less than a 48-grave plot, rectangular in shape, and with the minimum dimensions of 50 feet by 38 feet. 
(Code 1995, § 30-7; Ord. No. 1993, § 1, 11-8-1977) 
Sec. 26-8. - Setbacks for grave plot. 
    Should any such crypt or mausoleum be constructed on a lot of the size prescribed in section 26-7, there shall be a minimum of 14.6-foot setback from the front and rear of the lot and a 21.6-foot setback from each side. 
(Code 1995, § 30-8; Ord. No. 1993, § 2, 11-8-1977) 
Sec. 26-9. - Minimum size of crypt or mausoleum. 
    The minimum size for such crypt or mausoleum shall be seven feet in width and nine feet in length. 
(Code 1995, § 30-9; Ord. No. 1993, § 3, 11-8-1977) 
Secs. 26-10-26-36. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DIRECTOR 

Sec. 26-37. - Appointment. 
(a)  There is created the position of cemetery director of the Cedar Hill Cemetery, as a position under the classified service. 
(b)  Upon certification of a list of applicants qualified for the position by the county personnel board, the mayor is authorized and directed to appoint a qualified and certified applicant to fill the position. 
(Code 1973, § 2-57; Code 1995, § 30-31) 
Sec. 26-38. - Duties. 
    The cemetery director shall have the following duties: 
(1)  Sell lots at the Cedar Hill Cemetery. 
(2)  Collect payments on lots sold and turn the payments in to the clerk and treasurer. 
(3)  Keep accurate records of the sale price charged, the payments received, the interest charged and earned and the date of all transactions with reference to cemetery lots. 
(4)  Maintain historical records as to the burial of the dead in the cemetery. 
(5)  Plan for and supervise the extension of the Cedar Hill Cemetery for the survey and sale of additional lots at the cemetery. 
(6)  Plan for and execute a beautification program at the cemetery. 
(7)  Assist in the plans and arrangements for the burial of the dead at the cemetery. 
(8)  Provide and maintain a system for termination of contracts for the purchase of lots in the cemetery upon failure of the purchaser to carry out the terms of the contract. 
(Code 1973, § 2-58; Code 1995, § 30-32) 
Chapter 30 - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Charitable fraud generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-9-70 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Charitable means and includes the words patriotic, philanthropic, social service, welfare, benevolent, educational, civic, or fraternal, either actual or purported. 
    Contribution means and includes the words alms, food, clothing, money, property, subscription or pledge, and also donations under the guise of loans of money or property. 
    Cost of promotion means, in connection with a charitable solicitation, the reasonable cost of acquiring goods or merchandise or an entertainment event when such is used in connection with the solicitation but does not include the cost of selling the goods or admissions nor the cost of bona fide educational materials. No cost included in the definition of the term "cost of solicitation" shall be considered a cost of promotion. 
    Cost of solicitation means all costs of whatever nature incurred in raising the funds solicited, except bona fide educational material in such instances where the solicitation plan involves the promotion or sale of merchandise or an entertainment event. The cost of such merchandise or entertainment shall not be considered as part of the cost of solicitation. Compensation in whatever form paid to a professional promoter or professional solicitor is part of the cost of solicitation. 
    Professional promoter means a person who for compensation plans, promotes, conducts, manages or carries on or attempts to plan, promote, conduct, manage or carry on any drive or campaign for the purpose of solicitation of contributions for or on behalf of any charitable person or engages in the business of soliciting contributions for charitable purposes. A bona fide officer or regular employee of a charitable person shall not be deemed a professional promoter by reason of his participation in charitable solicitations made by or on behalf of his employer. 
    Professional solicitor means any person, other than a professional promoter, who is employed or retained for compensation to make solicitations in connection with a charitable solicitation. A bona fide officer or regular employee of a charitable person shall not be deemed a professional solicitor by reason of his participation in charitable solicitations made by or on behalf of his employer. 
    Religious and religion or church mean any activity directly involving the promulgation or observance of any system of worship or to the building or maintenance of places of worship. The terms "religious" and "religion" or "church" as used in this chapter do not include charitable activities, even though carried on or sponsored by a religious organization. 
    Solicit and solicitation mean the request, directly or indirectly, of money, credit, property, financial assistance, or other thing of value on the plea or representation that such money, credit, property, financial assistance, or other thing of value shall be used for a charitable purpose as those purposes are defined in this section. These terms shall also mean and include, but not be limited to, the following methods of securing such money, credit, property, financial assistance, or other thing of value: 
(1)  Any oral or written request. 
(2)  The making of any announcement to the local press or by telephone concerning a local appeal or campaign to which the public is requested to make a contribution for any charitable purpose connected therewith. 
(3)  The distribution, circulation, posting, or publishing of any handbill, written advertisement, or other local publications. 
(4)  The sale of, or the offer or attempt to sell any advertisement, advertising space, book, card, chance, coupon, device, membership, merchandise, subscription, ticket or other thing. 
    Solicitation means and shall be deemed to have taken place when the request is made, whether or not the person making the request receives any contribution referred to in this section. 
(Code 1973, § 15-2; Code 1995, § 34-2) 
Sec. 30-2. - Legislative findings of city council. 
(a)  The city council finds, determines and declares that: 
(1)  Numerous persons and organizations have been and are soliciting funds in the city on the representation that such funds are to be used for charitable purposes, when, in truth and in fact, such funds are being used in large part for the private profit of unscrupulous individuals promoting such solicitation. 
(2)  A variety of frauds and misleading devices are employed in such solicitations. 
(3)  Persons engaged in the business of promoting solicitations fail to properly account for funds solicited. 
(4)  Telephone solicitations by professional solicitors and professional promoters are a cause of annoyance to the individuals solicited, and, in many cases, tactics used by such solicitors are coercive, abusive or misleading. 
(5)  As a result of such pernicious activities, honest, deserving and needed charities suffer. 
(6)  Residents of the city have been and are in constant peril of being defrauded and imposed upon due to a lack of adequate regulation of charitable solicitations. 
(b)  The city council believes that if the public were given full information concerning the solicitations, it could protect itself against victimization by disreputable fundraisers, and therefore it is necessary in the interest of the public welfare of the city for the city council to regulate solicitations for charitable purposes. 
(Code 1973, § 15-1; Code 1995, § 34-1) 
Sec. 30-3. - Exceptions to chapter. 
(a)  The provisions of this chapter, with the exception of the applicable requirements of sections 30-6, 30-37, 30-38, 30-42, 30-43, and 30-44 shall not apply to any person soliciting charity for himself if such person is blind or incapacitated and unable to work. 
(b)  All solicitations by political parties and bona fide candidates for public office are specifically exempted from the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 15-3; Code 1995, § 34-3) 
Sec. 30-4. - Notice of intent. 
(a)  Required to be filed; contents. Any person, except churches and their directly connected agencies, desiring to conduct a charitable solicitation or on whose behalf a charitable solicitation is to be conducted shall file, at least 60 days prior to the commencement thereof, with the city council and clerk and treasurer a notice of intent containing the following information: 
(1)  The proposed use of the net proceeds of the solicitation under the general headings required for reports under subsection (a)(5) of this section. 
(2)  The manner in which the solicitation shall be conducted, and an estimate of the cost of solicitation and the cost of promotion, if any, and of the net proceeds expected for the charitable purpose. 
(3)  If a professional promoter or any professional solicitor is to be employed, a copy of the contract of each. 
(4)  A certified copy of the resolution or other action authorizing the solicitation. 
(5)  A report of all the receipts of the person conducting the solicitation during his preceding fiscal year or all of his receipts from solicitations during the most recent year in which a charitable solicitation was conducted by or on behalf of such charitable person. Such report shall show the gross amount raised by solicitation, during the period covered, what portion thereof, if any, is attributable to promotional activities, the cost of promotion, the cost of solicitation and the amounts, if any, paid to each professional promoter and professional solicitor. The report shall also show what portion of the proceeds, if any, was allocated for local use and what portion, if any, was allocated to a national organization. 
(b)  Report of fund allocation and use. The proportions allocated respectively to local use or to a national organization shall each be broken down in the report under the following categories insofar as they are applicable or among such other categories as may be approved by the city council: 
(1)  Agency administration. 
(2)  Information and public education activities. 
(3)  Social services. 
(4)  Hospital care. 
(5)  Educational institutions. 
(6)  Research. 
(7)  Other civic or philanthropic purposes. 
(8)  Capital improvements. 
(c)  Waiver of filing. The city council may, in its discretion, waive the filing of such statements as are duplicated substantially by reports already on file pursuant to this section or to any other section of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 15-13; Code 1995, § 34-4) 
Sec. 30-5. - Written receipt required; exception. 
(a)  Any person receiving money or anything having a value of $1.00 or more from any contributor under a solicitation made pursuant to a permit granted under this chapter shall give to the contributor, upon request, a written receipt signed by the solicitor showing plainly the name and permit number of the person under whose permit the solicitation is conducted, the date, and the amount received. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to any contributions collected by means of a closed box or receptacle used in solicitation with the written approval of the city council, where it is impractical to determine the amount of such contributions. 
(Code 1973, § 15-14; Code 1995, § 34-5) 
Sec. 30-6. - Misrepresentation in solicitations. 
(a)  No person shall directly or indirectly solicit contributions for any purpose by misrepresentation of his name, occupation, financial condition, social position, residence, or principal place of business. No person shall make or cause to be made any misstatement, deception, or fraud in connection with any solicitation of any contribution for any purpose in the city, or in any application or report filed under this chapter. 
(b)  No charitable organization or professional fundraiser soliciting contributions shall use a name, symbol, or statement so closely related or similar to that used by another charitable organization or governmental agency that the use would tend to confuse or mislead the public. 
(c)  No charitable organization or professional fundraiser shall solicit funds by the use of statements or material that would indicate that such funds were being raised for an organization or agency from which such organization or agency has not received explicit permission for the raising of such funds in accordance with other provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 15-10; Code 1995, § 34-6) 
Sec. 30-7. - Books and records required. 
    No person shall solicit any contributions for any charitable purpose without maintaining a system of accounting whereby all donations to it and all disbursements by it are entered upon the official books or records of the person's treasurer or other financial officer. 
(Code 1973, § 15-11; Code 1995, § 34-7) 
Sec. 30-8. - Report to city council required. 
    All persons registered and issued permits under this chapter shall furnish to the city council and clerk and treasurer, within 60 days after the solicitation has been completed, a report and financial statement showing the amount raised by the solicitation; the amount expended in collecting such funds, including a report of the wages, fees, commissions and expenses, paid to any person in connection with much solicitation; and the disposition of the balance of the funds collected by the solicitation. In the case of charitable organizations maintaining a permanent office in the city, the wages of regular fulltime staff employees may be entered as a total figure. The entire report filed by the person shall be available for public inspection. The permit holder shall make available to the city council, or to any person designated in writing by the city council as its representative for such purpose, all books, records, and papers whereby the accuracy of such report may be verified. 
(Code 1973, § 15-12; Code 1995, § 34-8) 
Sec. 30-9. - Solicitation from occupants of motor vehicles. 
    Solicitation of funds for charitable purposes from occupants of motor vehicles on the streets and at the intersections of streets in the city is prohibited. 
(Code 1995, § 34-9; Ord. No. 2225, 1-31-1984) 
Secs. 30-10-30-36. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REGISTRATION AND PERMIT 

Sec. 30-37. - Required; exception. 
(a)  No person shall solicit contributions within the city, for any person or charitable purpose unless the person, for whose benefit the solicitation is conducted, is registered with the city council, and a permit for such solicitation has been issued by the city council. 
(b)  The provisions of this article shall not apply: 
(1)  To any solicitation made by and on behalf of a person or charitable purpose if conducted by members or officers thereof voluntarily and without remuneration for such solicitation, among the established and bona fide membership thereof or the normal constituency or supporters thereof; or 
(2)  If the solicitation is in the form of collections or contributions of regular assembly or services of such person or charitable purpose. 
(Code 1973, § 15-4; Code 1995, § 34-31) 
Sec. 30-38. - Application; contents; changes. 
(a)  An application for registration and a permit to solicit shall be made to the city council upon forms prescribed by it. Such application shall be sworn to or affirmed and filed with the city council not less than 60 days prior to the time at which the permit applied for shall become effective; provided, however, that the city council may, for good cause shown, allow the filing of an application less than 60 days prior to the effective date of the registration and permit applied for. 
(b)  The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address or principal office of the person applying for the permit. 
(2)  If the applicant is not an individual, the names and addresses of the applicant's principal officers and executives and a copy of the resolution, if any, authorizing such solicitation, certified to as a true and correct copy of the original by the officer having charge of the applicant's records. 
(3)  The purpose for which solicitation is to be made, the total amount of funds proposed to be raised thereby, and the use or disposition to be made of any receipts therefrom.
