(4)  A specific statement, supported by facts and figures, if any, showing the need for the contributions to be solicited. 
(5)  The names and addresses of the persons by whom the receipts of such solicitations shall be disbursed. 
(6)  The names and addresses of the persons who shall be in direct charge of conducting the solicitation, and the names of all fundraisers connected or to be connected with the proposed solicitation if the fundraisers shall receive any paid compensation for their services. 
(7)  An outline of the methods to be used in conducting the solicitation. 
(8)  The time when such solicitation will be made, giving the preferred dates and the hour of day for the commencement and termination of such solicitation. 
(9)  The estimated cost of the solicitation. 
(10)  The amount of any wages, fees, commissions, expenses, or emoluments to be expended or paid to any person in connection with such solicitations, and the names and addresses of all such persons. The city council may elect not to require such information as to regular staff of charitable organizations maintaining a permanent office in the city. 
(11)  A financial statement for the past preceding fiscal year of any funds collected for charitable purposes by the applicant, the statement giving the amount of money so raised, together with the cost of raising it, and final distribution thereof. 
(12)  A full statement of the character and extent of the charitable work being done or to be done by the applicant, showing how much thereof is being done or to be done in the city. 
(13)  A statement to the effect that if registration and a permit is granted, it will not be used or represented in any way as an endorsement by the city or by any department or officer thereof. 
(14)  Such other information as may be reasonably required by the city council in order for it to determine the kind, character, and method of the proposed solicitation, and whether such solicitation is in the interest of, and not inimical to, the safety, convenience, or welfare of the residents of the city. 
(c)  If, while any application is pending, or during the term of any permit granted thereon, there is any substantial change in fact, policy, or method that would materially alter the information given in the application, the applicant shall notify the city council in writing thereof within 72 hours after such change. Should the applicant fail to so notify the city council, any permit issued to the applicant prior thereto shall stand suspended until a hearing is had pursuant to section 34-39. 
(Code 1973, § 15-5; Code 1995, § 34-32) 
Sec. 30-39. - Disclosure of cost of solicitation. 
    The cost of solicitation for a charitable solicitation shall be disclosed on the application for such permit. 
(Code 1973, § 15-8; Code 1995, § 34-33) 
Sec. 30-40. - Fees. 
    The city council shall establish a schedule of fees based upon the amount raised by solicitations on behalf of the person during its preceding fiscal year and the city's total expense of regulating charitable solicitations during the preceding calendar year. 
(Code 1973, § 15-6(b); Code 1995, § 34-34) 
Sec. 30-41. - Investigation of application; access to records. 
(a)  The city council and clerk and treasurer shall examine all applications filed under section 30-38 and make, or cause to be made, such further investigation of the application and the applicant as the city council and clerk and treasurer deems necessary in order for it to perform its duties under this article. 
(b)  Upon request by the city council, the applicant shall make available for inspection by the city council, or any person designated in writing by the city council as its representative for such purpose, all of the applicant's books, records, and papers at any reasonable time a permit is in effect, or after a permit has expired. 
(Code 1973, § 15-15; Code 1995, § 34-35) 
Sec. 30-42. - Standards for granting; notice of denial. 
(a)  The city council shall grant the registration and permit as provided in section 30-38 whenever it finds or reasonably believes: 
(1)  All of the statements made in the application are true. 
(2)  The applicant, or if the applicant is not an individual person, that its managing officers and managing agents be of good character and reputation for honesty and integrity. 
(3)  The local control and supervision of the solicitation will be under local, responsible and reliable persons. 
(4)  The applicant is not engaged in any fraudulent transaction or enterprise. 
(5)  The solicitation will not be a fraud on the public. 
(6)  The solicitation is prompted solely by a desire to finance the charitable cause described in the application, and will not be conducted primarily for private profit. 
(7)  That the kind, character, and method of the proposed solicitation are such that the solicitation will be in the interests of and not inimical to the safety, convenience, or welfare of the residents of the city. 
(b)  The city council shall file with its secretary for public inspection a written statement of its findings of fact and its decision upon each application. If the application is denied, the city council shall notify the applicant by certified mail, return receipt requested, at the address given in the application, stating the reasons therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 15-7; Code 1995, § 34-36) 
Sec. 30-43. - Content; identification card; transferability or assignability. 
(a)  Registrations and permits issued under this article shall bear the name and address of the person to whom the permit is issued, the serial number of the permit, the date issued, the dates within which the permit holder may solicit, and a statement that the permit does not constitute an endorsement by the city or by any of its departments, officers, or employees of the purpose or of the persons conducting this solicitation. All permits must be signed by the city clerk and treasurer. 
(b)  Each solicitor of the charitable organization will be provided with an information card or similar identification signed by the person having control and supervision of the solicitation. The card or identification shall carry on its face the name and address of the person to whom the permit was issued, the number of the permit, and the dates during which the permit holder may solicit. Any individual soliciting without the card or identification shall be deemed to be in violation of this article. The card or identification shall be provided for the individual solicitor by and at the expense of the permit holder. 
(c)  Any permit issued by the city council under this article shall not be transferable or assignable. 
(Code 1973, § 15-16; Code 1995, § 34-37) 
Sec. 30-44. - Denial of application; hearing; report. 
(a)  If the city council denies an application for registration and permit, it shall notify the applicant of its decision and the grounds therefor by certified mail, return receipt requested. Within five days after the receipt of such notification, the applicant may file a written request for public hearing on the application, together with exceptions to the grounds upon which the city council based its denial of the application. 
(b)  Upon the filing of such request, the city council shall fix a time and place for the hearing, within 15 days after the request is filed, and notify the applicant thereof. At the hearing, the applicant may present evidence in support of his application and exceptions. Any interested person may be allowed to participate in the hearing to present evidence in opposition to the application and exceptions. Within ten days after the conclusion of the hearing, the city council shall render a written report either granting or denying the application and state the grounds upon which the decision is based. 
(c)  A copy of the report shall be served upon the applicant by certified mail, return receipt requested. The report shall constitute a public record. 
(Code 1973, § 15-17; Code 1995, § 34-38) 
Sec. 30-45. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  For cause; notice. Whenever it is shown or whenever the city council has reason to believe that any person registered under this article has violated any of the provisions thereof, or that any promoter, agent, or solicitor of a permit holder has misrepresented the purpose of the solicitation, the city council shall immediately give the permit holder written notice to show cause in person or by certified mail, return receipt requested, of the hearing to be held as soon as practicable to determine whether or not the permit should be revoked. This notice must contain a statement of the facts upon which the city council acted in suspending the permit. 
(b)  Hearing. At the hearing, the permit holder and any other interested persons shall have the right to present evidence as to the facts upon which the city council based the suspension of the permit and any other facts which may aid the city council in determining whether this article has been violated and whether the purpose of the solicitation has been misrepresented. 
(c)  Written statement of revocation. If, after such hearing, the city council finds that this article has been violated or the purpose of the solicitation has been misrepresented, it shall, within two days after the hearing, file in its office for public inspection and send to the permit holder by registered mail, or serve him in any manner provided by general law for the service of notices, a written statement of the facts upon which it bases such a finding and immediately revoke the permit. 
(d)  Cancellation of suspension. If, after the hearing, the city council finds that this article has not been violated and the purpose of the solicitation has not been misrepresented, it shall, within two days after the hearing give to the permit holder a written statement canceling the suspension of the permit and stating that no violation or misrepresentation was found to have been committed. 
(e)  Notice to police chief. In all cases where a suspension of the permit occurs, the chief of police shall be notified immediately by the city council of the suspension or revocation of any permit issued under this article. In like manner, the city council shall immediately notify the chief of police, subsequent to any hearing on the decision of the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 15-18; Code 1995, § 34-39) 
Chapter 34 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Alabama Emergency Management Act of 1955, Code of Ala. 1975, § 31-9-1 et seq.; powers of governing body during local state of emergency, Code of Ala. 1975, § 31-9-10. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Civil emergency means: 
(1)  A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual force or violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power to execute by three or more persons acting together without authority of law. 
(2)  Any natural disaster or manmade calamity including a flood, conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion within the corporate limits of the city resulting in the death or injury of persons or the destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
    Curfew means a prohibition against any person from walking, running, loitering, standing or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public property or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the city, except persons officially designated for duty with reference to the civil emergency. 
(Code 1995, § 38-1) 
Sec. 34-2. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this chapter or any executive order issued by the mayor pursuant to the authority contained in this chapter shall be guilty of an offense against the city and shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1995, § 38-2) 
Sec. 34-3. - Proclamation by mayor. 
    When in the judgment of the mayor a civil emergency is deemed to exist, he shall forthwith proclaim in writing the existence of the emergency. Such a proclamation shall be effective for five days, unless extended by the city council. 
(Code 1995, § 38-3) 
State Law reference- Authority of mayor to close certain places in case of riot, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-82. 
Sec. 34-4. - Order of curfew may follow proclamation. 
    After proclamation of a civil emergency by the mayor and while the emergency is in effect, the city council may order a general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the city or to the city as a whole as they deem advisable, and the curfew shall be applicable during such hours of the day or night as they deem necessary in the interest of the public safety and welfare. 
(Code 1995, § 38-4) 
Sec. 34-5. - Orders authorized after proclamation. 
    After proclamation of a civil emergency and while the emergency is in effect, the mayor may also in the interest of public safety and welfare make any or all of the following orders: 
(1)  Order the closing of all retail liquor stores. 
(2)  Order the closing of all beer taverns. 
(3)  Order the closing of all private clubs or portions thereof wherein the consumption of intoxicating liquor or beer is permitted. 
(4)  Order the discontinuance of the sale of beer. 
(5)  Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing or giving away gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible products in any container, other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle. 
(6)  Order the closing of gasoline stations and other establishments, the chief activity of which is the sale, distribution or dispensing of liquid flammable or combustible products. 
(7)  Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, dispensing or giving away of any firearms or ammunition of any character whatsoever. 
(8)  Order the closing of any or all establishments or portions thereof, the chief activity of which is the sale, distribution, dispensing or giving away of firearms or ammunition. 
(9)  Issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the protection of life and property. 
(Code 1995, § 38-5) 
Secs. 34-6-34-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS 

Sec. 34-29. - Disaster committee; creation; purpose; members; policies and plans. 
(a)  There is hereby created a disaster committee, and such committee shall serve the purpose of being available to and assisting the mayor when there is a catastrophe, a casualty, an emergency, terrible accident, unfortunate event, and/or any disposal, release or threatened release of any hazardous substances or wastes within the city. 
(b)  The committee shall consist of each councilmember of the city council. The term of the committee members shall correspond to their official tenure as councilmember's. 
(c)  The committee shall make policies and plans that will be implemented in the event of a disaster. 
(Code 1995, § 38-31; Ord. No. 2613, 3-1-1994) 
Secs. 34-30-34-46. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER RATIONING 

Sec. 34-47. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Water means water supplied by the waterworks of the city, either directly or indirectly, by the Bessemer Water Service or through another entity. 
(Code 1995, § 38-51) 
Sec. 34-48. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this article or shall do any act prohibited by this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-8. 
(Code 1995, § 38-52; Ord. No. 2435, § 7, 6-28-1988) 
Sec. 34-49. - Enforcement of article. 
    Upon the publication of a declaration of a water service emergency by the mayor under section 34-50: 
(1)  Police officers. Every police officer of the city shall, in connection with his duties imposed by law, diligently enforce the provisions of this article. 
(2)  Discontinuance of service. The waterworks of the city shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this article by the discontinuance of water service, subject to the provisions of section 34-53 in the event of a violation of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 38-53; Ord. No. 2435, § 6, 6-28-1988) 
Sec. 34-50. - Declaration of water service emergency; article takes effect. 
    Whenever, upon request by the waterworks of the city or upon other determination by the mayor in consultation with such officials as he deems appropriate, the mayor determines that a water service emergency exists in the city, and the mayor issues and publishes a declaration of the existence of such a water emergency, this article shall become immediately effective upon the publication of such declaration in a daily newspaper generally circulated in the city. 
(Code 1995, § 38-54; Ord. No. 2435, § 2, 6-28-1988) 
Sec. 34-51. - Application of article. 
    Upon the publication of declaration by the mayor of a water service emergency under section 34-50, the provisions of this article shall apply to all persons using water both in the city and outside the city, within the police jurisdiction thereof. 
(Code 1995, § 38-55; Ord. No. 2435, § 3, 6-28-1988) 
Sec. 34-52. - Use and withdrawal of water; prohibitions. 
    The use and withdrawal of water by any person for the following purposes is hereby prohibited: 
(1)  Watering yards. The sprinkling, watering or irrigating of shrubbery, trees, lawns, grass, ground covers, plants, vines, gardens, vegetables, flowers, or any other vegetation. 
(2)  Washing mobile equipment. The washing of automobiles, trucks, trailers, trailer houses, railroad cars or any other type of mobile equipment, except as to motor vehicles where such washing is accomplished by a commercial automatic carwash installation engaged in the business of washing motor vehicles. 
(3)  Cleaning outdoor surfaces. The washing of sidewalks, driveways, filling station aprons, porches and other outdoor surface. 
(4)  Cleaning buildings. The washing of the outside of dwellings; the washing of the inside and outside of office buildings. 
(5)  Cleaning equipment and machinery. The washing and cleaning of any business or industrial equipment and machinery. 
(6)  Ornamental fountains. The operation of any ornamental fountain or other structure making a similar use of water. 
(7)  Swimming pools. Swimming and wading pools not employing a filter and recirculating system. 
(8)  Escape through defective plumbing. The escape of water through defective plumbing, which shall mean the knowing permission for defective plumbing to remain out of repair. 
(Code 1995, § 38-56; Ord. No. 2435, § 4, 6-28-1988) 
Sec. 34-53. - Exception to section 34-52. 
    The health officer shall have the authority to permit a reasonable use of water in any case necessary to maintain adequate health and sanitation standards, but such reasonable use shall not include any use prohibited by section 34-52. 
(Code 1995, § 38-57; Ord. No. 2435, § 5, 6-28-1988) 
Chapter 38 - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal planning, zoning, and subdivisions generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-1 et seq.; regional planning commissions generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-85-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 38-1-38-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - URBAN RENEWAL AND REDEVELOPMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to plan and undertake urban renewal projects generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 24-3-1 et seq. 

Sec. 38-19. - Legal authority. 
(a)  The project area, as shown in Plate 1: Project Area Map, encompasses the boundaries of the urban renewal plan for the downtown area of the city, entitled "Urban Redevelopment and Urban Renewal Plan for the Downtown Area in the City of Bessemer, Alabama," adopted by the city council on January 5, 1999 by Resolution No. 001-99. 
(b)  The downtown area redevelopment project is authorized under state law, as a separate, distinct and independent urban renewal and redevelopment project and is in accordance with the department of community development goals and objectives. 
(c)  The goals and objectives of the plan have identified a set of design review standards, adopted by the city council. 
(Code 1995, § 40-26; Ord. No. 3051, § 1, 1-5-1999) 
Sec. 38-20. - Urban renewal and redevelopment project description. 
(a)  Project summary. 
(1)  The project will establish a land use plan for the project area to define the development of urban neighborhoods, commercial development and office development in the targeted project area. 
(2)  The project includes public improvements, such as, landscaping, lighting, infrastructure (water and sanitary sewer), street improvements and acquisition, demolition and resale of property to be developed for uses appropriate to the project area. 
(3)  The project will carry out the development of residential, retail, office, commercial, parks, and open spaces. 
(4)  The project will make provisions for the revitalization of commercial property, as shown in Plate 1: Project Area Map, incorporated herein by reference. 
(b)  Boundary. Plate 1: Project Area Map shows the boundary of the project area which lies between 22nd Street and Highway 150 (14th Street) in the north-south direction and between Clarendon Avenue and I-59/20 in the east-west direction. Plate 1 is incorporated herein by reference. 
(c)  Redevelopment plan objectives. 
(1)  To prevent the spread or the development of blight and blighting factors and deteriorating conditions; 
(2)  To eliminate all blighted and deteriorated conditions and the affects of blighting and deteriorating influences of improved and unimproved property; 
(3)  To eliminate dilapidation, overcrowding, obsolescence, inappropriate design, faulty arrangements, poor site conditions, a lack of ventilation, light and sanitary facilities, excessive land coverage, deleterious land use, obsolete site layout, diversity of ownership or unusual conditions of title, and under-utilization; 
(4)  To promote sound growth of the downtown area and the community; 
(5)  To promote a practical and efficient transportation and traffic pattern that utilizes proper traffic flow and access management, emphasizing a balance between vehicular, transit, bicycle, pedestrian and other modes of travel and to minimize any disruption to existing and new development; 
(6)  To promote the development of sound retail businesses, offices/office complexes and urban residential neighborhoods; 
(7)  To provide and improve public services such as streets, sidewalks, lighting, utilities/infrastructure, parks, open spaces, plazas, landscaping, public place/park furniture and to create an attractive and inviting environment for pedestrians; 
(8)  To preserve and rehabilitate historic structures in the historic district, parts of which lie in the project area, which have been or may be designated by the city, the state or the United States Department of Interior; and 
(9)  To promote viable, well-designed urban residential neighborhoods, within the project area, with appropriate public infrastructure and amenities. 
(Code 1995, § 40-27; Ord. No. 3051, § 2, 1-5-1999; Ord. No. 3522, § I, 9-2-2014) 
Sec. 38-21. - Land use plan. 
(a)  Plate VII. The Plate VII: Proposed Land Use Map shows the land use categories described in this subsection and is incorporated herein by reference: 
(1)  Commercial/residential. 
(2)  Service/commercial. 
(3)  Cultural and institutional. 
(4)  Central business district. 
(b)  Land use provisions and building requirements. Land use and building requirements are as follows: 
(1)  Permitted uses. 
a.  Commercial/residential. The commercial/residential land use category shall include commercial uses and the types of residential uses which are suited to an urban environment. The commercial uses shall include retail, personal services, recreational, religious, tourist-oriented, offices and other related commercial uses which are compatible with urban residential uses. These uses shall comply closely with the requirements identified in the following districts of the city zoning ordinance, July 1996: C-2 (central business) and C-6 (planned shopping). Any use, not included in the zoning ordinance, will be adapted to the development plan in keeping with the spirit of the urban fabric and environment of downtown Bessemer. New construction for residential uses shall be permitted and so shall the rehabilitation, renovation and/or conversion of existing structures to residential uses. It is recommended that buildings and structures, which are renovated or newly constructed, should be complemented with open spaces, parks, plazas, and green space amenities, where architectural and urban design can afford such amenities. Off-street parking, as an ancillary use, shall be permitted as per the existing requirements, reflected in city codes. Alternative parking ideas, through the aid of physical design practices, to suit the urban environment of the city is highly recommended. Off-street parking and loading shall also be permitted and such shall be planned to adhere to design schemes which will include landscaping and adequate buffers, screens and noise-abatement measures. Existing commercial services, warehousing and light industrial activities, which are not in any conflict with other permitted uses in this category, shall act as prototypes for any proposed commercial, warehousing and light industrial uses. Commercial services, warehousing and light industrial uses, which are currently in existence but are in conflict with other uses, may not be expanded and their useful life may not be extended. An improvement in design from an aesthetic and functional perspective is highly recommended. 
b.  Service/commercial. This category shall include commercial, commercial services, auto/truck sales and services, building material sales, light industrial, research and development facilities, retail and office uses, warehousing, wholesaling. These uses shall comply closely with the requirements identified in the following districts of the city zoning ordinance, July 1996: C-1 (neighborhood commercial), SC-1 (neighborhood shopping center), C-2 (central business), C-3 (community business), C-4 (arterial services), C-5 (general business) and I-1 (light industrial). New construction for these uses shall be permitted and so shall the rehabilitation, renovation and/or conversion of existing structures to accommodate these permitted uses. Any use, not included in the zoning ordinance, will be adapted to the development plan in keeping with the spirit of the urban fabric and environment of downtown Bessemer. For the purpose of accommodating these and other permitted uses, ancillary off-street parking and loading facilities shall also be permitted and such ancillary uses shall be planned to adhere to design schemes which will include landscaping and adequate buffers, screens and noise-abatement measures. Alternative parking ideas through the aid of physical design practices, to suit the urban environment of the city are highly recommended. Uses pertaining to construction, light industrial, industrial maintenance, manufacturing and utilities, which are similar in nature to those preexisting, are also permitted, provided that such uses do not conflict with other uses permitted in this category. All preexisting uses of construction, light industrial, industrial maintenance, manufacturing and utilities, which do conflict with other uses permitted in this category, may neither be expanded nor may their useful life be extended. 
c.  Cultural and institutional. This category shall include cultural and entertainment complexes, governmental activities, research facilities and other related uses. Residential, retail, recreational, religious, office and other commercial support uses, which complement the cultural and institutional uses mentioned above, shall also be permitted. Other related uses permitted in this category are: Open spaces, parks, plazas, and other green space amenities. New construction for these uses shall be permitted and so shall the rehabilitation, renovation and/or conversion of existing structures to accommodate these permitted uses. All prescribed uses shall be incorporated, in keeping with the spirit of the urban fabric and environment of downtown Bessemer. For the purpose of accommodating these and other permitted uses, ancillary off-street parking and loading facilities shall also be permitted and such ancillary uses shall be planned to adhere to design schemes which will include landscaping and adequate buffers, screens and noise-abatement measures. Alternative parking ideas through the aid of physical design practices, to suit the urban environment of the city is highly recommended. Uses pertaining to light industrial, unrelated commercial and wholesaling, which are similar in nature to those preexisting, are also permitted, provided that such uses do not conflict with other uses permitted in this category. All preexisting uses of light industrial, unrelated commercial and wholesaling, which do conflict with other uses permitted in this category, may neither be expanded nor may their useful life be extended. 
d.  Central business. This category shall include uses which are standard central business district uses, such as, offices, support services, specialty and retail activities, cultural and entertainment activities, residential facilities, hotels, personal services, open spaces, parks, plazas, and other green space amenities, and other related uses. New construction for these uses shall be permitted and so shall the rehabilitation, renovation and/or conversion of existing structures to accommodate these permitted uses. All prescribed uses shall be incorporated, in keeping with the spirit of the urban fabric and environment of downtown Bessemer. For the purpose of accommodating these and other permitted uses, ancillary off-street parking and loading facilities shall also be permitted and such ancillary uses shall be planned to adhere to design schemes which will include landscaping and adequate buffers, screens and noise-abatement measures. Alternative parking ideas through the aid of physical design, to suit the city's urban environment are highly recommended. 
(2)  Building requirements for land to be acquired. 
a.  The city shall enter into a redevelopment agreement with a redeveloper/redevelopers (referred to as redeveloper, hereinafter), when acquiring a particular piece of property for redevelopment. Such property shall be shown on the plate proposed acquisition plan map and shall be referred to as acquisition property hereinafter. 
b.  The redevelopment agreement shall provide for the following: 
1.  All acquisition property used in the project area, by the redeveloper, shall be for the uses and purposes designated in the city urban renewal plan; 
2.  The redeveloper will begin improvements upon a building, as required by the city urban renewal plan, within a time-period determined by the city; 
3.  The redeveloper will comply with the conditions, deemed necessary, proper or convenient by the city, when carrying out the purposes of the Code of Ala. 1975, tit. 24, chs. 2 and 3, and the city urban renewal plan; and 
4.  The requirements of the city urban renewal plan shall be effectively implemented through the instruments of conveyance which allow the incorporation of covenants and conditions pertaining to the land. These covenants and conditions shall be for the sole use and benefit of the city. The redeveloper shall comply with the covenants and conditions of the plan as deemed necessary, proper, or convenient by the city. 
c.  The redeveloper shall not impose any restrictions on the basis of national origin, race, religion, sex, or color, by entering into, executing, or being a party to any covenant, conveyance, or any other written instrument, which would restrict the sale, lease, use or occupancy of the project area, or any part thereof, or any improvements placed thereon. The redeveloper shall duly comply with all federal, state, and local laws, in effect from time to time, that prohibit discrimination or segregation on the basis of national origin, race, religion, sex, or color. 
d.  Landscape treatment shall be applied to all land that is not covered by buildings, structures, paved parking, loading, or service areas. Landscape treatment shall include, but not be limited to, paved areas for pedestrian circulation, decorative surface treatments, and planting such as trees, shrubs, ground cover, grass and flowers. The extent and details of landscaping shall be determined by the nature of the development and shall augment the utility of the site, enhance the aesthetics of the structures, soften and relieve the effects of parking and paved areas, and provide visual harmony. The property owner shall be responsible for all landscaping and maintenance of this landscaping. 
e.  All exterior surface parking areas shall be paved with a hard, dust-free and erosion resistant material. Such areas shall be appropriately screened from all adjacent streets and sidewalks with, but not limited to, masonry walls, fences, trees, and shrubs planted at a regular, appropriate interval or a combination of these. Parking lots shall be designed with landscaped islands to accommodate deciduous trees at a minimum rate of one per 2,500 square feet of gross parking area. 
f.  All off-street loading spaces shall be provided as needed and shall conform with minimum design standards. Adequate maneuvering spaces shall be provided within the property lines. 
g.  No refuse or garbage shall be permitted to remain outside any building, except as permitted under codes and regulations. There shall be designated areas for the location of containers and receptacles to afford refuse and garbage and all such containers and receptacles shall be properly screened. 
h.  No signs shall be permitted except for those which identify the property or the use conducted thereon. There shall be no animated or pulsating signs. Any sign shall be located within the confines of the property. 
i.  The regulations and limitations of the city zoning ordinance shall apply to the project area. 
(3)  Provisions that apply to properties not being acquired. Properties that are not acquired, but are within the project area, shall be subjected to the conditions of subsection (b)(1) of this section, pertaining to permitted uses. Owners of properties located outside the acquisition area but within the project area, who acquire property that lie within the acquisition area and develop the two jointly, shall comply with all the provisions under subsection (b)(2) of this section, pertaining to building requirements for land to be acquired. 
(4)  Special building requirements. 
a.  All buildings within the 16 block downtown core, bounded by the railroad tracks to the northeast, 6th Avenue to the northwest, parts of 17th and 18th Streets to the southwest and 1st Avenue to the southeast, shall be intensely developed to promote pedestrian activities. The core area will encourage the development of high-intensity retail and other commercial uses at the sidewalk level and will discourage architecturally unaesthetic uses such as blank walls, parking garages/lots/facilities and curbcuts. 
b.  Parking shall be kept at a minimum on 18th and 19th Streets which are the ingress and egress of the project area and the 16 block core downtown area. 
(Code 1995, § 40-28; Ord. No. 3051, § 3, 1-5-1999) 
Sec. 38-22. - Creation of a design review board. 
(a)  Creation. The city council will create a design review board (hereafter DRB) to perform the duties and responsibilities of the city in accepting, considering, and approving or rejecting applications for certificates of appropriateness, as set out in the bylaws of the DRB. 
(b)  Members, number, appointment, terms, compensation, officers, rules and regulations. 
(1)  This board shall be composed of not less than seven members who shall have demonstrated experience or training in the fields of architecture, urban planning, or law. The DRB will be composed of the following persons: 
a.  Three members will serve by virtue of position. Those shall be: 
1.  The director of economic and community development; 
2.  Tthe director of building and inspection services; and 
3.  The chairman of the historic preservation commission. 
These members will serve on the DRB for the duration of their employment in these positions. 
b.  One member shall be a member of the city council and shall be appointed by the city council. 
c.  One member shall be an architectural design professional and shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council for a three-year term. 
d.  Two members shall be selected from the downtown business community and shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council for three-year terms. 
(2)  Members of the DRB may be removed for cause by the city council. 
(3)  Members of the DRB may select a chairman and vice-chairman and such other officers as the members deem necessary. The DRB shall adopt rules of procedure and shall communicate those rules of procedure to the city council and mayor. The rules of procedure shall specify what number of members of the DRB shall constitute a quorum. 
(4)  Members of the DRB will serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for reasonable expenses incurred on behalf of the DRB, in accordance with the rules of regulations for the reimbursement of expenses adopted by the DRB. 
(5)  The DRB may employ such professional, technical, office and other personnel, as may be necessary, to carry out the purposes and responsibilities of the DRB. 
(6)  Meetings of the DRB shall be public meetings and shall be held at designated times and places as are specified in the bylaws of the DRB. 
(7)  Members of the DRB may be reappointed. 
(8)  The city reserves the right and may delegate the duty to the design review committee (DRB) to review and approve the redeveloper's plans and specifications for redevelopment or rehabilitation. Such plans shall conform with the provisions of the city urban renewal plan and the harmonious development of the project area. All such review and approval shall be concerned with, but not limited to, urban design standards, site planning, architectural treatment, materials and color, lighting, signs, parking, loading, landscaping, detailed building plans, elevations, and construction specifications. Such review and approval shall be given in accordance with procedures as specified in the bylaws of the design review committee. 
(Code 1995, § 40-29; Ord. No. 3051, § 4, 1-5-1999) 
Sec. 38-23. - Development objectives plan. 
(a)  Objectives. The development objectives plan of the city urban renewal plan, incorporated herein by reference, shall include development objectives for the project area to guide the city in its review of all proposed developments in the project area. These objectives shall apply to all the properties within the project area. 
(1)  Urban neighborhood. 
(2)  Office/commercial. 
(3)  Research and development/business. 
(4)  Off-street parking. 
(5)  Institutional/semi-public/utility. 
(6)  Retail services, dining and entertainment facilities. 
(b)  Provisions for development; permitted uses. 
(1)  The urban neighborhood category shall include the following: dwellings and related uses, retail commercial uses to serve residents, employees and others, offices, hotels, conference centers, restaurants, banks, showrooms, ancillary off-street parking facilities and other related or nonconflicting uses. Urban neighborhood development uses shall be located within the commercial/residential, service/commercial and the cultural and institutional land use areas. 
(2)  The office/commercial category shall include the following: retail, personal services, recreational, office, ancillary off-street facilities, complementary residential facilities and other related or nonconflicting uses. Office/commercial development uses shall be located within the commercial/residential, service/commercial and central business district land use areas. 
(3)  The research and development/business category shall include the following: research and development firms, laboratories, offices, ancillary retail facilities, ancillary off-street parking facilities and other related or nonconflicting uses. Research and development/business development uses shall be located within the commercial/residential, service/commercial and cultural and institutional land use areas. 
(4)  The off-street parking category shall include the following: parking lots, parking decks, commercial facilities and other related or nonconflicting uses. It is the intent of the city urban renewal plan to encourage the development of commercial facilities and other pedestrian amenities along the street level of all existing and new parking decks. The off-street parking development uses shall be located within the commercial/residential land use areas. 
(5)  The institutional/semipublic/utility category shall include the following: places of worship and related uses, educational facilities, public utility facilities and other institutional and semipublic uses and other related or nonconflicting uses. Institutional/semipublic/utility development shall be located within the commercial/residential and cultural and institutional land use areas. 
(6)  The retail services, dining and entertainment facilities category shall include the following: banks and other legal lending institutions, delicatessens, hotels, offices, pharmacies and medical supply stores, restaurants, lounges, retail stores and personal service establishments and other related or nonconflicting uses. Retail services, dining and entertainment facilities development uses shall be located within the commercial/residential, cultural and institutional and central business districts. 
(c)  Revision and amendment of development objectives. 
(1)  The city planning commission shall have the authority to review the city urban renewal plan development objectives, from time to time. Based on the findings derived from these reviews, the city planning commission may amend the plan development objectives when it is determined that such amendments are necessary, proper and appropriate to uphold the spirit of the overall objectives of this plan. 
(2)  The decision of the city planning commission to amend the development objectives shall require the adopting of a resolution describing the amendment so made. Such resolution shall be adopted in a similar manner by which a resolution is adopted recommending the adoption of an urban renewal and urban redevelopment plan to the city council. The said amendment to the development objectives shall be effective upon adoption and a copy of the same shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and another copy shall be attached to the copy of the city urban renewal plan, also maintained in the files of the city clerk. 
(Code 1995, § 40-30; Ord. No. 3051, § 5, 1-5-1999) 
Sec. 38-24. - Project implementation. 
(a)  Authority and redevelopment. In implementing the city urban renewal plan, the city shall purchase or have the authority to acquire by the exercise of eminent domain a part of the project area that it deems necessary, convenient or proper to proceed with the purposes of the project. The city may also enter into an agreement with a redeveloper as it deems necessary, convenient, or proper to develop any part or whole of the project area, in accordance with the requirements set out herein. 
(b)  Public improvements. In addition to the improvements of the properties identified in the blighting conditions map, necessary minor repairs to storm drains, streets, street lighting, etc., will be undertaken. 
(c)  Acquisition. The city council has determined that it is necessary, desirable and in the interest of the public to acquire any identified properties by purchase or by the exercise of eminent domain. All such properties shall be acquired by fee simple or any interest therein and the existing structures thereon may be demolished or rehabilitated as appropriate for redevelopment. Likewise, other properties may be acquired and demolished or rehabilitated if the city council deems it to be necessary, desirable and in the public interest so that all such acquired properties shall constitute a part of the acquisition property. The city council may also acquire alleys and require the vacation of all acquired alleys for redevelopment if it is deemed necessary, desirable and in the public interest for such acquisition and vacation to take place. Such acquisition shall take place on a case-by-case basis. 
(d)  Disposition. The proposed acquisition plan is that properties that are considered blighted/blighting shall be considered on a case-by-case method. Upon assessment of each piece of property, the need to dispose of by means of sale, lease, conveyance or other to redevelopers shall be determined. Those parcels which are meant to be subdivided or combined may be done so by virtue of surveys that describe the precise details and shall be determined as necessary, proper or convenient by the city. 
(e)  Rehabilitation and new construction plan review. The redeveloper shall submit detailed plans to the design review committee, for new construction, including parking lots, or the rehabilitation of any property, located in the project area, not to be acquired under the provisions of the city urban renewal plan. The design review committee will review all the submitted plans, using any and all procedures defined in the bylaws of the DRB, for conformance with the provisions of the city urban renewal plan and the desired, harmonious development of the project area, and as such these shall concern, but not be limited to, urban design, site planning, architectural treatment, materials and color, lighting, signs, parking, loading, landscaping, building plans, building elevations and construction details. Upon the approval of the plans, a certificate of appropriateness will be issued by the DRB and the redeveloper may submit applications for building, soil erosion, and/or sedimentation control permits for any property located in the project area. When the design review committee approves the plans submitted by a redeveloper as being consistent with the objectives of the city urban renewal plan, the city shall authorize the processing of the plans for the issuance of the necessary building permit. 
(f)  Commercial revitalization. Commercial revitalization shall take place in conformance with the provisions of the design review process, applicable city codes, property maintenance standards, incentive programs, and the management and technical assistance to business people, property owners, and residents of the project area. 
(g)  Demolition. All applications requesting demolition permits shall be submitted to the design review committee for review and approval. The written approval, from the design review committee, of such an application shall be regarded as authorization for the processing of a demolition permit. If an application submitted to the design review committee has not been acted upon by the design review committee for a period of six months, as per proof presented by the property owner, then the building inspection services shall process the application for a demolition permit. 
(h)  Relocation. 
(1)  All efforts of acquisition, demolition and construction by a redeveloper, shall be undertaken in stages, as presented in the city urban renewal plan, so as to minimize any disruption to the surrounding, existing businesses and establishments. 
(2)  It is the explicit right of the city to provide or require a redeveloper to provide all assistance, as the city deems necessary, proper and convenient to effectuate the purposes of the city urban renewal plan. 
(3)  There shall be no permanent residents in the acquisition property. 
(i)  Zoning. Existing zoning classifications for the project area, as shown in the city zoning map, shall comply with the adoption of the city urban renewal plan. In the event that a zoning classification change is requested or applied for, all the established procedures, as described in the city zoning ordinance, shall be considered, including but not limited to ending notices to affected property owners and the right of such property owners to be heard in a public hearing. 
(j)  Historic preservation. The review and approval of plans submitted for rehabilitation or demolition may include consideration for the preservation of historic structures and districts, in accordance with the city urban renewal plan, which have been or may be designated by the city, the state or the United States Department of the Interior. 
(Code 1995, § 40-31; Ord. No. 3051, § 6, 1-5-1999) 
Sec. 38-25. - Enforcement and penalty provisions. 
(a)  Enforcement. Compliance with the terms of this article shall be enforced by the city's department of buildings and inspection. 
(1)  Failure to comply with a certificate of appropriateness shall be a violation of this article. The discontinuance of work or the lack of progress towards achieving compliance with a certificate of appropriateness, as laid out in the bylaws of the DRB shall be considered a failure to comply with the terms of this article. 
(2)  Nothing in this article shall prohibit, impair, or limit in any way the power of the city's department of buildings and inspection to prevent the alteration, construction, restoration, reconstruction, rehabilitation, or removal of buildings, structures, appurtenant fixtures, or outdoor signs in the project area in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(3)  The enforcement of any remedy provided in this article shall not prevent the use and enforcement of any other remedy provided for by this Code for violations of validly enacted ordinances of the city or state statutes. 
(b)  Violations. Whenever, by the provisions of this article and after review by the design review committee, the performance of any act is required or prohibited regarding the alteration, construction, demolition, or outdoor signage of any property under the jurisdiction of this article, a parties' failure to comply with such provisions shall constitute a violation of this article and shall be deemed a class A misdemeanor. 
(c)  Liability for violations. The owner, tenant or occupant of any land or structure, or part thereof, and any architect, builder, contractor, agent or other person who participates in, assists, directs, creates, or maintains any situation that is contrary to the requirements of this article shall be held responsible for the violation and be subject to the penalties and remedies provided therein. 
(d)  Procedure of notification upon discovery of violation. 
(1)  Upon discovery of a violation of this section, the design review committee shall notify in writing by first class mail the party responsible for said violation. Such notice shall indicate the provisions of this article violated, the nature of the violation, the action necessary to correct the violation, the date by which this violation must be remedied and the penalties for noncompliance. Service of such notice shall be deemed completed at the time of deposit in the post office or any United States mailbox in a sealed envelope, postage prepaid, and addressed to the person to be notified at his last known business or residence address as the same appears in the public records. Proof of this notice may be made by a return receipt signed by the recipient notified by United States mail. 
(2)  After written notification of such violation from the design review committee to the party responsible and the latter's subsequent failure to rectify the situation, the committee will notify the city's department of buildings and inspection of the noncompliance with this article. An authorized employee of that department or an employee of the city shall serve a notice of noncompliance to the party responsible for the violation indicating the provisions of this article violated, the nature of the violation, and ordering the action necessary to correct the violation. This notice shall be in the form of a written citation, signed by an authorized employee of the city's department of buildings and inspection and shall be delivered to the offender either at his residence or at his place of business or at the place where the violation occurred. This notice shall specify a date and time when the party responsible and/or their agents are commanded to appear before the municipal court of the city. If said party do not appear on the date specified, a warrant will be issued for this party's arrest. 
(e)  Penalty. Violation of any provision of this article shall subject the responsible party to a criminal penalty not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00 or imprisonment not to exceed six months or both and costs of court for each offense. Penalties imposed upon a corporation shall consist of the fine only, plus costs of court. Each day that a violation is allowed to continue in violation of this article shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(f)  Remedies. Any use of land or a structure, or construction or alteration of a structure in violation of this article is hereby declared to be a nuisance per se. The imposition of any penalty under the provisions of this section does not prevent equitable relief in the form of an injunction, mandamus, or other appropriate action or proceeding to correct or abate such violation or to prevent occupancy of such building structure. 
(Code 1995, § 40-32; Ord. No. 3051, § 7, 1-5-1999) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-45-9 and 11-45-9.1. 
Sec. 38-26. - Affirmation of existing building and zoning codes. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed as to exempt property owners from complying with existing city building and zoning codes, not to prevent any property owner from making any use of his property not prohibited by other statutes, ordinances, and regulations. 
(Code 1995, § 40-33; Ord. No. 3051, § 8, 1-5-1999) 
Sec. 38-27. - Conflict. 
    In the instance of a conflict between this article and Ordinance No. 2541 (historic preservation commission), Ordinance No. 2541 shall take precedence. 
(Code 1995, § 40-34; Ord. No. 3051, § 9, 1-5-1999) 
Secs. 38-28-38-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WESTERN AREA URBAN RENEWAL AND REDEVELOPMENT 

Sec. 38-58. - Legal authority. 
(a)  The project area, as shown in Figure 1, Project Area Map, encompasses the boundaries of the urban renewal plan for the western area of the city, entitled Urban Redevelopment and Urban Renewal Plan for the Western Area in the City of Bessemer, Alabama, adopted by the city council, on December 17, 2002 by Resolution No. 666-02. 
(b)  The western area redevelopment project is authorized under Code of Ala. 1975, tit. 24, chs. 2 and 3, as amended, as a separate, distinct, and independent urban redevelopment and renewal project and is in accordance with the department of community development goals and objectives. 
(c)  The goals and objectives of the plan have identified a set of design review standards, adopted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 3207, § I, 12-17-2002) 
Sec. 38-59. - Urban redevelopment and renewal project description. 
(a)  Project summary. The project will establish a land use plan for the project area to define the development of urban neighborhoods, commercial development and industrial development in the targeted project area. The project includes public improvements, such as, landscaping, lighting, infrastructure (water and sanitary sewer), street improvements and acquisition, demolition and resale of property to be developed for uses appropriate to the project area. The project will improve conditions for the continued development of residential, office, commercial, industrial, and recreational land uses. The project will make provisions for the revitalization of commercial, industrial, and residential property, as shown in Figure 10, Existing Land Use Map. 
(b)  Boundary. Figure 1, Project Area Map shows the boundary of the project area which lies predominantly northwest of Interstate 20/59 between the McAshan Drive Interchange (I-20/59 Exit #104) to the south and Murphy's Lane (County Road 36) and Valley Creek to the north. Figure 1 is incorporated herein by reference. 
(c)  Redevelopment plan intent. 
(1)  To prevent the spread or the development of blight and blighting factors and deteriorating conditions; 
(2)  To eliminate all blighted and deteriorated conditions and the effects of blighting and deteriorating influences of improved and unimproved property; 
(3)  To eliminate dilapidation; overcrowding; obsolescence; inappropriate design; faulty arrangements; poor site conditions; a lack of ventilation, light and sanitary facilities; excessive land coverage; deleterious land use; obsolete site layout; diversity of ownership or unusual conditions of title and under-utilization; 
(4)  To promote sound growth of the project area and the community; 
(5)  To promote a practical and efficient transportation and traffic pattern that utilizes proper traffic flow and access management, emphasizing a balance between vehicular, transit, bicycle, pedestrian and other modes of travel and to minimize any disruption to existing and new development; 
(6)  To promote the development of sound retail, service, and office businesses, industrial and manufacturing facilities, and residential neighborhoods; 
(7)  To provide and improve public services such as streets, sidewalks, lighting, utilities/infrastructure, parks and open spaces, and landscaping to create an attractive and inviting environment for pedestrians and motorists; 
(8)  To preserve and rehabilitate historic structures in the project area, which have been or may be designated as such by the city, the state or the United States Department of the Interior; and, 
(9)  To promote viable, well-designed residential neighborhoods, within the project area, with appropriate public infrastructure and amenities. 
(Ord. No. 3207, § II, 12-17-2002) 
Sec. 38-60. - Development goals and objectives. 
(a)  General intent and application. The development goals and objectives of the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city, incorporated herein by reference, shall include goals and objectives for the project area to guide the city in its review of all proposed developments in the project area. These objectives shall apply to all the properties within the project area. 
(b)  Goals and objectives. The goals and objectives are as follows: 
(1)  Goal 1. To encourage well-planned industrial development in and around the Powder Plant Road corridor. The objectives are as follows: 
a.  Establish appropriate zoning regulations to ensure industrial development is planned and designed to preserve the scenic nature of the area. 
b.  Establish appropriate design guidelines that facilitate well-planned, attractive industrial and heavy commercial developments. 
c.  Develop a transportation plan for the project area to determine potential need for new roads to serve industrial growth and the accommodation of the future northern beltway. 
(2)  Goal 2. To develop the Visionland Parkway and the Academy Drive area as a regional recreational and commercial tourist center. The objectives are as follows: 
a.  Promote the theme park and outlet center as regional attractions to tourists and area residents. 
b.  Improve traffic access and visibility of the theme park and outlet center from Interstate 20/59. 
c.  Encourage supporting recreational development adjacent to the theme park and outlet center. 
d.  Take advantage of access to the theme park and outlet center from the future northern beltway and future Cedar Hill/VisionLand Parkway interchange. 
e.  Refurbish the existing municipally-owned golf course (Frank House Municipal Golf Course) by installing new, updated irrigation equipment to ensure adequate water supply and updating the clubhouse facility to provide handicap accessible restrooms and meeting facilities. 
(3)  Goal 3. To encourage commercial development in support of the theme park and outlet center. The objectives are as follows: 
a.  Establish commercial zoning at the future Cedar Hill/VisionLand Parkway interchange for I-20/59. 
b.  Establish commercial zoning at the intersection of Powder Plant Road and VisionLand Parkway. 
c.  Encourage the revitalization and/or redevelopment of single-family residential areas adjacent to the theme park, outlet center, and future Cedar Hill/VisionLand Parkway interstate interchange. 
(4)  Goal 4. To enhance the visual quality and experience of the Academy Drive, Powder Plant Road, and VisionLand Parkway corridors. The objectives are as follows: 
a.  Establish design guidelines for industrial and commercial development within the project area to ensure appropriate site development, landscaping, and building design. 
b.  Preserve and protect natural, scenic areas through landscape easements, buffers, and other development regulations. 
c.  Develop appropriate signage standards to prevent visual clutter associated with industrial and commercial developments along the Academy Drive, Powder Plant Road, and Visionland Parkway corridors. 
d.  Collaborate with the Metropolitan Planning Organization on the design of the proposed northern beltway within the project area to integrate this roadway within the overall development plans for the project area. 
(5)  Goal 5. To encourage well-planned commercial and industrial development around the McAshan Drive interchange (#104) of Interstate 20/59. The objectives are as follows: 
a.  Establish design guidelines for commercial and industrial development around the interchange to ensure appropriate site development, landscaping, and building design. 
b.  Develop appropriate signage standards to prevent "visual clutter" associated with commercial developments along McAshan Drive. 
(6)  Goal 6. To expedite the commercial growth of the Academy Way Business Park. The objectives are as follows: 
a.  Provide adequate road access to facilitate commercial development. 
b.  Provide adequate water and sewer infrastructure. 
c.  Establish design guidelines for commercial development to ensure appropriate site development, landscaping, and building design. 
(c)  Revision and amendment of development objectives. Revision and amendment of development objectives: 
(1)  The city planning commission shall have the authority to review the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city development goals and objectives from time to time. Through the findings of these reviews, the planning commission may amend these goals and objectives when it is determined that such amendments are necessary and appropriate to uphold the spirit of the overall intentions of this plan. 
(2)  The decision of the city planning commission to amend the development goals and objectives shall require the adoption of a resolution describing the amendments so made. Such resolution shall be adopted in a similar manner by which it adopts a resolution for the adoption of an urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan to the city council. The said amendment to the development goals and objectives shall be effective upon adoption and a copy of the same shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and another copy shall be attached to the copy of the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city, also maintained in the files of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 3207, § III, 12-17-2002) 
Sec. 38-61. - Land use plan. 
(a)  Figure 12, Proposed Land Use Concept shows the land categories described as follows and is incorporated herein by reference: 
(1)  Agricultural; 
(2)  Commercial/general; 
(3)  Commercial/neighborhood; 
(4)  Commercial/office; 
(5)  Industrial and manufacturing/heavy; 
(6)  Industrial and manufacturing/light; 
(7)  Institutional; 
(8)  Parks and recreation; 
(9)  Residential/single-family; 
(10)  Residential/multifamily. 
(b)  Land use provisions and building requirements are as follows: 
(1)  Permitted uses. 
a.  Agricultural. The agricultural land use category shall include all agricultural uses and the types of residential uses which are suited to agricultural areas. The agricultural uses shall include farming, the raising of fowl and livestock, commercial activities associated with agricultural production, and low density residential uses. These uses shall comply with the requirements identified in the A-1 agricultural district of the city zoning ordinance, July 1996. 
b.  Commercial/general. The general commercial land use category shall include commercial services, retail sales, hotel and conference facilities, cultural and entertainment activities, and other related uses serving the community-at-large and surrounding areas. These uses shall comply with the requirements identified in the following districts of the zoning ordinance, July 1996: C-3 community business, C-4 arterial services, C-6 planned shopping, and C-7 health and institutional. For the purposes of accommodating these uses, ancillary off-street parking and loading facilities shall also be permitted and such ancillary uses shall be planned to adhere to design schemes which shall include landscaping and adequate buffers, screens, and noise abatement measures as necessary. 
c.  Commercial/neighborhood. The neighborhood commercial land use category shall include commercial and personal services, retail sales, offices, cultural and recreational activities, and other related uses intended to serve residential neighborhoods lying within and adjacent to the project area. These uses shall comply with the requirements identified in the following districts of the zoning ordinance, July 1996: C-1 neighborhood commercial, SC-1 neighborhood shopping center, C-7 health and institutional, and O-1 office services. For the purposes of accommodating these uses, ancillary off-street parking and loading facilities shall also be permitted and such ancillary uses shall be planned to adhere to design schemes which shall include landscaping and adequate buffers, screens, and noise abatement measures as necessary to provide compatibility with surrounding residential neighborhoods. The site layout and design of neighborhood commercial areas and associated off-street parking facilities are recommended to encourage pedestrian safety and accessibility from and within adjacent neighborhoods and building design of a character and scale appropriate to surrounding residential areas. 
d.  Commercial/office. The office commercial land use category shall include offices and office complexes, research and development facilities, support services, and other related uses. These uses shall comply with the requirements identified in the following districts of the zoning ordinance, July 1996: O-1 office services and C-7 health and institutional. For the purposes of accommodating these uses, ancillary off-street parking and loading facilities shall also be permitted and such ancillary uses shall be planned to adhere to design schemes which shall include landscaping and adequate buffers, screens, and noise abatement measures as necessary. 
e.  Industrial and manufacturing/heavy. The heavy industrial and manufacturing land use category shall include manufacturing facilities, processing plants, mining and extraction operations, and other related high intensity industrial uses. These uses shall comply with the requirements identified in the following districts of the zoning ordinance, July 1996: I-2 heavy industrial, I-3 industrial, I-3-S strip mining, and I-O obnoxious odors. For the purposes of accommodating these uses, ancillary off-street parking and loading facilities shall also be permitted and such ancillary uses shall be planned to adhere to design schemes which shall include landscaping and adequate buffers, screens, and noise abatement measures as necessary. 
f.  Industrial and manufacturing/light. The light industrial and manufacturing land use category shall include wholesaling, warehousing, and distribution centers; truck and bus terminal facilities; heavy equipment sales and repair services; light industrial, fabricating, and assembly operations; planned industrial development; and other related uses. These uses shall comply with the requirements identified in the I-1 light industrial and I-6 planned industrial districts of the city zoning ordinance, July 1996. For the purposes of accommodating these uses, ancillary off-street parking and loading facilities shall also be permitted and such ancillary uses shall be planned to adhere to design schemes which shall include landscaping and adequate buffers, screens, and noise abatement measures as necessary. 
g.  Institutional. The institutional land use category shall include churches, schools, libraries, hospital, government buildings, and other related uses. These uses shall comply with the requirements identified in the following districts of the zoning ordinance, July 1996: INST-1, INST-2, and INST-3 institutional districts. For the purposes of accommodating these uses, ancillary off-street parking and loading facilities shall also be permitted and such ancillary uses shall be planned to adhere to design schemes which shall include landscaping and adequate buffers, screens, and noise abatement measures as necessary. 
h.  Parks and recreation. The parks and recreation land use category shall include theme and amusement parks, campgrounds, sports venues, golf ranges, zoos, and other related uses. These uses shall comply with the requirements identified in the PRD planned recreational district of the city zoning ordinance, July 1996. For the purposes of accommodating these uses; ancillary off-street parking and loading facilities shall also be permitted and such ancillary uses shall be planned to adhere to design schemes which shall include landscaping and adequate buffers, screens, and noise abatement measures as necessary. 
i.  Residential/single-family. The homes single-family residential land use category shall include traditional single-family, duplexes, and patio/garden homes, as well as schools, parks, churches, child care centers, and other related uses which serve the residents of such neighborhoods. These uses shall comply with the requirements identified in following districts of the zoning ordinance, July 1996: R-1 single-family, R-2 single-family, R-3 single-family/two-family residential, and R-3-A patio home/garden home. For the purposes of accommodating related nonresidential uses as stated above, ancillary off-street parking and loading facilities shall also be permitted and such ancillary uses shall be planned to adhere to design schemes which shall include landscaping and adequate buffers, screens, and noise abatement measures as necessary to provide compatibility with surrounding residential neighborhoods. The site layout and design of such uses and associated off-street parking facilities are recommended to encourage pedestrian safety and accessibility from and within adjacent neighborhoods and building design of a character and scale appropriate to surrounding residential areas. 
j.  Residential/multifamily. The multifamily residential land use category shall include apartment buildings and complexes, single- and two-family dwellings, condominiums, patio/garden homes, townhouses, as well as schools, parks, churches, child care centers, and other related nonresidential uses which serve the residents of such neighborhoods. These uses shall comply with the requirements identified in the following districts of the zoning ordinance, July 1996: R-4 multifamily residential-low density and R-5 multifamily residential-medium density. For the purposes of accommodating related nonresidential uses as stated above, ancillary off-street parking and loading facilities shall also be permitted and such ancillary uses shall be planned to adhere to design schemes which shall include landscaping and adequate buffers, screens, and noise abatement measures as necessary to provide compatibility with surrounding residential neighborhoods. The site layout and design of such uses and associated off-street parking facilities are recommended to encourage pedestrian safety and accessibility from and within adjacent neighborhoods and building design of a character and scale appropriate to surrounding residential areas. 
(2)  Building requirements for land to be acquired are as follows: 
a.  The city shall enter into a redevelopment agreement with a redeveloper (referred to as "redeveloper", hereinafter), when acquiring a particular piece of property for redevelopment. Such property shall be shown on Figure 17, Property Ownership/Acquisition Map; such property shall be referred to as acquisition property hereinafter. The redevelopment agreement shall provide for the following: 
1.  All the acquisition property used in the area, by the redeveloper, shall be for the purposes designated in the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city; 
2.  The redeveloper will begin improvements upon a building or commence construction of improvements, as required by the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city, within a time period determined by the city; 
3.  The redeveloper will comply with the conditions, deemed necessary, proper or convenient by the city, when carrying out the purposes of the Code of Ala. 1975, tit. 24, chs. 2 and 3, and the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city; and, 
4.  The requirements of the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city shall be effectively implemented through the instruments of conveyance that allow the incorporation of covenants and conditions pertaining to the land. These covenants and conditions shall be for the sole use and benefit of the city. The redeveloper shall comply with the covenants and conditions of the plan as deemed necessary, proper or convenient by the city. 
b.  The city hereby authorizes the existing urban renewal design review board (hereafter DRB) to review and approve the redeveloper's plans and specifications for redevelopment or rehabilitation. Such plans shall conform with the provisions of the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city and the harmonious development of the project area. All such review and approval shall be concerned with, but not limited to, urban design standards, site planning, architectural treatment, materials and color, lighting, signs, parking, loading, landscaping, and detailed building plans, elevations and construction specifications. 
c.  The redeveloper shall not impose any restrictions on the basis of national origin, race, religion, sex or color, by entering into; executing; being a party to any covenant, conveyance; or any other written instrument, which would restrict the sale, lease, use or occupancy of the project area, or any part thereof, or any improvements placed thereon. The redeveloper shall duly comply with all federal, state and local laws, in effect from time to time, that prohibit discrimination or segregation on the basis of national origin, race, religion, sex or color. 
d.  Landscape treatment shall be applied to all land that is not covered by buildings, structures, paved parking, loading or service areas. Landscape treatment shall include, but not be limited to, paved areas for pedestrian circulation, decorative surface treatments and planting such as trees, shrubs, ground cover, grass and flowers. The extent and details of landscaping shall be determined by the nature of the development and shall augment the utility of the site, enhance the aesthetics of the structures, soften and relieve the effects of parking and paved areas; and, provide visual harmony. The property owner shall be responsible for all landscaping and maintenance. 
e.  All exterior surface parking areas shall be paved with a hard, dust-free and erosion resistant material. Such areas shall be appropriately screened from all adjacent streets and sidewalks with, but not limited to, masonry walls, fences, trees and shrubs planted at an appropriate, regular interval or a combination of these. Parking lots shall be designed with landscaped islands to accommodate deciduous trees at a minimum rate of one per 2,500 square feet of gross parking area. 
f.  All off-street loading spaces shall be provided as needed and shall conform with minimum design standards. Adequate maneuvering spaces shall be provided within the property lines. 
g.  No refuse or garbage shall be permitted to remain outside any building, except as permitted under city codes and regulations. There shall be designated areas for the location of containers and receptacles to afford refuse and garbage; and all such containers and receptacles shall be properly screened. Areas designated for the location of such containers shall not be permitted within the required front setback of a property. Areas designated for such containers and receptacles shall be located in the rear of the building or in a similar location which obscures the view of such receptacle from a public right-of-way. 
h.  No signs shall be permitted except for those which identify the property or the use conducted thereon. There shall be no animated or pulsating signs. All signs shall be located within the confines of the property. 
i.  All regulations and limitations of the city zoning ordinance shall apply to the project area. 
(Ord. No. 3207, § IV, 12-17-2002) 
Sec. 38-62. - Project implementation. 
(a)  Authority and redevelopment. In implementing the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city, the city shall purchase or have the authority to acquire by the exercise of eminent domain a part of the project area that it deems necessary, convenient or proper to proceed with the purposes of the project. The city may also enter into an agreement with a redeveloper, as it deems necessary, convenient or proper, to develop any part or the whole of the project area, in accordance with the requirements set out herein. 
(b)  Public improvements. In addition to the recommended improvements to properties identified in Figure 16, Proposed Public Improvements Map, necessary minor repairs to storm drains, streets, street lighting, etc., shall be undertaken. This shall include the planning of future public roads and other infrastructure needed to support the continued growth and redevelopment of the project area. 
(c)  Acquisition. As shown in the acquisition map, the city council has determined that it is necessary, desirable and in the interest of the public to acquire all the identified properties by purchase or by the exercise of eminent domain.
