All such properties shall be acquired by fee simple or any interest therein and the existing structures thereon may be demolished as appropriate for redevelopment. Likewise, other properties may be acquired and demolished if the city council deems it to be necessary, desirable and in the public interest so that all such acquired properties shall constitute a part of the acquisition property. The city council may also acquire alleys and require the vacation of all acquired alleys for redevelopment if it is deemed necessary, desirable and in the public interest for such acquisition and vacation to take place. 
(d)  Disposition. The acquisition map shows all the properties/parcels which are to be disposed of by means of sale, lease, conveyance or other to redevelopers. Those parcels which are meant to be subdivided or combined may be done so by virtue of surveys that describe the precise details and shall be determined as necessary, proper or convenient by the city. 
(e)  Rehabilitation and new construction plan review. The redeveloper shall submit detailed plans to the design review board, for new construction, including parking lots, or the rehabilitation of any property located in the project area, not to be acquired under the provisions of the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city. The design review board will review all the submitted plans for conformance with the provisions of the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city and the desired, harmonious development of the project area, and as such these shall concern, but not be limited to, urban design, site planning, architectural treatment, materials and color, lighting, signs, parking, loading, landscaping, building plans, building elevations and construction details. Upon the approval of the plans, the redeveloper may submit applications for building or soil erosion and sedimentation control permit for any property which is located in the project area. When the design review board approves the plans submitted by a redeveloper as being consistent with the objectives of the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city, the city shall authorize the processing of the plans for the issuance of the necessary building permit. 
(f)  Commercial revitalization. Commercial revitalization shall take place in conformance with the provisions of the design review process, applicable city codes, property maintenance standards, incentive programs, and the management and technical assistance to business people, property owners and residents of the project area. 
(g)  Demolition. All applications requesting demolition permits shall be submitted to the design review board for review and approval. The written approval, from the design review board, of such an application shall be regarded as authorization for the processing of a demolition permit. If an application submitted to the design review board has not been acted upon by the design review board for over a period of six months, as per proof presented by the property owner, then the building inspection services shall process the application for a demolition permit. 
(h)  Relocation. 
(1)  All efforts of acquisition, demolition and construction, by a redeveloper, shall be undertaken in stages, as presented in the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city, with the intent to minimize any disruption to existing development. 
(2)  It is the explicit right of the city to provide or require a redeveloper to provide all assistance, as the city deems necessary, proper and convenient, to effect the purposes of the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city. 
(3)  There shall be no permanent residents in the acquisition property. 
(i)  Zoning. Existing zoning classifications for the project area, as shown in the city zoning map, shall apply with the adoption of the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city. In the event that a zoning classification change is requested or applied for, all established procedures, as described in the city zoning ordinance, shall be considered, including but not limited to sending notices to affected property owners and the right of such property owners to be heard in a public hearing. 
(j)  Historic preservation. The review and approval of plans submitted for rehabilitation or demolition may include consideration for the preservation of historic structures and districts, in accordance with the urban redevelopment and urban renewal plan for the western area in the city, which have been or may be designated by the city, the state or the United States Department of the Interior. 
(Ord. No. 3207, § V, 12-17-2002) 
Sec. 38-63. - Design review board created. 
    The city council hereby authorizes the existing urban renewal design review board (hereafter DRB) to perform the duties and the responsibilities of the city in accepting, considering, and approving or rejecting applications for certificates of appropriateness, as set out in the bylaws of the DRB. 
(Ord. No. 3207, § VI, 12-17-2002) 
Sec. 38-64. - Enforcement and penalties provisions. 
(a)  Enforcement. 
(1)  Compliance with the terms of this article shall be enforced by the city department of buildings and inspection. 
(2)  Failure to comply with a certificate of appropriateness shall be a violation of this article. The discontinuance of work or the lack of progress towards achieving compliance with a certificate of appropriateness, as laid out in the bylaws of the design review board shall be considered a failure to comply with the terms of this article. 
(3)  Nothing in this article shall prohibit, impair, or limit in any way the power of the city department of buildings and inspections to prevent the alteration, construction, restoration, reconstruction, rehabilitation, or removal of buildings, structures, appurtenances, or outdoor signs in the project area in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(4)  The enforcement of any remedy provided in this article shall not prevent the use and enforcement of any other remedy provided for by the code of the city for violations against validly enacted ordinances of the city or state statutes. 
(b)  Violations. Whenever, by the provisions of this article and after review by the design review board, the performance of any act is required or prohibited regarding the alteration, construction, demolition, or outdoor signage of any property under jurisdiction of this article, a parties' failure to comply with such provisions shall constitute a violation of this article and shall be deemed a class A misdemeanor. 
(c)  Liability for violations. The owner, tenant, or occupant of any land or structure, or part thereof, and any architect, builder, contractor, agent or other person who participates in, assists, directs, creates, or maintains any situation that is contrary to the requirements of this article shall be held responsible for the violation and be subject to the penalties and remedies provided therein. 
(d)  Procedure of notification upon discovery of violation. 
(1)  Upon discovery of a violation of this section, the design review board shall notify in writing by first class mail the party responsible for said violation. Such notice shall indicate the provisions of the article violated, the nature of the violation, the action necessary to correct the violation, the date by which this violation must be remedied, and the penalties for noncompliance. Service of such notice shall be deemed completed at the time of deposit in the post office or any United States mailbox in a sealed envelope, postage prepaid, and addressed to the person to be notified at his last known business or residence address as appears in the public records. Proof of this notice may be made by a return receipt signed by the recipient notified by United States mail. 
(2)  After written notification of such violation from the design review board to the party responsible and the latter's subsequent failure to rectify the situation, the board will notify the city's department of building and inspections of the noncompliance with this article. An authorized employee of that department or an employee of the city shall serve a notice of noncompliance to the party responsible for the violation indicating the provisions of this article violated, the nature of the violation, and ordering the action necessary to correct the violation. 
(3)  This notice shall be in the form of a written citation, signed by an authorized employee of the city's department of building and inspections and shall be delivered to the offender either at their residence, at their place of business, or at the place where the violation has occurred. This notice shall specify a date and time when the party responsible and/or agents are commanded to appear before the municipal court of the city. If said party does not appear on the date specified, a warrant will be issued for this party's arrest. 
(e)  Penalty. Violation of any provision of the article shall subject the responsible party to a criminal penalty not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00, or imprisonment not to exceed six months, or both and costs of court for each offense. Penalties imposed upon a corporation shall consist of the fine only, plus costs of court. Each day that a violation of this article continues, it shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(f)  Remedies. Any use of land or a structure or construction or alteration of a structure, in violation of this article, is hereby declared to be a nuisance per se. The imposition of any penalty under the provisions of this section does not prevent equitable relief in the form of an injunction, mandamus, or other appropriate action or proceeding to correct or abate such violation or to prevent occupancy of such building or structure. 
(Ord. No. 3207, § VII, 12-17-2002) 
Sec. 38-65. - Affirmation of existing building and zoning codes. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed as to exempt property owners from complying with existing city building and zoning codes, nor to prevent any property owner from making any use of his property not prohibited by other statutes, ordinances, and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 3207, § VIII, 12-17-2002) 
Sec. 38-66. - Conflict. 
    In the instance of a conflict between this article and Ordinance No. 2541 (Historic Preservation Commission), Ordinance No. 2541 shall take precedence. 
(Ord. No. 3207, § IX, 12-17-2002) 
Chapter 42 - COURT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal courts generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - Willful failure to appear. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully fail to appear in the municipal court, pursuant to his written bond or in response to a traffic citation given by a police officer of the city, for which the fine has not been paid, or an appearance made in accordance with the ordinances of the city, or willfully fail to appear from time to time as the court may direct, regardless of the disposition of the charge upon which he was originally arrested. Any failure to appear shall be presumed prima facie to be willful. 
(Code 1973, § 22-16; Code 1995, § 42-1; Ord. No. 2011, § 1, 2-21-1978) 
Sec. 42-2. - Assessment of court costs, fees upon convictions for violations of traffic and nontraffic offenses. 
(a)  Upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, for a violation of any traffic ordinance or any applicable law of the state related to traffic offenses, there shall be taxed against the defendant, as court costs and fees, an amount not to exceed the court costs and fees then levied in the district court of the county (Bessemer Division), and further provided that in all cases which are nol prossed before conviction the court may, in the discretion of the municipal judge, tax all the court costs and fees in an amount not to exceed the court costs and fees then levied in the district court of the county (Bessemer Division). 
(b)  Upon conviction in the municipal court of the city for a violation of any nontraffic ordinance or any applicable law of the state related to nontraffic offenses, there shall be taxed against the defendant, as court costs and fees, an amount not to exceed the court costs and fees then levied in the district court of the county (Bessemer Division), and further provided that in all cases which are nol prossed before conviction the court may, in the discretion of the municipal judge, tax all costs and fees in an amount not to exceed the court costs and fees then levied in the district court of the county (Bessemer Division). 
(c)  Upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, for violation of any offense for driving while under the influence of alcohol, there shall be taxed against the defendant, as court costs and fees, an amount not to exceed the court costs and fees then levied in the district court of the county (Bessemer Division) and further provided that in all cases which are nol prossed before conviction the court may, in the discretion of the municipal judge, tax all costs and fees in an amount not to exceed court costs and fees then levied in the district court of the county (Bessemer Division). 
(d)  All costs taxed, as herein provided, shall be collected by the court clerk and paid into the city treasury, and all said costs shall be in addition to officers' fees provided by law. The costs in every case tried before the municipal judge shall be entered on a trial docket and in no case shall any person be entitled to any fees unless such fees are clearly set out on the docket, and it shall be the duty of the municipal judge to enforce this provision. Such costs shall automatically be increased in the future as permitted by state law. 
(Ord. No. 3218, § 1, 4-15-2003) 
Secs. 42-3-42-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL JUDGES 

Sec. 42-23. - Appointment; terms; presiding judge; qualifications; vacancies; oath; hearing of applicable cases. 
(a)  The city council shall, by vote of a majority of its members, appoint judges of the municipal court. 
(b)  The term of office of the municipal judges shall be two years or until a successor has been appointed and qualified. This provision shall not be construed as an automatic renewal of a successive two-year term. 
(c)  The mayor shall designate a presiding judge, who shall have such additional duties and powers and be entitled to receive such additional compensation as provided by ordinance. 
(d)  Each judge must be licensed to practice law in this state and must be a qualified elector of the state. No judge shall be otherwise employed in any capacity by the city during his term of office. 
(e)  The office of a municipal judge shall be vacant if he dies, resigns or is removed, and vacancies shall be filled by the city council in the same manner as original appointments are made. 
(f)  Each municipal judge shall, before assuming office, take and sign the oath provided by the state constitution, and a copy thereof shall be filed in the office of the secretary of state, the administrative director of courts and the clerk and, provided that failure to file as required by this subsection shall not render invalid any act, order or judgment of the municipal judge. 
(g)  Municipal judges shall be subject to all grounds of disqualification from hearing specific cases as are applicable to circuit judges. 
(Code 1995, § 42-26; Ord. No. 1998, § 4, 11-22-1977; Ord. No. 2369, § 2, 1-13-1987) 
Sec. 42-24. - Number. 
    The city shall have two parttime municipal judges. 
(Code 1995, § 42-27; Ord. No. 1998, § 4, 11-22-1977; Ord. No. 2369, § 2, 1-13-1987) 
Sec. 42-25. - Powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties of municipal judges shall be the same powers and duties as those set out under state law. 
(Code 1995, § 42-28; Ord. No. 2369, § 6, 1-13-1987) 
Sec. 42-26. - Compensation. 
    The salaries of the municipal judges shall be fixed from time to time by the city council and paid by the city, but no judge's salary shall be diminished during his term. 
(Code 1995, § 42-29; Ord. No. 2369, § 7, 1-13-1987) 
Sec. 42-27. - Adoption of state statutes. 
    The city council adopts as part of this article, all other provisions of Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-1 et seq., which have not specifically been set forth in this article. 
(Code 1995, § 42-30; Ord. No. 2369, § 8, 1-13-1987) 
Secs. 42-28-42-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - INDIGENT DEFENSE SYSTEM[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipality retaining a court is required to provide indigent defense services, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-9. 

Sec. 42-58. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Appointed counsel means any attorney licensed to practice law in the state who is appointed by the court to represent one or more indigent defendants. 
    Indigent defendant means any person charged in a proceeding in the municipal court for which proceeding representation by counsel is constitutionally required and who under oath or affirmation states that he is unable to pay for his defense and who is found by the court to be financially unable to pay for the defense. 
    Indigent defense system means any method or mixture of methods for providing legal representation to indigent defendants, including use of appointed counsel or any alternative method meeting constitutional requirements. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 3, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 42-59. - Title. 
    This article shall also be known as the Indigent Defense Ordinance of the City of Bessemer, Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 42-60. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to: 
(1)  Establish the indigent defense system to be used in the municipal court of the city; 
(2)  Provide for the collection, accounting and disbursement of monies used in the indigent defense system; and 
(3)  Provide legal counsel for any person found to be indigent by the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 2, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 42-61. - Provision of indigent defense services. 
    Pursuant to state law, indigent defense services in the municipal court of the city, shall be provided pursuant to the provisions of this section, as follows: 
(1)  Appointment of counsel. Any indigent defendant who has been determined by a judge of such court to be an indigent shall be entitled to counsel and the municipal judge making such determination shall appoint an attorney at law from the roster of attorneys authorized to practice law in this state to represent such indigent defendant. 
(2)  Roster of attorneys. The clerk of the municipal court shall keep and maintain a roster of attorneys licensed to practice law in this state from which municipal judges shall appoint attorneys to represent indigent defendants. Attorneys licensed to practice in this state may sign-up with the clerk of the municipal court to be placed on the roster. It is the desire and intent of the governing body that the appointment of attorneys from the roster be made as follows: 
a.  The roster of attorneys shall be kept in chronological order in the order that attorneys sign up for the roster. 
b.  That appointments be made commencing with the first name on the roster and continuing down the roster to the next name on the roster, in order, until the names on the rosters are exhausted at which time appointments shall re-commence from the top of the roster. 
c.  In order to provide immediate representation for incarcerated indigent defendants appearing before the municipal court and in cases where indigent defendants appear before the court for plea negotiations, guilty pleas and sentence impositions from previous appearances and the next attorney on the roster of attorneys is not available in court, and it would otherwise be proper and expedient to appoint indigent counsel so as not to delay such cases, the next attorney on the roster, present in court, may be appointed to represent said indigent defendants. 
d.  Except as set forth in section, unless good cause exists (the next attorney on the roster is not available, cannot provide adequate representation or when a conflict of interest is evident), the order of appointment shall continue in chronological order. 
e.  The clerk of the municipal court, or his designee, shall make the roster of attorneys available at each session of the municipal court with clear delineation of the last attorney to have been appointed. 
(3)  Compensation. Compensation of counsel appointed by a judge of the municipal court shall be paid by the city from the proceeds of the fair trial tax pursuant to state law, in amounts not in excess of $60.00 per hour for time expended in court and $40.00 per hour for time reasonably expended out of court in the preparation of such case. The total fees to any one attorney in any one case, from the time of appointment through the trial of the case, shall not, however, exceed $500.00, unless leave is granted to exceed said sum is made by the appointing judge. Counsel shall also be entitled to be reimbursed for any expenses reasonably incurred in such defense to be approved in advance by the trial judge, but in no individual case shall such expenses exceed one-half of the allowable attorney fees provided in this subsection. 
(4)  Fee petition. Within a reasonable time after the conclusion of the trial or after an acquittal or other judgment disposing of the case, counsel shall submit to the trial judge a fee petition or bill for services rendered, in the form prescribed by the presiding judge, not to exceed the amount provided in subsection (3) of this section, and such bill if approved by the trial judge shall be submitted by the clerk of the municipal court to the treasurer of the city for payment from the proceeds of the fair trial tax, as authorized under state law. 
(5)  Fair trial tax. Pursuant to state law, the clerk of the municipal court shall collect the appropriate fair trial tax on all applicable cases and deposit the moneys in the general fund of the city. Upon using and expending so much of the moneys as is necessary to defray the costs of providing representation for indigent defendants in the municipal court and after payment of such costs, the city shall pay into the state treasury any funds not used for that purpose with an accounting of the moneys expended. Attorney's fees to be paid by the city from this fund must be claimed on the proper fee declaration form duly authenticated and authorized by the signature of the municipal judge. The clerk of the municipal court and the treasurer of the city shall render an accounting of such funds to the state treasurer, as required by law, with a copy of said accounting to the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 4, 11-1-2005) 
Chapter 46 - EMERGENCY SERVICES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 46-1-46-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - E-911 SERVICE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Emergency telephone service generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-98-1 et seq. 

Sec. 46-19. - City emergency telephone communication district-Creation. 
    There is hereby created the city emergency telephone communication district, which shall encompass all of the territory lying within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 46-26; Ord. No. 2331, § 1, 7-1-1986; Ord. No. 2603, § I, 12-21-1993) 
Sec. 46-20. - Same-City council to govern. 
    The city emergency telephone communication district shall be governed by members of the city council. The city council recognizes that should other governmental entities in the county elect to become subscribers to the E-911 emergency service, the geographical boundaries, the designation, and the constituency of the city council of the emergency telephone communication district will be appropriately changed as provided for in Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-98-1 et seq. 
(Code 1995, § 46-27; Ord. No. 2331, § 2, 7-1-1986; Ord. No. 2603, § II, 12-21-1993) 
State Law reference- Authority of council to serve as the boards, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-98-4(e). 
Sec. 46-21. - Levy of emergency telephone service charge; collection; disbursal of funds; reduction of levy. 
    The city councilmembers of the emergency telephone communications district shall: 
(1)  Levy on all of the telephone subscribers within the emergency telephone communications district an emergency telephone service charge in an amount not to exceed five percent of the local service tariff rates charged to these subscribers by the telephone companies servicing the communication district; 
(2)  Collect from local telephone companies on a quarterly basis the amount collected by these companies attributable to the emergency telephone service charge to telephone subscribers; 
(3)  Disburse funds collected from the emergency telephone service charge, or any other source in the discharge of its responsibilities under law; and 
(4)  Where the revenues set in subsection (1) of this section prove to be in excess of the amounts needed to operate the service, the city council shall reduce the subscribers' levy accordingly. 
(Code 1995, § 46-228; Ord. No. 2331, § 4(a), (c)-(e), 7-1-1986) 
State Law reference- Authority to levy service charge, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-98-5(a); to reduce charge, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-98-5(b). 
Secs. 46-22-46-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AMBULANCE SERVICE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Ambulances, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-18-1 et seq.; local regulation of ambulances, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-18-7. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-46. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    ADPH means the Alabama Department of Public Health. 
    ADPH/OEMST means Alabama Department of Public Health Office of Emergency Medical Service and Trauma. 
    Ambulance means a motor vehicle including a convalescent ambulance that is intended to be used for and is maintained or operated for the transportation to a medical care facility of persons who are sick or injured. 
    Ambulance driver means any individual who has successfully completed the Emergency Vehicle Operation Course (EVOC) as prescribed by the ADPH/OEMST and who has been granted a current valid license by the ADPH/OEMST. 
    Emergency medical technician, basic (EMT-B) means any person 18 years of age or older who has successfully completed the basic emergency medical technician course of instruction, or its equilvalent, as approved by the state board of health or its designee, and passed the state EMT basic examination and who has been granted a current and valid license by the state board of health or its designee. 
    Emergency medical technician, intermediate (EMT-I) means any person 18 years of age or older who has successfully completed the intermediate emergency medical technician course of instruction, or its equivalent, as approved by the state board of health or its designee, and passed the state EMT intermediate examination and who has been granted a current and valid license by the state board of health or its designee. 
    Emergency medical technician paramedic (EMT-P) means any person 18 years or older who has successfully completed the EMT paramedic course of instruction, or its equilvalent, as approved by the state board of health or its designee, and passed the state EMT paramedic examination and who has been granted a current and valid license by the state board of health or its designee. 
    Fire chief means the chief of the Bessemer Fire Department, or such member of the fire department as he may from time to time designate to act for him under this chapter. 
    Mutual aid means an agreement made between two like entities to provide assistance to each other in times of emergencies. 
    Patient means an individual who receives or requests medical care, or for whom medical care is requested, because such individual is sick or injured. 
    Public safety dispatch center means the location that houses the dispatchers for the fire department and police department of the city. 
    Public safety-emergency medical dispatcher (dispatcher) means an individual, trained to meet ADPH/OEMST requirements, who receives emergency calls, dispatches and maintains communications with fire, police and public safety personnel. 
(Code 1995, § 46-51; Ord. No. 1938, § 2, 5-25-1976) 
Sec. 46-47. - Applicability of article. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to the operation of any ambulance while traveling without a patient into, through or from the city, or while being used to transport a patient through the city, or from without the city to a location within the city. 
(Code 1995, § 46-52; Ord. No. 1938, § 1, 5-25-1976) 
Sec. 46-48. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this article or fail to comply therewith or with any requirement thereof, or who shall do any act prohibited therein or fail to do any act required therein, shall, upon conviction, be punished within the limits of and as provided by the Code of Alabama for a misdemeanor. Each offense and each day's continuance of the offense shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Code 1995, § 46-53; Ord. No. 1938, § 22, 5-25-1976) 
Sec. 46-49. - Liability insurance required. 
    No permit required by this article or business license shall be granted to any person to operate any ambulance upon the streets of the city until such person shall have first filed with the city clerk and treasurer a personal injury and property damage liability insurance policy issued to such person by a public liability insurance company authorized to do business in the state providing insurance coverage for each ambulance as follows: 
(1)  For each ambulance the insurance policy shall provide insurance coverage in the amount of $500,000.00 for personal injury or death arising from any one accident, $100,000.00 for property damage liability, and $1,000,000.00 per occurrence for injury to or death of a person, or damage to property, resulting from an accident or collision arising out of or occurring by reason of the careless or negligent operation of such vehicle by such person, his agent, servant or employee, or by any person in possession of such vehicle. 
(2)  The insurance coverages required by this section shall at all times be maintained for the full amount. The policy of insurance required by this section to be filed with the city clerk and treasurer shall contain a clause obligating the company issuing the insurance to give not less than 30 days' written notice to the city clerk and treasurer before cancellation thereof. Notice of cancellation shall not relieve the company issuing such policy of liability for any injury or claim arising before the cancellation becomes effective. The cancellation of any such policy shall have the effect of suspending the permit of such person to operate the ambulances or invalid coaches covered thereby until a new policy complying with the provisions of this section is filed with the city clerk and treasurer. 
(3)  Every insurance policy required under this section shall contain a provision for a continuing liability thereunder to the full amount thereof, notwithstanding any recovery thereon, that the liability of the insurer shall not be affected by the insolvency or the bankruptcy of the insured, and that until the policy is cancelled the insurance company will not be relieved from liability on account of nonpayment of premium, or any act or omission by the named insured. Such policy of insurance shall be further conditioned for the payment of any kind and all judgments, up to the limits of the policy, recovered against any person other than the owner, his agent or employee who may operate the ambulance with the consent or acquiescence of the owner. 
(Code 1995, § 46-54; Ord. No. 1938, § 9, 5-25-1976) 
Sec. 46-50. - Emergency calls-Communications. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of any person operating ambulances, upon receiving an emergency call, to first report such call to the dispatcher on duty at the public safety dispatch center, give the name of the person requesting the ambulance and/or the address of the response location, or the circumstances under which the call was received and obtain the oral permission of such dispatcher before sending, permitting or driving any ambulance to answer such emergency call. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the dispatcher at the public safety dispatch center, upon receiving a request for permission to send or drive an ambulance to answer an emergency call made as provided in this section to immediately give permission thereof, unless an ambulance has already been permitted to go to the scene of the same accident or emergency, in which case such dispatcher shall refuse permission for another ambulance to answer such call unless he is convinced that more than one ambulance is necessary to take care of the emergency properly. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to send, drive, permit or allow an ambulance to answer an emergency call without having first obtained permission from the dispatcher as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person operating any ambulance or place of business wherein an ambulance service business is conducted, or any place used in connection therewith to permit any radio at such place of business or in any vehicle used by such business to be so adjusted or tuned to receive messages or signals on frequencies assigned by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to police, firefighters, or contract ambulance service of the city unless such private ambulance or ambulance service business has been designated as an emergency vehicle receiving station to be assigned the use of frequencies assigned to the city. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to any radio station licensed by the FCC for these frequencies. 
(Code 1995, § 46-55; Ord. No. 1938, § 17, 5-25-1976) 
Sec. 46-51. - Same-Response; personnel. 
    All emergency calls will be responded to as outlined in this article concerning permission, communication, reporting and traffic law obedience. There shall be no less than two emergency personnel in the vehicle on all emergency calls, an attendant-driver and a paramedic, for purposes of patient care and ambulance driving. These must be licensed personnel as required by the ADPH/OEMST. 
(Code 1995, § 46-56; Ord. No. 1938, § 18, 5-25-1976) 
Sec. 46-52. - Same-Record. 
    Each holder of an ambulance license issued under this article shall maintain accurate records concerning the transportation of each patient within the city or from one place therein to another place within or beyond its limits, upon forms in words and figures substantially as follows: Such records shall be available for inspection by the fire chief at any reasonable time, and copies thereof shall be made available by the holder of such license within 24 hours after a request by the fire chief. 
(Code 1995, § 46-57; Ord. No. 1938, § 19, 5-25-1976) 
Sec. 46-53. - Calling ambulance without cause. 
    No person shall knowingly and willfully summon an ambulance or report that an ambulance is needed when such person knows that the services of such ambulance are not needed. 
(Code 1973, § 15-120.1; Code 1995, § 46-58) 
Sec. 46-54. - Obedience of driver to traffic laws, ordinances and regulations. 
(a)  The driver of an ambulance, when responding to an emergency call or while transporting a patient, may exercise the privileges set forth in this section, but such privileges are subject to the conditions stated in this section, and shall be exercised only when such driver has reasonable grounds to believe that an emergency in fact exists requiring the exercise of such privileges. 
(b)  Subject to the provisions of this section the driver may: 
(1)  Park or stand, irrespective of the otherwise applicable provisions of law, ordinance or regulation; 
(2)  Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, only after coming to a complete stop; 
(3)  Exceed the maximum speed limits permitted by law, ordinance or regulation so long as he does not endanger life or property; and 
(4)  Disregard laws, ordinances or regulations governing direction or movement or turning in specified directions. 
(c)  The provisions of subsection (b) of this section shall not relieve the driver of an ambulance from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons, nor shall such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(Code 1995, § 46-59; Ord. No. 1938, § 20, 5-25-1976) 
Secs. 46-55-46-81. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUSINESS LICENSE 

Sec. 46-82. - Ambulance license-Required. 
(a)  No person, either as owner, agent or otherwise, shall furnish, operate, conduct, maintain, advertise or otherwise be engaged in or profess to be engaged in the business or service of the transportation of patients upon the streets, alleys or any public way or place in the city unless he holds a currently valid business license for an ambulance issued under this division. 
(b)  No ambulance shall be operated, and no individual shall drive, attend or permit an ambulance to be operated for such purposes on the streets, alleys or any public place or public way in the city, unless such ambulance shall be under the immediate supervision and direction of a person who is holding a currently valid license as an ambulance driver or an EMT licensed by the ADPH/OEMST. 
(c)  No such license, however, shall be required for an ambulance or for the ambulance driver, EMT of an ambulance which: 
(1)  Is rendering assistance to licensed ambulances in the case of a major catastrophe or emergency with which the licensed ambulances of the city are insufficient or unable to cope; 
(2)  Is rendering mutual aid assistance to licensed ambulances. Mutual aid agreements by licensed ambulances with non-licensed ambulances must be approved by the fire chief; 
(3)  Is operated from a location or headquarters outside the city in order to transport patients who are picked up beyond the limits of the city to locations within the city, or through the city, but no such outside ambulance shall be used to pick up patients within the city for transportation to locations within the city. 
(Code 1995, § 46-71; Ord. No. 1938, § 3, 5-25-1976) 
Sec. 46-83. - Same-Application. 
    Application to the city council for an ambulance license under this division shall be made and sworn to upon such forms as may be prepared or prescribed by the city clerk and shall contain: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant and of the owner of the ambulance service, including the owner's residence and place of business. 
(2)  The trade or corporate name under which the applicant does business and proposes to do business. 
(3)  The location and description of the places from which it is intended to operate. 
(4)  The names and addresses where previous and current ambulance service has or is provided by the applicant. 
(Code 1995, § 46-72; Ord. No. 1938, § 4, 5-25-1976) 
Sec. 46-84. - Same-Hearing upon application; issuance or denial. 
    Within 21 days after the application has been filed with the city clerk, the city council shall set a date for a hearing investigated by the fire chief on the application, and at the hearing, or upon any date to which the hearing is continued, shall hear all evidence offered by any party that may be presented bearing upon such application. If the city council finds that the applicant is ready, willing and able to comply with all the provisions of this article, state law and that the territory proposed to be served by the operation under the license is, in the opinion of the city council, not adequately served by ambulance facilities, and that the public necessity and convenience require the issuance of such license, then such application shall be granted and a license issued to operate such number of ambulances upon the streets of the city as the city council deems in the public interest, which license shall be issued by the city clerk upon payment to the city by the applicant of a license fee. The amount for an ambulance service license shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 46-73; Ord. No. 1938, § 5, 5-25-1976) 
Sec. 46-85. - Same-Transferability of license. 
    Any change of ownership of an ambulance for which a license has been or shall have been granted under this article shall terminate such license and shall require a new application and new license and conformance with all the requirements of this article as upon an original application. 
(Code 1995, § 46-74; Ord. No. 1938, § 7, 5-25-1976) 
Sec. 46-86. - Same-Revocation of license. 
(a)  The city council may and is hereby authorized to suspend or revoke an ambulance license issued under this division for failure of a licensee to comply or to maintain compliance with, or for his violation of any applicable provisions, standards or requirements of this article, or for regulations promulgated under this article, or for failure to operate or cause to be operated for which such license was issued, or when, in the opinion of the city council, the public necessity, convenience or good renders such revocation advisable, upon not less than ten days' notice to the licensee and after a public hearing. 
(b)  An ambulance equipment and/or premises inspection report of the ADPH/OEMST or fire chief, shall be prima facie evidence of compliance or noncompliance with, or violation of the provisions, standards and requirements provided in this division, and of the regulations promulgated under this article. 
(c)  Upon suspension, revocation or termination of an ambulance license under this division, such ambulance service shall cease operations as such, and no person shall permit such ambulance service to continue operations as such. 
(d)  Each written complaint received by the city or an officer or employee thereof relating to the operations of ambulance services or their employees in the city shall, in addition to such other action as may be taken thereon, be referred to the fire chief and public safety committee. 
(Code 1995, § 46-75; Ord. No. 1938, § 16, 5-25-1976) 
Sec. 46-87. - Inspection of ambulances. 
(a)  Subsequent to issuance of an ambulance license, the fire chief shall cause to be inspected each ambulance and its equipment and premises. 
(b)  All reports resulting from inspections by the ADPH/OEMST will be provided to the fire chief within 24 hours of said inspections. 
(c)  Each ambulance or invalid coach, its equipment and the premises designated in the application, and all records relating to its maintenance and operation as such shall be open to inspection by the fire chief or his designated representative at any time during the usual hours of operation. 
(Code 1995, § 46-76; Ord. No. 1938, § 8, 5-25-1976) 
Sec. 46-88. - Investigation and report by fire chief. 
    Each and every application for an ambulance license filed with the city clerk shall be immediately referred by him to the fire chief for investigation and report. The fire chief shall investigate the facts set out in the application and report to the public safety committee the results of his investigation, as follows: 
(1)  His finding as to the truth or falsity of the facts set out in the application. 
(2)  Whether or not the applicants ambulances and equipment comply with all requirements of the ADPH/OEMST. 
(3)  Whether or not the personnel employed by the applicant comply with all requirements of the ADPH/OEMST. 
(4)  Any facts which he has which bear upon or may bear upon the question of whether or not the applicant is a responsible and proper person or company to conduct or work in the proposed business. 
(5)  Provide a recommendation as to weather or not the public necessity and convenience require or will be served by the proposed ambulance service. 
(Code 1995, § 46-77; Ord. No. 1938, § 10, 5-25-1976) 
Sec. 46-89. - Fire department ambulance service provider. 
(a)  The fire department will utilize one or more licensed ambulance services to provide patient transport for calls that originate through the public safety dispatch center. 
(b)  The fire chief will recommend the ambulance service to be used by the fire department to the mayor for approval. 
(c)  Ambulance services providing transport service arising out of the public safety dispatch center will not be compensated in any manner by the city. 
(d)  On all calls where fire department personnel are on the scene, fire department personnel will be in charge of the scene and ambulance personnel shall cooperate and assist fire department personnel. 
(1)  If any disagreement over patient care should arise, the online medical control physician shall be contacted immediately. 
(2)  Fire department personnel will maintain the right to provide and/or assist with patient care during transport to receiving medical facility. 
(e)  Ambulance services shall have the capability to provide continuous operation to ensure that ambulances consistently respond to calls for emergency services within the city. 
(f)  The ambulance service provider will be responsible to dispatch a mutual aid service, in the event that they are unable to respond on request. The provider will notify the dispatch center that the call has been rolled and provide the name and ETA of the responding ambulance service. 
(g)  The ambulance service provider will respond within 12 minutes to all calls requested by the fire department. This response time shall be complied with no less than 90 percent of the time. 
(h)  The ambulance service provider will provide the fire chief with a monthly report of response times of the provider for all calls originating out of the public safety dispatch center. 
(1)  Report shall be provided no later than the tenth day of each month. 
(2)  Time period will be from the first day of each month to the last day of each month. 
(i)  The fire chief may at any time suspend or terminate the use of an ambulance service providing transport for the fire department for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Failure to comply with any part of this division. 
(2)  Failure to maintain required response times. 
(3)  Any act involving dishonesty, fraud or deceit which gives rise to a cause of action by any person. 
(4)  For any reason deemed to be in the best interest of the citizens and employees of the city. 
(j)  A suspended or terminated ambulance service may appeal to the mayor of the city. 
(k)  If an employee of the ambulance service has any grievance or complaint against the city, fire department or any employee of the city, a supervisor of the ambulance service should give notice of the same to the fire chief, in writing and with sufficient detail to allow the problem to be addressed in a reasonable manner. Employees of the ambulance service should follow the chain of command up to the supervising manager of the ambulance service, who may then determine whether to make a written grievance to the fire chief. Employees of the ambulance service, other than a supervising manager should not lodge complaints with the fire chief. 
(Code 1995, § 46-82; Ord. No. 1938, § 15, 5-25-1976) 
Chapter 50 - ENVIRONMENT 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 50-1. - Levy of stormwater fees. 
(a)  Under the authority of Acts 1995, p. 1835 (No. 95-775) and pursuant to the city's police powers, the city herby levies upon each parcel of real property or portion thereof located in the corporate limits of the city a fee to be established by the city council, from time to time. The purpose of the fee is for funding the city's stormwater program and to comply with the requirements of any national pollutant discharge elimination system (NPDES) permit held by the city: 
(1)  The fee is levied on properties designated by the county tax assessor pursuant to Amendment No. 325 to the Constitution of Alabama, 1901, and Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-8-1, as class I and class II land use classifications in an amount per parcel or portion thereof located in the corporate limits of the city. 
(2)  The fee is levied on the properties designated by the county tax assessor pursuant to Amendment No. 325 to the Constitution of Alabama, 1901, and Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-8-1, as class III use classification in an amount per parcel or portion thereof located in the corporate limits of the city. 
(3)  There will be no exemptions for this fee on any parcels located within the city, regardless of whether ad valorem taxes are exempted for such parcels, except for those parcels designated by the county tax assessor as schools, churches or owner occupied residences for which homestead exemption has been allowed by the tax assessor and for which the over age 65 years exemption has been allowed by the tax assessor. 
(b)  The procedures implemented by the tax assessor and tax collector of the county necessary and appropriate to assess and collect this fee are hereby adopted by reference and incorporated herein as if set out fully. All stormwater fees, collected pursuant to this section by the tax assessor and tax collector of the county will be remitted to the city. 
(c)  The mayor is hereby authorized to take whatever actions are necessary to implement the assessment and collection of this fee as authorized by law. 
(Ord. No. 3334, 6-12-2007; Ord. No. 3360, 2-6-2008) 
State Law reference- Stormwater discharges into municipal separate storm sewers, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-89C-1 et seq. 
Secs. 50-2-50-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 50-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accidental discharge means a discharge prohibited by this article into the MS4 or community water which occurs by chance and without planning or consideration prior to occurrence. 
    Adverse impact means any deleterious effect on waters or wetlands, including their quality, quantity, surface area, species composition, aesthetics or usefulness for human or natural uses which are or may potentially be harmful or injurious to human health, welfare, safety or property or to biological productivity, diversity or stability, or which would unreasonably interfere with the enjoyment of life or property. 
    Agriculture means activities undertaken on land for the production of plants, crops, and animals which are useful to man. 
    Alabama Department of Environmental Management (ADEM) means the state regulatory agency, created under Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-22A-1 et seq., responsible for administering and enforcing the stormwater laws of the United States of America and the State of Alabama. 
    Applicant means any person or governmental agency who executes the necessary forms to procure approval of best management practices plans from the official. 
    Best management practices (BMP) means activities, prohibitions of practices, maintenance procedures and management practices designed to prevent or reduce the pollution of waters to the MS4. Best management practices also include treatment requirements, operating procedures and practices to control facility site runoff, spillage or leaks, sludge or waste disposal or drainage from raw material storage and construction sites. 
    Best management practices plan or BMP plan means a set of drawings and/or other documents submitted by a person as a prerequisite to obtaining a permit, which contain all of the information and specifications pertaining to BMP. 
    Clean Water Act (CWA) means the federal act (33 USC 1251 through 1387) which was formerly referred to as the Federal Water Pollution Control Act and Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972, Public Law 92-500, as amended by Public Law 95-217, Public Law 95-576, Public Law 6-483 and Public Law 97-117, 33 USC 1251 through 1387. 
    Clearing means the removal of trees and brush from the land, not including the ordinary mowing of grass or the maintenance of previously cleared areas. 
    Community waters means any or all rivers, streams, creeks, branches, lakes, reservoirs, ponds, drainage systems, springs, wetlands, wells and other bodies of natural or artificial surface or subsurface water into which the MS4 outfalls flow. 
    Contour means a line of equal elevation above a specified datum, usually mean sea level. 
    Contour line means a line joining points having or representing equal elevations. 
    Discharge means the passing of water or other liquid through an opening or along a pipe, conduit or channel; the rate of flow of water, silt, or other mobile substance which emerges from a pipe, conduit or channel, usually expressed as cubic feet per second, gallons per minute or million gallons per day. 
    Drainage means the removal of surface water from a given area either by gravity or by pumping; commonly applied to surface water and groundwater. 
    Drainage area means that area contributing runoff to a single point measured in a horizontal plane, which is enclosed by a ridge line; the area of a drainage basin or watershed, expressed in acres, square miles or other unit of area. 
    Engineer means a person currently licensed by the Alabama State Board of Registration for Professional Engineers and Land Surveyors to provide engineering services. 
    Erosion means wearing away of lands by running water. 
    Erosion control means the application of measures to reduce erosion of land surfaces. 
    Grading means any act by which soil is cleared, stripped, stockpiled, excavated, scarified or filled, or any combination thereof. 
    Illicit connection means any manmade conveyance connecting an illicit discharge directly to the MS4. 
    Illicit discharge means any discharge that is not composed entirely of stormwater, except discharges pursuant to an NPDES permit (other than the NPDES MS4 permit issued to the City of Bessemer by ADEM) and discharges which are specifically excepted from this article. 
    Minor extension means an addition to an existing utility pipeline or other utility line in which the land disturbed consists of fewer than 7,500 linear feet. 
    Municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) means a system of conveyances (including roads with drainage systems, municipal streets, catchbasins, curbs, gutters, ditches, manmade channels and storm drains), owned or operated by a city, town or county or other public body (created by, or pursuant to, state law) having jurisdiction over stormwater. 
    NPDES means national pollutant discharge elimination system. 
    Official shall be the person responsible, on behalf of the city, to enforce the provisions of this article as a part of the city's stormwater management program. The official shall be the city engineer and/or director of building inspections. 
    Outfall means a point source (meaning any discernible, confined and discrete conveyance, including, but not limited to, any pipe, ditch, channel, tunnel, conduit, well, discrete fissure, container rolling stock, concentrated animal feeding operation, landfill leachate collection system, vessel or other floating craft from which pollutants are or may be discharged, but not including return flows from irrigated agriculture or agricultural water runoff) at the point of a discharge to waters of the United States of America. 
    Permit means any permit issued pursuant to this article. 
    Permittee means a person, party, government entity and all others who receive a permit to discharge under the NPDES. 
    Pollutant includes, but is not limited to, the pollutants specified in Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-22-1(b)(3) and any other effluent characteristics specified in a permit. 
    Pollutant loading means the amount of a pollutant entering the MS4. 
    Qualified credentialed professional means a certified professional in erosion and sediment control (CPESC) as determined by the Soil and Water Conservation Society (SWCS) or the International Erosion Control Association (IECA). Other registered or certified professionals such as a professional engineer or a landscape architect, registered land surveyor, registered architect, registered geologist, registered forester, registered environmental manager as determined by the National Registry of Environmental Professionals (NREP), certified professional soil scientist (CPSS) as determined by the American Registry of Certified Professionals in Agronomy, Crops and Soils (ARCPACS), who can document the necessary education, training, and professional certification, registration, or credentials acceptable to the official and can demonstrate proven experience in the field of erosion and sediment control shall be considered a qualified credentialed professional. The qualified credentialed professional must be in good standing with the authority granting the registration. The qualified credentialed professional must be familiar, and have expertise, with current industry standards for erosion and sediment controls and must be able to inspect and ensure that nonstructural BMPs or other pollution control devices (silt fences, erosion control fabric, rock check devices, etc.) and erosion control efforts, such as grading, mulching, seeding and growth management, or management strategies have been properly implemented and regularly maintained according to good engineering practices and the requirements of this permit. A professional engineer (PE) registered in the State of Alabama must certify the design and construction of structural practices such as spill prevention control and counter measures (SPCC) plan containment structures, dam construction, etc. 
    Sediment means solid material settled from suspension in a liquid that has been transported and deposited from its site of origin by air, water, ice or gravity as a product of erosion and has come to rest on the earth's surface either above or below a water surface, usually, inorganic or organic particles originating from weathering, chemical precipitation, or biological activity. 
    Silviculture means the care and cultivation of forest trees, including site preparation, planting, pruning, thinning and harvesting. 
    Site means any tract, lot or parcel of land or combination of contiguous tracts, lots or parcels of land which are in one ownership, and any combination of tracts, lots and parcels which are contiguous, are owned by two or more parties and are to be developed as a unit, subdivision or project. 
    Stabilization means the prevention of soil movement by any of various vegetative and/or structural means. 
    Stormwater means the excess water running off from the surface of a drainage area during and immediately after a period of rain. It is that portion of the rainfall and resulting surface flow that is in excess of that which can be absorbed through the infiltration capacity of the surface of the basin. 
    Stormwater management means the incorporation of a variety of activities and equipment into a plan to address concerns associated with stormwater for the purpose of preventing pollution, improving water quality, keeping pollutants out of runoff and the implementation of best management practices. 
    Stormwater management program (herein referred to as "the management program" or "the program") means a program which covers the duration of the permit. It shall include a comprehensive planning process which involves public participation and, where necessary, intergovernmental coordination, to reduce the discharge of pollutants, to the maximum extent practicable, using management practices control techniques and system design and engineering methods and such other provisions which are appropriate. 
    Stormwater permit means a permit which grants permission to the holder to discharge stormwater to the MS4 under the NPDES. 
    Stream means a course of running water usually flowing in a particular direction in a definite channel and discharging into some other course of running water or body of water. 
    Structural controls means measures incorporated into existing stormwater drainage systems or newly constructed systems to prevent or minimize the discharge of pollutants for the purpose of maintaining and/or improving water quantity and quality management; quantitative control by a system of vegetative and structural measures that control the increased volume and rate of surface runoff caused by manmade changes to the land; qualitative control by a system of vegetative, structural and other measures that reduce or eliminate pollutants that might otherwise be carried by surface runoff. 
    Turbidity means a condition in water or wastewater caused by the presence of suspended matter, resulting in the scattering and absorption of light rays. A measure of fine suspended matter in liquids. 
    Utility means a business or service which is engaged in regularly supplying the public with some commodity or service which is of public consequence and need, such as electricity, gas, water, telephone service and telegraph service. 
    Variance means the modification of the minimum stormwater management requirements in situations in which exceptional circumstances, applicable to the site with respect to which the variance is requested, exist so that strict adherence to the provisions of this article would result in unnecessary hardship and the granting of such modification would not result in a condition contrary to the intent of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 48-26; Ord. No. 3066, § 1.01, 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 3360, § 48-26, 2-6-2008) 
Sec. 50-22. - Administration. 
    The official is hereby appointed to administer and implement the provisions of this article. Whenever the term "official" is used in this article, it shall be the person responsible, on behalf of the city, to enforce the provisions of this article as a part of the city's stormwater management program. 
(Code 1995, § 48-27; Ord. No. 3066, § 2.01, 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 3360, § 48-27, 2-6-2008) 
Sec. 50-23. - Notices. 
    Whenever the city is required or permitted to: 
(1)  Give a notice to any party, such notice must be in writing; or 
(2)  Deliver a document to any party, such notice or document may be delivered by personal delivery, certified mail (return receipt requested), registered mail (return receipt requested) or a generally recognized overnight carrier, to the address of such party which is in the records of the city or is otherwise known to the city. 
(Code 1995, § 48-28; Ord. No. 3066, § 9.01, 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 3360, § 48-28, 2-6-2008) 
Secs. 50-24-50-34. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - APPLICATION AND FEES 

Sec. 50-35. - Application. 
(a)  Before the commencement of any land disturbing activity that is not exempted from obtaining a permit under this article, the owner of the land on which such activity shall be conducted, or his duly authorized agent, must file with the official an application for the approval of the owner's BMP plan. The official must either approve or disapprove the BMP plan within 21 days of the day it is filed with the official. If the BMP plan is disapproved, the official must inform the applicant, in writing, of the reasons for its disapproval. If the applicant, on one or more occasions, revises the BMP plan or submits to the official additional documents or information in connection with the BMP plan, the official must make a written response to the applicant with respect to whether such revised BMP plan and/or additional documents and information have been approved or disapproved by the official. All such additional responses must be made by the official to the applicant within 21 days of the day such revised BMP plan or additional documents or information are submitted to the official. The land disturbing activity may not be commenced prior to the issuance of the permit by the official. The issuance of the permit shall not excuse the owner from the need to obtain other required state and local permits or licenses. 
(b)  The minimum standards for the issuance of a permit must meet the requirements of this article. 
(c)  Facilities that are covered under an ADEM NPDES permit for stormwater discharge associated with construction activities are exempt from the permitting requirements of this article. However, prior to the commencement of any land disturbing activity, the owner or developer of facilities that are covered under an ADEM NPDES permit shall submit to the official copies of the ADEM NPDES permit authorization issued by ADEM, any relevant notice of intent and a copy of the BMP plan. The holders of an ADEM NPDES permit shall be subject to the relevant portions of section 50-51 and divisions 4 and 5 of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 48-36; Ord. No. 3066, § 3.01, 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 3360, § 48-36, 2-6-2008) 
Sec. 50-36. - Permit application fee. 
    Each application for the issuance of a permit shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee as established by ordinance or resolution of the city council, from time to time and that fee shall be available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code, for individual single-family residences and for all other types of land disturbing activities, to help defray the city's cost of processing and reviewing the application and the inspections associated with the application. The applicant must submit three sets of its BMP plan with its application and fee to the official. The amount of these permit fees shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1995, § 48-37; Ord. No. 3066, § 3.02, 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 3068, 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 3360, § 48-37, 2-6-2008) 
Sec. 50-37. - Data required on application for a permit. 
(a)  All applications for a permit must include the following information: 
(1)  Name of the applicant; 
(2)  Telephone number, telecopier number, if any, and e-mail address, if any, of the applicant; 
(3)  Address where the applicant, or other person who can furnish information about the land disturbing activity (contact person), can be reached; 
(4)  Name, address, telephone number, telecopier number, if any, and e-mail address, if any, of the owner of the project, the owner of the property on which the project is to be located and the ground lessee of the property, if any, on which the land disturbing activity is to be conducted if the applicant is not the owner of the project and such property; 
(5)  Legal description and address, if any, of the property upon which the land disturbing activity is to be conducted; 
(6)  Names, addresses, telephone numbers, telecopier numbers, if any, and e-mail addresses, if any, of all contractors and subcontractors who shall implement any BMP plan; provided, however, that if the contractor and the subcontractors have not been selected when the application for a permit is filed, the applicant shall furnish such information to the official within five days of the day on which the contractor and/or subcontractors are selected; 
(7)  Name, address, telephone number, telecopier number, if any, and e-mail address, if any, of the qualified credentialed professional who has approved the BMP plan application (this is required for all land disturbing activities except those related to the construction of individual single-family residences); 
(8)  Each application for a permit must be accompanied by a map or a plot of the land on which the land disturbing activity will be conducted and any other information that is required under the provisions of division 3 of this article. 
(b)  The detail of the BMP plan must be commensurate with the size of the project, severity of the site condition and potential for off-site damage, as provided in division 3 of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 48-38; Ord. No. 3066, § 3.03, 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 3360, § 48-38, 2-6-2008) 
Sec. 50-38. - Maintenance of records. 
    Records of compliance with the provisions of the permit shall be maintained in the office of the owner or the applicant, shall be available to the contact person and shall be made available at any time for review by the official; provided that if such records are maintained without the state and, because of their size, cannot be transmitted to the official by telecopier, such records must be delivered to the official (at no expense to the city or the official) within 48 hours of the earliest of the receipt by the owner, applicant or contact person of a request by the official for such records. 
(Code 1995, § 48-39; Ord. No. 3066, § 3.04, 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 3360, § 48-39, 2-6-2008) 
Sec. 50-39. - Amended application; transfer of permit. 
(a)  A permit may be amended, without the payment of an additional fee, upon the filing with the official of an amended or restated permit application, containing all changes from the original application; provided, that the holder of the permit shows to the reasonable satisfaction of the official that there are no proposed changes which may affect the quantity and/or quality of stormwater runoff. If an amended or restated application is filed with the official with respect to land disturbing activities for which a permit has been issued, such existing permit shall continue in effect, and the holder of the permit may continue to operate under it unless and until an amended permit is issued in response to the amended or restated application (amended permit) at which time the original permit shall expire and all land disturbing activities must be conducted in accordance with the amended permit. 
(b)  A permit may be transferred, without the payment of an additional fee, upon the filing with the official of an application for transfer; provided, that the holder and proposed transferee of the permit show to the reasonable satisfaction of the official that, upon or following the transfer, there will be no proposed changes which may affect the quantity and/or quality of stormwater runoff. If there is a request for the transfer of a permit and there are to be one or more changes in the operation of the project which is the source of the land disturbing activity which may affect the quantity and/or quality of stormwater runoff the new owner or operator of such project must apply to the city for a new permit prior to his involvement with the operation of such project. 
(Code 1995, § 48-40; Ord. No. 3066, § 3.05, 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 3360, § 48-40, 2-6-2008) 
Sec. 50-40. - Signatory requirements. 
(a)  All applications and correspondence required by this article to be submitted to the official shall be signed as follows: 
(1)  If an application or correspondence is submitted by a corporation, it must be signed by the president of the corporation or by a vice-president of the corporation who is in charge of a principal business function of the corporation, or any other person who performs similar policy-making or decision-making functions for the corporation, or who has been authorized to sign such applications and/or correspondence by a resolution adopted by the board of directors of the corporation. Proof of the authority of the signatory shall be provided to the official, upon his request. 
(2)  If an application or correspondence is submitted by a limited liability company, it must be signed by a manager or other person who serves the same or similar function as the president of a corporation. 
(3)  If an application or correspondence is submitted by a partnership, it must be signed by a general partner of the partnership. 
(4)  If an application or correspondence is submitted by a sole proprietorship, it must be signed by the proprietor. 
(5)  If an application or correspondence is submitted by a municipality, the state or the federal government or by any municipal, state or federal agency, it must be signed by either the chief executive officer or a principal executive officer of any such government or by either the chief executive officer, a principal executive officer or a senior executive officer having responsibility for the over-all operations of a principal geographic unit of any such governmental agency. 
(b)  Any person signing any application or correspondence required by this article shall make the following certification: 
"I certify, under penalty of law, that this document and all attachments were prepared under my direction or supervision and that I have personally examined and I am familiar with the information in this document and such attachments. Based on my inquiry of those individuals immediately responsible for obtaining the information, I believe the submitted information is true, accurate and complete. I am aware that there are significant penalties for submitting false information, including the possibility of fine and civil penalty." 
(Code 1995, § 48-41; Ord. No. 3066, § 3.06, 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 3360, § 48-41, 2-6-2008) 
Sec. 50-41. - Exclusion. 
(a)  No person may conduct any land disturbing activity without: 
(1)  Having obtained a permit from the official; or 
(2)  Having provided the official with a copy of an ADEM NPDES permit any relevant notice of intent and a copy of the BMP plan. 
(b)  Land disturbing activities shall include any land change which may result in soil erosion from water or wind and the movement of sediment to the MS4, including, but not limited to, the clearing, dredging, grading, excavating, transporting and filling of land, except that the term shall not include the following: 
(1)  Any land change on property about which the owner of the property has submitted information to the official proving, to the satisfaction of the official, that such property does not drain to the MS4. Determination as to whether such property drains to the MS4 shall be made by the official. 
(2)  Agriculture. 
(3)  Silviculture. 
(4)  Such minor land disturbing activities as home gardens, landscaping on individual residential lots (excluding landscaping performed by, or on behalf of a developer or builder, who builds a house on any such lot), home repairs, home maintenance work, minor additions to houses, the construction, maintenance or repair of accessory structures and other related activities which result in minor soil erosion. 
(5)  Minor land disturbing activities such as individual connections for utility services and sewer services for single- or two-family residences, minor grading for driveways, yard areas and sidewalks, excluding any grading done by, or on behalf of a developer or builder in connection with the construction of a house. 
(6)  Minor maintenance, minor repair, and the minor extension of any existing underground public utility lines, except sewer lines; provided that the utility company which owns such lines has received approval of a general BMP plan from the official for such maintenance, repair, and extension; and provided further that any utility company making a minor extension in connection with which the land disturbed consists of more than 1,000 linear feet must give the official written notice of such extension prior to the commencement of such minor extension. 
(7)  The construction, repair or rebuilding of railroad tracks. 
(8)  Minor subsurface exploratory excavations under the direction of soils engineers or engineering geologists. 
(9)  The opening of individual burial sites in property which has been approved for such use by all necessary governmental authorities. 
(10)  Digging of water wells or environmental monitoring wells. 
The activities referred to in subsections (b)(2) through (9) of this section may be undertaken without a permit; however, the persons conducting these excluded activities shall remain responsible for otherwise conducting such activities in accordance with the provisions of this article and any other applicable law, including the proper control of sedimentation and runoff to the MS4. This article shall apply to such land disturbing activities that drain to the MS4 if a stormwater pollution problem is shown to be caused by such activity following monitoring procedures and complaints. 
(Code 1995, § 48-42; Ord. No. 3066, §§ 4.01, 4.02, 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 3360, § 48-42, 2-6-2008) 
Secs. 50-42-50-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BMP APPROVAL REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 50-51. - General requirements. 
    No land disturbing activity shall be conducted within the city until either a permit has been issued by the official allowing such activity pursuant to the provisions of this article or an authorization issued by ADEM under the ADEM NPDES permit, any relevant notice of intent and a copy of the BMP plan has been submitted to the official. The ADEM NPDES permit, notices of intent and BMP plans shall be kept on file by the official and shall be on the job site, or other reasonable location, for inspection by the official until the project has been completed and notice of termination of the relevant NPDES permit has been sent to ADEM. The ADEM NPDES permits shall be required in addition to any building permits or other local permits required for land disturbing activities or other activities on the site. The following are BMP approval requirements: 
(1)  Persons conducting land disturbing activities shall take all reasonable measures referred to, or provided for, in this article to protect all public and private property from damage caused by such activities and to reduce stormwater pollution to the maximum extent practicable. 
(2)  No land disturbing activities subject to this article shall be undertaken except in accordance with the following requirements: 
a.  The person proposing to conduct any land disturbing activity or an agent, contractor or other representative of such person must contact the official at least five business days before commencement of the land disturbing activity to advise the official of the commencement of such land disturbing activity, unless, for good cause shown, the official permits such person, contractor, agent or other representative to contact him nearer to the date of the commencement of such land disturbing activity. 
b.  Other than land clearing activities required to install the appropriate BMP in accordance with BMP plans, any downslope erosion and sediment control measures, on-site stream channel protection and upslope diversion of drainage required by the BMP plan shall be in place and functional before any clearing or earth-moving operations begin, and shall be constructed and maintained throughout the construction period. Temporary measures may be removed at the beginning of the workday, but shall be replaced at the end of the workday.
