    It shall be unlawful for any person over 19 years of age, who has borrowed or withdrawn any book or other material from the Bessemer Public Library, or any parent, guardian, or other person having custody of a minor child, who has requested in writing that the Bessemer Public Library permit such minor child to borrow or withdraw from the library any book or other material and agrees in writing to be responsible for the care and proper return thereof to the library, to not return or cause to be returned such book or other material within 60 days of the due date to the Bessemer Public Library, together with all overdue assessments or late charges, in compliance with rules of the library with respect thereto, within 21 days after written notice from the library that the book or other material is overdue. The notice shall be by certified mail, return receipt requested, with the return card showing the receipt or refusal by the addressee. Such notice shall contain a copy of this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 74-2; Ord. No. 1900, § 1, 7-22-1975) 
Sec. 74-2. - Signature on membership application card constitutes evidence. 
    In any prosecution for any violation of this chapter, any membership application card on file with the Bessemer Public Library shall be prima facie evidence of the genuineness of any signature appearing thereon. 
(Code 1995, § 74-3; Ord. No. 1900, § 2, 7-22-1975) 
Chapter 78 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- State Criminal Code generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Application of state statutes; penalty for violation. 
(a)  Any person committing an offense within the corporate limits of the city, which is declared by laws of the state now existing or hereafter enacted to be a misdemeanor, shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(b)  Any person committing an offense within the corporate limits of the city or within the police jurisdiction thereof, which is declared by laws of the state now existing or hereafter enacted to be a violation, shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(c)  Any person committing within the corporate limits of the city, or within the police jurisdiction thereof, an offense as defined by Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-1-2 of the Alabama Criminal Code, which offense is not declared by laws of the state now existing or hereafter enacted to be a felony, misdemeanor or violation, shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(d)  Any person found to be in violation of subsections (a) through (c) of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than $1.00 nor more than $500.00 and/or may be imprisoned or sentenced to hard labor for the city for a period not exceeding six months, at the discretion of the court trying the case, unless otherwise provided in this section. Any corporation found to be in violation of subsections (a) through (c) of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than $1.00 nor more than $500.00 at the discretion of the court trying the case. Any person found to be in violation of Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-191, as amended, shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than $5,000.00 and/or may be imprisoned or sentenced to hard labor for not more than one year. 
(Code 1995, § 78-1; Ord. No. 2074, § 4, 11-18-1979; Ord. No. 2215, §§ 1-4, 8-30-1983) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt state offenses by reference, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-2. 
Sec. 78-2. - Nuisances. 
(a)  No person shall create or cause or, being the owner or in control, permit any nuisance on or about any lot, place or premises or on or about any street or other public place, or commit any act or create or cause or, being the owner or in control, permit the existence of anything calculated to endanger the safety of property, or which is prejudicial to the health or comfort or offensive to the senses of ordinary citizens. 
(b)  No person shall create or maintain any nuisance within the city limits. 
(Code 1973, § 15-47; Code 1995, § 78-2) 
Sec. 78-3. - Places of business; maintenance; noise. 
    No person shall in the operation of his business maintain or have an unclean, unsanitary or offensive place or premises, or allow unnecessary noises or boisterous conduct therein or thereabout. 
(Code 1973, § 15-62; Code 1995, § 78-3) 
Sec. 78-4. - Behavior in places of public exhibition or entertainment; penalty for violation. 
(a)  Throwing of rubbish. It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or cause to be thrown any bottle, cushion, paper, magazine, food, beverage or other article in or from the stands or seats in any athletic field, stadium, auditorium, hall, theatre or coliseum. 
(b)  Ticket stub required for occupying seat. It shall be unlawful for any person occupying a seat at any athletic field, stadium, auditorium, hall, theatre or coliseum at or during any event, contest, performance or exhibition for which admission is charged to refuse to vacate such seat after having been requested to move by an usher or policeman unless such person has in his possession and exhibits to the usher or policeman a ticket or stub entitling him to occupy that seat. 
(c)  Sitting; standing in aisles. It shall be unlawful for any person to sit or stand in any aisle in any athletic field, stadium, auditorium, hall, theatre or coliseum during any event, contest, performance or exhibition. 
(d)  Unauthorized entry into areas not open to public. It shall be unlawful for any person to enter any back stage dressing room, press box, or other area not open to the general public in any athletic field, stadium, auditorium, hall, theatre or coliseum at or during any event, contest, performance or exhibition without having been granted permission by authorized personnel. 
(Code 1995, § 78-4; Ord. No. 2294, §§ 1-5, 1-14-1986) 
Sec. 78-5. - Covering wells; cisterns; mine shafts. 
    Any person on whose premises or lands are located abandoned or unused wells, cisterns, mining shafts or other dangerous excavations shall cover or fill them up. If he wishes to retain them for possible future use, he shall place and maintain a substantial enclosure around such wells, cisterns, mining shafts or other dangerous excavations in order that no persons or livestock may be injured thereby. 
(Code 1973, § 15-61; Code 1995, § 78-5) 
Secs. 78-6-78-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 

Sec. 78-29. - Damaging city property; rewards. 
    The city clerk and treasurer, upon the direction of the mayor, is authorized to pay out of the general funds of the city, from time to time, rewards to persons furnishing the city or any official thereof information leading directly to the arrest and conviction of any person for a violation of the provisions of this section. The amount of the reward payable in any one instance shall not exceed $25.00. 
(Code 1973, § 15-54; Code 1995, § 78-31) 
Sec. 78-30. - Possession of burglary tools. 
    No person shall have in his possession any implement or instrument designed and intended by him to aid in the commission of burglary or larceny in the city, or elsewhere. 
(Code 1973, § 15-100; Code 1995, § 78-32) 
Secs. 78-31-78-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES INVOLVING THEFT (RESERVED) 

Secs. 78-50-78-71. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES INVOLVING FORGERY AND FRAUDULENT PRACTICES 

Sec. 78-72. - Changing name with intent to defraud. 
    No person shall change or alter his name with the intent to defraud, avoid payment of any debt, or to conceal his identity. 
(Code 1973, § 15-37; Code 1995, § 78-82) 
Sec. 78-73. - Disposal of mortgaged property. 
    No person shall sell, convey or otherwise dispose of any personal property upon which he has given a written mortgage, lien or other deed of trust, and which is then unsatisfied, in whole or in part, without first notifying the lawful holder thereof prior to such sale, conveyance or disposition. 
(Code 1973, § 15-44; Code 1995, § 78-83) 
Sec. 78-74. - Selling property purchased on conditional sale. 
    No purchaser of personal property under a written or printed contract of conditional sale, the consideration in whole or in part remaining unpaid, shall, without notice to the vendor, sell, give away or otherwise dispose of or conceal such property, so that the vendor cannot, by due process of law, recover the property under the terms of the contract. 
(Code 1973, § 15-46; Code 1995, § 78-85) 
Secs. 78-75-78-91. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC ORDER AND SAFETY 

Sec. 78-92. - Public drunkenness. 
    No person shall appear upon the streets or other public ways or places of the city, or in the public view, though on private property, in a drunken or intoxicated condition. 
(Code 1973, § 15-102; Code 1995, § 78-106) 
Sec. 78-93. - Loud; disturbing; unnecessary; enumeration. 
(a)  No person shall make or cause to be made any unreasonably loud, disturbing or unnecessary noise within the city limits. No person shall permit any such noise to be made in or upon any house or premises owned or possessed by him or under his management or control or by a motor vehicle. 
(b)  The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, raucous, disturbing or unnecessary noises in violation of this section, but such enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
(1)  The sounding of any horn or signal device on any automobile, motorcycle, bus or other vehicle, except as a danger signal when and as required by laws or ordinances of the city or by the state highway code, the creation by means of any such signal device of any unreasonable, loud or harsh sound and the sounding of such device for an unnecessary or unreasonable period of time. The provisions of this section regulating the sounding of a horn or signal device on vehicles shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles, such as ambulances, fire department equipment and police department vehicles, while the drivers of such vehicles are operating the vehicles in an emergency in the necessary performance of public duties, and when the sounding of such horn or signal device is made as a warning or danger signal. 
(2)  The keeping of any animal or bird which by causing frequent or long continued noise shall disturb the comfort or repose of any ordinary person in the vicinity. 
(3)  The blowing of any steam whistle attached to any stationary boiler, except to give notices of the time to begin or stop work or as a warning of danger. 
(4)  The discharging into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motor vehicle or motorboat engine except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent the emission of loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
(5)  The shouting or crying of peddlers, hawkers and vendors which disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. 
(6)  The explosion of firecrackers, skyrockets, Roman candles, pinwheels or any other form of fireworks. 
(7)  The use of any drum, pan, pail, bell, horn, trumpet, loudspeaker or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention or intended to attract attention to any performance, show, sale or display of merchandise, or for any other advertising purposes. 
(8)  The use of calliopes, mechanical loudspeakers or amplifiers, whether used upon a vehicle or not, for advertising or other purposes. 
(Code 1973, § 15-135; Code 1995, § 78-109) 
Sec. 78-94. - Use of sound amplifying equipment; permit. 
(a)  Nothing contained in sections 78-93 and 78-98 shall be construed as prohibiting a candidate for political office from using sound amplifying equipment or loudspeakers during daylight hours, for the making of a political speech, conducting a political rally or notifying people of such rally. Such candidate may employ or authorize others to use such equipment in his name. Any person may use sound amplifying equipment for the purpose of notifying people of the fact that it is election day in order to encourage voting. 
(b)  Prior to the use of such equipment a permit showing the time and nature of such activity shall be obtained from the chief of police. 
(Code 1973, § 15-136; Code 1995, § 78-111) 
Sec. 78-95. - Curfew of minors. 
(a)  No minor shall loiter, wander about or play in or on any public street, alley, park or other public place or any place of amusement or vacant lot between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to any minor: 
(1)  Accompanied by his parent or guardian or any other adult person having the care and custody of such minor; 
(2)  Where such minor is on an emergency errand or legitimate business directed by his parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor; 
(3)  When the minor is returning directly home from a school activity, entertainment, recreational activity, or dance; 
(4)  When the minor is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the above-referenced places during the prescribed period of time; 
(5)  When the minor is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of first amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly, or free exercise of religion; 
(6)  When the minor is in a motor vehicle of parental consent for normal travel. All cases of interstate travel through Norcross are excepted from the curfew; 
(7)  When the minor is an emancipated minor as defined in Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 26-21-2, 26-23A-3. 
(Code 1973, § 15-142; Code 1995, § 78-114) 
Sec. 78-96. - Responsibility of parents of minor. 
    No adult person having the care and custody of a minor shall knowingly permit such minor to wander, loiter, wander about, stroll or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, public places or buildings, places of amusement and entertainment, vacant lots or other unsupervised places in violation of section 78-95. 
(Code 1973, § 15-143; Code 1995, § 78-115) 
Sec. 78-97. - Abandoned iceboxes; refrigerators; other airtight containers. 
    No person shall leave outside of any building or dwelling in a place accessible to children any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or any other container of any kind which has an airtight door or lock which may not be released for opening from the inside of the icebox, refrigerator or container, or which has an airtight snap-lock or other device thereon without first removing the snap-lock or doors from the icebox, refrigerator or container. 
(Code 1973, § 15-144; Code 1995, § 78-116) 
Sec. 78-98. - Production of noise. 
(a)  Purpose and intent. The city council finds and declares that: 
(1)  Inadequately controlled noise through the operation or playing of any radio, television, phonograph, musical instrument, sound amplifier, or other device which produces, reproduces, or amplifies sound in buildings, structures, premises or motor vehicles within the jurisdictional limits of the city presents a growing danger to the health and welfare of the residents of the city; 
(2)  The making and creation of disturbing, excessive, or offensive noises from the operation or playing of any radio, television, phonograph, musical instrument, sound amplifier, or other device which produces, reproduces, or amplifies sound in buildings, structures, premises or motor vehicles within the jurisdictional limits of the city is a condition which has persisted, and the level and frequency of occurrences of such noises continues to increase; 
(3)  The making and creation of such excessive noises which are prolonged or unusual in their time, place, and use, affect and are a detriment to the public health, comfort, convenience, welfare, and prosperity of the residents of the city; 
(4)  Every person is entitled to an environment in which the noise is not detrimental to his life, health, or enjoyment of property; and 
(5)  The necessity, in the public interest, for the provisions and prohibitions hereinafter contained and enacted is declared to be a matter of legislative determination and public policy, and it is further declared that the provisions and prohibitions hereinafter contained and enacted are in pursuance of and for the public health, comfort, convenience, safety, welfare, prosperity, peace, and quiet of the city and its inhabitants. 
(b)  General prohibition. It shall be unlawful to operate, play, or permit the operation of any radio, television, phonograph, musical instrument, sound amplifier, or other device which produces, reproduces or amplifies sound in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet, and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for the person who are in the room, chamber, on the premises, or in the motor vehicle in which such machine or device is operated and who are voluntary listeners; thereto, is hereby prohibited in the city or its police jurisdiction. 
(c)  Prima facie violation of this provision. 
(1)  Prima facie violation. 
a.  The operation, playing, or permitting the operation of any radio, television, phonograph, musical instrument, sound amplifier, or other device which produces, reproduces or amplifies sound in such a manner as to be audible at a distance of 50 feet from the building, structure, or premises in which such device is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
b.  The operation, playing, or permitting the operation of any radio, musical instrument, sound amplifier, or other device which produces, reproduces or amplifies sound in such a manner as to be audible at a distance of ten feet from any car, truck, or other motor vehicle in which such device is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
c.  The operation, playing, or permitting the operation of any radio, musical instrument, sound amplifier, or other device which produces, reproduces or amplifies sound in such a manner as to be audible at a distance of five feet from the location where such device is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
(2)  Enforcement of prima facie violations. Any person who is authorized to enforce the provisions of this section and who encounters evidence of a prima facie violation of this section is empowered to confiscate and impound as evidence, any or all of the components amplifying or transmitting the sound. 
(d)  Violations and enforcement. 
(1)  Violations; additional remedies; injunctions. As an additional remedy, the operation or maintenance of any activity, device, instrument, or vehicle in violation of any provision of this article, which disturbs the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring residents or persons in the area or endangers the comfort or health of persons or residents in the area shall be deemed, and is declared to be, a public nuisance, and may be subject to abatement summarily by a restraining order or injunction issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2)  Manner of enforcement. Violations of this article shall be prosecuted in the same manner as other misdemeanor violations of this Code; however, nothing in this article shall prevent efforts to obtain voluntary compliance by way of warning, notice or educational means. 
(e)  Exemptions from section. 
(1)  Noises resulting from any authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency call or acting in time of emergency. 
(2)  Any other noise resulting from activities of a temporary duration permitted by law and for which a lease or permit therefore has been granted by the city. 
(f)  Applications for a special permit. 
(1)  Applications for a permit for relief from this section on the basis of undue hardship may be made to the mayor or his duly authorized representative. Any permit granted by the mayor hereunder shall set forth in detail the approved method of achieving compliance and shall specify a reasonable time that the permit shall be effective. 
(2)  If in the judgment of the mayor the time for compliance cannot be reasonably determined, a permit to cause the noise may not be issued for a period to exceed three days. In determining the reasonableness of the terms of any proposed permit, said mayor shall consider the magnitude of the nuisance caused by the offensive noise, the uses of the property within the area of impingement by the noise, and the general public interest and welfare. 
(3)  The mayor may prescribe any conditions or requirements he deems necessary to minimize adverse effects upon the continuity or the surrounding neighborhood. 
(4)  A nominal fee shall be charged to each applicant for the processing of permits. Fee schedules shall be approved by council resolution. 
(Code 1995, § 78-118; Ord. No. 3057, §§ 101-601, 3-16-1999) 
Secs. 78-99-78-124. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC ADMINISTRATOR 

Sec. 78-125. - Entering restricted area in vicinity of jail or prison. 
(a)  The chief of police may, if he deems it advisable, prescribe a reasonable distance in the vicinity of any jail or other place where prisoners are held within which any person shall not come without the permission of the officer in charge of such jail or place. 
(b)  No person shall knowingly and wilfully, without lawful excuse, come within the limits prescribed under subsection (a) of this section without the required permission, and refuse to retire after being informed to do so by a police officer. 
(Code 1973, § 15-150; Code 1995, § 78-141) 
Sec. 78-126. - Demonstrations in public buildings. 
    No person shall take part in or otherwise participate in any demonstration within any public building. 
(Code 1973, § 15-151; Code 1995, § 78-142) 
Sec. 78-127. - Police line or checkpoint-Authority to establish; maintain. 
(a)  The chief of police is authorized to establish a police line or checkpoint at any location in the city where the circumstances in his judgment require such action for the purpose of maintaining law and order within the area to the rear of the line or checkpoint. 
(b)  Some of the circumstances giving rise to action under subsection (a) of this section, but not limited to such enumeration, shall be: 
(1)  Civil emergencies such as explosions, fires, or epidemics. 
(2)  Civil disturbances which require such measures for the containment of the disturbance. 
(3)  All activities of a similar or like nature to subsections (b)(1) and (b)(2) of this section. 
(c)  The chief of police may maintain the line or checkpoint as long as in his judgment these measures are necessary to maintain law and order in the affected areas. 
(Code 1973, § 15-152; Code 1995, § 78-143) 
Sec. 78-128. - Same-Entry into restricted area. 
    Police officers, firefighters or other law enforcement officers at any police line or checkpoint shall be authorized to prohibit any person from entering the area for which such line or checkpoint is being maintained, except residents of such area, persons engaged in the operation of businesses in such area, customers of such businesses and persons servicing such businesses, and such other person as the chief of police or the superior officer on duty at such line or checkpoint determines has business in such area of a nature not likely to impede the maintenance of law and order therein. 
(Code 1973, § 15-153; Code 1995, § 78-144) 
Sec. 78-129. - Same-Conduct. 
(a)  No person shall enter the area to the rear of any police line or checkpoint in disregard of the order of any police officer, firefighter or other law enforcement officer at the line or checkpoint. 
(b)  No person who is permitted to enter any such area as a customer of any business therein or to service any business therein shall fail to proceed directly to the business and to leave such area without delay upon the completion of the activity for which he was permitted to enter such area. 
(c)  No person shall congregate in the vicinity of the line or checkpoint and refuse to disperse and leave after being ordered to do so by any police officer, firefighter or other law enforcement officer at the line or checkpoint. 
(d)  No person shall remain at or loiter at or in the vicinity of any such line or checkpoint after having been requested to depart by any police officer, firefighter or other law enforcement officer at such line or refuse to leave the area for which any such line or checkpoint is being maintained, after having been requested to do so by any police officer maintaining law and order or attempting to maintain law and order therein. 
(Code 1973, § 15-154; Code 1995, § 78-145) 
Sec. 78-130. - Same-Enforcement. 
    The power and authority delegated to the chief of police, any police officer, firefighter or other law enforcement officer under the provisions of this article shall be cumulative and in addition to all other power and authority which the chief of police, police officer, firefighter or other law enforcement officer may have under any other rule, regulation, ordinance or law. 
(Code 1973, § 15-155; Code 1995, § 78-146) 
Secs. 78-131-78-158. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC HEALTH AND MORALS 

Sec. 78-159. - Use of force or threats. 
    No person shall use force, threats, intimidation or other unlawful means to prevent any other person from engaging in any lawful occupation or business. 
(Code 1973, § 15-72; Code 1995, § 78-172) 
Sec. 78-160. - Illegal possession of property or instrumentality. 
    No person shall, without a just cause or legal excuse but with the intent to supplant, nullify or impair the owner's, operator's or manager's control of any lawful business or enterprise, or without just cause or legal excuse, take, retain, attempt or threaten to take or retain possession or control of any property of another or any instrumentality used in any lawful business or enterprise of another. 
(Code 1973, § 15-75; Code 1995, § 78-175) 
Sec. 78-161. - Illegal drug house. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this article the term "illegal drug house" means any property, including premises, wherein controlled substances, as defined by the 1991 Alabama Uniform Controlled Substances Act codified in Code of Ala. 1975, tit. 20, ch. 2, as amended, and any schedule incorporated thereafter, are unlawfully possessed, used, bought, sold, delivered, stored or distributed. 
(b)  Visiting. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to visit or resort to an illegal drug house with the intent to unlawfully possess, use, buy, sell, deliver, store or distribute controlled substances. 
(2)  Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such intent is manifested are: 
a.  Such person having been convicted of possessing, selling, or distributing a controlled substance, within the last two years, under state law, the fact of such conviction being known to the arresting officer at the time of such arrest. 
b.  Such person was then engaged in an unlawful drug-related activity, including but not limited to acting as a lookout, furtively transferring small objects or packages, attempting to conceal a controlled substance, taking flight or manifestly attempting to conceal himself upon the entrance or arrival of a law enforcement officer. 
c.  Such person is in possession of drug paraphernalia, as defined in Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-12-260, as amended. 
d.  Controlled substances are found in close proximity to such individual. 
(3)  Any combination of these circumstances shall establish prima facie evidence of such unlawful intent, but in no event shall any person be convicted of violating this section for visiting his own residence unless a court of competent jurisdiction previously declared the residence a drug-related public nuisance due to unlawful drug activity and such judicial finding had not been set aside or declared remedied prior to said visits. Any person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished as prescribed by this section. 
(Code 1995, § 78-177; Ord. No. 2690, § I, 2-18-1997) 
Secs. 78-162-78-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - OFFENSES IN PUBLIC ENTERTAINMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Alabama Anti-Obscenity Enforcement Act, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-12-200.1 et seq.; public lewdness, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-12-130; indecent exposure, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-6-68. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 78-191. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abnormal sexual act means anything done or performed by any person to attain sexual gratification in an unnatural manner or at variance with or contrary to nature, which shall include, but not be limited to, homosexuality, sadomasochism, lesbianism, masturbation, or any form of sodomy. 
    Advertisement means any commercial promotional material initiated by or in behalf of an exhibitor designed to bring any public entertainment to the public attention or to increase the attendance of the public at such public entertainment, whether by newspaper, billboard, motion picture, television, radio, or other media within or originating within the city. 
    Exhibit means to project or perform any public entertainment at any public place to which an admission charge is made or where the public is invited free of charge. 
    Extramarital sexual relations means sexual conduct by a married person with a person other than such married person's spouse. 
    Nudity means the showing or exhibiting of the human male or female genitals, pubic area or buttocks with less than a full opaque covering, or the showing of the female breasts with less than a full opaque covering of any portion thereof below the upper portion of the nipple, or the depiction of covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state. 
    Public entertainment means and includes all or any of the following types and places of entertainment open to the public generally: traveling shows, carnivals, circuses, motion pictures, theatrical or variety performance, plays, concerts, exhibitions of any nature, theaters, tent shows, nightclubs or any other place where live entertainment is given. 
    Public entertainment not suitable for minors means: 
(1)  Any public entertainment which describes, depicts, represents or portrays either nudity, sexual promiscuity, sexual conduct, extramarital sexual relations, or abnormal sexual acts when such public entertainment: 
a.  Predominantly appeals to the prurient, shameful or morbid interest of minors; 
b.  Is patently offensive to the prevailing standards in the adult community as a whole with respect to what is suitable to be shown to minors; and 
c.  Is without redeeming social importance or value for minors. 
(2)  Any public entertainment which, in whole or in part, describes, depicts, represents or portrays brutality, violence, criminality or sadism, and when such public entertainment: 
a.  Is patently offensive to the prevailing standards in the adult community as a whole with respect to what is harmful to minors; and 
b.  Is without redeeming social importance or value for minors. 
(3)  Any public entertainment which, in whole or in part, uses obscene language, and when such public entertainment: 
a.  Is patently offensive to the prevailing standards in the adult community as a whole with respect to what is suitable to be shown to, or heard by, minors; and 
b.  Is without redeeming social importance or value for minors. 
(4)  Any public entertainment which in whole or in part, would lead the average viewer to no other logical conclusion that the acts enumerated in subsections (1), (2) and (3) of this definition are being performed. 
    Public entertainment not suitable for public viewing means any obscene motion picture or public entertainment that: 
(1)  Actually describes, depicts, represents or portrays abnormal sexual acts or other sexual conduct when such public entertainment: 
a.  Appeals to the prurient, shameful or morbid interests as a whole; 
b.  Is patently offensive to the prevailing community standards as a whole; and 
c.  Is utterly without redeeming social value. 
(2)  Describes, depicts, represents or portrays brutality, violence, criminality or sadism when such public entertainment: 
a.  Glorifies such actions; 
b.  Is patently offensive to the community standards as a whole; and 
c.  Is utterly without social redeeming value. 
    Sexual conduct means sexual intercourse and/or lewd lascivious physical contact with a person's clothed or unclothed genitals, pubic area, buttocks, or, if such person is a female, her breasts. 
(Code 1973, § 4-12; Code 1995, § 78-212) 
Sec. 78-192. - Interpretation of article. 
    It is hereby expressly provided that no provision of this article may be construed to be in conflict with state law and all provisions shall be interpreted to be in conformance therewith. 
(Code 1995, § 78-211) 
Secs. 78-193-78-222. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CLASSIFICATION BOARD 

Sec. 78-223. - Created; composition; officers; quorum. 
(a)  There is hereby created a classification board. 
(b)  The board shall be composed of seven members. The membership shall elect from among its members a chairman and vice-chairman. 
(c)  The city clerk and treasurer shall act as the secretary of the classification board. The clerk need not be a member of the board. 
(d)  A quorum of the board shall consist of four members. 
(e)  A majority of the entire board shall be required for any action by the board. 
(Code 1973, § 4-13; Code 1995, § 78-226) 
Sec. 78-224. - Membership; qualifications; term; vacancies; compensation. 
(a)  Members of the classification board shall be: 
(1)  Residents of the city; 
(2)  Chosen so far as reasonably practicable in such a manner as to represent a cross section of the community. 
(b)  The members' terms of office shall coincide with the term of office of the appointing board. 
(c)  If a vacancy occurs on the classification board, the city council shall appoint a new member to fill the vacancy. 
(d)  Members of the classification board shall serve without pay. 
(Code 1973, § 4-14; Code 1995, § 78-227) 
Sec. 78-225. - Powers and duties. 
    The board of classification shall, upon receipt of the application for classification, either: 
(1)  Approve the classification as requested; 
(2)  Classify it as not suitable for minors; or 
(3)  Classify it as not suitable for public viewing. 
(Code 1973, § 4-15; Code 1995, § 78-228) 
Sec. 78-226. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  The classification board shall adopt such rules and regulations as it deems necessary to govern its proceedings and deliberations. 
(b)  Such rules and regulations shall be subject to approval by the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 4-16; Code 1995, § 78-229) 
Secs. 78-227-78-245. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CLASSIFICATION PROCEDURES 

Sec. 78-246. - Application; contents; exhibitor to file. 
(a)  Before any initial exhibition of a public entertainment, the exhibitor shall file an application with the board for the classification of the public entertainment to be exhibited. The application shall be submitted 15 days in advance of this exhibition, and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The classification requested; 
(2)  The exhibitor's name and address; 
(3)  The name and address of the theater or other place in which the public entertainment is to be exhibited; 
(4)  The title of the public entertainment, if any; 
(5)  The date the public entertainment is to be first shown; 
(6)  A summary of the plot of the performance, if any; 
(7)  A list of names of the main actors appearing in the show; and 
(8)  Such other reasonable information as the classification board may require. 
(b)  Before any initial exhibition of a motion picture, the exhibitor shall be required to file an application for classification. 
(Code 1973, § 4-17; Code 1995, § 78-241) 
Sec. 78-247. - Procedure. 
(a)  The classification board shall examine the applications filed under section 78-246. If the board fails to hold a hearing and take action on an application within seven days after such application is filed or additional information requested by the board, the proposed classification shall be considered approved. 
(b)  Any action by the board, as required in this section, shall include the following: 
(1)  If the board approves the application submitted by the exhibitor, it shall be marked "approved" and filed as the board's own classification order. 
(2)  If upon examination of the application submitted by the exhibitor a majority of the board finds the information, as furnished by such exhibitor, inadequate or insufficient, and the board is not satisfied that it can make a proper determination based on such inadequate or insufficient information, the board may direct the exhibitor to furnish additional information deemed necessary by the board. After such additional information has been filed, the board may approve the application, or, if a majority of the board is not satisfied that the proposed classification is proper, it shall order the exhibitor to project or perform the film or public entertainment before any four or more members of the board. 
(3)  If upon examination of the application a majority of the board is not satisfied that the proposed classification is proper, the board shall order the exhibitor to project or perform the film or public entertainment before any four or more members of the board at a suitably equipped place and at the earliest time practicable with due regard to the availability of the necessary facilities and personnel which are to be provided by the exhibitor. Such exhibition shall be at such exhibitor's expense, and the exhibitor, or his designated representative, may at such time make such statement to the board in support of his proposed classification and present such testimony as he may desire. Within two days from the date of this hearing, the board shall make and file its classification of the film or public entertainment in question. 
(4)  If the board approves a proposed classification of a motion picture or other public entertainment without viewing it, classifying it primarily on the basis of the information furnished by the exhibitor, and a subsequent investigation or viewing of such film or public entertainment indicates that the information furnished was misleading and has led to a possible erroneous classification, the board may direct the exhibitor to project or perform the film or public entertainment before any four or more members of the board. Within two days from the date of this hearing, the board shall make and file its classification or reclassification of the film or public entertainment in question. If the film or public entertainment is reclassified, the exhibitor shall have seven days in which to alter his advertising and audience policy to comply with the classification. 
(Code 1973, § 4-18; Code 1995, § 78-242) 
Sec. 78-248. - Reclassification. 
(a)  Any exhibitor may file an application for a change in classification of any film or public entertainment previously classified. No exhibitor shall be allowed to file more than one application for change of classification of the same film or public entertainment. Such application shall contain a sworn statement of the grounds upon which the application for reclassification is based. The board shall hold a hearing and take action on such application within seven days from the date of its filing. If the board fails to do so, the proposed reclassification shall be considered approved. 
(b)  If the board is not satisfied that the film or public entertainment should be reclassified, it may direct the exhibitor to project or perform the film or public entertainment before any four or more members of the board, at a suitably equipped place and at the earliest time practicable with due regard to the availability of the film and the necessary facilities and personnel which are to be provided by the exhibitor. Such projection of the film shall be at the expense of the exhibitor. The exhibitor, including all exhibitors who may be exhibiting or preparing to exhibit the film or public entertainment or designated representatives of such exhibitor, may at such time make such statement to the board and present such testimony in support of his application for reclassification as he may desire, and the board shall within two days thereafter make and file its order approving or denying the application for reclassification. 
(Code 1973, § 4-19; Code 1995, § 78-243) 
Sec. 78-249. - Effects on subsequent exhibitors. 
    A classification shall be binding upon any subsequent exhibitor unless a change of classification is obtained. 
(Code 1973, § 4-20; Code 1995, § 78-244) 
Sec. 78-250. - Notification. 
(a)  Upon the filing by the board of any classification order or any board order or official board action, the secretary of the board shall immediately issue and mail a notice of such order or such action to the exhibitor involved, and to any other exhibitor or other interested party who shall request such notice and who has in writing designated a local agent to receive such notice. 
(b)  If the board enters a classification order as not suitable for minors or not suitable for public viewing contrary to the requested classification, the classification order filed by the board shall state the following: 
(1)  The classification of the board for such film or public entertainment; 
(2)  The portion of the classification standard that represents the basis for the film's classification; 
(3)  Any findings used by the board as a basis for its classification; and 
(4)  Any other information which the board considers helpful to the exhibitor with respect to the reasons the particular film or public entertainment was classified not suitable for minors or not suitable for public viewing. 
(Code 1973, § 4-21; Code 1995, § 78-245) 
Sec. 78-251. - Judicial review. 
(a)  Within five days after the filing of any classification order by the board, the exhibitor may file an exception to the board's classification. If the exhibitor states his intention or gives any indication of his intent to exhibit the film or public entertainment in question in violation of the board's order, the board shall immediately make application to a court of competent jurisdiction, for a temporary and/or permanent injunction to enjoin the defendant-exhibitor, being the exhibitor who contests the classification, from advertising or exhibiting the film or public entertainment in question contrary to the board's classification. 
(b)  There shall be a judicial determination as to whether the film or public entertainment in question is not suitable for minors or not suitable for public viewing. The board shall have the burden of proving the film or public entertainment is one that is not suitable for minors or not suitable for public viewing, and shall request the court to make and file findings of fact and conclusions of law regarding the trial. 
(c)  The filing of an exception by the exhibitor shall not suspend nor set aside the board's order. 
(Code 1973, § 4-22; Code 1995, § 78-246) 
Secs. 78-252-78-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - MINORS 

Sec. 78-281. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Knowingly means having general knowledge of or reason to know, or belief or grounds for belief which warrants further inspection or inquiry of: 
(1)  The character and content of any material described in this article which is reasonably susceptible of examination by the defendant; and 
(2)  The age of the minor, provided that an honest mistake shall constitute an excuse from liability under this division if the defendant made a reasonable bona fide attempt to ascertain the true age of such minor. 
    Minor means any person who has not attained the age of 18 years. 
(Code 1973, § 4-23; Code 1995, § 78-256) 
Sec. 78-282. - Prohibited acts by exhibitors. 
    No person shall knowingly: 
(1)  Exhibit any motion picture or public entertainment classified not suitable for minors if any current advertisement of such public entertainment by such exhibitor fails to state clearly the classification of such public entertainment; 
(2)  Exhibit any public entertainment classified not suitable for minors without keeping such classification posted prominently in front of the theater or other place in which such public entertainment is being exhibited; 
(3)  Sell or give to any minor a ticket to any public entertainment classified not suitable for minors, which ticket is used by such minor to gain admittance to or view such public entertainment; 
(4)  Permit any minor to view the exhibition of any public entertainment classified not suitable for minors; 
(5)  Exhibit any public entertainment classified not suitable for minors or any scenes from any film or other public entertainment, or from an unclassified film or public entertainment, whether moving or still, in the same theater or other public place and on the same program with a film or other public entertainment classified suitable for minors, provided that any advertising preview containing scenes from an unclassified public entertainment or a film or other public entertainment classified not suitable for minors may be shown at any time if the scenes have been separately classified as suitable for minors; 
(6)  Make any false or misleading statement in any application for classification, application for change of classification, or any other proceedings before the board. 
(Code 1973, § 4-24; Code 1995, § 78-257) 
Sec. 78-283. - Offenses by minors. 
    No minor shall: 
(1)  Give his age falsely as 18 years of age or over, for the purpose of gaining admittance to an exhibition of any public entertainment classified not suitable for minors. 
(2)  Enter or remain in the viewing room of any theater where a film or public entertainment classified not suitable for minors is being exhibited. 
(3)  State falsely that the adult accompanying him is his parent, legally appointed guardian or spouse for the purpose of gaining admittance to the exhibition of any public entertainment classified as not suitable for minors. 
(Code 1973, § 4-25; Code 1995, § 78-258) 
Sec. 78-284. - Injunctions against exhibitors. 
    Whenever the board has probable cause to believe that any exhibitor has committed any of the acts in section 78-282, the board shall have the duty to make application to a court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction restraining the commission of such acts. 
(Code 1973, § 4-26; Code 1995, § 78-259) 
Sec. 78-285. - Exception to division. 
    The provisions of this division shall not apply to any minor attending any film or public entertainment classified not suitable for minors when such minor is accompanied by his parent or legally appointed guardian, adult husband or wife, throughout the viewing of the film or public entertainment. 
(Code 1973, § 4-27; Code 1995, § 78-260) 
Secs. 78-286-78-303. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - ADULT STANDARDS 

Sec. 78-304. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Obscene means any: 
(1)  Brutality, violence or sadism; or 
(2)  Abnormal sexual acts as defined in section 78-191 when the: 
a.  Dominant theme appeals to prurient interest; 
b.  Is utterly without social redeeming value; and 
c.  Is patently offensive to the prevailing standards of the community as a whole. 
(Code 1973, § 4-28; Code 1995, § 78-271) 
Sec. 78-305. - Obscene motion pictures or public entertainments. 
    No person shall show for profit, charge admission to or otherwise exhibit in any place where the public is invited any obscene motion picture or other public entertainment classified not suitable for public viewing. 
(Code 1973, § 4-29; Code 1995, § 78-272) 
Sec. 78-306. - Obscene advertising. 
    No person shall advertise any motion picture, show or performance or other public entertainment by any means which show or depict any obscene picture, posture, representation, thing or any other like matter. 
(Code 1973, § 4-30; Code 1995, § 78-273) 
Secs. 78-307-78-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - DANGEROUS WEAPONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation of pistols preempted by the state, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-1.1. 

Sec. 78-331. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dangerous weapon means any Bowie knife, dirk, blackjack, razor, airgun, slingshot, brass knuckles, loaded shotgun, loaded rifle, or other firearms or weapons of a similar nature. 
(Code 1973, § 15-156; Code 1995, § 78-296) 
Sec. 78-332. - Carrying concealed weapons. 
    No person shall carry in an automobile that he is driving or over which he exercises control and possession, any dangerous weapon, either within the city limits or its police jurisdiction. 
(Code 1973, § 15-157; Code 1995, § 78-297) 
Sec. 78-333. - Report of knife or gunshot wound by physician. 
    Every physician treating any knife or gunshot wound within the city limits shall report immediately to the chief of police such fact together with the name and address of the person so treated. 
(Code 1973, § 15-160; Code 1995, § 78-298) 
Sec. 78-334. - Throwing or discharging weapons; exception. 
(a)  No person shall throw any stone or missile at, into or against any dwelling, schoolhouse, public building or other building within the city limits. 
(b)  No person shall discharge within the city limits any dangerous weapons, except in the reasonable defense of his person or property, or at a licensed rifle or pistol range or at a gun club or skeet range. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to peace officers or members of the armed forces of the state or the United States, who discharge firearms in the performance of their duties as such officers. 
(Code 1973, § 15-163; Code 1995, § 78-299) 
Secs. 78-335-78-356. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - BOW HUNTING 

Sec. 78-357. - Area designated. 
    Any individual who holds a valid state hunting license may obtain a bow hunting permit to bow hunt for game on the following real estate owned by the city situated in the county, and more particularly described as follows, to-wit: 
The south half of the southwest quarter and the southwest quarter of the southeast quarter of Section 23 and the north half of the north half of Section 26, all in Township 19 South, Range 5 West, Jefferson County, Alabama. 
(Code 1995, § 78-325; Ord. No. 2637, § I, 10-25-1994) 
Sec. 78-358. - Permit fee; validity. 
    The cost of a bow hunting permit shall be a fee as established by ordinance or resolution of the city council, from time to time and shall be valid for the hunting season in which it is issued. There shall be a hunting permit for each hunting season. 
(Code 1995, § 78-326; Ord. No. 2637, § II, 10-15-1994) 
Sec. 78-359. - Revenue director to issue permits and collect fees. 
    The revenue director of the city is hereby authorized and directed to issue said permits and collect said permit fee. 
(Code 1995, § 78-327; Ord. No. 2637, § V, 10-15-1994) 
Sec. 78-360. - Transfer. 
    No permit can be transferred and assigned. 
(Code 1995, § 78-328; Ord. No. 2637, § VI, 10-15-1994) 
Sec. 78-361. - Compliance with regulations; revocation of permit. 
    Each person granted a permit to bow hunt on the hereinabove described property shall comply with all hunting rules and regulations set forth by the game and fish commission for the state and all rules and regulations of such commission shall be strictly enforced. Violation of any such rule and/or regulation shall be grounds for revocation of the permit. 
(Code 1995, § 78-329; Ord. No. 2637, § III, 10-15-1994) 
Sec. 78-362. - Responsibility to report violations. 
    Each person holding a permit shall be responsible to report any violation of any rule and/or regulation of the game commission or of the conservation laws of the state. 
(Code 1995, § 78-330; Ord. No. 2637, § IV, 10-15-1994) 
Chapter 82 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- General authority relative to parks and recreational facilities, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-210 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 82-1-82-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RULES AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 82-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bicycle means any two- or three-wheeled vehicle whether motor-powered or self-propelled. The term "bicycle," unless otherwise specified, includes motor bike or motor scooter. It is not intended by the addition of this definition to remove "bicycle," "motor bike," or "motor scooter" from the definition of the term "vehicle." 
    Director means the director of the city parks and recreation department, the person in charge of recreation areas serving the city, or other appropriate person designated by the mayor to enforce the regulations herein contained. 
    Park means any public park, public playground, public recreational center or any other area in the jurisdiction of this article devoted to active or passive public recreation. In addition, the term "park" shall include, but not be limited to, any property belonging to the City of Bessemer not otherwise designated or dedicated as a public park but owned by the city and utilized or required to be utilized, whether on a fulltime or parttime basis, for any of the park purposes. 
    Vehicle means any wheeled conveyance, whether motor-powered, animal-drawn, or self-propelled. The term "vehicle" shall include any trailer in tow regardless of the size or description; provided, however, baby carriages or vehicles in the service of the park and recreation administrative or supervisor authority are not included within this definition. 
(Ord. No. 3296, § 1, 2-14-2006) 
Sec. 82-20. - Scope. 
    The ordinance from which this article is derived shall be effective within the public parks of the city within the corporate limits of the city, within the police jurisdiction of the city, and within those areas owned by the city. 
(Ord. No. 3296, § 2, 2-14-2006) 
Sec. 82-21. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall be enforced by any police officer of the city, by the director of the parks and recreation department, and by duly authorized park attendants; provided that none of the foregoing, except police officers, shall have the power of arrest. 
(b)  The director of parks and recreation department, police officers and park attendants shall have authority to direct any person to leave the park who is violating any applicable law, rule or regulation. Any person who fails or refuses to promptly leave the park after having been so directed shall be guilty of an offense against the city and punished in accordance section 82-29 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 3296, § 3, 2-14-2006) 
Sec. 82-22. - Parks operating policy. 
(a)  Hours. Except for unusual and unforeseen emergencies, parks shall be open to the public every day of the year during designated hours. Except as otherwise provided, all parks in the city shall be open during the period from one-half hour before sunrise and one-half hour after sunset, unless such person is at the time a participant or spectator of an activity officially scheduled by the parks and recreation department. 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided or permitted, it shall be unlawful for any person to be upon the grounds of any public park under the supervision of the director of parks and recreation during the period from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise. 
(2)  This section shall be effective as to each park in the city from and after such time as appropriate signs are erected in such park informing the public of the provisions of this section. 
(3)  The opening and closing hours for each individual park shall be posted therein for public information. It shall be unlawful for any person to use the park at a time contrary to the posted hours for use of such park. 
(b)  Closed areas. Any section or part of any park may be declared closed to the public by the director at any time and for any interval of time, either temporarily or at regular and stated intervals, as the director shall find reasonably necessary. It shall be unlawful to use any park or any area thereof which has been posted by the director as closed. 
(c)  Lost and found articles. All lost and found articles located in the park shall be turned in to the director of parks and recreation or employees of the parks and recreation department who shall report the same to the director. The director shall safeguard such articles and shall make every reasonable effort to find the owner thereof, and the park attendant shall make every reasonable effort to locate articles reported as lost and to return such articles to the owner. 
(d)  Permits. A permit shall be obtained from the director before participating in the following park activities: 
(1)  Any activity requiring or seeking exclusive use of the park or any park facility. 
(2)  Any use of the park or park facilities by a group of persons which will exceed nine in number. 
(3)  Any activity or use of the park or park facilities which amounts to a special event or special activity, not normal to every-day park use and activity. 
(e)  Application. A person seeking issuance of a permit hereunder shall file an application with the director of parks and recreation. The application shall state: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  The name and address of the persons sponsoring the activity; 
(3)  The day and hour for which the permit is desired; 
(4)  The park or portion thereof for which such permit is desired; 
(5)  An estimate of the anticipated attendance; 
(6)  Whether or not there will be a charge for admission for the event or activity, acceptance of donations or a thing of value to attend the event or activity, or solicitation of donations or a thing of value as part of or in connection with the event or activity; 
(7)  Any other information which the director shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued hereunder. 
(f)  Standards for issuance. The director shall issue a permit hereunder when such director finds: 
(1)  The proposed activity or use of the park will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the general public enjoyment of the park; 
(2)  The proposed activity and use will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the promotion of public health, welfare, safety and recreation; 
(3)  The proposed activity or use will not lead to or incite violence, crime, or disorderly conduct; 
(4)  The proposed activity will not entail unusual, extraordinary or burdensome expense to the parks and recreation department or the city; or 
(5)  The facilities desired are adequate and have not been reserved for other use at the date and hour required. 
(g)  Admission charges. A permit for any event or activity, regardless of the number of persons, in which the permittee proposes to charge an admission to the event or activity, or to accept donations or a thing of value to attend the event or activity, or to solicit donations or a thing of value as part of or in connection with the event or activity must also be approved by the city council, whose decision shall be final. 
(h)  Appeal. Within seven days after receipt of an application, the director shall either grant or refuse a permit, apprising the applicant in writing of such director's reasons for refusing a permit. In the event such permit is refused, any person aggrieved by such refusal shall have the right to appeal in writing within seven days to the city council and the decision of the city council shall be final. 
(i)  Effect of permit. A permittee shall agree to be bound by all park rules and regulations. 
(j)  Liability of permittee. The persons to whom a permit is issued shall be liable for any loss, damage or injury sustained by any person whomsoever by reason of the negligence of the persons to whom such permit shall have been issued. 
(k)  Revocation. The director shall have the authority to revoke the permit on a finding of violation of any rule or ordinance, or upon good cause being shown therefor. 
(Ord. No. 3296, § 4, 2-14-2006) 
Sec. 82-23. - Damage, etc., or injury to improvements, vegetation and wildlife. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in any park: 
(1)  Improvements. To wilfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, displace or remove, any building, bridge, table, bench, fireplace, railing, paving or paving material, water lines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof, signs, notices or placards whether temporary or permanent, monuments, stakes, posts, or other boundary markers, or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property, or appurtenances, whatsoever, either real or personal. 
(2)  Restrooms and washrooms. To litter, dirty or soil restrooms and washrooms, or to fail to cooperate in maintaining restrooms and washrooms in a neat and sanitary condition. No person over the age of five years shall use the restrooms and washrooms designated for the opposite sex. 
(3)  Removal of natural resources. To dig or remove any beach sand, whether or not submerged, or any soil, rock, stone, tree, shrub or plant, cut down timber or other wood or materials, or make any excavation by tool, equipment, blasting, or other means or agency. 
(4)  Erection of structures. To construct or erect any building or structure, of whatever kind, whether permanent or temporary in character, run or string any public utility into, upon, or across such lands, except on written permit issued by the proper authorities. 
(5)  Injury to and removal of vegetation. To damage, cut, carve, transplant, or remove, any tree or plant, or injure the bark, or pick the flowers or seeds, of any such tree or plant. To attach any rope, wire, or other contrivance to any tree or plant. To dig in, or otherwise disturb, grass areas, or in any other way to commit acts which cause injury to, or impair, the natural beauty or usefulness of any area. 
(6)  Climbing, etc., trees. To climb, stand or sit upon buildings, monuments, vases, fountains, railings, fences, or upon any other property not provided for or customarily used for such purposes. 
(7)  Injuring, etc., animals. To hunt, molest, harm, frighten, kill, trap, chase, tease, shoot or throw missiles, at any animal, reptile or bird; to remove or have in possession the young of any wild animal, or the eggs or nest or young of any reptile or bird; provided, however, snakes which are poisonous when found on park property may be killed on sight. 
(8)  Feeding of animals. To give or offer, or attempt to give or offer, to any animal or bird any tobacco, alcohol, or other poisonous or noxious substances. 
(Ord. No. 3296, § 5, 2-14-2006) 
State Law reference- Criminal damage to property, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-7-20 et seq. 
Sec. 82-24. - Sanitation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, while in the park: 
(1)  Pollution of waters. To throw, discharge, or otherwise place or cause to be placed, in the waters of any fountain, pond, lake, stream, or other body of water, in or adjacent to any park, or any tributary, stream, stormwater drain, or drain flowing into such waters, any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which will or may result in the pollution of said park waters. 
(2)  Refuse and trash. To dump, deposit, throw, or leave, any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage, debris, or refuse or other trash, into any park area. It shall be the duty of every person to place all such trash, rubbish, waste, refuse, or garbage, in the proper receptacles where they are provided; where receptacles are not so provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence, and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(Ord. No. 3296, § 6, 2-14-2006) 
State Law reference- Criminal littering, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-7-29. 
Sec. 82-25. - Traffic. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a park: 
(1)  To fail to comply with all applicable provisions of state laws and municipal ordinances in regard to equipment and operation of vehicles. 
(2)  To fail to obey the parks and recreation director, police officers and park attendants, in directing traffic or specifying parking areas, in the parks, and on the highways, streets, or roads, immediately adjacent thereto. Such traffic officers and park rangers are hereby authorized to direct and control the flow of traffic and the parking of vehicles in the parks and on the highways, streets, or roads immediately adjacent thereto, in accordance with the provisions of these regulations, to ensure safety in the use of the park area. 
(3)  To fail to observe all traffic signs in the park or adjacent thereto, indicating speed, direction, caution, stopping or parking, and all other such signs posted for proper control of vehicles and to safeguard life and property. 
(4)  To drive a vehicle at a rate of speed exceeding 15 miles per hour, except upon such roads as may be designated by posted signs for speed in excess of said rate. 
(5)  To drive any vehicle on any area except the paved park roads, or parking areas, or such other areas as may on occasion be specifically designated as temporary parking areas by the director, or designated as temporary roadways by the director. 
(6)  To park a vehicle in other than an established or designated parking area, or to fail to enter, exit, or use such parking area in accordance with posted directions, or in accordance with the instructions of any park ranger, employee, or attendant, who may be present to direct such traffic. 
(7)  To park on the travelled portion of the road or driveway within the park or adjacent thereto at any time, unless directed by a park official so to park. 
(8)  To leave any vehicle anywhere in the park with one or more wheels chained, or in any manner fixed or arranged so that such vehicle cannot readily be moved by hand. Provided this section shall not apply to the locking or securing of vehicles at places designated for the parking of such vehicles. 
(9)  To abandon any disabled vehicle in the park area or to fail to immediately notify an attendant or park ranger of an emergency in the nature of a breakdown, requiring the assistance of a tow truck, mechanic, or other persons. 
(10)  To double park any vehicle on any road or parkway unless directed by a park official. 
(11)  To operate any vehicle in the park without a muffler or baffle adequate to deaden the sound of the engine in such vehicle. 
(12)  To ride a bicycle on other than a paved or surfaced vehicular road or path, or to ride on any area not designated for bicycle use. Provided, however, a bicyclist shall be permitted to roll a bicycle (not including motor bikes or motor scooters) by hand over grassy areas or wooden trails. 
(13)  To ride a bicycle other than on the right side of the roadway or designated bike route; to ride other than single file when two or more are operating as a group. 
(14)  To operate a bicycle without reasonable regard for the safety of others; to fail to signal all turns, to fail to pass on the right of any vehicle they are overtaking; or to fail to pass to the right of any meeting or oncoming vehicle. 
(15)  For more than two persons to ride on a bicycle in a park. 
(16)  To leave a bicycle in a place other than a bicycle rack when such rack is provided and there is space available. 
(17)  To leave a bicycle lying on the ground or paving, or set against trees, or in any place or position where other persons may trip over or be injured by such bicycle. 
(Ord. No. 3296, § 7, 2-14-2006) 
Sec. 82-26. - Recreational activities. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a park: 
(1)  Bathing and swimming in designated places. To bathe, swim, or wade in any waters or waterways in or adjacent to any park, except in such waters and in such places as are provided therefor, or to swim, bathe, wade or congregate in any such areas contrary to the directions of posted signs placed by the authority of the director, or contrary to the verbal instructions of any park ranger or other attendant at the time in charge of such area. 
(2)  Indecent exposure. To appear in a public park in a bathing suit or garment which indecently exposes the person of the wearer, or which costume does not conform to customary accepted standards. 
(3)  Bath houses. To dress or undress in any public area, or in any vehicle, toilet or other place, except in such bath houses or structures as may be provided for that purpose. 
(4)  Launching or removing boats. To launch a boat or to remove a boat from the water at any place or point within the public recreation area, other than those places or points designated for the purpose of launching or removing boats from the lake area. 
(5)  Operation of boats. To enter into or depart from the waters immediately adjacent to the public recreation area at a speed greater than trolling speed, or to enter into or depart from said area by any route other than those designated for entering and leaving such area. 
(6)  Fishing. To fish in any waters immediately adjacent to the public recreation area, unless such waters have been designated by the director for fishing. 
(7)  Weapons and hunting. To use, carry or possess firearms of any description or air rifles, spring guns, bows and arrows, slings, or other forms of weapons, unless expressly permitted by the director, or to hunt, trap, or pursue wildlife at any time in the park area. It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot into the park areas from areas beyond the boundaries thereof. 
(8)  Picnics in designated areas. To picnic or lunch in a place other than those designated for that purpose. Attendants shall have the authority to regulate the activities in such area when necessary to prevent congestion and to secure the maximum use of the area for the comfort and convenience of all. Persons using the area shall comply with any directions given by the director and attendants to achieve this end. 
(9)  Availability of picnic facilities. All individual fireplaces, tables and benches, in the park area are provided under the rule of first come, first served in the use of such facilities. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate such rule. 
(10)  Nonexclusive use of picnic area. Unless a permit is obtained for the exclusive use of any of the park facilities by any group, the use of any portion of the picnic area, or the buildings or structures therein, to the exclusion of other persons, shall be unlawful and no person shall use such area and facilities for an unreasonable time if the facilities are crowded. 
(11)  Duty of picnicker to put out fire and clean up. To leave a picnic area before the fire is completely extinguished, or to leave the area without placing trash, boxes, papers, cans, bottle, garbage, and other refuse, in disposal receptacles if provided, or to fail to carry such debris away if no such receptacles are available. 
(12)  Camping. All campsite vehicles must be registered for a campsite. All camping must be done in the areas designated by the director as camping areas. 
(13)  Games. To take part in the playing of any games involving throwing or propelling balls, stones, arrows, or model airplanes, except in areas set apart for such form of recreation. The director may prescribe the location and type of games to be enjoyed in the area, and it shall be unlawful for any person to engage in such games contrary to the directions of the park attendant, park ranger, or other person in charge of such area. 
(14)  Horseback riding. To ride a horse except on a designated bridle trail or ring, or to ride a horse without proper restraint and without due care. 
(Ord. No. 3296, § 8, 2-14-2006) 
Sec. 82-27. - Illegal acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a public park to: 
(1)  Drinking, etc., alcoholic beverage. To drink alcoholic beverages in the park, or to possess alcoholic beverages in the park for the purpose of drinking the same therein. 
(2)  Intoxication. To be or remain in any area of the public park while under the influence of intoxicating beverages. 
(3)  Fireworks and explosives. To possess, to set off, or otherwise cause to explode, or discharge or burn, any firecrackers, torpedoes, rockets, or other explosives, of inflammable material, or discharge or throw them into such area from highways or adjacent areas. Firework displays or shows may be held only when authorized by a permit from the director and by a permit from the chief of the fire department. 
(4)  Dogs. To bring a dog into the park area, unless such dog is restrained at all times on an adequate leash, not greater than ten feet in length. 
(5)  Reserved facilities. To occupy any seat, bench, or to enter into or loiter or remain, in any pavilion, park structure, or area or section thereof, which may be reserved by the city and so marked. 
(6)  Dress. To appear at any place in other than proper clothing. For the purpose of this subsection, the term "proper clothing" means that clothing which is not offensive to, and which is generally acceptable to the public. 
(7)  Alms. To solicit alms or contributions for any purpose whether private, public, or charitable, without permission from the director. 
(8)  Fires. To build or attempt to build a fire, except in such area and under such regulations as may be designated by the director. 
(9)  Closed areas. To enter an area posted as closed or as closed to the public, or to use any area contrary to and in violation of posted notices. 
(10)  Games of chance. To gamble or to participate in any game of chance in the park area. 
(11)  Loitering and boisterousness. To sleep or protractedly lounge on the seats or benches, or other areas, or to engage in loud, boisterous, threatening, abusive, insulting, or indecent language, which is offensive to other persons present in the area and which tends to a breach of the public peace. 
(12)  Permits. To fail to produce and exhibit any permit from the director for inspection when requested so to do by any park official or police officer. 
(13)  Interference with permittees. To disturb or interfere unreasonably with any person or party occupying an area or participating in an activity under the authority of a valid permit. 
(Ord. No. 3296, § 9, 2-14-2006) 
Sec. 82-28. - Merchandising, advertising, and signs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the park: 
(1)  Vending and peddling. To expose or offer for sale any article or thing, or to station or place any stand, cart, or vehicle, for the transportation, sale, or display of such article or thing offered for sale; provided, this section shall not apply to a regularly licensed concessionaire, acting by and under the authority of a permit for such activity. 
(2)  Advertising. To announce, advertise, or call to the public attention in any way, any article or service for sale or hire, or to engage in political advertising by posted sign or loudspeaker, except under duly authorized permit for such activity. 
(3)  Signs. To paste, glue, tack, or otherwise post, any sign, placard, advertisement, or inscription whatever, or to erect or cause to be erected, any sign whatever, on any public lands or highways or roads adjacent to a park. 
(Ord. No. 3296, § 10, 2-14-2006) 
Sec. 82-29. - Authority to ban persons from public parks; readmittance. 
    The director or his designee is authorized to ban persons from public parks who have been arrested or cited in a public park for a criminal offense or who have been directed to leave a public park. Such bans by the director or his designee shall be for a minimum of one year. After one year, the banned person may apply in writing to the director to be readmitted to the park. The director shall respond to a request for readmittance within a reasonable time not to exceed 30 days. 
(Ord. No. 3296, § 11, 2-14-2006) 
Secs. 82-30-82-46. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CAMP BESSEMER 

Sec. 82-47. - Administration. 
    Camp Bessemer shall be structured as follows: 
(1)  Program coordinator. The program coordinator for Camp Bessemer shall oversee, manage and have general supervision and responsibility for the Camp Bessemer summer program in the city. The program coordinator shall have experience in managing, organizing, promoting and devising recreational, educational enrichment programs for ages six through 13 and overseeing a summer jobs placement program for young adults, 14 years of age and over. 
a.  The program coordinator shall make biweekly reports of any and all funds expended and disbursed by Camp Bessemer. The report shall be provided to the mayor with a copy to the council president. The reports shall state the amount and purpose of each expenditure. Each sum expended by the Camp Bessemer program shall be made pursuant to a duly made appropriation by the city council. Each person making an expenditure not so duly appropriated shall be personally liable for such expenditure. 
b.  The program coordinator shall be compensated at a rate that shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. 
c.  Failure to make the report of expenditures required by subsection (1)a of this section when due or within five working days after demand by the council shall, by a vote of the council, result in the termination of the unexpended portion of the sum appropriate in subsection (1)b of this section. 
(2)  Day camps. There shall be three day camps operated by Camp Bessemer to accommodate the recreational, and educational enrichment programs for ages six through 13 years and any young adult not employed in the jobs placement and training program. The program coordinator shall be responsible for initiating and overseeing the recreational and educational enrichment programs. 
a.  The day camps shall be made available at three sites: First Baptist Carver Life Center; A.G. Gaston Boys and Girls Club; and Kate Waller Community Center. 
b.  Each day camp site shall have one director and four aides. The directors shall be paid at a rate that shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and the aide shall be paid at the prevailing minimum hourly wage.
