(3)  Job placement and training. A number of local employers have indicated a willingness to have one or more students assigned to their companies for the purpose of actual work and training. The employers will supervise the students and the city will pay such students at the prevailing minimum hourly wage. 
a.  The program coordinator shall be responsible for coordinating with interested local employers and assigning suitable students for employment/training to such employers. 
b.  The program coordinator shall compile a list of assignment of all students referred for employment/training and file the same with the mayor and the city council through the president of the city council not later than June 16 of each year. No student may be paid by the city unless the list of assignment is filed with the mayor and the council. 
(Ord. No. 3303, § 1, 5-17-2006) 
Sec. 82-48. - End-of-program report. 
    The program coordinator shall issue an end-of-program report following the close of Camp Bessemer. The end-of-program report shall account for all sums expended by Camp Bessemer and shall include: 
(1)  Each expenditure made; 
(2)  The date of said expenditure; 
(3)  The council authorization for such expenditure; and 
(4)  The purpose of each said expenditure. 
The program coordinator will be personally liable for any unauthorized expenditure. 
(Ord. No. 3303, § 2, 5-17-2006) 
Sec. 82-49. - Employment applications. 
    Applications for employment and participation in the program shall be handled by the mayor or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 3303, § 3, 5-17-2006) 
Sec. 82-50. - Budget request. 
    The mayor of the city shall submit to the city council for adoption a detailed budget for operation of Camp Bessemer consistent with this article prior to the beginning of this program, and each year thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 3303, § 4, 5-17-2006) 
Chapter 86 - SECONDHAND GOODS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 86-1-86-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - JUNK[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Highway Beautification Act - Junkyard Control, Code of Ala. 1975, § 23-1-240 et seq. 

Sec. 86-19. - Dealers-Purchases from minors. 
    No junk dealer or other person shall purchase or procure from any minor within the city limits any brass or iron of any quality, lead or any kind of scrap or tools of any substance without first obtaining permission in writing from the parent or guardian of such minor. 
(Code 1973, § 7-65; Code 1995, § 82-26) 
Sec. 86-20. - Same-Record of purchases required; inspection. 
    Every person carrying on the junk business or dealing in junk shall provide and keep a book and enter therein each purchase or acquisition of junk of each kind or character acquired or purchased, together with the name, age, address and description of the person from whom the respective purchases were made. Such record shall show the driver's license number or the social security number of the seller. The record shall also note the time and date of the respective purchase. Such books shall be kept for six months subsequent to any purchase, open to inspection during business hours by any person who may make a request to examine the records. 
(Code 1995, § 82-27; Ord. No. 1901, § 1, 8-12-1975) 
Secs. 86-21-86-43. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PAWNBROKERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Alabama Pawnshop Act, Code of Ala. 1975, § 5-19A-1 et seq. 

Sec. 86-44. - Definitions. 
    The definitions set forth in the Alabama Pawnshop Act, Code of Ala. 1975, § 5-19A-2, shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this article. All words, terms and phrases used herein shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in the "Alabama Pawnshop Act," and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in the Alabama Pawnshop Act. 
(Code 1973, § 7-100; Code 1995, § 82-51) 
Sec. 86-45. - Entering information on pawn ticket. 
    At the time of making the pawn or purchase transaction, the pawnbroker shall enter on the pawn ticket a record of the following information which shall be typed or written in ink and in the English language: 
(1)  A clear and accurate description of the property, including the model and serial number, if indicated on the property. 
(2)  The name, residence address, and date of birth of the pledgor or seller. 
(3)  Date of the pawn or purchase transaction. 
(4)  Type of identification and the identification number accepted from pledgor or seller. 
(5)  Description of the pledgor, including approximate height, sex, and race. 
(6)  Amount of cash advanced. 
(7)  The maturity date of the pawn transaction and the amount due. 
(8)  The monthly rate and pawn charges. 
(Code 1973, § 7-101; Code 1995, § 82-52) 
Sec. 86-46. - Contents of pawn tickets. 
    The following information shall be printed on all pawn tickets: 
(1)  The statement, "Any personal property pledged to a pawnbroker within this state is subject to sale or disposal when there has been no payment made on the account for a period of 30 days past maturity date of the original contract, and no further notice is necessary." 
(2)  The statement, "The pledgor of this item attests that it is not stolen, it has no liens or encumbrances against it, and the pledgor has the right to sell or pawn the item." 
(3)  The statement, "The item pawned is redeemable only by the bearer of this ticket." 
(4)  A blank line for the pledgor's signature. 
(Code 1973, § 7-101; Code 1995, § 82-53) 
Sec. 86-47. - Statement of ownership; records of transactions; maintenance of goods on premises. 
(a)  The pledgor or seller shall sign a statement verifying that the pledgor or seller is the rightful owner of the goods or is entitled to sell or pledge the goods and shall receive an exact copy of the pawn ticket which shall be signed or initialed by the pawnbroker or any employee of the pawnbroker. 
(b)  The pawnbroker shall maintain a record of all transactions of pledged or purchased goods on the premises. A pawnbroker shall make available to the police a record of the transactions. These records shall be a correct copy of the entries made of the pawn or purchase transaction, except as to the amount of cash advanced or paid for the goods and the monthly pawnshop charge. 
(c)  All goods purchased by the pawnbroker except for automobiles, trucks, and similar vehicles shall be maintained on the premises by the pawnbroker for at least 15 business days before the goods may be offered for resale. Automobiles, trucks, and similar vehicles shall be maintained on the premises for 21 calendar days. 
(Code 1973, § 7-101; Code 1995, § 82-54) 
Sec. 86-48. - Prohibition of certain acts. 
    A pawnbroker or any clerk, agent, or employee of a pawnbroker, shall not do any of the following: 
(1)  Fail to make an entry of any material matter in the record book. 
(2)  Make any false entry therein. 
(3)  Falsify, obliterate, destroy, or remove from the place of business records, books, or accounts relating to the licensee's pawn transactions. 
(4)  Refuse to allow the police or other designated city official to inspect the pawn records or any pawn goods during the ordinary hours of business or other acceptable time to both parties. 
(5)  Fail to maintain a record of each pawn transaction for at least four years. 
(6)  Accept a pledge or purchase property from a person under the age of 19 years. 
(7)  Make any agreement requiring the personal liability of a pledgor or seller or waiving any of the provisions of this section or providing for a maturity date less than 30 days after the date of the pawn transaction. 
(8)  Fail to return or replace pledged goods to a pledgor or seller upon payment of the full amount due the pawnbroker unless the pledged goods have been taken into custody by a court or by a law enforcement officer or agency. 
(9)  Sell, lease, or agree to sell or lease pledged or purchased goods back to the pledgor or back to the seller in the same or related transaction. 
(10)  Sell or otherwise charge for insurance in connection with a pawn transaction. 
(Code 1973, §§ 7-101, 7-102, 7-104, 7-105; Code 1995, § 82-55) 
Sec. 86-49. - No confiscation of property on seven-day hold; conditions by which property may be placed on hold. 
(a)  No pledged or purchased goods may be confiscated if the property pledged to or purchased by a pawnbroker may be put on a seven-day hold by the police chief, but the pledged or purchased property may not be placed on hold unless: 
(1)  A police report is made in a timely manner. 
(2)  A warrant is sworn out for the person who pledged or sold the goods to the pawnbroker or for alias if the person is unknown. 
(3)  A warrant or writ is issued for the merchandise to be confiscated along with a request for restitution, pursuant to law. 
(b)  This section shall not affect the right of any person who has an ownership interest or prior lien in the pledged or purchased goods. 
(Code 1995, § 82-56) 
Secs. 86-50-86-71. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AUTOMOBILE SALVAGE AND WRECKING YARDS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Salvage yards generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-12-410 et seq. 

Sec. 86-72. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Salvage yard means any yard, premises, lot or tract of land in or upon which nonoperating motor vehicles are stored or upon which motor vehicles are wrecked or dismantled for the purpose of wrecking. 
(Code 1973, § 7-36; Code 1995, § 82-76) 
Sec. 86-73. - Fences required; specifications. 
(a)  Any salvage yard establishment shall be carried on, maintained or conducted in an enclosed building or upon a lot fenced on all sides. 
(b)  The side which abuts any street or avenue within the city which is open shall be chainlink or the equivalent and shall be at least six feet and no more than ten feet in height. Fences along other than streets and avenues shall be of a metal or woven metal wire of at least ten-gage line wire and 121/2 gage filler or stay. There shall be placed in the fence fronting any street or avenue slats or blinds so as to screen the premises from the view from the street or avenue. 
(c)  All fences shall be maintained in a neat, substantial, safe condition. 
(Code 1973, § 7-37; Code 1995, § 82-77) 
Sec. 86-74. - Regulation of salvage yard. 
(a)  The material located in or upon any salvage yard premises shall be so arranged so that reasonable inspection or access on all parts of the premises can be had at any time by the proper fire, health, police and building authorities. 
(b)  Water shall not be permitted to accumulate in any of the car bodies until it becomes vile, stagnant or infested with mosquitoes. 
(c)  Weeds and rank vegetation shall not be permitted on the premises. 
(d)  The entire salvage yard shall be kept free from vermin, rodents, reptiles and animals of all kind other than properly licensed pets. 
(Code 1973, § 7-38; Code 1995, § 82-78) 
Sec. 86-75. - Burning. 
    The intentional burning of any automobile bodies or parts is prohibited. 
(Code 1973, § 7-39; Code 1995, § 82-79) 
Chapter 90 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Solid Waste Disposal Act, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-27-1 et seq.; local solid waste management programs required, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-27-47. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 90-1. - Definitions. 
    The definitions set forth in Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-27-2 (Solid Wastes Disposal Act-Definitions), shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this chapter. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-27-2, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-27-2. 
(Code 1973, § 19-1; Code 1995, § 86-1) 
Sec. 90-2. - Dumping-On streets and thoroughfares. 
    No person shall dump, deposit, place, throw or leave refuse, paper, litter, rubbish, debris, filthy or odoriferous objects, substances or other trash upon a street or public thoroughfare of the city or the right-of-way therefor, or within 20 yards of a street or other public thoroughfare in the city. 
(Code 1973, § 19-8; Code 1995, § 86-2; Ord. No. 1910, § 1, 9-2-1975) 
State Law reference- Criminal littering, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-7-29. 
Sec. 90-3. - Same-Vehicle driver. 
    If an offense described above is committed from a motor vehicle, the driver of the vehicle shall be presumed to be the offender. 
(Code 1995, § 86-3; Ord. No. 1910, § 2, 9-2-1975) 
Sec. 90-4. - Provisions of sections 90-2 and 90-3 cumulative. 
    The provisions of sections 90-2 and 90-3 shall be cumulative to existing ordinances as statutes relating to the throwing, placing or otherwise depositing of debris, rubbish, trash or other items or substances of a prohibited nature upon the public highways of the state and the streets of the city and shall in no way repeal nor affect any of such laws. 
(Code 1995, § 86-4; Ord. No. 1910, § 3, 9-2-1975) 
Sec. 90-5. - Sanitary sewer maintenance fee. 
(a)  There shall be a sewer maintenance fee charged to all users of the city sanitary sewer system. 
(b)  The sanitary sewer maintenance fee shall be determined according to each 100 cubic feet of water used by the municipal sewer user. The amount of the fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(c)  The sanitary sewer maintenance fee shall be collected by the city water service and shall be billed on the water bill issued for water usage. The city water service shall collect the fee from the sanitary sewer user. 
(d)  All bills for sewer service charges shall be incorporated in the water bill, shall be rendered monthly, shall be due when rendered and shall be paid within 18 days after the original date of billing. A ten percent late charge shall be assessed on all bills paid later than 18 days after being rendered. If the amount of such sewer service charge shall not be paid within 30 days from the rendition of such bill, and if permitted by general law, the city shall discontinue furnishing water to such premises and shall disconnect the same from the water distribution system and shall proceed forthwith to recover the amount of such sewer service charge, together with all applicable penalties, in such lawful manner as it may deem advisable. 
(e)  The proceeds collected from the sanitary sewer service fee shall be deposited in a special fund designated as the city sanitary sewer maintenance fund. A copy of all deposits shall be forwarded to the city clerk of the city. 
(f)  The proceeds of the sanitary sewer maintenance fee shall be used for repairs, maintenance, rehabilitation and extension of sewer lines to the city sanitary sewer system. The funds will also be used to make payments to the state revolving fund for the proceeds used for sewer repairs and maintenance at the 12th Street sewer project. The funds shall also be used for the extension of sanitary sewer extension lines for the purpose of assisting in the extension of sanitary sewer lines within the city and for the purpose of installing sewer lines within the city as laterals to be connected with the county sewer trunk lines and the repair and maintenance of the sewer lines which include cost of engineering, evaluations, rehabilitations and other charges associated with said purposes. The proceeds of the fund can be used for the payment of indebtedness, including bonds, incurred for sanitary sewer purposes for the city. 
(g)  The city sanitary sewer maintenance fund can be drawn on by the mayor and city clerk. 
(h)  All contracts for the maintenance, repair, rehabilitation and extension of sewer lines shall be approved by the governing body of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 86-5; Ord. No. 2665, §§ 1-7, 12-19-1995) 
Secs. 90-6-90-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-29. - Franchise-Required. 
    Any person operating a garbage pickup or trash removal service and operating on the streets and alleys of the city shall obtain a franchise from the city council prior to the commencement of business. 
(Code 1973, § 7-135; Code 1995, § 86-31) 
Sec. 90-30. - Same-Information required in application. 
    In order to obtain the franchise the person applying shall furnish to the city council: 
(1)  A list of the equipment it proposes to use in such service sufficient to perform the necessary services, which shall be a containerized system. 
(2)  The franchisee shall agree to abide by all of the rules and regulations promulgated by the street department in the operation of its garbage disposal facility. 
(Code 1973, § 7-136; Code 1995, § 86-32) 
Sec. 90-31. - Same-Liability insurance required. 
    The applicant for a franchise shall obtain and furnish to the city an all perils liability insurance policy insuring itself from any claims arising from the operation of its trucks or vehicles or from the incidental operation of its business, in an amount of not less than $1,000,000.00. 
(Code 1973, § 7-137; Code 1995, § 86-33) 
Sec. 90-32. - Garbage disposal. 
(a)  Any owner or person in charge or control of any dwelling, hotel, restaurant, delicatessen or store where food for human consumption is prepared or kept for sale, or any other place where garbage originates, shall keep and maintain at or in such premises a sufficient number of garbage cans or special garbage and rubbish containers to receive the garbage originating upon such premises. 
(b)  No person shall cause or permit the disposal of garbage originating upon such premises other than by depositing the garbage in such garbage cans or special garbage and rubbish containers for removal to a city garbage and rubbish disposal area under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 19-2; Code 1995, § 86-34) 
Sec. 90-33. - Rubbish disposal; garbage prohibited. 
(a)  Any person in charge or control of a dwelling, hotel, restaurant, delicatessen, store or other place where ashes, cinders or rubbish originate or are created to keep and maintain in or upon such premises a sufficient number of rubbish cans for the reception of ashes, cinders, rubbish, and other nonburnable waste substances originating or created upon such premises. 
(b)  No person shall deposit or permit to be deposited any garbage in a rubbish can provided for ashes, cinders, gravel, rock, sand, earth, mineral, rubbish or other nonburnable substances. 
(Code 1973, § 19-5; Code 1995, § 86-35) 
Sec. 90-34. - Disposal of decomposable or decaying material. 
(a)  No person shall keep, maintain, store or deposit on or about any place or premises within the city limits any decomposable, decaying or putrefactive material, either animal or vegetable in nature or origin, except in a substantial, watertight and flyproof container, either made for or appropriate to be used for such purposes, and to prevent access of flies to the material or the reproduction or propagation of flies on or about the material. 
(b)  No person shall cause or permit the soiling of the ground by such material on or about such place or premises so as to cause, permit or favor the propagation or reproduction of flies. 
(c)  The presence or existence in such container or on or about such place or premises of live fly larvae shall be prima facie evidence of the propagation or reproduction of flies and of a violation of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 19-9; Code 1995, § 86-36) 
Sec. 90-35. - Disposal in authorized areas. 
    No person shall dispose of garbage or refuse anywhere other than in authorized disposal areas. 
(Code 1973, § 19-12; Code 1995, § 86-37) 
Sec. 90-36. - Accumulation of rubbish. 
    No occupants of any building or premises shall store, accumulate or allow to accumulate any empty boxes, barrels or other rubbish of like nature upon their premises. 
(Code 1973, § 19-14; Code 1995, § 86-38) 
Sec. 90-37. - Collection of boxes or crates; method. 
    No person operating any place of business in the city or any employee, servant or agent of any such person, shall place or deposit in any street, sidewalk or alley any pasteboard or wooden boxes, crates or cartons for the purpose of being collected by the trash collection employees or for any other purpose, unless they are first broken down and securely fastened into bales or bundles not exceeding 100 pounds in weight or four feet in any dimension. 
(Code 1973, § 19-15; Code 1995, § 86-39) 
Secs. 90-38-90-62. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONTAINERS 

Sec. 90-63. - Lids secured. 
    The lids or covers of garbage cans or special garbage and rubbish containers shall be kept tightly fitted thereon at all times other than when garbage or rubbish is being deposited in such container. All garbage cans or special garbage and rubbish containers shall be so kept and maintained as to prevent the access of flies therein and the soiling of the ground, floor or structure upon which they stand. 
(Code 1973, § 19-3; Code 1995, § 86-51) 
Sec. 90-64. - Rubbish prohibited. 
    No person shall deposit or permit to be deposited in any garbage can provided and intended for garbage any ashes, cinders, gravel, rock, sand, earth, mineral, rubbish or other nonburnable substance of any description. 
(Code 1973, § 19-4; Code 1995, § 86-52) 
Sec. 90-65. - Restricted on streets to certain hours. 
(a)  No person in charge or control of any dwelling, hotel, restaurant, delicatessen or store where garbage, rubbish or any other materials are placed in a garbage can, rubbish can or special garbage or rubbish container shall permit any such cans or containers to be placed out for collection on the streets or sidewalks before 5:00 p.m. on the day before regular city garbage or trash collection service is to be rendered. 
(b)  Cans or containers shall be removed from the sidewalks, between the hours from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. 
(Code 1973, § 19-6; Code 1995, § 86-53) 
Sec. 90-66. - Dumping of containers. 
    No person shall dump any garbage cans, rubbish cans, special garbage and rubbish containers or other boxes or receptacles upon any public streets or sidewalks within the city limits. 
(Code 1973, § 19-7; Code 1995, § 86-54) 
Sec. 90-67. - Opening or disturbing; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall open any garbage can, rubbish can or other container provided for in this article in which garbage or trash has been deposited for collection, or search in any such can or container for garbage or trash, or remove from any such cans any garbage, trash, or other thing. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to the owner of such can or container or to any person employed by the city for the purpose of collecting garbage or trash. 
(Code 1973, § 19-10; Code 1995, § 86-55) 
Sec. 90-68. - City trash receptacles; use limited. 
    No person operating any place of business in the city or any employee, servant or agent of any such person shall place or deposit garbage, trash, paper, rubbish or other waste material in any trash basket or waste receptacle maintained by the city upon a public street or sidewalk, when such garbage, trash, paper, rubbish or waste material accumulated in or came from such place of business. 
(Code 1973, § 19-13; Code 1995, § 86-56) 
Sec. 90-69. - Number. 
(a)  No person shall keep or maintain upon any premises or in any public way where permitted adjacent thereto, in excess of four garbage or rubbish cans for each dwelling unit upon the premises at any one time, containing garbage, rubbish or trash to be collected or picked up by the city. 
(b)  Where any premises as described in subsection (a) of this section contain in excess of two dwelling units, there shall at no time be kept or maintained in excess of ten garbage and rubbish cans on or upon such premises or in any public way, where permitted, adjacent thereto. 
(c)  There shall not be maintained upon any premises devoted to business, commercial or industrial use or in any public way, where permitted, adjacent thereto in excess of four garbage or rubbish cans at any one time, containing garbage, rubbish or trash to be collected or picked up by the city. 
(Code 1973, § 19-16; Code 1995, § 86-57) 
Sec. 90-70. - Special containers required for over ten dwelling units. 
(a)  Where any owner, lessee or agent acting for such owner or lessee or for any other person, or any person acting for himself or another rents to others, leases or subleases to others, manages or otherwise provides for occupancy, dwelling units in any structure containing in excess of ten dwelling units or on any premises upon which is situated in excess of ten dwelling units, the owner, lessee or agent for the other person shall provide for such structure or premises a special garbage and rubbish container, and provide for servicing thereof, unless all garbage and rubbish regularly originating from such premises and to be picked up by the city may be placed in ten garbage and rubbish cans or less. 
(b)  No owner, lessee, agent or other person shall fail to provide the special garbage and rubbish container and service as required in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 19-17; Code 1995, § 86-58) 
Sec. 90-71. - Special containers required for over four cans in a business, commercial or industrial establishment. 
(a)  Any person conducting or operating a business, commercial or industrial establishment or operation upon any premises in the city and requiring in excess of four garbage or rubbish cans, as permitted under section 90-69 shall provide for such premises a special garbage and rubbish container and provide for serving thereof. 
(b)  No person shall fail to provide such special garbage and rubbish container and service as required in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 19-18; Code 1995, § 86-59) 
Sec. 90-72. - Accumulation in special containers. 
    No owner, lessee or agent as described in sections 90-70 and 90-71 shall allow or permit any garbage or rubbish to accumulate in any special garbage and rubbish container serving dwelling units owned, managed or controlled by such owner, lessee or agent unless he has provided for the collection of garbage from such container. 
(Code 1973, § 19-19; Code 1995, § 86-60) 
Sec. 90-73. - Maintenance of special container area; notice. 
(a)  Any owner, lessee, or agent acting for such owner or lessee or for any other person, or any person acting for himself or others who rents to others, leases or subleases to others, manages or otherwise provides for occupancy dwelling units in any structure containing in excess of four dwelling units shall keep or cause to be kept free of garbage and rubbish the area immediately surrounding the garbage cans, rubbish cans or special garbage and rubbish containers serving such dwelling units. 
(b)  If the area at any time becomes so littered, unclean or unsanitary and such person is advised in writing by or on behalf of the superintendent of streets and sanitation or any other person who is the administrative head of the division of the county health officer, such person shall within 24 hours place or cause to be placed such area in a clean, sanitary and unlittered condition. No such person shall fail to clean or cause to be cleaned any such area in the time set out in this section. 
(Code 1973, § 19-20; Code 1995, § 86-61) 
Secs. 90-74-90-104. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LANDFILL 

Sec. 90-105. - Use of site. 
    No person who resides outside of the city or does not have a license to do business in the city shall be permitted to use the landfill site for the dumping of trash. Only residents of the city or businesses licensed by the city may use the landfill site under the conditions set forth in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 19-34; Code 1995, § 86-81) 
Sec. 90-106. - Dumping hours. 
    Any resident of the city may dump their personal trash or debris at the city landfill site between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m., Monday through Friday and at no other times and only at such places as are designated by the employee in charge of the site. 
(Code 1973, § 19-35; Code 1995, § 86-82) 
Sec. 90-107. - Fee. 
(a)  The fee for delivering inert material to the Bessemer Landfill shall be determined on a per cubic yard basis. The amount of the fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(b)  There shall be a minimum charge for all inert material delivered to the Bessemer Landfill. The amount of the minimum charge shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 86-83; Ord. No. 2670, §§ I, II, 3-26-1996; Ord. No. 2671, §§ I-III, 4-2-1996; Ord. No. 3130, § 1, 11-21-2000) 
Chapter 94 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- The Municipal Public Improvement Act, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-48-1 et seq.; municipal streets, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-49-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 94-1. - Billposting. 
    No person shall post, tack or attach any handbills or signs of wood, paper, cloth, etc., on telephone poles, power poles or any building or anywhere other than signboards, within the city limits or the police jurisdiction thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 15-48; Code 1995, § 90-1) 
Sec. 94-2. - Defects in streets and sidewalks-Repair required. 
    No person shall allow a defect, crack, obstruction or other hazard to the travelling public to remain in or on the street or sidewalk in front of, along or abutting on premises occupied by such person after the expiration of ten days from service of a notice of such defect, crack, obstruction or other hazard by the street superintendent. 
(Code 1973, § 21-83; Code 1995, § 90-2) 
Sec. 94-3. - Same-Liability of property owner; notice. 
    No owner of any property shall allow a defect, crack or obstruction or other hazard to the travelling public to remain in or on the street or sidewalk in front of, along or abutting the property owned by such person after the expiration of ten days from the receipt by such person of a notice from the street superintendent. 
(Code 1973, § 21-84; Code 1995, § 90-3) 
Sec. 94-4. - Same-Notice to owner of costs. 
    The city clerk and treasurer shall, upon receipt of the information required to be transmitted by the street superintendent, advise the property owner by registered mail of the amount due for repairing the defect. The owner shall be advised to pay the cost within 30 days at the office of the city clerk and treasurer, or the matter will be placed in the hands of the city attorney for legal action. 
(Code 1973, § 21-81; Code 1995, § 90-4) 
Sec. 94-5. - Mixing cements on pavement. 
    No person shall mix or place on the bare surface of the pavement of any street, sidewalk or other public property, any hydraulic cement, Portland cement, bituminous cement or other substance which may permanently deface, stain or damage the pavement. 
(Code 1973, § 15-67; Code 1995, § 90-5) 
Sec. 94-6. - Throwing substances on streets. 
(a)  Dirt and mud. No owner, driver, manager or operator of any cart, wagon, car, truck or other vehicle which tracks dirt, mud or other similar substance from private property upon or onto any paved street in the city shall fail to remove all such dirt, mud or other substance from such paved street within six hours after the substance has been tracked thereon. 
(b)  Removal of dirt and mud. No person engaged in grading or making an excavation or fill on any private or public property in the city shall fail to remove from the paved street near or adjacent to such work all dirt, mud or other substances which is tracked from the work area on such private or public property upon or onto such paved street by any cart, wagon, car, truck or other vehicle, within six hours after the substance has been tracked thereon. 
(c)  Oil. No person shall knowingly deposit oil upon any of the paved streets within the city limits. 
(d)  Obstructions. No person shall obstruct any public street or any portion thereof except by parking vehicles thereon as provided by law. 
(e)  Glass; tacks; similar items. No person shall knowingly place, throw or deposit any glass, tacks or like substance upon any of the public streets or sidewalks within the city limits. 
(f)  Peelings; other refuse. No person shall throw, drop or leave any peelings, parings, rinds, sweepings, trash, garbage or other refuse matter upon the streets or sidewalks within the city limits. 
(Code 1973, §§ 15-66, 21-32-21-34; Code 1995, § 90-6) 
State Law reference- Putting glass or other injurious substance on highway, road, street or public right-of-way prohibited, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-60. 
Sec. 94-7. - Throwing substances from buildings. 
    No person shall throw anything upon any public street or sidewalk from the upper stories of any building. 
(Code 1973, § 21-35; Code 1995, § 90-7) 
Sec. 94-8. - Removing or defacing street markings or street name signs. 
    No person shall remove any post, stake or other mark indicating the lines of grade of any street or pull down, remove or deface any board, sign or place indicating the name of any street. 
(Code 1973, § 21-37; Code 1995, § 90-8) 
Sec. 94-9. - Writing on pavement or curbstone. 
    No person shall write, paint or print any letters, figures, signs, devices, pictures or marks on any of the pavements, sidewalks or curbstones within the city limits. 
(Code 1973, § 21-38; Code 1995, § 90-9) 
Sec. 94-10. - Flying kites on streets. 
    No person shall fly a kite in the streets within the city limits. 
(Code 1973, § 21-39; Code 1995, § 90-10) 
Sec. 94-11. - White canes or walking sticks; use by blind only; full stop required. 
(a)  For the purpose of guarding against accidents in traffic on the public streets, no person, except persons wholly or partially blind, shall carry or use on the public streets within the city limits any canes or walking sticks which are white in color or white with a red end or bottom. Such canes or walking sticks may be used on the streets and other public places of the city by persons wholly or partially blind, as a means of protecting them and for the purpose of identifying them by drivers of vehicles and other pedestrians with whom they come in contact on such streets and public places. 
(b)  Any driver of a vehicle or pedestrian who is not wholly or partially blind who approaches or comes in contact with a person wholly or partially blind, carrying a cane or walking stick white in color, or white with a red end, shall immediately come to a full stop and take any precautions before proceeding as may be necessary to avoid accident or injury to the person carrying a white cane or walking stick. 
(Code 1973, § 21-46; Code 1995, § 90-11) 
Sec. 94-12. - Pedestrians to keep right on sidewalks. 
    Pedestrians shall keep to the right on all public sidewalks and shall not obstruct the sidewalks by stopping except at or near either edge of the walk, and not in the middle of the sidewalk. 
(Code 1973, § 21-63; Code 1995, § 90-12) 
Sec. 94-13. - Encumbering gutter, drain or sewer. 
    No person shall encumber or throw any filth or rubbish into any gutter, drain or sewer, along the public streets or sidewalks within the city limits. 
(Code 1973, § 21-47; Code 1995, § 90-13) 
Sec. 94-14. - Parking of vehicles for sale; penalty for violation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for anyone engaged in the sale of automobiles, both new and used, to park the vehicles on the sidewalks and city rights-of-way within the city limits. 
(b)  Violation of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor and subject the party so convicted of the offense to punishment according to the general penalties described by section 1-8. 
(Code 1995, § 90-14; Ord. No. 2411, §§ 1, 2, 10-13-1987) 
Sec. 94-15. - [Honorary street sign program.] 
(a)  [Creation.] There is hereby created the "Honorary Street Sign Program in the City of Bessemer, Alabama," under the terms and conditions set forth herein below. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following terms shall have the meanings: 
(1)  Significant person shall mean a person, whether now living or deceased, who has made a substantial and well documented positive contribution affecting the lives of people residing in the City of Bessemer. 
(2)  Significant place or community marker shall mean a place, an edifice, historic event or thing of similar import which has made a substantial and well documented positive contribution affecting the lives of people residing in the City of Bessemer. 
(3)  Well documented shall mean that the contributions made the basis of the request for an honorary street sign which have been reduced to writing and/or evidenced by acceptable written documentation and other wise capable of being verified from reliable sources and accounts. 
(c)  Application process. A person desiring to have a street named in honor of a person, place or community marker shall file an application with the city clerk of the City of Bessemer in a form prescribed by the mayor. Such application shall contain, but may not be limited to: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone numbers of the applicant(s); 
(2)  The name of the person, place or community marker to be recognized on an honorary sign; 
(3)  A detailed written history or biographical of the significant person, significant place or community marker; 
(4)  A detailed writing of the contributions clearly demonstrating and well documenting the service to or place in the community deserving of honorary recognition; and 
(5)  A copy of each document relied upon by the applicant(s) which shows the contribution or points of historical significance to the community deserving of honorary status. 
(d)  Application fee. In order to defray the cost of processing the application, including staff time required to research and verify the matters contained in the application; and producing and installing honorary signs, there is hereby assessed a nonrefundable fee in the amount of $150.00. 
(e)  Approval of honorary sign. The city council, with recommendations from the mayor and sign committee, in its sole discretion, shall determine whether the request for an honorary sign is meritorious and deserving. 
(f)  Description of honorary sign. The honorary sign shall have a white reflective background, trimmed in blue with blue lettering and shall measure 30 inches in width and 18 inches in height. Each honorary sign shall have the words "Honorary Sign" across the top of the sign in a similar style. The signage shall use a minimum of .030 aluminum backing and be mounted using galvanized poles. This panel style should correspond with the regulations for memorial signage as provided in MUTCD (Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices). The mayor shall approve the final description and may amend the style as needed to accommodate the honorary name provided. 
(g)  Location of honorary sign. The location of the honorary signs shall be determined by the mayor. 
(h)  Removal of sign. The City Council of the City of Bessemer may, at any time and within its sole discretion, remove any honorary sign when it deems to be in its best interest so to do. 
(Ord. No. 3514, 1-21-2014) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3514, adopted Jan. 21, 2014, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence codification as § 94-15 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 94-16-94-31. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SUPERINTENDENT OF DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS 

Sec. 94-32. - Responsibilities. 
    There is created the position of superintendent of department of public works, who, under the direction of the mayor, shall be responsible for;aoh1; Chapter 94\STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES 
(Code 1973, § 21-1; Code 1995, § 90-36) 
Sec. 94-33. - Qualifications. 
    The superintendent of department of public works at the time of his appointment shall have not less than five years' experience in street and road construction and maintenance or other heavy construction work. 
(Code 1973, § 21-2; Code 1995, § 90-37) 
Sec. 94-34. - Duties. 
    The superintendent of department of public works shall manage all operations concerning the streets and ways of the city. Under the direction of the mayor, he shall: 
(1)  Prepare a public improvement plan each year for the improvement of the streets, alleys, sidewalks, storm and sanitary sewers and other construction and obtain the engineering specifications, profiles, grades and estimates of cost for the proper drafting of ordinances for public improvements, so arranged as to provide maximum work at minimum cost. 
(2)  Prepare an equipment plan showing the use made of equipment and providing for replacement and purchase of new equipment in order to provide that work is accomplished at the lowest practicable cost. 
(3)  Supervise all construction of public improvements authorized by the city council. 
(4)  Plan for the cleanliness and repair of all streets, alleys and sidewalks and to schedule equipment and personnel for efficient operations. 
(5)  Supervise all routine operations in the street department and provide means of meeting any emergencies that may occur within the city affecting the safe use of the streets and sidewalks. 
(6)  Supervise the operation of all storm and sanitary sewers and to provide for enforcement of all laws pertaining to such sewers. 
(7)  In consultation with the chief of the police department, obtain maximum safety of the streets, ways and sidewalks in the construction, maintenance, inspection and removal of obstacles and defects. 
(8)  In cooperation with the parks and recreation director, develop beautification of the streets and ways of the city. 
(9)  Recommend to the commissioner for public improvements all matters relating to the employment, transfer, promotion and discharge of personnel within the street department. 
(Code 1973, § 21-3; Code 1995, § 90-38) 
Secs. 94-35-94-56. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 94-57. - Permit required; application. 
(a)  No person shall excavate, cut into, take up or undermine any street without first having obtained a written permit from the engineering department. A separate permit shall be obtained for any excavation work done on each block of street. 
(b)  The engineering department shall issue permits to any person who files an application and complies with the provisions of section 94-58. 
(Code 1973, § 21-9; Code 1995, § 90-61) 
Sec. 94-58. - Cutting or disturbing pavement; approval and bond required; backfill. 
    It shall hereafter be unlawful for any person to cut, dig, destroy or otherwise disturb the pavement of any public street or alley within the city without complying with the following: 
(1)  Any person wishing to cut, damage, or disturb any public street or alley within the city shall, prior to beginning the work, do the following: 
a.  Receive written approval from the engineering department; 
b.  Post a bond in the amount of $5,000.00 insuring compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(2)  When the work on the streets or alleys of the city is complete, the person doing the work shall backfill in such manner as to comply with the requirements of the public works department. 
(Code 1995, § 90-62; Ord. No. 2203, § 1, 3-29-1983) 
Sec. 94-59. - Replacement material specified. 
    All excavations shall be replaced with chert, slag or such material as may be approved by the public improvement department. All paving shall be replaced with a 1: 2: 3 mixture concrete of Portland cement, penetration pavement or tar cap of such material as may be required by the street superintendent. 
(Code 1973, § 21-13; Code 1995, § 90-63) 
Sec. 94-60. - Rates for replacement of excavation or pavement materials by city. 
(a)  Any person failing or refusing to replace an excavation or paving within five days after notice from the street superintendent shall be charged a rate per square yard by the city for making such replacements. The amount of the rate shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a rate schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(b)  All other work shall be done at the cost of labor and material, plus ten percent for supervision. 
(Code 1973, § 21-14; Code 1995, § 90-64) 
Sec. 94-61. - Guarding excavations; barricades and lights. 
(a)  No person shall permit any excavation in any street or sidewalk to remain open, uncovered or unguarded to the danger of others. 
(b)  The excavation shall be guarded by barricades and warning lights. The warning lights shall be maintained from one-half hour after sunset until one-half hour before sunrise. 
(Code 1973, § 21-15; Code 1995, § 90-65) 
Sec. 94-62. - Repair of defective work; notice. 
    Any person engaged in doing the work described in section 94-57 whose work does not conform to the rules and regulations set out in section 94-59 or whose work is constructed with inferior materials and workmanship shall, on notice from the street superintendent, make changes at once in order to remedy same. If the work has not been changed after five days' notice from the street superintendent, the work shall be replaced by the street superintendent and his assistants and charged to the person as provided in section 94-60. 
(Code 1973, § 21-10; Code 1995, § 90-66) 
Secs. 94-63-94-82. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SEWER, MAIN OR CONDUIT CONSTRUCTION OR REPAIR 

Sec. 94-83. - Permit required; exception. 
    No person, other than an authorized officer, employee or agent of the city, or in case of an emergency as prescribed in section 94-84, shall make any opening, cut or excavation in or under the surface of any street, alley, sidewalk or public way of the city without having first obtained a permit as provided in this division. 
(Code 1973, § 21-48; Code 1995, § 90-76) 
Sec. 94-84. - Emergency excavation; permit exception. 
(a)  If any sewer, main, conduit or other utility installation in or under any street, alley, sidewalk or public way shall burst, break or otherwise be in such condition as seriously to endanger persons or property, the owner of such sewer, main, conduit or other installation shall immediately repair such trouble and immediately take all necessary steps to make the location safe and secure. The owner shall not, however, begin making any permanent repairs to such street, alley or sidewalk until he has secured a permit as provided in this division. 
(b)  The permit shall be secured within 18 hours or the next business day after such break or serious trouble shall have developed and the necessary repairs to the street, alley or sidewalk shall be made as directed by the city engineer and shall be completed as soon as practicable after receipt of the permit. 
(Code 1973, § 21-49; Code 1995, § 90-77) 
Sec. 94-85. - Deposit required; permit fee; restoration costs. 
(a)  Subject to the provisions of section 94-86, any person desiring to make any opening, cut or excavation in or under the surface of any paved, curbed or otherwise improved street, alley or sidewalk, for any rightful and necessary purpose, shall first pay to the city clerk and treasurer such sum as may be reasonably necessary, as determined by the city engineer or by his authorized deputy, to defray the cost to the city of properly restoring the street, alley or sidewalk to as good condition as it was before making such opening, cut or excavation and of maintaining the same in such condition, normal wear and tear excepted, for a period of five years. 
(b)  The city engineer shall thereupon issue to such person a permit authorizing such work. A fee shall be paid for the permit. The amount of the fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(c)  No such restoration cost shall be required before making any opening, cut or excavation in any unpaved, uncurbed or unimproved street or alley, but a permit as provided in this division shall first be obtained. 
(Code 1973, § 21-50; Code 1995, § 90-78) 
Sec. 94-86. - Paving of streets required by ordinance; notices. 
(a)  Whenever the city council shall pass any ordinance providing for the paving or repaving of any alley or any portion of the vehicular way of any street, a written notice shall be mailed to each public utility maintaining any sewers, mains, conduits or other utility installations in or under the alley or roadway, and to each abutting property owner to whom a copy of the improvement ordinance is mailed as required by law, notifying all the persons that: 
(1)  No permit will be issued for openings, cuts or excavations in the paving to be constructed under the ordinance for a period of one year without the approval of the street superintendent after the date of completion of such paving. 
(2)  Each such public utility is required by law to install all underground sewers, mains, conduits or other utility installations and to make all necessary repairs thereto within 30 days from the date the public improvement ordinance has been confirmed. 
(3)  Each such abutting property owner, within 30 days from the date the public improvement ordinance has been confirmed, is required either to install all necessary service lines connecting with any mains, sewers, conduits, or other utility installations or to stub out or extend the connections to the property lines, failing which the right to make any such installations shall be forfeited for a period of one year after the date of completion of such new paving. 
(b)  Copies of the notices shall be mailed to the occupants of all houses and buildings located on premises abutting streets and alleys which are proposed to be improved by the ordinance. Copies of the notices shall be transmitted to the manager of the city water service. 
(Code 1973, § 21-51; Code 1995, § 90-79) 
Sec. 94-87. - Excavation permit restricted. 
    During the period of one year after the date of completion of any new paving or other permanent improvement to the surface of any street or alley constructed or reconstructed pursuant to any improvement ordinance, or city, state or county decision, no permit shall be issued to open, cut or excavate in or under the surface of such street or alley, except where in the opinion of the city engineer or of his duly authorized deputy, an emergency such as that described in section 94-84 may exist of such nature as to make the issuance of such permit absolutely necessary. 
(Code 1973, § 21-55; Code 1995, § 90-80) 
Sec. 94-88. - Applicability of technical codes. 
    Any and all provisions of the electrical code, gas code and plumbing code of the city relating to excavations in streets and alleys shall be subject to the restrictive provisions of section 94-87 in every case where new paving is involved, and shall also be subject to the provisions of section 94-85, relating to the payment of the costs of fully restoring and maintaining streets, alleys and sidewalks. 
(Code 1973, § 21-56; Code 1995, § 90-81) 
Secs. 94-89-94-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 94-120. - Construction; supervision. 
    All sidewalks constructed within the city limits shall be constructed under the direction and supervision of the street superintendent, and in accordance with the specifications and grades of the city for sidewalks as on file in the office of the engineering department. 
(Code 1973, § 21-57; Code 1995, § 90-101) 
Sec. 94-121. - Construction permit-Exception. 
(a)  Before any sidewalk is constructed upon any street within the city limits, the owner or agent of the property in front of which the sidewalk is to be constructed shall secure from the engineering department a permit to construct the sidewalk. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this section shall be held to apply to work done under contract with the city. 
(Code 1973, § 21-58; Code 1995, § 90-102) 
Sec. 94-122. - Same-Application; contents. 
    The application for the sidewalk construction permit required by section 92-121 shall state: 
(1)  The street upon which the construction is planned; 
(2)  Describe the property in front of or along which the construction is planned; 
(3)  The party by whom the construction will be performed; 
(4)  The material of which the sidewalk is to be constructed; and 
(5)  The width and length of the sidewalk. 
(Code 1973, § 21-59; Code 1995, § 90-103) 
Sec. 94-123. - Same-Refusal to issue permit; appeal. 
    If, in the opinion of the engineer the material to be used or the manner of constructing a sidewalk is unsatisfactory, or for any other good cause, he may refuse to issue the permit. The applicant shall have the right to appeal to the city council at its next regular meeting. 
(Code 1973, § 21-61; Code 1995, § 90-104) 
Sec. 94-124. - Staking out and supervision of construction; fee; refund. 
(a)  There shall be a fee charged per square yard by the city for staking out and supervising the construction of sidewalks. The engineer shall not issue a permit for the construction unless the application is accompanied by a receipt from the city clerk and treasurer showing that the fee has been paid. The amount of the fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(b)  If the permit is refused, the engineer shall write across the back of such receipt "permit refused" and, upon its presentation to the city clerk and treasurer, the amount so paid in shall be refunded to the applicant. 
(Code 1973, § 21-60; Code 1995, § 90-105) 
Secs. 94-125-94-146. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 94-147. - Construction permit-Required. 
    No person shall construct a driveway across a sidewalk in the city without first obtaining a permit. 
(Code 1973, § 21-4; Code 1995, § 90-126) 
Sec. 94-148. - Same-Application; fee. 
(a)  Any person desiring to construct a driveway across a sidewalk in the city shall submit an application to the engineering department giving: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner and occupant of the premises abutting the place where the driveway is to be constructed; 
(2)  A description of the property by lot and block number; 
(3)  Street address; and 
(4)  A description of the width, slope and specifications for the driveway. 
(b)  The application shall be signed by both the owner and occupant of the abutting premises, and shall be accompanied by an inspection and permit fee. The amount of the inspection and permit fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 21-5; Code 1995, § 90-127) 
Sec. 94-149. - Same-Inspection of proposed driveway; issuance. 
(a)  The engineering department shall inspect the place where the proposed driveway is to be constructed and the specifications for the construction. If the engineering department is satisfied that the proposed driveway can be constructed according to the specifications submitted in a way as to be safe to the travelling public along the public sidewalks, he shall issue a permit for the construction of such driveway. 
(b)  If an inspection indicates to the engineering department that the width, specifications or slope of the driveway would constitute an unsafe condition, such department shall require of the applicant such change in width, slope and specifications of the driveway as will not constitute a dangerous condition to the travelling public along the sidewalk before the engineering department issues such permit. 
(Code 1973, § 21-6; Code 1995, § 90-128) 
Sec. 94-150. - Inspection after construction; notice. 
(a)  The engineering department shall inspect all driveways for which a permit has been issued to determine that the driveway has been constructed in accordance with the width, slope and specification of the application. 
(b)  If, upon inspection, the person constructing the driveway has neglected and failed to build a driveway in accordance with the width, slope and specifications of the application, the engineering department shall notify him in writing of the variance between the application and the actual construction. The applicant shall, within ten days after receipt of such notice, correct the construction to be in accordance with the application. 
(Code 1973, § 21-7; Code 1995, § 90-129) 
Sec. 94-151. - Violation of article. 
    Any person who shall construct a driveway across a sidewalk in the city at a different width, slope or specification from that contained in the application required by section 94-148, and after a ten days' notice to correct the defects fails or neglects to correct the construction to be in accordance with the application, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 21-8; Code 1995, § 90-130) 
Secs. 94-152-94-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OBSTRUCTIONS 

Sec. 94-171. - Permit required. 
    No person shall obstruct any street or sidewalk or other public way so as to prevent the free passage of persons on such streets, sidewalks or other public ways without first obtaining a permit from the chief of police. 
(Code 1973, § 21-62; Code 1995, § 90-151) 
Sec. 94-172. - Showcases on sidewalks. 
    No person shall erect or construct upon any sidewalk or any part thereof any showcase or device for advertising purposes, or place any obstruction of any kind or nature on any sidewalk. 
(Code 1973, § 21-69; Code 1995, § 90-152) 
Sec. 94-173. - Meter boxes and appliances; exact grade required; no projections. 
    All gas meters and water meter boxes, cutoffs, pipes and other appliances in the sidewalks or streets of the city shall be placed on an exact grade so as not to project above or be an obstruction in the sidewalk or street. They shall be placed within 12 inches of the curb or curbline. Any appliances not complying with this section may be condemned, as other nuisances are condemned and removed. 
(Code 1973, § 21-74; Code 1995, § 90-153) 
Sec. 94-174. - Placement of pipes and tanks; depth below grade. 
    All service lines for water and gas shall be laid or placed at least 18 inches below grade and all gasoline or oil service tanks shall be placed at least 21/2 feet below the surface of the street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1973, § 21-28; Code 1995, § 90-154) 
Sec. 94-175. - Cellars and vaults; entrances. 
(a)  No person shall leave open, or cause to be left open, the opening to any cellar or vault underneath the sidewalk when the opening is not in actual use, or at night. 
(b)  No person shall allow the entrance to any cellar or vault under any sidewalk under his control to remain in such condition as to render it unsafe or dangerous to persons using the sidewalk. 
(Code 1973, § 21-30; Code 1995, § 90-155) 
Secs. 94-176-94-203. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - HOUSE NUMBERS 

Sec. 94-204. - Display of number; costs. 
(a)  The city council shall have power at any time, by resolution, to require the owners of all buildings to have a number of plain, black figures on a light background put on each house within the city limits in such a conspicuous place as to be legible from the street. The letters shall be not less than two inches in size, and placed on the house by some person designated by the city council to do the work. 
(b)  The owner shall pay such person for each house on which figures are placed. The owners shall be allowed to place on their houses gilt or ornamental figures if they see fit. The amount of the fee paid to the person affixing the house numbers shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 21-17; Code 1995, § 90-176) 
Sec. 94-205. - Displaying unassigned number. 
    No person shall use or display any street number to designate the location of any property owned or controlled by such person, unless such number has been assigned to such property in accordance with the house number plan established by the city. 
(Code 1973, § 21-18; Code 1995, § 90-177) 
Sec. 94-206. - Numbering new buildings; time limit. 
    Every owner or occupant of any building hereafter erected in this city shall within 30 days after the erection of the building, place a number upon the building according to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 21-19; Code 1995, § 90-178) 
Sec. 94-207. - Destruction or change of numbers. 
    No person shall take down, alter, deface or destroy any number assigned to any building or place, retain, substitute or permit to be placed, retained or substituted an erroneous or improper number on any building. 
(Code 1973, § 21-20; Code 1995, § 90-179) 
Secs. 94-208-94-237. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PARADES 

Sec. 94-238. - Permit-Required. 
    No person shall publicly solicit persons together at any place for the purpose of engaging in a parade, procession or other public demonstration on the streets unless a permit for such parade, procession or other public demonstration has been previously secured as required by section 90-202. 
(Code 1973, § 15-148; Code 1995, § 90-201) 
Sec. 94-239. - Same-Procedure for securing. 
(a)  Parade to be in accord with permit specifications. No parade or procession shall occupy, march or proceed along any street except in accordance with a written permit, issued by the police department and such other regulations as are set forth in this chapter or other city ordinances which may apply. 
(b)  Application; contents. Application to conduct such parade or procession shall be made in writing to the chief of police by the person in charge, control or responsible thereof or therefor. Such application shall set forth the route along which such parade or procession is to proceed, the time of starting, the name of the person in control or responsible thereof or therefor, and the purpose of such parade or procession. 
(c)  Investigation of applicant. Upon such application being made, the police chief shall investigate or cause to be investigated the person making the application and the truth of the statements made in such application regarding the purpose or object of such parade or procession. 
(d)  Issuance. If the police chief shall find that such parade or procession will not in any manner tend to a breach of the peace, or unnecessarily interfere with the public use of the streets of the city or the peace and quiet of the inhabitants thereof, it shall issue such permit to the person making application therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 21-21; Code 1995, § 90-202) 
Sec. 94-240. - Parade escort required. 
    An escort shall be required for all parades and processions. The escort required shall be persons who are skilled in directing traffic. If not off-duty police officers, they shall be especially commissioned by the chief of the police department as city police officers in order to have authority to direct the traffic of other vehicles that are likely to endanger persons participating in the parade. 
(Code 1973, § 21-22; Code 1995, § 90-203) 
Sec. 94-241. - Parade column required; escort's position. 
    Parades passing over the streets of the city by automobile shall maintain a column with the escort at the head of the column or at points of danger from intersecting traffic. 
(Code 1973, § 21-23; Code 1995, § 90-204) 
Sec. 94-242. - Marking of parade automobiles; red lights may be ignored. 
(a)  The automobiles in the parade shall keep their headlights lighted or shall have a distinguishing mark or a pennant to indicate that the automobile is a part of the parade. 
(b)  Automobiles so marked as a part of the parade under escort may proceed across traffic control signals where the light is red. 
(Code 1973, § 21-24; Code 1995, § 90-205) 
Sec. 94-243. - Interference with parade by automobiles. 
    No automobile shall cut into, between or in front of a parade proceeding under escort and marked as provided in section 94-242. 
(Code 1973, § 21-25; Code 1995, § 90-206) 
Chapter 98 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Sales and use taxes generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-51-200 et seq.; state sales and use tax, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-23-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 98-1. - Conversion of city taxes for personal use. 
    No officer or person charged with the collection of taxes, general or special, for the city, shall embezzle or fraudulently convert to his own use, or fraudulently secrete with intent to convert to his own use, such taxes, or any portion thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 15-32; Code 1995, § 94-1) 
Sec. 98-2. - Finance director. 
    The finance director is hereby authorized to administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
Secs. 98-3-98-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SALES AND USE TAX 

Sec. 98-23. - Provisions of state sales tax statutes applicable to this article and taxes levied. 
    The taxes levied by section 98-25 shall be subject to all definitions, exceptions, exemptions, proceedings, requirements, rules, regulations, provisions, discounts, penalties, fines, punishments, and deductions that are applicable to the taxes levied by the state sales tax statutes, except where inapplicable or where otherwise provided in this chapter, including all provisions of the state sales tax statutes for enforcement and collection of taxes. 
(Code 1995, § 94-26; Ord. No. 2489, § 2, 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 98-24. - State statutes applicable to excise taxes levied in section 98-26. 
    The taxes levied by section 98-26 shall be subject to all definitions, exceptions, exemptions, proceedings, requirements, rules, regulations, provisions, discounts, penalties, fines, punishments and deductions that are applicable to the taxes levied by the state use tax statutes, except where inapplicable or where otherwise provided in this chapter, including all provisions of the state use tax statutes for enforcement and collection of taxes. 
(Code 1995, § 94-27; Ord. No. 2489, § 4, 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 98-25. - Levy of privilege tax on businesses; application of rates against gross sales or receipts. 
    There is hereby levied, in addition to all other taxes of every kind now imposed by law, and shall be collected as provided in this section, a privilege or license tax against the person on account of the business activities and in the amount to be determined by the application of rates against gross sales, or gross receipts, as the case may be, as follows: 
(1)  Upon every person including the state, the University of Alabama, Auburn University and all other institutions of higher learning in the state, whether such institutions be denominational, state, county or municipal institutions and any association or other agency or instrumentality of such institutions, engaged or continuing within the city in the business of selling at retail any tangible personal property whatsoever, including merchandise and commodities of every kind and character, not including, however, bonds or other evidences of debts or stocks, nor sale of material and supplies to any person for use in fulfilling a contract for the painting, repair or reconditioning of vessels, barges, ships, other watercraft and commercial fishing vessels of over five tons load displacement as registered with the U.S. Coast Guard and licensed by the state of department of conservation and natural resources, an amount equal to four percent of the gross proceeds of sales of the business except where a different amount is expressly provided in this section; provided, however, that any person engaging or continuing in business as a retailer and wholesaler or jobber shall pay the tax required on the gross proceeds of retail sales of such business at the rates specified, when his books are kept so as to show separately the gross proceeds of sales of each business, and when his books are not so kept he shall pay the tax as retailer on the gross sales of the business. 
(2)  Upon every person engaged, or continuing within the city in the business of conducting or operating places of amusement or entertainment, billiard and pool rooms, bowling alleys, amusement devices, musical devices, theaters, opera houses, moving picture shows, vaudevilles, amusement parks, athletic contests, including wrestling matches, prizefights, boxing and wrestling exhibitions, football and baseball games, including athletic contests, conducted by or under the auspices of any educational institution within the city or any athletic association thereof, or other association whether such institution or association is a denominational, a state or county, or a municipal institution or association or a state, county or city school or other institution, association or school, skating rinks, race tracks, golf courses or any other place at which any exhibition, display, amusement or entertainment is offered to the public or place when an admission fee is charged, including public bathing places, public dancehalls of every kind and description within the city, an amount equal to four percent of the gross receipts of any such business. Provided, however, notwithstanding any language to the contrary in the prior portion of this article, the tax provisions so specified shall not apply to any athletic event conducted by a public or nonpublic primary or secondary school or any athletic event conducted by or under the auspices of the Alabama High School Athletic Association. The tax amount which would have been collected pursuant to this article shall continue to be collected by the public or nonpublic primary or secondary school, but shall be retained by the school which collected it and shall be used by the school for school purposes. 
(3)  Upon every person engaged or continuing within the city in the business of selling at retail machines used in mining, quarrying, compounding, processing and manufacturing of tangible personal property, an amount equal to 11/2 percent of the gross proceeds of the sale of such machines; provided that the term "machines," as used in this subsection, shall include machinery which is used for mining, quarrying, compounding, processing or manufacturing tangible personal property, and the parts of such machines, attachments and replacements thereof, which are made or manufactured for use on or in the operation of such machines and which are necessary to the operation of such machines and are customarily so used. 
(4)  Upon every person engaged or continuing within the city in the business of selling at retail any automotive vehicle or truck trailer, semitrailer or house trailer, an amount equal to two percent of the gross proceeds of sale of such automotive vehicle or truck trailer, semitrailer or house trailer, or mobile home setup materials and supplies; provided where a person subject to the tax provided for in this subsection withdraws from his stock in trade any automotive vehicle or truck trailer, semitrailer or house trailer, for the use by him or his employee or agent in the operation of such business, there shall be paid, in lieu of the tax levied in this subsection, a fee of $5.00 per year or part thereof during which such automotive vehicle, truck trailer, semitrailer or house trailer shall remain the property of such person. Each such year or part thereof shall begin with the day or anniversary date, as the case may be, or such withdrawal and shall run for the 12 succeeding months or part thereof during which such automotive vehicle, truck trailer, semitrailer or house trailer shall remain the property of such person. Where any used automobile vehicle or truck trailer, semitrailer or house trailer is taken in trade or in a series of trades, as a credit or part payment on the sale of a new or used vehicle, the tax levied in this subsection shall be paid on the net difference, that is, the price of the new or used vehicle sold, less the credit for the used vehicle taken in trade. 
(5)  Upon every person engaged or continuing within the city in the business of selling at retail any machine, machinery or equipment which is used in planting, cultivating and harvesting farm products, or used in connection with the production of agricultural produce or products, livestock or poultry on farms, and the parts of such machines, machinery or equipment, attachments and replacements therefor which are made or manufactured for use on or in the operation of such machine, machinery or equipment, and which are necessary to and customarily used in the operation of such machine, machinery or equipment, an amount equal to 11/2 percent of the gross proceeds of the sale thereof; provided, however, that the 11/2 percent rate prescribed in this subsection with respect to parts, attachments and replacements shall not apply to any automotive vehicle or trailer designed primarily for public highway use, except farm trailers used primarily in the production and harvesting of agricultural commodities. Where any used machine, machinery or equipment which is used in planting, cultivating, and harvesting farm products, or used in connection with the production of agricultural produce or products, livestock and poultry on farms is taken in trade or in a series of trades as a credit or part payment on a sale of a new or used machine, machinery or equipment, the tax levied in this subsection shall be paid on the net difference, that is, the price of the new or used machine, machinery or equipment sold, less the credit for the used machine, machinery or equipment taken in trade. 
(6)  Upon every person engaged or continuing within the city in the business of selling through coin-operated dispensing machines, food and food products for human consumption, not including beverages other than coffee, milk, milk products and substitutes therefor, there is hereby levied a tax equal to three percent of the cost of such food, food products and beverages sold through such machines, which cost for the purpose of this subsection shall be the gross proceeds of sales of such business. 
(Code 1995, § 94-28; Ord. No. 2489, § 1, 8-22-1989; Ord. No. 2552, § I(1), 9-17-1991) 
Sec. 98-26. - Levy of excise taxes on storage; use; consumption of tangible personal property purchased at retail. 
(a)  Imposed. An excise tax is hereby imposed on the storage, use or other consumption in the city of tangible personal property, not including materials and supplies bought for use in fulfilling a contract for the painting, repairing or reconditioning of vessels, barges, ships, other watercraft and commercial fishing vessels of over five tons load displacement as registered with the U.S. Coast Guard and licensed by the state department of conservation and natural resources, purchased at retail on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived for storage, use or other consumption in the city, except as provided in subsections (b), (c) and (d) of this section at the rate of four percent of the sales price of such property within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Machines used in mining; compounding; manufacturing of property. An excise tax is hereby imposed on the storage, use or other consumption in the city of any machines used in mining, quarrying, compounding, processing and manufacturing of tangible personal property purchased at retail on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived at the rate of 11/2 percent of the sales price of any such machine, within the corporate limits of the city; provided the term "machine," as used in this subsection, shall include machinery which is used for mining, quarrying, compounding, processing, or manufacturing tangible personal property, and parts of such machines, attachments and replacements therefor, which are made or manufactured for use on or in the operation of such machines and which are necessary to the operation of such machines and are customarily so used. 
(c)  Automotive vehicles; truck trailers; semitrailers; house trailers; mobile home setup materials and supplies. An excise tax is hereby imposed on the storage, use or other consumption in the city of any automotive vehicle or truck trailer, semitrailer, or house trailer and mobile home setup materials and supplies, including but not limited to steps, blocks, anchoring, cable pipes and any other materials pertaining thereto, purchased at retail on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived for storage, use or other consumption in the city at the rate of two percent of the sales price of any such automotive vehicle or truck trailer, semitrailer, or house trailer, and mobile home setup materials and supplies as specified above within the corporate limits of the city. Where any used automotive vehicle, truck trailer, or semitrailer or house trailer is taken in trade, or in a series of trades, as a credit or part payment on the sale of a new or used vehicle, the tax levied in this subsection shall be paid on the net difference, that is, the price of the new or used vehicle sold, less the credit for the used vehicle taken in trade. 
(d)  Machines, machinery or equipment used on farms, in planting, cultivating and harvesting or production of produce, livestock or poultry.
