An excise tax is hereby levied and imposed on the storage, use or other consumption in the city of any machine, machinery or equipment which is used in planting, cultivating and harvesting farm products, or used in connection with the production of agricultural produce or products, livestock or poultry on farms, and the parts of such machines, machinery or equipment, attachments and replacements therefor which are made or manufactured for use on or in the operation of such machine, machinery or equipment, and which are necessary to and customarily used in the operation of such machine, machinery or equipment which is purchased at retail after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, for the storage, use or other consumption in the city at the rate of 11/2 percent of the sales price of such property within the corporate limits of the city, regardless of whether the retailer is or is not engaged in the business in this city; provided, however, that the 11/2 percent rate prescribed in this subsection with respect to parts, attachments, and replacements shall not apply to any automotive vehicle or trailer designed primarily for public highway use, except farm trailers used primarily in the production and harvesting of agricultural commodities. Where any used machine, machinery or equipment which is used in planting, cultivating, and harvesting farm products or used in connection with the production of agricultural produce or products, livestock and poultry on farms is taken in trade or in a series of trades, as a credit or part payment on the sale of a new or used machine, machinery or equipment, the tax levied in this subsection shall be paid on the net difference, that is, the price of the new or used machine, machinery or equipment, sold less the credit for the used machine, machinery or equipment taken in trade. 
(Code 1995, § 94-29; Ord. No. 2489, § 3, 8-22-1989; Ord. No. 2552, § II(3), 9-17-1991) 
Sec. 98-27. - Article cumulative to city license schedule or ordinance. 
    This article shall not be construed to repeal any of the provisions of the city license schedule or ordinance of the city, but shall be held to be cumulative, and the amounts of all other license taxes imposed by the city by its city license schedule or ordinance. 
(Code 1995, § 94-30; Ord. No. 2489, § 5, 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 98-28. - [Sales tax holiday.] 
(a)  Under the authority granted in Section 1 of Act No. 2017-120 of the Alabama Legislature, there shall be a sales tax holiday each year commencing the third Friday of July at 12:01 a.m. and ending the following Sunday at 12:00 midnight, during which time the payment of the sales tax collected by the City of Bessemer, Alabama will be exempt on the sale of "certain covered items" as the term "certain covered items" is defined in Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-23-210 et seq., as amended. 
(b)  If a vendor charges tax in error during this period, the vendor should refund the tax upon request of the customer. If the vendor fails to refund the tax, the vendor must remit the tax to the city. If taxes collected by the vendor in error are not refunded to the customer, the tax must be remitted to the city when filing and paying the taxes for the month of August. 
(Ord. No. 3459, §§ 1, 2, 4-19-2011; Ord. No. 3559, §§ 1, 2, 4-18-2017) 
Editor's note- Sections 1 and 2 of Ord. No. 3459, adopted April 19, 2011, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence codification as § 98-28 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 98-29-98-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RENTING, LEASING OF PERSONAL PROPERTY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Leasing or renting tangible personal property generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-12-221 et seq. 

Sec. 98-58. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business means all activities which may be licensed under Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-51-90. 
    Gross proceeds means the value proceeding or accruing from the leasing or rental of tangible personal property, without any deduction on account of the cost of the property, so leased or rented, the cost of materials used, labor or service cost, interest paid or any other expenses whatsoever, and without any deduction on account of loss, but shall not include proceeds accruing from charges made for the rental or use of hospital beds. 
    Leasing or rental means a transaction whereunder the person who owns or controls the possession of tangible personal property permits another person to have the possession or use thereof for a consideration and for the duration of a definite or indefinite period of time without transfer of the title to such property. The detention by the user thereof of freightcars, oxygen and acetylene tanks and similar property, in respect of which detention a demurrage or per diem charge is made against the user of such property, shall not be deemed to constitute a transaction whereunder property is leased or rented to another within the meaning of this article. 
    Tangible personal property means personal property which may be seen, weighed, measured, felt or touched or is in any other manner perceptible to the senses. The term "tangible personal property" shall not include stocks, bonds, notes, insurance or other contracts or securities. 
(Code 1995, § 94-51; Ord. No. 2490, § 1, 8-22-1989; Ord. No. 2553, § 1, 9-17-1991) 
Sec. 98-59. - Levy of tax. 
    There is hereby levied in addition to all privilege license taxes of every kind now imposed by law, and shall be collected as provided in this section, a privilege or license tax on each person engaging or continuing within the city in the business of leasing or renting tangible personal property. Such tax shall be in the amounts to be determined by the application of the rates against gross proceeds as follows: At the rate of four percent of the gross proceeds derived by the lessor or renter from the lease or rental of tangible personal property; provided the privilege or license tax on each person engaging or continuing within this city in the business of leasing or renting any automotive vehicle or truck trailer, semitrailer or house trailer shall be at the rate of 11/2 percent of the gross proceeds derived by the lessor from the lease or rental of such automotive vehicle or truck trailer, semitrailer or house trailer; provided further that the tax levied in this section shall not apply to any leasing or rental, as lessor, by the state, or any municipality or county in the state. 
(Code 1995, § 94-52; Ord. No. 2553, § 1(2), 9-17-1991) 
Sec. 98-60. - Exemptions. 
    There shall be exempted from the computation of any tax due under this article the following: 
(1)  The gross proceeds accruing from the leasing or rental of film to a lessee who charges admission for viewing such film. 
(2)  The gross proceeds accruing from any charge in respect of the use of docks or docking facilities furnished for boats or other craft operated on waterways. 
(3)  The gross proceeds accruing from any charge made by a landlord to a tenant in respect to the leasing or furnishing of tangible personal property to be used on the premises of real property leased by the same landlord to the same tenant for use as a residence or dwelling place, including mobile homes. 
(4)  The gross proceeds accruing from the leasing or rental of tangible personal property to a lessee who acquires possession of the property for the purpose of leasing or renting to another the same property under a leasing or rental transaction subject to a tax under this article. 
(5)  The gross proceeds accruing from any charge made by a landlord to a tenant in respect to the leasing or furnishing of tangible personal property to be used on the premises of any room, lodging, or accommodations leased or rented to transients in any hotel, motel, inn, tourist camp, tourist cabin, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings or accommodations are regularly furnished to transients for a consideration. 
(6)  The gross proceeds accruing from the leasing or rental of tangible personal property which the city is prohibited from taxing under the Constitution or laws of the United States or under the constitution or laws of the state. 
(7)  The gross proceeds accruing from the leasing or rental of nuclear fuel assemblies, together with the nuclear material contained therein and other nuclear material used or useful in the production of electricity and assemblies containing ionizing radiation sources together with the ionizing radiation sources contained therein used or useful in medical treatment or scientific research. 
(8)  The gross proceeds accruing from a transaction whereunder the lessor leases a truck or tractor-trailer or semitrailer, for operation over the public roads and highways, and such lessor furnishes a driver for each such vehicle. 
(9)  The gross proceeds accruing from the leasing or rental of vehicles in interchange between regulated motor carriers on a per diem basis. 
(10)  The gross proceeds accruing from the leasing or rental of all structures, devices, facilities and identifiable components of any structure, device or facility thereof acquired primarily for the control, reduction or elimination of air or water pollution, and the gross proceeds accruing from the leasing or rental of all materials used or intended for use in structures built primarily for the control, reduction or elimination of air or water pollution. 
(11)  The gross proceeds derived by the lessor (which term includes a sublessor) from the leasing or rental of tangible personal property when the lessor and lessee (which term includes a sublessee) are wholly owned subsidiary corporations of the same parent corporation or one is the wholly owned subsidiary of the other, provided that the appropriate sales or use tax, if any was due, has been paid on such item of personal property, and provided further, that in the event of any subsequent subleasing of such tangible personal property to any person other than any such sister, parent or subsidiary corporation, any privilege or license tax due and payable with respect to such subsequent subleasing under the provisions hereof shall be paid. 
(12)  The gross proceeds accrued or accruing from any leases or rental contracts in effect before October 1, 1989; provided, however, that the exemption hereby afforded shall not apply to any renewal or extension of such leases or contracts and shall not apply to gross proceeds accruing after two years from October 1, 1989. 
(Code 1995, § 94-53; Ord. No. 2490, § 3, 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 98-61. - Tax due and payable in monthly installments; penalty for violation. 
    The privilege license tax levied under this article, except as otherwise provided, shall be due and payable in monthly installments on or before the 20th day of the month next succeeding the month in which the privilege license tax accrues. On or before such 20th day every person on whom the amounts levied under this article are imposed shall render to the city on a form prescribed by the city, a true and correct statement showing the gross proceeds of his business, for the next preceding month, the amount of gross proceeds which are not subject to the privilege license tax, or are not to be used as a measurement of the amounts due by such person and the nature thereof, together with such other information as the city may require, and at the time of making such monthly report such person shall compute the privilege license taxes due and shall pay to the city the amounts shown to be due. If any person subject hereto should fail to render any report required hereby or should willfully make a false statement of facts in the statements or returns required under this article, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction, be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-8. 
(Code 1995, § 94-54; Ord. No. 2490, § 4, 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 98-62. - Cash or credit rentals; method of tax payment. 
    Any person taxable under this article who makes cash or credit leases or rentals, may report such cash leases or rentals only, and he shall thereafter include in each monthly report all credit collections made during the month preceding, and shall pay the privilege license tax due thereon at the time of filing such report. 
(Code 1995, § 94-55; Ord. No. 2490, § 5, 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 98-63. - Recordkeeping; examination; penalty for violation. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every person engaging or continuing in any business for which a privilege tax is imposed by this article to keep and preserve suitable records of the gross proceeds of any such business and such other books or accounts as may be necessary to determine the amount of tax for which he is liable under this article. It shall be the duty of every person to keep and preserve for a period of three years all invoices of gross proceeds, proceeding or accruing from the leasing or rental taxed in this article. All such books, invoices and other records shall be open for examination at any time by the city or its agent. Any person leasing, who in addition leases for re-leasing, shall keep his books so as to show separately the gross proceeds of leasing and the gross proceeds of leasing for re-leasing. Each occurrence of a failure to keep records or allow examination thereof shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Any person who shall fail to keep records as required in this section or who shall refuse to permit such examination thereof, or who violates any other provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-8. 
(Code 1995, § 94-56; Ord. No. 2490, § 6, 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 98-64. - Penalty for late payment. 
    Any person who fails to pay the tax levied by this article within the time required by this article shall pay, in addition to the tax, a penalty of ten percent of the amount of tax due, and such penalty to be assessed and collected as part of the tax, provided the city, if a good and sufficient reason is shown, may waive or remit the penalty of ten percent or a portion thereof. 
(Code 1995, § 94-57; Ord. No. 2490, § 9, 8-22-1989) 
Secs. 98-65-98-88. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LODGING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Transient occupancy tax generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-26-1 et seq. 

Sec. 98-89. - Levy of license tax. 
(a)  License and tax required. Every person engaging in the business in the city or its police jurisdiction of renting or furnishing any rooms, lodgings or accommodations to transients in any hotel, motel, inn, tourist cabin, tourist camp or other place in which rooms, lodgings or accommodations are regularly furnished to transients for a consideration shall take out and pay to the city a license as follows: 
(1)  Business conducted in city limits. If such business is being conducted within the corporate limits of the city, the license shall be an amount determined by the application at the rate of six percent of the charge for such room, rooms, lodgings or accommodations including the charge for the use of the rental of personal properties or services purchased in such room. 
(2)  Business conducted outside of city limits. If such business is conducted outside the corporate limits but within the police jurisdiction of the city, the license tax levied in this article shall be an amount equal to one-half of the amount of the license within the corporate limits. 
(3)  Payable in monthly installments. The license tax levied under this article shall be in addition to every other license tax levied and shall be due and payable in monthly installments on or before the 20th day of the month next succeeding the month in which the license accrued. 
(b)  Payment to city clerk and treasurer. The licensee shall compute the amount of tax due and pay the same to the city clerk and treasurer at the time of making the monthly report required. 
(c)  Evidence of amount due. Licensees may, if they desire, submit a copy of the license required to be submitted to the county, as evidence of the amount due. 
(Code 1995, § 94-81; Ord. No. 2224, 1-17-1984; Ord. No. 2554, 9-17-1991; Ord. No. 3465, § I, 6-21-2011) 
Sec. 98-90. - Penalty for violation. 
    If any person subject to this article should fail to render any report required hereby or should willfully make a false statement of facts in the statements or returns required under this article, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction, be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-8. 
Chapter 102 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS 

Sec. 102-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to it in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cable television service means any and all services provided by or through the facilities of any cable television system or closed circuit coaxial cable communications system, or any microwave or similar transmission service used in connection with any cable television system or other similar closed circuit coaxial cable communications system. 
(Code 1995, § 26-1; Ord. No. 2166, § 1, 3-16-1982) 
Sec. 102-2. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and on such conviction shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-8. 
(Code 1995, § 26-2; Ord. No. 2166, § 4, 3-16-1982) 
Sec. 102-3. - Destruction or tampering with equipment; illegal use of signals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person without the authority of the television company to intentionally or in any way obstruct, injure, break, tamper with or destroy or in any manner interfere with or interrupt any cable television service, line or cable or the transmission of television signals in connection with such line or cable, or in any manner use and receive any television, radio, audio or video signal from any unauthorized connection with such line or cable, or to take, carry away, injure or destroy any of the posts, cables, wires, insulators, fixtures, equipment, installations or other things belonging to any cable television service or used in connection with the furnishings of cablevision services. 
(Code 1995, § 26-3; Ord. No. 2166, § 2, 3-16-1982) 
State Law reference- Criminal tampering, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 13A-7-24-13A-7-26. 
Sec. 102-4. - Diversion of signals; fraud. 
    The presence at any time on or about such wires, cables or cablevision equipment of any device or wire resulting in the diversion of television, radio, audio or video signals shall constitute prima facie evidence of knowledge and intent to divert on the part of the person having custody or control of the room or place where such signals are diverted and received, and shall constitute prima facie evidence of the intention on the part of such person, to defraud and shall bring such person prima facie within the scope, meaning and penalties of this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 26-4; Ord. No. 2166, § 3, 3-16-1982) 
Chapter 106 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles and traffic generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-1-1 et seq.; powers of local authorities generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-1; appearance upon arrest for misdemeanor generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-1-4; depositing driver's license in lieu of bail, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 32-1-5, 32-1-6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 106-1. - Adoption of traffic code. 
    The provisions of Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 32-5-1 et seq. and 32-5A-1 et seq., regulating the operation of motor vehicles and rules of the road are adopted by reference in this chapter as if fully set out. 
(Code 1995, § 98-1) 
Sec. 106-2. - Obstruction of driver's view at intersection; exceptions; obstruction defined. 
(a)  No person who is the owner or occupant of any real property within the city limits abutting upon any public street or avenue shall erect, construct or maintain, or permit the erection, construction or maintenance of any obstruction of such height, size or nature as to obstruct the view of the driver of a vehicle upon such public street in approaching the intersection of such public street with another public street of the city. 
(b)  The obstruction shall be deemed to obstruct the view of the driver of a vehicle upon such street in approaching an intersection of another street therewith, when, at any time during the last 50 feet of his approach to such intersection, the presence of such obstruction upon the property prevents the driver having a clear and uninterrupted view of such approach to such intersection and of the traffic upon all of the thoroughfares or streets entering such intersection for a distance of 200 feet from such intersection. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply within the fire limits of the city, nor shall they apply to property abutting or adjoining the intersection of public streets in the city where automatic signal traffic lights are at all times maintained and operated by the city. 
(d)  For the purpose of this section the term "obstruction" means any bush, hedge, building, structure or other erection erected, maintained or situated along any public street or avenue within the city limits, and within 50 feet of the intersection of such street or avenue with another public street or avenue of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 21-76; Code 1995, § 98-3) 
Sec. 106-3. - Riding outside vehicles prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall ride upon the outside, upon the running board, or upon the fender of any vehicle upon the public streets of the city. 
(b)  No person other than a bus or truck employee in the discharge of his duty shall, without permission of the driver or other person in charge of the bus or truck and with the intention of being transported free and without paying the fare for such transportation, ride or attempt to ride on or about any bus or truck or any part thereof operated on any street in the city operating subject to a certificate of public convenience and necessity granted by the state public service commission. 
(Code 1973, § 22-72; Code 1995, § 98-7) 
Sec. 106-4. - Engine repair or adjustment on street prohibited. 
    No person operating a garage within the city limits or working for such person shall repair or adjust any automobile engine on the streets of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 22-73; Code 1995, § 98-8) 
Sec. 106-5. - Pedestrians crossing streets. 
    No pedestrian shall cross any street within the business district of the city, except and unless he crosses at an intersection, at a right angle to such street, and within the sidewalk lines of such street extended across such intersection. 
(Code 1973, § 22-79; Code 1995, § 98-10) 
Sec. 106-6. - Bicycles-Riding on sidewalks prohibited. 
    No person shall ride a bicycle along or on any sidewalk within the city limits. 
(Code 1973, § 21-40; Code 1995, § 98-12) 
Sec. 106-7. - Same-Warning devices required. 
    Any person riding a bicycle on the streets within the city limits shall have attached to the bicycle a warning device. Any person so riding a bicycle shall be required to sound the warning device on approaching any person on the streets. 
(Code 1973, § 21-41; Code 1995, § 98-13) 
Sec. 106-8. - Driving through processions; exception. 
(a)  No vehicle shall be driven through a procession except by permission of a police officer. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to the vehicles carrying United States mail, ambulances and vehicles of the police and fire departments. 
(Code 1973, § 22-66; Code 1995, § 98-14) 
Sec. 106-9. - Movement of traffic on one-way streets, alleys and terraces. 
    Upon the streets and parts of streets and in those alleys or terraces described in the city traffic schedule as amended, which is adopted by reference and made a part hereof, vehicular traffic shall move only in the indicated direction when signs indicating the direction of traffic are erected and maintained at every intersection where movement in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Code 1973, § 22-59; Code 1995, § 98-16; Ord. No. 2018, § 1, 5-30-1978) 
State Law reference- Authority to provide one-way streets, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-1. 
Sec. 106-10. - Speed limits. 
(a)  Any person driving a vehicle on a public thoroughfare within the city limits shall drive the vehicle at a careful and prudent speed not greater than is reasonable and proper, having due regard to the traffic, surface and width of the public thoroughfare and to any other conditions then existing. No person shall drive any vehicle upon a public thoroughfare at such speed as to endanger the life, limb or property of any person. 
(b)  Subject to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section and except in those instances where a lower speed is specified, it shall be prima facie lawful for the driver of a vehicle to drive the vehicle at a speed not exceeding the speeds set forth in the city traffic schedule when such speed is safe and reasonable. 
(Code 1973, § 22-7; Code 1995, § 98-17) 
State Law reference- Establishment of speed limits generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-49-4; posting required, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-49-5. 
Sec. 106-11. - Turns. 
    No person shall make a left turn or a right turn at any of the locations described in the city traffic schedule. 
(Code 1973, § 22-62; Code 1995, § 98-19) 
Sec. 106-12. - U-turns. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, any vehicle, in crossing from one side of the street to the other, shall do so by turning to the left at the end of the block, so as to head in the same direction as the traffic on the side of the street to which the vehicle is going. 
(b)  No person operating a vehicle shall make a turn of 180 degrees, or what is commonly known as a U-turn, at any intersection where there is installed and in operation, a traffic control signal lamp. 
(Code 1973, § 22-63; Code 1995, § 98-20) 
State Law reference- Turns at intersections generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-130. 
Sec. 106-13. - Signage and emblems for city vehicles. 
(a)  All city vehicles shall have signage and emblems as hereinafter set out. 
(b)  Automobiles and trucks shall be identified on both driver and passenger doors. The city seal will be approximately six inches circular for automobiles and eight inches circular for trucks. 
(c)  Vehicles operated by the mayor shall be exempt from this section. 
(Code 1995, § 98-21; Ord. No. 3092, 12-21-1999) 
Secs. 106-14-106-44. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 106-45-106-61. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FINES AND PENALTIES 

Sec. 106-62. - Additional costs for moving violation. 
(a)  In accordance with Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-313, there is established, imposed and assessed an additional penalty of $1.50 upon the driver of any motor vehicle convicted in the municipal court for an offense involving a moving traffic violation or being cited by a police officer in accordance with section 106-64. 
(b)  There is hereby assessed as additional costs for all convictions, whether based on state law or local ordinances, the additional sum of $16.00 which is required by Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-19-250. 
(Code 1973, § 22-20; Code 1995, § 98-51; Ord. No. 1977, § 1, 6-7-1977) 
Sec. 106-63. - Fines and costs for moving traffic violations. 
    The fines and costs are authorized for summary disposition of moving traffic violations in the city in accordance with Rule 19 of the Judicial Rules of Administration, Alabama Rules of Court, 1977, as amended, shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and will be available for public examination in a fines schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 22-19; Code 1995, § 98-52; Ord. No. 1973, § 1, 5-3-1977; Ord. No. 1977, § 1, 6-7-1977; Ord. No. 2413, §§ 1, 2, 10-13-1987; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 11-20-2001) 
Sec. 106-64. - Traffic violation citation; presumption as to offender. 
(a)  The officer noting a traffic violation shall issue a citation designating the date, time, location and offense and the name of the officer who issues the citation. The citation shall also contain the make of the car and the license number. 
(b)  It is declared that the person in whose name the motor vehicle is registered presumptively committed the offense for which the citation has been issued. This presumption shall remain as a matter of law until the registered owner shall make further explanation as to the name and address of the person who had possession of the motor vehicle at such time and date. 
(Code 1973, § 22-15; Code 1995, § 98-53) 
State Law reference- Requirement of use of uniform traffic ticket and complaint, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-12-53. 
Sec. 106-65. - Auto defect repair; inspection; citation voided; fine payment. 
(a)  Any person cited under the provisions of this chapter and charged with defective brakes, driving without lights, no taillight, one headlight out, or unnecessary noise shall, within seven days following the date the officer issues the citation for such offense, have the right to have such automobile repaired so as to correct the defect noted, and any other defects of like manner then present on the car. If such person shall then present such automobile to the city police department at the police building between 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. during such seven-day period for examination and the defects have been repaired, the citation shall then be voided by the inspecting officer. 
(b)  If such citation is voided, the date, time and place of the examination shall be noted on the citation given to the motorist and shall then be noted on the copy held by the police department, and a copy of such ticket showing the inspection shall be forwarded to the office of the city clerk and treasurer so that no arrest order shall issue. 
(c)  If the payment of the minimum fine has not been paid or the citation voided as provided in this section, then such motorist must pay the fine in the manner provided in section 106-63. 
(Code 1973, § 22-19.1; Code 1995, § 98-54) 
Sec. 106-66. - Remittance to state treasurer. 
    The clerk and treasurer shall remit to the state treasurer the additional costs collected under the provisions of sections 106-62 and 106-63. 
(Code 1973, § 22-21; Code 1995, § 98-55) 
Secs. 106-67-106-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate or prohibit parking, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-1(e); authority to designate stop, yield intersections, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-113. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 106-91. - Purpose of article. 
    This article shall be deemed and construed to be an exercise of the police power of the city and for the preservation and protection of public safety. All of its provisions shall be liberally construed with a view to the effectuation of such purpose. 
(Code 1973, § 22-57; Code 1995, § 98-76) 
Sec. 106-92. - Stopping vehicle in street. 
    No vehicle in the city, unless blocked by other traffic, or to allow pedestrians or other vehicular traffic to cross its path, shall stop in any public street of the city unless it is parked in the manner provided for in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 22-86; Code 1995, § 98-77) 
Sec. 106-93. - Designation of stop intersections; stopping for signs. 
(a)  The intersections described in the city traffic schedule are designated as stop intersections. Stop signs shall be installed as required. 
(b)  All vehicles while traveling along any public street in the city, and before entering the intersection of such street with any other street in the city, shall come to a stop at a point within 20 feet of such intersection and before entering such intersection, if the city has erected and is maintaining a stop sign clearly visible at such intersection and located on the right-hand side of and facing the traffic on such street in the direction in which such vehicle is then traveling. 
(Code 1973, § 22-80; Code 1995, § 98-78) 
Sec. 106-94. - Driving upon parking lots-Speed limit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle upon any parking lot in the city in excess of 15 miles per hour. 
(Code 1995, § 98-79; Ord. No. 1912, § 1, 9-16-1975) 
Sec. 106-95. - Same-Willful or wanton disregard of safety of persons or property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle upon any parking lot in the city in wilful or wanton disregard for the safety of persons or property. 
(Code 1995, § 98-80; Ord. No. 1912, § 1, 9-16-1975) 
Sec. 106-96. - Violation of parking ordinance; presumption of vehicle owner's violation. 
(a)  No person shall park, cause to be parked, or knowingly permit an automobile or other motor vehicle which he owns to be parked on any street in the city in violation of any ordinance of the city. 
(b)  The presence of an unattended automobile or other motor vehicle parked on the streets of the city in violation of an ordinance of the city shall raise a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of the automobile or other motor vehicle committed or authorized the parking violation. The burden of proof shall be upon the registered owner to show otherwise. 
(Code 1973, § 22-81; Code 1995, § 98-81) 
State Law reference- Presumption as to person parking in violation of ordinance, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-152. 
Sec. 106-97. - Parallel parking; designated areas. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided in this article, no vehicle shall remain stationed upon any public street unless it is placed parallel to the curb, with the inside wheels at a distance of not more than 18 inches from the curbline of the street. 
(b)  Any vehicle, when not in motion, shall be parked with all wheels parallel to, and the inside wheels within 18 inches of the curb on the right-hand side, reckoned from the direction in which the front of such vehicle is headed, along any streets and avenues described in the city traffic schedule. 
(c)  No vehicle within the fire limits shall be stopped with its left side to the curb. 
(Code 1973, § 22-82; Code 1995, § 98-82) 
State Law reference- Additional parking regulations, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-138. 
Sec. 106-98. - Parking prohibited at all times on certain streets. 
    No person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the streets or parts of streets described in the city traffic schedule. 
(Code 1973, § 22-83; Code 1995, § 98-83) 
Sec. 106-99. - Parking time limited on certain streets. 
    Except on Saturday and Sunday and designated holidays, no person shall park a vehicle for longer than the time limit shown in the city traffic schedule upon any of the streets or parts of streets described in the city traffic schedule. 
(Code 1973, § 22-84; Code 1995, § 98-84) 
Sec. 106-100. - Parking in alleys. 
    No person shall park any vehicle upon any public alley of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 22-88; Code 1995, § 98-85) 
Sec. 106-101. - Parked vehicles of excessive length; lights. 
    No person shall park any vehicle upon or along any street or avenue of the city in the nighttime, where the length of such vehicle exceeds 20 feet or where the height of such vehicle exceeds seven feet unless parking lights are operated and maintained on such vehicle as provided by law. 
(Code 1973, § 22-94; Code 1995, § 98-86) 
Sec. 106-102. - Exemption of certain vehicles. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to public or private ambulances, police cars, police motorcycles and firefighting equipment of the city, when they are being used in their regular course of duty. 
(Code 1973, § 22-96; Code 1995, § 98-87) 
Secs. 106-103-106-132. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LOADING ZONES 

Sec. 106-133. - Designation. 
    The locations described in the city traffic schedule are designated as loading zones. 
(Code 1973, § 22-101; Code 1995, § 98-101) 
Sec. 106-134. - Parking. 
    No person shall park or leave standing any automobile or motor truck or other vehicle on or along, and within a distance of 20 feet of the curbline of any portions of the public streets and avenues of the city designated in section 106-133 as a loading zone. 
(Code 1973, § 22-102; Code 1995, § 98-102) 
Sec. 106-135. - Marking. 
    The curbline on and along each parking space described in the city traffic schedule shall be painted yellow. A sign shall be placed on or along each prohibited parking space with substantially the following legend printed thereon: "LOADING ZONE-NO PARKING." 
(Code 1973, § 22-103; Code 1995, § 98-103) 
Sec. 106-136. - Use restriction. 
    The prohibited parking zones described in the city traffic schedule shall be used only for the loading and unloading of motor trucks or other freight vehicles serving businesses located in the block where such prohibited zone is designated. No prohibited zone shall be used as a parking place for any vehicle. 
(Code 1973, § 22-104; Code 1995, § 98-104) 
Sec. 106-137. - Bus loading zones-Designation. 
    The locations described in the city traffic schedule are designated as bus loading zones. 
(Code 1973, § 22-105; Code 1995, § 98-105) 
Sec. 106-138. - Same-Parking. 
    No person shall park or leave standing any automobile, motor truck or other vehicle on or along and within a distance of 20 feet of the curbline of any designated portions of the public streets and avenues designated in section 106-137 as bus loading zones. 
(Code 1973, § 22-106; Code 1995, § 98-106) 
Sec. 106-139. - Same-Marking. 
    The curbline on and along the prohibited parking spaces designated in the city traffic schedule as bus loading zones shall be painted yellow. A sign shall be placed on or along each such prohibited parking space with substantially the following wording: "NO PARKING-BUS LOADING ZONE." 
(Code 1973, § 22-107; Code 1995, § 98-107) 
Sec. 106-140. - Same-Use restriction. 
    The prohibited parking zones described in the city traffic schedule shall be used only as loading and unloading zones for common carriers of passengers for hire operating bus transportation in or through the city. 
(Code 1973, § 22-108; Code 1995, § 98-108) 
Sec. 106-141. - Loading zones designated in parking zones; use. 
(a)  The chief of police shall mark off loading zones in the parking zones described in the city traffic schedule and in any other zones established. 
(b)  The loading zones shall be designated by lines painted or durably marked on the curbing or surface of the street. Each space so marked shall be used for the purpose of loading and unloading. 
(Code 1973, § 22-44; Code 1995, § 98-109) 
Secs. 106-142-106-165. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TWENTY-FOUR-HOUR PARKING 

Sec. 106-166. - Parking over 24 hours. 
    No person shall park any vehicle or allow any vehicle to stand continuously for more than 24 hours upon the public streets of the city in the territory described in the city traffic schedule. 
(Code 1973, § 22-91; Code 1995, § 98-121) 
Secs. 106-167-106-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - METERED PARKING 

Sec. 106-186. - Parking spaces designated; use. 
    The chief of police shall mark off individual parking spaces in the parking zones described in the city traffic schedule and in any other zones established. The parking spaces shall be designated by lines painted or durably marked on the curbing or surface of the street. At each space so marked, no person shall park any vehicle in such a way that such vehicle will not be entirely within the limits of the space so designated. 
(Code 1973, § 22-45; Code 1995, § 98-131) 
Secs. 106-187-106-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - TWO-HOUR PARKING 

Sec. 106-211. - In front of city police department; limited use; penalty for violation. 
(a)  No person shall park any vehicle in front of the city police department on the north side of that section of 15th Street, located between Alabama Avenue and 1st Avenue between the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., except and unless that person has business to conduct in the police department building, and then the vehicle shall not remain parked in a space in excess of two hours. 
(b)  Any person parking a vehicle in the area designated by the provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be subject to the penalty in section 1-8. 
(Code 1995, § 98-141; Ord. No. 2590, §§ 2, 3, 6-15-1993) 
Sec. 106-212. - On streets between 8:00 a.m. until 6:00. p.m., Mondays through Saturdays except holidays. 
(a)  No motor vehicle shall be parked upon the streets of the city for more than two hours from 8:00 a.m. until 6:00 p.m. on Mondays through Saturdays, except holidays in the following areas: 
(1)  On both sides of First Avenue between 18th and 20th Streets; 
(2)  On both sides of Second Avenue between 17th and 21st Streets; 
(3)  On both sides of Third Avenue from 17th Street to 20th Street; 
(4)  On the Northeast side of 17th Street between Second Avenue and Third Avenue; 
(5)  On both sides of 18th Street between First Avenue and Fourth Avenue; 
(6)  On both sides of 19th Street between First Avenue and Sixth Avenue. 
(b)  The chief of police shall have the authority to designate certain parking spaces in the areas described in subsection (a) of this section as loading zones, handicapped parking spaces or less than two-hour parking. 
(Code 1995, § 98-142; Ord. No. 2625, 6-21-1994) 
Secs. 106-213-106-232. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RAILROADS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Railroad companies using municipal streets are required to keep their tracks, the streets between their rails, and 18 inches of the streets on each side of their tracks in repair as may be prescribed by the municipal governing body, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-49-3. 

Sec. 106-233. - Conformity to grade of streets. 
(a)  Every railroad company building a railway through the streets of the city shall be required to conform strictly to the grade of such street. Any railroad company shall, before laying down its tracks in or upon any street within the city limits, first obtain from the city engineer the proper grade of such street over which such line of railway is to run, if such street has been brought to grade. Such road shall be put on exact grade so as not to interfere with or impede travel. If such street has not been brought to grade, then such railway shall be required to conform to the then surface of the street, so as not to interfere with or impede travel over and along such street. 
(b)  If any company shall lay down tracks on streets not brought to grade, the right of the city to grade such streets in the future shall not be prejudiced. The owners, proprietors or lessees of such railway tracks shall, whenever required by the city council, raise or lower such tracks so as to conform to the grade of the streets without cost to the city. 
(Code 1973, § 18-5; Code 1995, § 98-161) 
Sec. 106-234. - Assessment of costs of improvements against railroads. 
(a)  If a railroad track on any street or highway improved or reimproved, the cost of such improvement, except stormwater and sanitary sewers, between the tracks and the rails of the tracks and, in case there are two or more tracks, the space between such tracks and 18 inches on each side of the tracks, including switches and turnouts, shall be paid by the owner of the railroad and shall be assessed against and form a lien on the railroad and the property connected therewith. If stormwater sewers are constructed which drain, serve or benefit the streets or avenues or rights-of-way on which a railroad is located, whether the sewer is a continued or separate system, there shall be assessed against such railroad a fair and just proportion of the cost of construction of such sewer, to be determined by the council, and such assessment shall be a lien like other assessments and may be collected in like manner, and the council may require the owners of such railroad to prepare or construct its tracks for the receipt of such paving or other improvements in a manner satisfactory to the council. 
(b)  If protection against storms and floods are constructed which protect or benefit streets or avenues or rights-of-way on which a railroad is located, whether the protection is a continued or separate system, there shall be assessed against such railroad a fair and just proportion of the cost of construction of such protection against storms and floods, to be determined by the city council, and such assessment shall be a lien like other assessments and may be collected in like manner; provided, however, that such assessments shall not exceed the increased value of such railroad by reason of the benefits received by such railroad from the construction of such protection. 
(Code 1973, § 18-6; Code 1995, § 98-162) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-48-19. 
Sec. 106-235. - Alterations or extensions; permit; distance of sidetrack extensions. 
(a)  No railroad company within the city limits shall make alterations in its lines, or extend its sidetracks or turnouts, without first obtaining permission from the city council. 
(b)  No railroad company shall extend sidetracks for a longer distance than one block. 
(Code 1973, § 18-7; Code 1995, § 98-163) 
Sec. 106-236. - Laying tracks; obstructions; rubbish removal. 
(a)  All railroad companies in the construction or repair of their roads or roadbeds shall carefully lay the ties and rails so as to prevent hindrance to the free passage of vehicles. They shall allow no holes or excavations to remain open sufficiently long to cause the same to hold stagnant water, or to disfigure the streets. 
(b)  No rubbish or abandoned work of any kind shall be left in such condition as to disfigure the streets, impede the free use of the streets or endanger persons or vehicles. 
(Code 1973, § 18-8; Code 1995, § 98-164) 
Sec. 106-237. - Culverts required; penalty. 
    At any point along a railroad where culverts for drainage may be deemed necessary by the city engineer, the owners, proprietors or lessees of such roads shall be required to put in good substantial culverts of sufficient capacity to carry off all water that may run through them. If any company, the owner, proprietor or lessee of such road, fails to build such culverts after due notice being given by the city council, such company shall not have the right to run cars through the city over such roads until the provisions of this section have been complied with. 
(Code 1973, § 18-9; Code 1995, § 98-165) 
Sec. 106-238. - Automatic signal warning lights and safety gates required; locations. 
(a)  The Alabama Great Southern Railroad Company shall provide, maintain and operate constantly, automatic crossing safety gates and automatic signal warning lights where its tracks cross the following streets within the city: First Street, Ninth Street, 14th Street, 15th Street, 16th Street, 19th Street and 20th Street. 
(b)  The crossing safety gates shall be erected and maintained by the railroad company in a manner approved by the city council. Such gates shall be erected in such a manner so as to prevent the passage of any vehicle over or upon such crossing when any train is approaching such crossings with sufficient nearness so as to constitute a menace to the safe crossing of any such crossing. 
(Code 1973, § 18-12; Code 1995, § 98-166) 
Sec. 106-239. - Blocking streets or sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall block any of the streets or sidewalks of the city for a longer period of time than five minutes by the placing of any engine or car thereon. 
(b)  Railroad cars shall not stop so as to obstruct any intersection, including that part of the street which is within the line of the sidewalk projected. 
(Code 1973, § 18-14; Code 1995, § 98-167) 
Secs. 106-240-106-256. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ABANDONED VEHICLES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to abate nuisances generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-117; abandoned motor vehicles generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-13-1 et seq.; officers authorized to remove vehicles, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-139. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 106-257. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Highway means every highway or portion thereof on which vehicular traffic is given preferential right-of-way, and at the entrances to which vehicular traffic from intersecting highways is required by law to yield the right-of-way to vehicles on such through highway in obedience to a stop sign, yield sign, or other official traffic control device, when such signs or devices are erected as provided in this chapter. 
    Impounding agency means the City of Bessemer Police Department. 
    Legal owner means a lienholder, person with a security interest in a motor vehicle, a lessor of a motor vehicle, assignee of the lessor, or the person who is the registered owner of the motor vehicle. 
    Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled and shall include, without limitation, an automobile, a truck, a trailer, a motorcycle and a tractor. 
(b)  The definition of "abandoned motor vehicle" set forth in Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-13-1 (Abandoned motor vehicle defined; posted notice), shall be effective as a definition of that terms when used in this article. 
(Code 1995, § 98-191; Ord. No. 2579, § 1, 12-25-1992; Ord. No. 3281, § 1(a), 4-19-2005) 
Sec. 106-258. - Abandonment on public property. 
    No person shall abandon a motor vehicle on any street, highway, alley, or other public way of this city. 
(Code 1995, § 98-193; Ord. No. 2579, § 2, 12-25-1992) 
Sec. 106-259. - Abandonment on property of another. 
    No person shall abandon for any length of time a motor vehicle on the private property of another person without the express or implied permission of the owner or lessee of the private property. Any resident of the city on whose property a motor vehicle is abandoned may file a complaint with the police department. Thereafter, the motor vehicle shall be impounded and subject to the same treatment as provided for motor vehicles abandoned on the public ways. 
(Code 1995, § 98-194; Ord. No. 2579, § 3, 12-25-1992) 
Sec. 106-260. - Abandonment on operator's personal property. 
    No person in charge or control of any property within the city, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee, or otherwise, shall allow any partially dismantled nonoperating, wrecked, discarded or abandoned motor vehicle to remain on such property longer than seven days; except that this article shall not apply with regard to a vehicle in an enclosed building; a vehicle on the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place and manner, when necessary to the operation of such business enterprises; or a vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner by the city. 
(Code 1995, § 98-195; Ord. No. 2579, § 4, 12-25-1992) 
Sec. 106-261. - Removal procedure; impoundment. 
(a)  Any regularly employed and salaried law enforcement officer of this city or other employee of the city designated by the city council, who has reasonable grounds to believe that a motor vehicle has been abandoned, shall affix to the windshield or other prominent part of the vehicle, a tow warning emblem. The emblem shall be five by seven inches or larger, bright orange in color, with the printed words "Towing Warning" in bold letters at least two inches high, and shall also state that unless the vehicle is removed before ____________ a.m./p.m. in the ____________ of the day of ____________ , ____________ , the vehicle will be impounded and taken to ____________ , and after 60 days it will be sold to recover the costs of removal, storage, and sale. The emblem shall be self-adhesive, and the blanks indicated in this subsection shall be completely filled in with permanent dark ink indicating the required details. The time set for removal shall be at least seven days after the emblem is affixed. After the time set for removal has expired, any designated city employee or officer shall cause the motor vehicle to be removed to the depository maintained by the city for the purpose of storing such motor vehicles. If the vehicle is illegally parked or is disabled, a tow warning emblem need not be affixed, and the vehicle may be immediately impounded. 
(b)  Upon arrival at the depository, the vehicle shall be impounded and its contents inventoried. 
(c)  The police department shall, within five days after a motor vehicle is impounded, notify the state department of motor vehicles of the impoundment of the motor vehicle, and such notification shall include such information as is available that will enable the department of motor vehicles to identify the registered owner of the vehicle. 
(Code 1995, § 98-196; Ord. No. 2579, § 5, 12-25-1992) 
Sec. 106-262. - Notification of owner and claiming of impounded vehicles. 
(a)  The police department shall give written notice to the owner, secured parties of record, and known lienholders, if any, at least 30 days prior to the date of the sale of the motor vehicle advising such parties of: 
(1)  The complete description of the vehicle and the date and place the vehicle was found or taken into possession; 
(2)  The approximate amount owed for the cost of repair, towing and storage; 
(3)  The location of the vehicle; 
(4)  The time and place that a sale of the vehicle will be held; 
(5)  The right of the owner, secured parties or lienholders to contest the right to sell such vehicle by the filing, within ten days before the date of the sale of the vehicle, of an application for hearing to be conducted before the date of the sale of the vehicle of an application for hearing to be conducted before the judge of the district court or circuit court of the county in which the sale is to be held. The notice required by this section shall be deemed to be given when sent by certified mail, postage prepaid, to the address of the owner, secured party of record, and known lienholder shown on any public filing evidencing such ownership, security interest, or lien; or if none, to any such address ascertained by reasonable effort. 
(b)  If the name and address of the owner, secured parties or lienholders of the vehicle are known or cannot be reasonably ascertained, then the notice required in this section shall be given by publication once a week for two successive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the county in which the sale is to be held. The first publication shall be at least 30 days before the date of sale. 
(c)  The registered owner, or other person who can prove he is entitled to possession of a motor vehicle impounded pursuant to the provisions of this article, may claim the motor vehicle within 30 days of the date of impoundment by presenting himself at the depository and by paying a fee determined by the chief of police to reimburse the city for the reasonable and necessary costs of removing and storing the motor vehicle. The fees for costs of removal and storage shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in a fee schedule maintained in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. The standard towing charges for privately owned vehicles shall be as established by ordinance or resolution of the city council, from time to time. The amount of the charge shall be available for public examination in a fee schedule in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 98-197; Ord. No. 2579, § 6, 12-25-1992) 
Sec. 106-263. - Disposal. 
(a)  If a motor vehicle remains unclaimed after the expiration of 60 days from the date of impoundment, the chief of police shall cause such vehicles to be disposed of in accordance with the procedures established under state statutes, garageman's, materialman's, or mechanic's liens. 
(b)  The proceeds of the sale shall be applied first to the expenses of the sale, and to the costs of removal and storage as expenses of the sale, and to the costs of removal and storage as determined pursuant to section 106-262. Any remaining proceeds from the sale shall be held by the chief of police for six months after the date of the sale and shall be turned over to the person who can prove he held the title to the motor vehicle upon the demand of such person. If at the end of the six months period, no person has claimed the proceeds of the sale, they shall be turned over to the city clerk and treasurer for deposit in the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 98-198; Ord. No. 2579, § 7, 12-25-1992) 
Secs. 106-264-106-289. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - IMPOUNDMENT PROCEDURE 

Sec. 106-290. - Vehicle parked overtime; declared obstruction; removal. 
    Any vehicle parked upon a public street of the city at a place, in a manner or for a length of time prohibited by any section of this chapter or other ordinance of the city is, if unoccupied, declared to be an obstruction in such street and a public nuisance. Any police officer of the city shall cause the vehicle to be removed to and impounded in the depository provided by the city for such purposes. 
(Code 1973, § 22-22; Code 1995, § 98-211) 
Sec. 106-291. - Removal of vehicles; authorization. 
    Whenever any police officer of the city finds upon any public street of the city, or upon any street within the police jurisdiction of the city, any vehicle which he has reasonable cause to believe to be lost, stolen or abandoned, or any vehicle which is or is likely to become an obstruction on a public way, or to be without proper protection by reason of the person in charge or control thereof having been arrested and incarcerated, the officer shall have authority to immediately cause the vehicle to be removed to, and impounded in the depository provided by the city for such purposes. 
(Code 1973, § 22-23; Code 1995, § 98-212) 
Sec. 106-292. - Authority of contract hauler. 
    Where a contract exists between the city and any person, under the terms of which such person agrees to haul and store vehicles for the city in a depository provided for in such contract, the person and his employees, servants or agents, when requested by any police officer of the city to haul or store any vehicle which is upon a public street or alley, shall have the authority to haul or store such vehicle as requested by such officer. 
(Code 1973, § 22-24; Code 1995, § 98-213) 
Sec. 106-293. - Report of removal. 
    Whenever any police officer of the city shall cause the removal and impounding of any vehicle, he shall immediately report to the chief of police in writing, giving a description of such vehicle and the date and cause of removal and impounding of such vehicle. 
(Code 1973, § 22-25; Code 1995, § 98-214) 
Sec. 106-294. - Recovery by owner prior to sale; release. 
    Any owner or person entitled to possession of an impounded vehicle may claim the vehicle at any time before its sale by filing a written claim with the chief of police, upon a form to be provided by the chief. If the chief of police is satisfied that the claimant is the owner or entitled to possession of such vehicle, he shall notify the depository and agent to cause the vehicle to be released to the claimant upon payment of proper charges. 
(Code 1973, § 22-26; Code 1995, § 98-215) 
Sec. 106-295. - Sale of impounded vehicle. 
    When any vehicle has remained in the depository provided by the city for as long as 60 days from its reception and no claim for such vehicle has been made within such period, the chief of police is authorized to release the vehicle to the depository agent in order that it may be sold as provided in the code of the state to recover their charges. 
(Code 1973, § 22-27; Code 1995, § 98-216) 
Sec. 106-296. - Impoundment of vehicles driven by unlicensed drivers. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of law, and except as otherwise provided in this section, a motor vehicle is subject to impoundment as a nuisance if it is driven on a highway or other public roadway in the city, and any of the following conditions exist: The motor vehicle is driven by a person whose driver's license or license privilege is revoked for any reason under the laws of this state or similar laws of any other state or territory, or while his driver's license or driving privilege is suspended as a consequence of a DUI-related offense, including, but not limited to, being adjudicated delinquent or a youthful offender based on a DUI-related offense, or while his driver's license or driving privilege is suspended as a result of failure to comply with the implied consent law of this state or laws of another state, or who has been adjudicated a delinquent child or a youthful offender based on an offense that if the person had been an adult would have been a conviction of driving under the influence of a controlled substance or alcohol or failure to comply with the implied consent law. 
(b)  If a driver is unable to produce a valid driver's license on the demand of the police officer, the vehicle shall be impounded regardless of ownership, unless the police officer is reasonably able, by other means, to verify that the driver is properly licensed. Prior to impounding the vehicle, a police officer shall make a reasonable attempt to verify the license status of a driver who claims to be properly licensed, but who is unable to produce the license on demand of the police officer. A notation of the officer's attempt to verify that the driver is properly licensed shall be noted on the arrest/incident offense report. The driver and occupants of the vehicle will be transported to a place of safety by the impounding officer and an impoundment or tow-in report made with a full inventory of items in the vehicle. 
(c)  A police officer shall not impound a vehicle pursuant to this section if the license of the driver expired within the preceding 90 days and the driver would otherwise have been properly licensed. 
(d)  If the owner of the vehicle or another family member of the owner is present in the vehicle and has a valid driver's license, the vehicle shall not be impounded and towed. 
(e)  If there is a medical necessity jeopardizing life or limb, the law enforcement officer may elect not to impound the vehicle. 
(f)  A vehicle impounded pursuant to this section shall be released if: 
(1)  The registered owner appears at the police department or a representative with written notarized authorization from the registered owner appears, and presents a valid driver's license, a copy of the title, tag receipt, or notarized bill of sale, and a copy of the written authorization, if applicable, to be copied by the police department. 
(2)  If the registered owner does not have a valid driver's license he may bring someone with them who has a verified valid driver's license and the vehicle may be released without written notarized permission upon signing a release. 
(g)  Any owner of a vehicle who suffers any loss due to the impoundment of any vehicle pursuant to this section may recover the amount of the loss from the unlicensed, suspended or revoked driver. 
(h)  The person redeeming the vehicle at the wrecker lot will be responsible for paying the established towing and storage fees, as well as an administrative fee to be forwarded by the wrecker company to the city. 
(i)  Any vehicle impounded that is not redeemed pursuant to this division within 60 days may be sold by the wrecker company for fees owed according to the Alabama Abandoned Motor Vehicle Act (Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-13-1). 
(Ord. No. 3281, §§ 1(b)-1(d), 4-19-2005) 
Secs. 106-297-106-325. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TRUCK ROUTES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit or impose limits on the weight of vehicles on designated streets, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-1-3. 

Sec. 106-326. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Deviating truck means a truck which leaves and departs from a truck route while traveling inside the city. 
    Truck means any vehicle designed or operated for the transportation of property, and whose frame, rack or body has a load capacity of 2,000 or more pounds. 
    Truck route means a way over certain streets, over and along which trucks coming into and going out of the city shall operate. 
(Code 1973, § 22-109; Code 1995, § 98-236) 
Sec. 106-327. - Trucks restricted to truck routes; exceptions. 
(a)  All trucks within the city shall be operated only over and along the truck routes established in this article and on the other designated streets over which truck travel is permitted. 
(b)  This article shall not prohibit: 
(1)  The operation of trucks upon any street where such operation is necessary to the conduct of business at a destination point, provided the streets upon which such traffic is permitted are used until reaching the intersection nearest the destination point. 
(2)  The operation of emergency vehicles upon any street of the city. 
(3)  The operation of trucks owned or operated by the city, public utilities, any contractor or materialman, while engaged in the repair, maintenance or construction of streets, public improvements, or street utilities within the city. 
(4)  The operation of trucks upon any officially established detour in any case where such truck could lawfully be operated upon the street for which such detour is established. 
(Code 1973, § 22-110; Code 1995, § 98-237) 
Sec. 106-328. - Designation of truck routes. 
    The streets or parts of streets described in the city traffic schedule are designated as truck routes. 
(Code 1973, § 22-111; Code 1995, § 98-238) 
Sec. 106-329. - Truck traffic from outside city; deviation by shortest permissible route. 
(a)  Single destination. All trucks entering the city for a destination point in the city shall proceed only over an established truck route and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street upon which such traffic is permitted, nearest to the destination point. Upon leaving the destination point, a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest permissible route. 
(b)  Multiple destinations. All trucks entering the city for multiple destination points shall proceed only over established truck routes and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street upon which such traffic is permitted, nearest to the first destination point. Upon leaving the first destination point a deviating truck shall proceed to other destination points by the shortest direction and only over streets upon which such traffic is permitted. Upon leaving the last destination point, a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest permissible route. 
(Code 1973, § 22-112; Code 1995, § 98-239) 
Sec. 106-330. - Truck traffic from within city. 
(a)  Destinations-Outside city. All trucks, on a trip originating in the city and traveling in the city for a destination point outside the city shall proceed by the shortest direction over streets on which such traffic is permitted to a truck route. 
(b)  Same-Within city. All trucks, on a trip originating in the city, and traveling in the city for destination points in the city shall proceed from the point of origin to the nearest established truck route and over the established truck route to the point thereon nearest the point of destination, thence from the point on the truck route nearest the point of destination by the shortest route to the point of destination. All trucks leaving a first point of destination in the city to another point in the city shall proceed to the nearest established truck route, thence over the truck route to the point nearest the second or latter destination point, thence by the shortest possible route to the point. 
(Code 1973, § 22-113; Code 1995, § 98-240) 
Sec. 106-331. - Maintenance of maps. 
    The city clerk and treasurer shall keep and maintain accurate maps setting out truck routes and streets upon which truck traffic is established and designated as truck routes. The maps shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and treasurer and shall be available for inspection by the public. 
(Code 1973, § 22-115; Code 1995, § 98-241) 
Sec. 106-332. - Maintenance of signs. 
    The chief of police shall cause all truck routes to be clearly marked by appropriate signs. It shall not be a legal defense for violation of this article that the truck routes have not been marked with such clearness as to give warning to any person charged with such violation. 
(Code 1973, § 22-116; Code 1995, § 98-242) 
Sec. 106-333. - Enforcement; duty of police officers. 
    It shall be the duty of police officers on duty observing a motor truck on a street in the city, other than on an established truck route, to stop the truck and inspect the bill of lading, invoice or other papers to determine that the truck is being operated on streets as required by the terms of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 22-117; Code 1995, § 98-243) 
Sec. 106-334. - Presumption of intercity passage. 
    Any person driving a motor truck over any street in the city other than a designated truck route shall be presumed to be passing through the city and not making a local delivery, and unless the driver has a bill of lading or invoice showing a local delivery, it shall be the duty of any police officer apprehending such truck driver to arrest him for violation of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 22-118; Code 1995, § 98-244) 
Secs. 106-335-106-360. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TRAFFIC CALMING DEVICES 

Sec. 106-361. - Policy. 
    This article establishes a policy for the installation of traffic calming devices and establishes certain warranting criteria to be used to determine whether a traffic calming device may be installed along a roadway in the city. 
(Ord. No. 3407, § 1, 6-2-2009) 
Sec. 106-362. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Traffic calming devices means any device installed in the roadway designed to limit vehicle operating speeds and to encourage vehicles to seek alternative routes, including, but not limited to, the following: 
    Rumble strips means a series of small raised pavement undulations, often seen on the approaches to intersections on high speed roadways. The rumble strip is a series of five to seven raised pavement areas, each being eight inches wide and one-half inch high, spaced on ten inch gaps. 
    Speed bumps , also referred to as a speed breaker, means a raised pavement section typically less than one foot wide and three to four inches in height, typically found in commercial parking lots and driveways. The design of speed bumps generally makes them inappropriate for use on the public right-of-way. 
    Speed humps means a raised pavement section approximately 12 to 14 feet long and three inches high. Speed humps typically have the cross section of a section of an arc of a circle, and extend from edge of asphalt paving to edge of asphalt paving on the roadway without obstructing the gutter using a 12-inch taper to the gutter seam. Typical materials for the construction of a spend hump are asphalt, concrete, rubber, and brick. 
    Speed lumps , also known as speed cushions, are a variation of speed humps. Instead of a continuous hump, it is divided into several smaller sections which allows for unobstructed passage of emergency vehicles, buses, trucks and other wide wheelbase vehicles and allows for improved drainage. The gaps are spaced such that only one set of standard vehicle tires will go through the gap while the other set of vehicle tires must go over the hump. 
    Speed tables means devices similar to speed humps, except that the overall length of the table is extended to approximately 22 feet, which allows for a ten- to 12-foot flat area on top of the speed hump. This flat area is sometimes used as an area for pedestrian crossing and is known as a raised crosswalk. 
(Ord. No. 3407, § 2, 6-2-2009) 
Sec. 106-363. - Approval required prior to installation; traffic calming study and criteria. 
    No traffic calming device shall be installed along a roadway in the city without the prior approval of the city council. Prior to the installation of a traffic calming device upon any roadway in the city, there shall be conducted a traffic calming study which may or may not recommend the installation of a traffic calming device based upon the following warranting criteria: 
(1)  Traffic volume criteria. Traffic calming devices will not be considered for roadways which have less than 750 total vehicles traveling in both directions on a daily basis, nor more than 7,500 total vehicles traveling in both directions on a daily basis. 
(2)  Speed criteria. Traffic calming devices will not be considered unless the average travel speed of all vehicles observed is equal to or greater than 35 miles per hour or the 85th percentile travel speeds of all vehicles is equal to or greater than 40 miles per hour. 
(3)  Roadway classification criteria. Traffic calming devices will not be installed on roadways which are classified as a federal aid route according to the current roadway classification map for the Birmingham Study Area as held by the Regional Planning Commission of Greater Birmingham. Traffic calming devices will not be installed on roadways which are classified in the city's major street plan. 
(4)  Roadway geometric criteria. Traffic calming devices will not be installed in the following roadway geometric conditions: 
a.  A horizontal curve or a vertical curve where the visibility of the traffic calming device is restricted, or on an approach to such curves; 
b.  On roadways at any location where the grade exceeds five percent, including the approaches to each traffic calming device installation; 
c.  On roadways more than two lanes wide or less than 18 feet wide; 
d.  On roadways having a posted speed limit of greater than 30 miles per hour; 
e.  On roadways that have a curb and cutter or valley gutter on both sides of the roadway; or 
f.  Where placement of traffic calming devices are impractical due to the location of the public roadway intersections and/or driveways. 
(5)  Accident criteria. Accident patterns shall be studied to determine trends of accidents which: 
a.  Might have been prevented if vehicle operating speeds were generally lower on the subject roadway; or 
b.  Might have been more severe if traffic calming devices were in place. 
There are no criteria for the minimum number of accidents which might have been prevented if operating speeds were generally lower. However, there must have been no more than two accidents in the three-year period which would have been possibly made more severe if traffic calming devices were in place. 
(6)  Traffic diversion criteria. An estimate of the diversion of traffic to other residential roadways which would result if traffic calming devices were installed on the roadway, which is the subject of the complaint, shall be performed. Traffic calming devices will not be installed if the traffic diversion would result in a traffic increase on any other residential roadway of 50 percent or more for that roadway. 
(7)  Emergency access and route criteria. Traffic calming devices shall not be permitted on roadways which serve as a primary route for emergency vehicles (defined as an average of at least five emergency vehicles a day or an emergency call) or a primary access route for emergency vehicles into an area of 100 or more residential dwelling units or ten or more businesses. 
(8)  Public involvement criteria. The preferable method of public involvement for the installation of traffic calming devices is through an established homeowner's association. In the absence of a homeowner's association, or if the geographic area encompassed by the homeowner's association does not cover the full impact are of the proposed traffic calming device installation, a geographic area determined by the city shall be considered in the public involvement process. Public input may be gathered by either ballot or petition. The installation of traffic calming devices must be approved ay a 75 percent majority of all dwelling units within the confines of either the homeowner's association or geographic impact area as determined by the city. In any case, only one vote or signature on a petition per dwelling unit will be allowed. 
(Ord. No. 3407, § 3, 6-2-2009) 
Sec. 106-364. - Limitations on placement. 
    The following shall be limitations upon the use or installation of certain traffic calming devices in the city: 
(1)  Speed bumps. Because of their design, speed bumps are generally considered inappropriate for use on the public right-of-way. 
(2)  Speed humps. Speed humps shall not be placed in the following locations: 
a.  On horizontal and vertical curves, or the approaches to such curves; 
b.  On a grade of five percent or greater, or the approach to such grades; 
c.  Adjacent to a driveway; 
d.  Within 250 feet of a traffic signal; 
e.  Within 50 feet of a public roadway intersection; 
f.  Over or near manholes; 
g.  Adjacent to fire hydrants; or 
h.  Immediately upstream of drainage inlets. 
(3)  Rumble strips. Rumble strips are not recommended for use in traffic calming situations. Any recommendation calling for their use shall be accompanied by a compelling reason. 
(4)  Striping, signage and pavement markings. Any recommendation to install a traffic calming device shall include recommendations for appropriate striping, signage and other pavement markings to delineate the traffic calming device. 
(Ord. No. 3407, § 4, 6-2-2009) 
Secs. 106-365-106-380. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - AUTOMATED TRAFFIC SAFETY SYSTEM[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3562, §§ 1-17, adopted May 16, 2017, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as art. VIII, §§ 106-381-106-397 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 106-381. - [Title.] 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Bessemer Automated Traffic Safety System Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-382. - Findings. 
    The City Council of the City of Bessemer, Alabama makes the following findings as the basis for the undertakings on its part herein contained: 
(1)  Vehicles that violate traffic control regulations and signage have been and are a dangerous problem in the City of Bessemer, Alabama.
