(2)  Studies have found that automated traffic camera enforcement in a municipal area is a highly accurate method for detecting violations of traffic control regulations and signage and is very effective in reducing the number of traffic violations and decreasing the number of traffic accidents, deaths, and injuries. 
(3)  Current Alabama law provides that failing to stop and remain stopped at a traffic-control signal which is emitting a steady red signal is a criminal misdemeanor. Current Alabama law also provides that failing to abide by traffic signage or speed limits is also a criminal misdemeanor. Under Alabama law one who commits any of these misdemeanors is subject to prosecution only if the misdemeanor was witnessed by either a duly empowered police officer or other witness who makes a verified complaint to a sworn magistrate. 
(4)  A reduction in the number of drivers exceeding speed limits and running red lights and stop signs through a program utilizing photographic evidence and enforcement through the imposition of civil fines will help promote and protect the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the City of Bessemer. Act Number 2016-323 duly enacted by the Legislature of Alabama granted to the City of Bessemer to establish a program to enforce traffic signal violations, stop sign violations, and speeding violations by the use of photographic evidence and the imposition of civil fines. 
(5)  By providing for the use of automated traffic cameras in traffic signal enforcement, stop sign enforcement, and speed limit enforcement in the City of Bessemer, the city council expects to decrease the occurrence in the city of traffic signal violations, stop sign violations, and speeding violations. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 2, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-383. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
    City means the City of Bessemer, Alabama. 
    City council means the governing body of the City of Bessemer, Alabama. 
    Civil violation means a violation of the provisions of this article, the penalty for which violation shall be the payment of a fine, the enforcement of which will not be otherwise permissible. 
    Fine means the monetary amount assessed by the City of Bessemer pursuant to this article for a determination of civil liability for a traffic signal violation, stop sign violation, or speeding violation, which may include administrative hearing costs associated with the infraction. 
    Intersection means the place or area where two or more streets intersect. 
    Owner means the owner or owner of record of a motor vehicle as shown on the motor vehicle registration and title records of the Alabama Department of Revenue or the analogous department or agency of another state or nation. The term shall not include motor vehicles displaying dealer license plates, in which event "owner" shall mean the person to whom the vehicle is assigned for use; nor shall the term include the owner of any stolen motor vehicle, in which event "owner" shall mean the person who is guilty of stealing the motor vehicle and who was operating the vehicle at the time of the civil violation. 
    Photographic stop sign traffic enforcement system means a system that: 
(1)  Consists of a still camera system and full motion video camera system (30 frames per second or greater); and 
(2)  Is capable of producing at least two separate recorded images, i.e.: 
a.  An image of the rear of a vehicle prior to entering the intersection; and 
b.  An image of the rear of the vehicle showing the license plate. 
    Photographic traffic signal enforcement system means a system that: 
(1)  Consists of a still camera system and full motion video camera system (30 frames per second or greater) installed to work in conjunction with an electrically operated traffic control signal; and 
(2)  Is capable of producing at least three separate recorded images, i.e.: 
a.  An image of the rear of a vehicle prior to entering the intersection on a red signal; 
b.  An image of the rear of the vehicle showing the license plate; and 
c.  An image of the rear of the vehicle in or through the intersection when the red signal is visible. 
(3)  All images must be synchronized to a single time source and provide the elapsed time between the first, second, and third photographs or digital images specified in this subparagraph b. 
    Photographic vehicle speed enforcement system means a system that: 
(1)  Has a mobile or fixed electronic speed enforcement system, or both, which is certified and in compliance with the rules of the Federal Communications Commission; and 
(2)  Is capable of producing two or more recorded images, at least one depicting the license plate attached to the rear of a vehicle being operated at a speed in excess of the applicable speed limit. 
    Recorded image means an image recorded by the system depicting the rear of a vehicle which is automatically recorded as a photograph or digital image, which also depicts the recorded speed, date, location, and time of the recorded image. 
    Speed limit means the established maximum speed limit on a given roadway prescribed by law. 
    Speeding violation means any violation of a motor vehicle at a speed that exceeds the legal maximum speed limits set forth in or adopted pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 32-5A-170 to 32-5A-178, inclusive, or of any combination thereof; provided, however, that speed limits set by action of the Bessemer City Council, if any, shall supersede the limits set in Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 32-5A-170 to 32-5A-178, inclusive. A speeding violation shall be a civil violation as defined in this article. 
    Stop sign means a fixed sign of the type authorized by the Alabama Department of Transportation which requires a vehicle to come to a complete stop before entering the intersection. 
    Stop sign violation means any violation of Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-112, wherein a vehicle proceeds into an intersection after failing to stop at a clearly marked stop line. A stop sign violation shall be a civil violation as defined in this article. 
    Traffic control signal means any device, whether manually, electrically, or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and permitted to proceed as defined in Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-1-1.1. 
    Traffic signal violation means any violation of Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 32-5A-31, 32-5A-32, or 32-5A-35, or of any combination thereof, wherein a vehicle proceeds into a signalized intersection at a time while the traffic-control signal for that vehicle's lane of travel is emitting a steady red signal. A traffic signal violation shall be a civil violation as defined in this article. 
    Trained technician means a sworn law enforcement officer or a person certified by the Alabama Peace Officers' Standards and Training Commission (APOSTC), employed or contracted by the city, who has received instruction and training in the proper use of the photographic traffic signal enforcement system, the photographic stop sign enforcement system, and the photographic vehicle speed enforcement system used by the city, the city's traffic engineer or the city's designee. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 3, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-384. - Imposition of fine and/or costs for civil violations of this article; signage required where photographic enforcement systems are located. 
(a)  (1)  Fines collected pursuant to this article for traffic signal violations and stop sign violations shall be $110.00. 
(2)  a.  Except for speeding violations that occur in school zones, fines collected pursuant to this article for speeding violations shall not exceed the fines as shown in the following table. The following fine shall apply to the owner when captured by the photographic vehicle speed enforcement system where the vehicle was recorded as traveling at the following speeds over the speed limit: 
Speed over Speed Limit Fine 5 through 10 mph $ 60.00 Greater than 10 mph through 15 mph 110.00 Greater than 15 mph through 20 mph 135.00 Greater than 20 mph 160.00  
b.  The fines stated above in subsection (a)(2)a. shall be doubled if that violation occurs and was electronically recorded within a segment of the roadway or intersection designated with signage or signals as a school zone only during school hours when school is in session and one hour before and after school hours. 
(3)  The first $10.00 of each fine authorized by this article and collected by the city or its designee shall be paid to the Alabama Criminal Justice Information Center as compensation for record keeping with respect to violation notices issued pursuant to this article in accordance with Act No. 2016-323 of the Legislature of Alabama. 
(4)  Administrative hearing costs shall be assessed only in contested cases. A person who is found liable after an administrative hearing or who requests an administrative hearing and thereafter fails to appear at the time and place of the hearing shall pay the fine amount plus any late fee in addition to a $30.00 administrative hearing fee. If the person is found not liable at the administrative hearing, the $30.00 administrative hearing fee will not be assessed or any fine and fee paid related to that citation shall be refunded. 
(b)  The city or its designee may place photographic traffic signal enforcement systems, photographic stop sign enforcement systems, and photographic vehicle speed enforcement systems at locations within the city without notice of the specific location and may change locations without public notice. 
(c)  The city or its designee shall post a sign or signs at each intersection at which a photographic traffic signal enforcement system or photographic stop sign enforcement system is located informing motorists that such devices are in operation at the intersection. The city or its designee shall post a sign or signs along each roadway or street at which a photographic vehicle speed enforcement system is located informing motorists that such a device is in operation. 
(d)  The city may contract with a vendor to perform services authorized by this article. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 4, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-385. - Enforcement; procedures. 
(a)  The city or its designee shall mail a notice of violation by U.S. mail to the owner of the motor vehicle which is recorded by the photographic traffic signal enforcement system, photographic stop sign enforcement system, or photographic vehicle speed enforcement system while committing a traffic signal violation, stop sign violation, or speeding violation. The notice shall be sent not later than the 30th day after the date the traffic signal violation, stop sign violation, or speeding violation is recorded to: 
(1)  The owner's address as shown on the records of the Alabama Department of Revenue; or 
(2)  If the vehicle is registered in another state or country, to the owner's address as shown on the motor vehicle registration records of the department or agency of the other state or country analogous to the Alabama Department of Revenue. 
(b)  A notice of violation issued under this article shall contain the following: 
(1)  Description of the violation; 
(2)  The date, time, and location of the violation; 
(3)  A copy of a recorded image of the vehicle; 
(4)  The amount of the fine to be imposed for the violation; 
(5)  The date by which the fine must be paid; 
(6)  A statement that the person named in the notice of violation may pay the fine in lieu of appearing at an administrative hearing; 
(7)  Information that informs the person named in the notice of violation: 
a.  Of the right to contest the imposition of the fine in an administrative hearing; 
b.  Of the manner and time in which to contest the imposition of the fine; and 
c.  That failure to pay the fine or to contest liability is an admission of liability; 
(8)  A statement that a recorded image is evidence in a proceeding for the imposition of a fine; 
(9)  In the case of a motor vehicle rental or leasing company, the procedure for transferring liability to the renter or lessee and a request for the name, address, and driver's license number of the renter or lessee; 
(10)  A statement that failure to pay the fine within the time allowed shall result in the imposition of a late penalty not exceeding $25.00; and 
(11)  Any other information deemed necessary by the city or its designee. 
(c)  A notice of violation under this article is presumed to have been received on the tenth day after the date the notice of violation is placed in the United States mail. 
(d)  A fine imposed pursuant to this article shall be paid within 30 days of the tenth day after the date the notice of violation is mailed. 
(e)  It shall be within the discretion of the trained technician to determine which of the recorded traffic signal violations, stop sign violations and speeding violations are to be enforced based upon the quality and legibility of the recorded image. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 5, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-386. - Administrative adjudication hearing. 
(a)  An administrative hearing officer appointed by the mayor of the city is vested with the power and jurisdiction to conduct administrative hearings of civil violations provided for in this article. In conducting administrative hearings of violations of this article, the hearing officer shall have the powers and duties conferred by Act No. 2016-323 of the Legislature of Alabama. 
(b)  A person who receives a notice of violation may contest the imposition of the fine by submitting a request for an administrative hearing of the civil violation, in writing, within 15 days of the tenth day after the date the notice of violation is mailed. Upon receipt of a timely request, the city or its designee shall notify the person of the date and time of the administrative hearing by U.S. mail. 
(c)  Failure to pay a fine or to contest liability in a timely manner is an admission of liability in the full amount of the fine assessed in the notice of violation. 
(d)  Any fine imposed pursuant to this article shall not be collected if, after a hearing, the administrative hearing officer appointed by the mayor of the city enters a finding of no liability. 
(e)  If an administrative hearing is requested, the city shall have the burden of proving the traffic signal violation, stop sign violation, or speeding violation by a preponderance of the evidence. The reliability of the photographic traffic signal enforcement system or photographic stop sign enforcement system used to produce the recorded image of the violation may be attested to by affidavit of a trained technician. An affidavit of a trained technician that alleges a violation based on an inspection of the pertinent recorded image is admissible in a proceeding under this article and is evidence of the facts contained in the affidavit. 
(f)  The notice of violation, the recorded and reproduced images of the traffic signal violation, stop sign violation, or speeding violation, regardless of the media on which they are recorded, accompanied by a certification of authenticity of a trained technician, and evidence of ownership of a vehicle as shown by copies or summaries of official records shall be admissible into evidence without foundation unless the administrative hearing officer finds there is an indication of untrustworthiness, in which case the city shall be given a reasonable opportunity to lay an evidentiary foundation. 
(g)  All other matters of evidence and procedure not specifically addressed in this article shall be subject to the rules of evidence and the rules of procedure as they apply in the small claims courts of this state, except that on any petition to Jefferson County Circuit Court for trial de novo, the evidence and procedures shall be as for any civil case in the district court except as otherwise provided in this article and Act No. 2016-323 of the Legislature of Alabama. 
(h)  A person who is found liable for a civil violation pursuant to this article after an administrative hearing or who requests a hearing and thereafter fails to appear at the time and place of the hearing is liable for administrative hearing costs and fees set out herein in addition to the amount of the fine assessed for the violation. A person who is found liable for a civil violation after an administrative hearing shall pay the fine and costs within ten days of the hearing. 
(i)  Whenever payment of a fine is owed to the city, the amount of the fine as set by this article may not be increased, decreased, or abated by the city, and the liability may be satisfied only by payment. 
(j)  It shall be an affirmative defense to the imposition of civil liability under this article, to be proven by a preponderance of the evidence, that: 
(1)  The traffic control signal was not in proper position and sufficiently visible to an ordinarily observant person; 
(2)  The operator of the motor vehicle was acting in compliance with the lawful order or direction of a police officer; 
(3)  The operator of the motor vehicle violated the instructions of the traffic control signal so as to yield the right-of-way to an immediately approaching authorized emergency vehicle; 
(4)  The motor vehicle was being operated as an authorized emergency vehicle under Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 32-5A-7 and 32-5-213, and that the operator was acting in compliance with those chapters; 
(5)  The motor vehicle was stolen or being operated by a person other than the owner of the vehicle without the effective consent of the owner; 
(6)  The license plate depicted in the recorded image of the violation was a stolen plate and being displayed on a motor vehicle other than the motor vehicle for which the plate had been issued; 
(7)  The presence of ice, snow, unusual amounts of rain, or other unusually hazardous road conditions existed that would make compliance with this article more dangerous under the circumstances than noncompliance; or 
(8)  There was no sign installed as required by this article near the location at which the violation allegedly occurred warning that a photographic traffic signal enforcement system was being used. 
(k)  To establish that at the time of the violation the motor vehicle was a stolen vehicle or the license plate displayed on the motor vehicle was a stolen plate, the owner must submit proof acceptable to the hearing officer that the theft of the vehicle or license plate, prior to the time of the violation or promptly following the theft, had been timely reported to the appropriate law enforcement agency. 
(l)  No person who rents to another person or is the lessor of a motor vehicle pursuant to a written lease agreement, nor any affiliates thereof, shall be liable for a photographic stop sign traffic enforcement system, photographic vehicle speed enforcement system, or photographic traffic signal enforcement system violation involving such motor vehicle during the period of the rental or lease, provided that upon request of the city or its designee received within 60 days after the violation occurred, such person provides to the city within 30 days after receipt of such request the name and address of the renter or lessee of such motor vehicle. The driver's license number of the renter or lessee may be subsequently specifically requested by the city or its designee if needed for the enforcement of this article. Upon the provision by the lessor, its affiliate or its designee, of the information as described in this subsection, the city or its designee may issue a new notice of violation to the renter or lessee of the vehicle in the same manner it would issue a notice of violation to an owner pursuant to section 106-385, except that the notice will be sent no later than 30 days after receiving the renter's or lessee's information from the person, or any affiliate thereof, who rented or leased the motor vehicle. The renter or lessee may be held liable for the violation in the same manner that an owner may be held liable pursuant hereto. 
(m)  Notwithstanding anything in this act to the contrary, a person who fails to pay the amount of a fine or to contest liability in a timely manner is nevertheless entitled to an administrative hearing on the violation if: 
(1)  The person files a sworn affidavit with the hearing officer stating the date on which the person received the notice of violation that was mailed to the person, if such notice was not received by the tenth day after same was mailed as set out in subsection (a) of section 106-385; or 
(2)  Within 15 days of the date of actual receipt of such notice, such person requests an administrative hearing. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 6, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-387. - Order of hearing officer. 
(a)  Following an administrative hearing, the administrative hearing officer shall issue an order stating: 
(1)  Whether the person charged with the civil violation is liable for the violation; and 
(2)  If the person is found to be liable, the amount of the fine assessed against the person, along with the fees and costs provided for herein. 
(b)  Orders issued under this section may be filed in the office of the judge of probate in any county in Alabama, and shall operate as a judicial lien in the same manner and with the same weight and effect as any other civil judgment filed therein. 
(c)  A person who is found liable after an administrative hearing may challenge that finding of civil liability in the Jefferson County Circuit Court, by filing a petition for judicial review with the Jefferson County Circuit Court. The petition for judicial review must be filed not later than the 14th day after the date on which the administrative hearing officer entered the finding of civil liability. The filing of a petition for judicial review shall stay the enforcement of the fine. After a petition for judicial review has been filed, civil liability will be determined by the circuit court by trial de novo pursuant to the jurisdiction granted in Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-11-30. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 7, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-388. - Procedures for judicial review. 
    The circuit court hearing a petition for judicial review shall utilize the procedures applicable to proceedings in the Jefferson County District Court with the following qualifications: 
(1)  The proceedings shall retain their civil nature with the circuit court applying the preponderance of the evidence standard; 
(2)  If the person is adjudicated by the circuit court to be responsible for payment of the fine, circuit court costs shall be owed by the person adjudicated responsible, with 100 percent of those court costs collected to be retained by the circuit court, which costs shall be calculated in the same manner as court costs for criminal appeals from the Jefferson County District Court, provided that, in the event the circuit court finds the person petitioning for judicial review to not be responsible, any fine or fee paid, related to that citation, shall be refunded by the city; 
(3)  Regardless of the civil nature of the proceedings, the circuit court may assign case numbers as for criminal appeals or civil appeals and place the appeals on criminal dockets in the same manner as criminal appeals from the Jefferson County District Court or on civil dockets in the same manner as civil appeals from the Jefferson County District Court; 
(4)  The circuit court shall sit as trier of both fact and law in the civil proceedings in the circuit court; and 
(5)  The city attorney shall represent the city in the circuit court proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 8, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-389. - Clarity of license plate image required to issue notice of violation. 
    In the event the evidence produced by a photographic traffic signal enforcement system, a photographic stop sign enforcement system or a photographic vehicle speed enforcement system does not produce an image of the license plate with sufficient clarity for a trained technician to determine the identity of the owner, and if the identity thereof cannot otherwise be reliably established, then no notice of violation may be issued pursuant to this article. If, however, a notice of violation is issued, to the degree constitutionally allowed, those issues related to the identity of the vehicle or its owner shall affect the weight to be accorded the evidence and shall not affect its admissibility. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 9, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-390. - Late fees; effect of liability for violations of ordinance. 
    Late fees not exceeding $25.00 shall attach to untimely paid fines that are authorized pursuant this article and imposed pursuant hereto. No person may be arrested or incarcerated for nonpayment of a fine or late fee. No record of an adjudication of civil violation made under this article shall be listed, entered, or reported on any criminal record or driving record, whether the record is maintained by the city or an outside agency. An adjudication of civil violation provided for in this article shall not be considered a conviction for any purpose, shall not be used to increase or enhance punishment for any subsequent offense of a criminal nature, and shall not be considered a moving violation. The fact that a person is held liable or responsible for a fine for a traffic signal violation, stop sign violation or speeding violation shall not be used as evidence that the person was guilty of negligence or other culpable conduct, and as evidence in any other proceedings if it is or becomes admissible under the rules of evidence applicable therein. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 10, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-391. - Collection actions. 
    The city attorney or his designee is authorized to file civil actions to enforce the provisions of this article, including but not limited to pursuing collection actions to obtain judgments for unpaid fines, fees or both, imposed under this article, by lawful means to secure payments of the same. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 11, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-392. - Statistical data required. 
(a)  The city shall keep statistical data regarding the effectiveness of photographic traffic signal enforcement systems or photographic stop sign enforcement systems in reducing traffic-control device violations and intersectional collisions and shall communicate the data on an annual basis to the Alabama Department of Transportation and the Alabama Criminal Justice Information Center. 
(b)  The city shall keep statistical data regarding the effectiveness of automated photographic speeding enforcement systems in reducing speeding violations and collisions and shall communicate the data on an annual basis to the Alabama Department of Transportation and the Alabama Criminal Justice Information Center. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 12, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-393. - Placement and timing of traffic signals. 
    The placement of control devices in the city and timing of yellow lights and red light clearance intervals shall conform to the most recent edition of the Traffic Engineering Handbook. It shall be presumed that such devices and timing are in compliance with this section unless the contrary is shown by a preponderance of the evidence. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 13, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-394. - Exclusion of civil remedy. 
    No fine may be imposed and no adjudication of liability for a civil violation may be made under this article if the operator of the vehicle was arrested or was issued a citation and notice to appear by a sworn police officer for a criminal violation of any portion of Code of Ala. 1975, art. 2, ch. 5A, tit. 32, including, but not limited to, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 32-5A-31, 32-5A-34, and 32-5A-35, or any other municipal ordinance which embraces and incorporates the statutes contained in that article, and which occurred simultaneously with and under the same set of circumstances that were recorded by the photographic traffic signal enforcement system, the photographic stop sign enforcement system, or the photographic vehicle speed enforcement system. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 14, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-395. - Impartiality of trained technician. 
    Under no circumstances shall the salary or other compensation of the trained technician be related to the number of notices of violation issued or amount of fines collected. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 15, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-396. - [Not to invoke provisions.] 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed as invoking the provisions of the Alabama Administrative Procedure Act, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 41-22-1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 16, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 106-397. - Uses of penalties, fines and fees collected. 
    The penalties, fines, and fees collected from the imposition of civil liability under this article shall be deposited into the Bessemer Traffic Safety Fund Account established by the city council. Funds deposited into this traffic safety fund shall be expended first for the costs of the system for payment to the vendor/operator of the system, public relations, and general implementation of the program. The remaining funds shall be used for the following purposes, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Traffic or pedestrian public safety programs; 
(2)  Transportation planning; 
(3)  The construction, reconstruction, maintenance widening, alteration and improvement of public roads, bridges, streets and other public ways, including payment of the principal and interest on any securities at any time issued by the city pursuant to law in connection with the construction, reconstruction, maintenance widening, alteration and improvement of public roads, bridges, streets and other public ways; 
(4)  Intersection safety improvements; 
(5)  Driver education; 
(6)  Police officers dedicated to traffic safety; or 
(7)  Projects or programs subject to the joint written determination by the mayor of the city and the city council, but only if such expenditures are public safety related. 
(Ord. No. 3562, § 17, 5-16-2017) 
Chapter 110 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Public utilities generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-50-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 110-1. - Adoption of city utilities consumer handbook. 
    The most current edition of the Bessemer Utilities Consumer Handbook, as approved by the mayor and council, is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated herein as if fully set out in this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 102-1) 
Sec. 110-2. - Adoption of state standards for public utilities. 
    The state highway department standards for accommodating utilities on highway rights-of-way and any and all amendments thereto are adopted by this reference and made a part of this chapter as set out in full in this section, as standards for use by the city for accommodating utilities on roads and streets under the jurisdiction of the city on those roads and streets which have or will involve the expenditure of state or federal highway funds. 
(Code 1973, § 23-9; Code 1995, § 102-2) 
Sec. 110-3. - Sale or transfer of city-owned utilities; voters approval. 
    The city council shall not sell, trade or transfer any or all of the utilities which are now owned by the city or which hereafter may become the property of the city, unless such proposal of sale or transfer has first been submitted to the qualified voters of the city and unless a majority of the voters have approved any such proposal or sell or transfer any of the utilities owned by the city or any part thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 23-10; Code 1995, § 102-3) 
Sec. 110-4. - License tax on sellers of electric current outside city limits. 
(a)  Each person engaged in the business of selling electric current or energy outside the city limits but within the police jurisdiction thereof, shall be charged a license tax in an amount equal to 11/2 percent of the gross receipts derived during the preceding calendar year from the sale of electrical current or energy to consumers, users or distributors thereof, residing or having a place of business outside the city limits, but within the police jurisdiction of the city, when such current or energy after sale thereof at any place, is consumed or used outside the corporate limits, but within the police jurisdiction of the city by such consumers or users, or is distributed from any point outside the city limits but within the police jurisdiction of the city by such distributors. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the term "gross receipts" shall have the same meaning as defined in section 22-2. 
(Code 1973, § 10-79; Code 1995, § 102-4) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to and maximum amount of license tax municipality may annually assess and collect from utility doing business in the municipality, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-51-90.2(f), 11-51-129. 
Sec. 110-5. - Adoption of utility rate charges and service fees. 
(a)  The rules, regulations and rate charges of Bessemer Electric and Water Service shall be reviewed and adjusted each year on the first day of February, 2017 and every year thereafter, based on the consumer price index (CPI) of the United States Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor Statistics for all urban consumers, using the October CPI of each preceding year as the base denominator (i.e. October 2016 is used to calculate for 2016-2017), and are hereby adopted by the city council to be effective as of February 1, 2017 and each year thereafter. 
(b)  A copy of the rules, regulations and rate charges of Bessemer Electric and Water Service are available for public examination in deposit and rate schedules as maintained in the office of the city clerk and as published online at www.bessemerutilities.com or any other approved online or print medium. 
(c)  As of February 1, 2017, the following comprises the Bessemer Electric and Water Service Deposit, Rate and Service Fee Schedule and is stated fully herein: 
Exhibit A-"Bessemer Electric and Water Service Rate Charges and Service Fees Schedule" is attached hereto and is incorporated by reference as if stated fully herein. 
(Code 1995, §§ 102-42, 102-63; Ord. No. 2425, § II, 3-15-1988; Ord. No. 2582, § 1, 1-19-1993; Ord. No. 3134, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 3561, § 1, 5-2-2017) 
Sec. 110-6. - Deposit. 
(a)  All residential or commercial accounts for utility service(s) require a deposit and service fee for each service regardless of the number of accounts or properties the customer has with Bessemer Electric and Water Service. 
(b)  The minimum deposits required for utility service shall be established and comprised in the Bessemer Electric and Water Service Rate Charges and Service Fee Schedule as stated in section 110-5(c) and under the instructions provided in section 110-50 "deposit policy." 
(Code 1995, §§ 102-42, 102-63; Ord. No. 2425, § II, 3-15-1988; Ord. No. 2582, § 1, 1-19-1993; Ord. No. 3134, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 3561, § 2, 5-2-2017) 
Secs. 110-7-110-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER AND ELECTRIC SERVICE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 110-31-110-48. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SERVICE POLICIES AND PROCEDURES 

Sec. 110-49. - Service policies. 
(a)  Upon application for service or upon request, a utility service customer will be given a copy of the customer information handbook which contains a summary of the service, deposit and billing; a copy and explanation of current rates, instructions on how to read the electric and water meters, including a diagram of the meters; and a copy of the customer collection and account review procedure. 
(b)  Upon request a customer will receive a statement of his monthly kilowatt hours (kwh) consumption for the prior 12-month period. 
(c)  Notice of rate schedules, rate schedule changes, consumption information, and service policies will be given to the public by local newspapers or public service announcements on radio or television or publication online at www.bessemerutilities.com. 
(d)  After receipt of the required deposit and service fee(s), utility service will begin the following day from the date of customer's application for electric or water service. Same day service is available for an additional fee and will be charged for each service. 
(e)  If a customer requests that utility service be restored after said service has been discontinued or disconnected, an additional reconnection fee will be charged; and the customer may be required to post an additional deposit prior to service reconnection. 
(Code 1995, § 102-41; Ord. No. 2425, § I, 3-15-1988; Ord. No. 3561, § 3, 5-2-2017) 
Sec. 110-50. - Deposit policy. 
(a)  For a new customer, a presently disconnected customer, or a return customer, Bessemer Electric and Water Service requires a deposit to establish electric, water and sewer utility service, prior to providing service and to guarantee final bill payment. In addition, when service is upgraded or renewed the current deposit amount for water and electric must be also upgraded. This includes account name changes and reconnects. 
(b)  For residential water customers only. All residential customers will pay at least a one month deposit of the residential class average monthly bill of the past 12 months or the minimum deposit amount as provided in the Bessemer Electric and Water Service Rate Charge and Service Fee Schedule, whichever is greater. Such deposit may be sent by separate bill or included in the customer's first monthly billing but payment is required prior to receiving service. If such deposit is not made at the time specified, Bessemer Electric and Water Service may withhold service. If service is disconnected for non-payment, Bessemer Electric Service reserves the right to increase the deposit up to twice the average monthly bill for the actual billing location prior to re-initiation of service, and service shall not be reconnected until said deposit is paid. 
(c)  Minimum deposit for residential water customers only. A minimum deposit as determined in the Bessemer Electric and Water Service Rate Charge and Service Fee Schedule is required for meter sizes less than one inch. For meter sizes of one inch or larger, the deposit will be no less than two times the minimum deposit charge for each meter or the average estimated usage, whichever is greater. 
(d)  Minimum deposit for residential electric customers only. A minimum deposit of $75.00 or as determined in the Bessemer Electric and Water Service Rate Charge and Service Fee Schedule, whichever is greater, is required for residential electric customers. 
(e)  For commercial customers. All commercial customers will pay a two-month deposit of the average monthly bill for the billing location as determined over the past 12-month period. Where a billing history does not exist, the deposit will be estimated based on projected energy loading or usage for the customer. Such deposit may be sent by separate bill or included in the customer's first monthly billing. If such deposit is not made at the time specified, Bessemer Electric and Water Service may withhold service. If service is disconnected for non-payment, Bessemer Electric and Water Service reserves the right to increase the deposit up to three times the average monthly bill for the actual billing location prior to re-initiation of service, and service shall not be reconnected until said deposit is paid. 
(f)  Deposits shall accrue interest annually at the rate, if any, as determined by the deposit holding account. Such interest shall be paid annually, calculated to December 1 of each year for the time such deposit was held by the utility, unless such period is less than one month. Said interest, if any, will be paid by credit to the customer's account on the December billing. 
(g)  If any customer's account is no longer in good standing and frequently becomes past due, Bessemer Electric and Water Service may require an additional deposit should the customer's usage increase sufficiently to warrant an additional deposit. 
(h)  Upon disconnection or discontinuation of service, the customer's deposit, where available, including any interest accrued shall be credited to their final bill. Any remaining deposit balance will be returned to the forwarding address provided by the customer at time of service disconnection (within approximately four to six weeks). If deposit balance remains unclaimed for more than one year from service disconnection, said deposit will be turned over to the office of the Alabama State Treasurer, Unclaimed Property Division. 
(Code 1995, § 102-42; Ord. No. 2425, § II, 3-15-1988; Ord. No. 3561, § 4, 5-2-2017) 
Sec. 110-51. - Billing. 
(a)  Meters will be read as nearly as possible the same day each month or the same day each quarter. 
(b)  Each month will be divided into eight billing cycles and bills will be mailed within eight calendar days from the day the first account is read for that billing cycle. 
(c)  Bills will be due no less than 15 days after bills are mailed. 
(d)  Bills will contain current meter readings, amount used, amount of charges for each service, the date the bill is due, the amount before the late payment charge, the amount of the late payment charge, and the amount including the late charge. 
(e)  A late payment charge will be added to each bill after the due date. A late payment charge of five percent on electric and ten percent on water of the current bill charged will be added to the customer's current balance. 
(f)  Payments received by mail after the due date will not be charged a late charge provided the U.S. postmark is on or before the due date regardless as to when the payment is actually received. 
(g)  If the due date is on a Sunday or holiday, the following day will be considered a day of grace if the payment is made in the office and not in the night depository. 
(h)  A notice will be mailed no earlier than two business days after the due date advising the customer that their bill has not been paid. This notice will advise the customer that the late charge has been added and that an additional ten days has been granted. If the bill is not paid, service will be discontinued. Such notice shall contain instructions on how to apply for a hearing if the bill is disputed or if the customer is in financial distress and unable to pay the bill. 
(i)  If the customer fails to respond either with payment or by notifying the utility, disputing the amount of the bill, or by advising the office of the customer's inability to pay, service will be discontinued as scheduled. 
(j)  If the customer disputes the amount owed or the right of Bessemer Electric and Water Service to collect or is unable to pay the bill, then the customer can follow the instructions set out in section 102-44. 
(k)  Bessemer Electric and Water Service evaluates weather conditions daily through the National Weather Service at www.weather.gov, which is a component of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and is the operating unit of the U.S. Department of Commerce, and in the event that the forecasted high temperature is expected to exceed 98 degrees Fahrenheit (F) or is expected to be below 32 degrees Fahrenheit (F) on that day, Bessemer Electric and Water Service will postpone the disconnection of service of residential customers for non-payment. During such extreme weather events where disconnection is postponed due to weather conditions, the postponement will not extend beyond the extreme weather condition, and the customer will be billed and is responsible for any utility used during this period. 
(l)  Customers with life threatening medical conditions may provide a letter from a medical doctor or nurse practitioner licensed to practice in the State of Alabama and submit it to Bessemer Electric and Water Service documenting his/her life threatening medical condition. The letter must include a signature from an attending physician or nurse practitioner affirming that the disconnection of electricity would create a medical emergency and possibly death. It is the responsibility of the customer to ensure that the form is on file with the Bessemer Electric and Water Service. A life threatening medical condition does not relieve a customer from its obligation to pay for electrical service, including any late fees incurred or other applicable charges. Upon acceptance of the form by Bessemer Electric and Water Service, the disconnection will be postponed for 30 days from the original scheduled disconnection date. Bessemer Electric and Water Service will only grant this postponement of termination two times in a 12-month period for the life threatening medical conditions. If full payment of the past due amount including all late fees is not received by the end of the 30-day postponement period, electric or water service will be terminated on the next available date. The customer will be billed and is responsible for any utility used during this period. 
(Code 1995, § 102-43; Ord. No. 2425, § III, 3-15-1988; Ord. No. 3561, § 5, 5-2-2017) 
Sec. 110-52. - Account review and collection. 
(a)  This shall be the primary document from which specific procedures and guidelines governing all aspects of the account review and collection function of Bessemer Utilities are drawn and shall be the statement of basic policy which governs all Bessemer Utilities account review and collection activities. 
(b)  This policy is based on the premise that it shall be the duty and responsibility of Bessemer Utilities to maintain customer accounts in such a manner that the investment made in these public utility agencies, owned over the years by the city, may be protected and maintained in trust for all past, present, and future citizens and customers and in such a manner that current customers may be protected against possible inequities arising from the failure of persons to pay bills. 
(c)  Due process shall be offered customers of Bessemer Utilities through notification that both a customer collections procedure and accounts review procedure exist and will be furnished on request, and that a customer can be represented by anyone of his choosing at any stage of the proceedings. 
(d)  The account review procedure will provide all customers of the system an opportunity to maintain utility service by entering into an agreement that within ten days after a final determination, the customer will pay the amount determined unless the customer elects to use the provisions of the customer collections procedure. 
(e)  The customer collections procedure will provide all customers of the system an opportunity to maintain utility service by entering into and honoring a written agreement that they will keep all monthly bills current and paid in full and reduce any balance that is in arrears to zero dollars over an agreed period. 
(f)  Failure to pay, or to make arrangements to pay, or to honor the arrangement to pay the bill due to Bessemer Utilities in a manner which will keep all monthly bills current and paid in full and reduce any balance that is in arrears to zero dollars in an agreed period will be cause, after notification by the mailing of a final notice, for termination of service. 
(g)  The accounts review procedure will provide customers of Bessemer Utilities adequate opportunity for an investigation, hearing and review process. The customer shall have the right to an informal hearing before a designated supervisor where an agreement as to the balance due on their bill cannot be reached. 
(h)  The customer has the right, if he so requests, to a formal hearing before a board of review made up of the office manager, accountant, and engineering assistant of the utilities, or their appointed representatives. It shall also offer an opportunity for the temporary maintenance of service or the temporary restoration of service to customers whose claim entitles them to consideration under this procedure. Such maintenance or restoration of service shall be temporary and for the term of this procedure only. Customers seeking such relief will agree in writing to firm conditions concerning such maintenance or temporary restoration of service before service is continued or actually restored. It shall be the responsibility of the customer to produce sufficient documentation to support the possible validity of the claim. 
(i)  The employees of Bessemer Utilities are prohibited from collecting part payment except as provided in the customer collection procedures as set out in section 110-53. 
(j)  A daily log of all transactions and account dispositions pertinent to the account review and collection policy review shall be maintained. 
(k)  The accounts review procedure shall be as follows: 
(1)  This provision is to provide and guarantee each customer of Bessemer Electric and Water Service of an adequate opportunity for investigation and a due process hearing for the purpose of resolving the customer's complaint. It shall also offer an opportunity for temporary continuance of service, or if the service has been discontinued, the temporary restoration of service to customers whose claim entitles them to consideration under this procedure. Such restoration of service shall be temporary and for the term of this procedure only. 
(2)  When it is determined that the customer disputes the amount owed, or the correctness of the bill, or the accuracy of the meter reading, or that their account has not been properly credited, or the right of Bessemer Utilities to terminate his services, or honor written agreements, the customer will be routed to the account clerk, who will first make an attempt to resolve the issue raised by the customer. If the account clerk is unable to resolve the issue raised by the customer, then the account clerk will grant to the customer an informal hearing. 
(3)  At the opening of the hearing, the account clerk will give the customer a copy of this article and explain to the customer the procedure to be used. The customer will be advised that he has the right to have his service restored if it has been discontinued or continued while the account review procedures are in progress, if the customer is willing to sign an agreement concerning the continuance or restoration of service. Failure to sign an agreement will cause the customer to forfeit his rights to have his service continued or restored as the case may be. As part of the proceedings the customer has the right to examine Bessemer Utilities records pertaining to that customer's service. If, after examining the records, the account clerk or the customer has a question about the reading on the meter, then the hearing will be recessed to a date certain and a utilities representative will be sent to obtain a current reading. The customer will be notified at the time when the representative will read the meter so the customer may be present. At the appointed time, the hearing will be reconvened, all pertinent records, including the latest reading of the meter, will be available. The customer may be present and represented by any one of his choosing, to cross examine witnesses and present any evidence he may desire. Within five days of the hearing a written decision will be mailed to the customer. This decision shall include a notification to the customer that he has a right to a formal hearing before a board of review and advise him of the necessary steps to invoke the review process. 
(4)  If the customer accepts the judgment of the account clerk then he will have ten days in which to pay the amount found due by the account clerk or to invoke the customer collection proceedings as set out in subsection (1) of this section. If the customer fails to give notice of appeal to the account review board within five days of the decision being hand delivered or mailed, paying the amount determined to be due or exercising his right under the customer collection procedure within ten days, then a final notice will be sent and service terminated within five days of sending the notice. 
(5)  If the customer wishes to appeal the account clerk's decision and files a notice of appeal, the office manager shall set a time and date for a hearing and a notice of such hearing shall be sent to the customer. The notice must be sent at least five days before the hearing. Within five days after the hearing, a written decision shall be mailed to the customer. The decision will determine the amount owed by the customer and the date by which it must be paid. This will then be entered in the records of Bessemer Utilities. 
(6)  If the customer fails to make payments as provided in the decision or fails to exercise his rights under the customer collection procedures, then a final notice shall be sent to the customer, and service shall be terminated within five days of mailing the final notice. 
(Code 1995, § 102-44; Ord. No. 2425, § IV, 3-15-1988) 
Sec. 110-53. - Customer collection procedure. 
(a)  If the customer is not disputing the amount owed, nor the right of Bessemer Utilities to collect due bills, line employees, including cashiers and customer complaint clerks will deal directly with each customer's collection inquiry. The employee will determine specifically the customer's problem and, if possible, provide the appropriate relief under this policy and guidelines as provided by the utilities manager and enter into a written agreement with the customer at that time. The line employee must maintain adequate records on each such transaction. All agreements with the customer to maintain service shall be executed in writing, routed to the supervisor of the service desk for review, filed, and appropriate interaction with the data processing section taken. A daily log of all inquiries, transactions, and account dispositions shall be maintained by each employee and routed at the end of each working day to the supervisor of the service desk. The same basic process shall apply to longterm agreements exceeding one month. In all cases, the customer will pay monthly bills in full and an agreed portion of the arrears each month. 
(b)  If the customer fails to make payments as provided in the agreement, then a final notice shall be sent to the customer and service terminated within five days. 
(c)  The circumstances under which the line employees must refer the customer to the supervisor of the service desk for review and decision on inquiry by the customer includes any case in which a customer: 
(1)  Reveals, through a CRT search and other indicators, that he may not be either willing or able to enter into a longterm written agreement to pay current bills and arrears in a manner consistent with the declining account balance policy. 
(2)  Claims special circumstances prevent him from entering into a written agreement. 
(3)  Discloses that a total dollar amount in excess of $300.00 is owed. 
(4)  May be a verifiable hardship case. 
(5)  Is in an uncontrollable emotional state. 
(d)  If the customer is referred to the supervisor of the service desk or his designated representative, the supervisor will listen to the customer's claim, establish a written record of what the customer is alleging, and determine whether it is within the supervisor's authority to make a final disposition of the inquiry, whether it is a situation which requires further investigation, whether, in fact, it is a dispute over the amount of the bill or a customer relations dilemma rather than a collection matter. If it is determined that it is other than a collection matter, then the written record of each transaction will be routed to the account clerk. 
(e)  If the issues raised by the customer fall within the collection procedures guideline and an agreement cannot be worked out with the customer, then an informal hearing will be conducted by the supervisor of the service desk, and within five days of the hearing a written decision will be handed to or mailed to the customer. As part of the decision, the supervisor will determine whether or not the customer is entitled to an extension and, if so, the amount to be paid by the customer on the arrearage each month and will advise the customer that he has a right to a final review process and shall be informed of the nature of such final review process. The customer shall have five days from the day the decision is mailed or the decision is personally delivered to him by the supervisor to invoke the appeals process to the review board. If the customer fails to invoke the appeals process, it shall be construed as consent to the decision of the supervisor, and the decision of the supervisor will be entered in the same manner as an agreement and the customer will be expected to pay as directed by the supervisor. 
(f)  If the customer fails to make payments as provided in the agreement with the supervisor or the supervisor's determination, as the case may be, then a final notice shall be sent to the customer and service terminated within five days. 
(g)  In the event the customer wishes to appeal the supervisor's decision and files a notice of appeal, the office manager shall set a time and date for a hearing and a notice of such hearing shall be sent to the customer. The notice must be sent at least five days before the hearing. Within five days after the hearing, a written decision shall be mailed to the customer. The decision will determine whether the customer is entitled to an extension and the amount to be paid by the customer on the arrearage each month. This will then be entered in the records of the Bessemer Utilities and the customer notified of his schedule of payments. 
(h)  If the customer fails to make payments as provided in the decision, then a final notice shall be sent to the customer and service terminated within five days. 
(Code 1995, § 102-45; Ord. No. 2425, § IV, 3-15-1988) 
Sec. 110-54. - Diversion of water or electricity; determination; assessment of penalty; posting of notice; hearing. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to tamper with a meter, reverse the meter, remove the meter installed by Bessemer Utilities and substitute a jumper, another meter not assigned or some other device designated to divert electricity or water in any manner. 
(b)  On an account where service has been terminated or discontinued, if the service is turned on by someone other than an authorized employee of Bessemer Utilities or someone does one or more of the prohibited acts as set out in subsection (a) of this section, the service will be immediately discontinued at this location without notice, and steps shall be taken to prevent the unauthorized restoration of service. A penalty will be charged against the location for the unlawful act and service will not be restored until this penalty and the other charges provided in this article are paid. 
(c)  On an active account, if someone does one or more of the prohibited acts as set out in subsection (a) of this section, the employees of Bessemer Utilities shall immediately remove the device and preserve it for evidence, install a new meter and seal it with locking devices, and give notice at the location that within five business days a hearing will be held before the accounts review board, as provided in section 110-52. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the accounts review board to determine if there has been a diversion of water or electricity. If this is determined in the affirmative, the accounts review board will determine if the person responsible for the location, as reflected in the records of Bessemer Utilities, knew of the diversion or benefited from it. If this is found in the affirmative, then the accounts review board will determine if service is to be immediately discontinued or continued and on what conditions. If the accounts review board determines that there has been a diversion, and that the customer of Bessemer Utilities knew of the diversion or benefited from it, then the board is hereby authorized to determine the value of the water or electricity diverted and may assess this against the customer or account and are further authorized to assess a penalty for an amount within the discretion of the board. 
(e)  The posting of the following notice on the entrance of the customer's residence or business, as the case may be, will be sufficient service. The notice will advise the customer of the date and time of the hearing, that they may be represented by counsel, that the hearing could result in the termination of their utility service, a determination being made by the review board of the amount of water or electricity diverted and their being charged for this plus a penalty and a new deposit and fees for reconnecting the service. 
(f)  The amount of any penalty charge, new deposit or other fee listed in this section shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1995, § 102-46; Ord. No. 2425, § V, 3-15-1988) 
State Law reference- Tampering with availability of gas, electricity, or water, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-8-23. 
Sec. 110-55. - Implementation of article. 
    The utility manager is hereby authorized and directed to issue such guidelines and directives as are necessary to implement this article. 
(Code 1995, § 102-47; Ord. No. 2425, § VI, 3-15-1988) 
Sec. 110-56. - Delinquent charges. 
(a)  No member of a customer's family, or any person living in the same house, building, or on such property with the customer where the electricity service or water service has been discontinued, shall have the right to make a deposit for electricity and/or water, or to request that the electricity and/or water be turned on at such place, so long as: 
(1)  The delinquent customer lives therein or thereon; and 
(2)  The electricity and/or water bill or charges (plus a reasonable charge for turning on and off the electricity and/or water) is unpaid. 
(b)  Delinquent charges owed by any member of the customer's family or anyone else living in the same house, building, or on such property with the customer will be charged back by the city utilities to the current, active customer account for electricity and/or water service for this residence. 
(Code 1995, § 102-50; Ord. No. 3097, 2-22-2000) 
Secs. 110-57-110-71. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - WATER SERVICE 

Sec. 110-72. - Rates. 
    The rates for water service shall be as established by ordinance or resolution of the city council, from time to time, and shall be available for public examination in a fee schedule in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 102-61; Ord. No. 2582, § 1, 1-19-1993) 
Sec. 110-73. - Incidental services fees and charges. 
    The fees and charges for the other incidental services furnished by the city water service shall be as established by ordinance or resolution of the city council, from time to time, and shall be available for public examination in a fee schedule in the office of the city clerk and attached as an appendix to this Code 
(Code 1995, § 102-62; Ord. No. 2582, § 1, 1-19-1993) 
Sec. 110-74. - Capital recovery fees. 
(a)  Establishment of water capital recovery fees. The owner of any property who or which connects said property to the city's water system shall pay a nonrefundable capital recovery fee to the City of Bessemer in the following amount: 
Size of Line Fee 3/4" $1,000.00 1" 1,000.00 2" 1,500.00 4" and above 5,000.00  
For each unit on said property to be serviced by the city's water system. Said fee is payable to the City of Bessemer at the time an application for water service is tendered to the City of Bessemer Water Service and prior to connecting to the city's water system. Said water capital recovery fee is payable in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other fee now existing or hereinafter established by the city. The fees generated pursuant to this section shall be placed in a separate bank account and used by the city only for capital improvements to the city's water system. 
(b)  Definition of "unit." A unit, for purposes of this section, is hereby defined as follows: A structure having a roof supported by columns or walls for the shelter, support, or enclosure of persons; and when supported by division walls from the ground up without ingress and egress provided between such divisions by suitable openings, each portion of such building so divided shall be deemed a separate unit. For residential purposes, any portion of a building used as a separate abode for a family shall be considered a "unit." For commercial and industrial purposes, any portion of a building used as separate quarters for the operation of a separate business shall be considered a "unit." 
(c)  Establishment of water capital recovery fees for hotels/motels, apartments, nursing homes/assisted living facilities, and hospitals. 
(1)  Hotels/motels. 
Water capital recovery fee. The owner of any property who or which constructs a hotel or motel on said property and connects said property to the city's water system shall pay a nonrefundable capital recovery fee in an amount determined by multiplying the number of rooms in the hotel/motel by .35 by the amount set forth for a three-quarter-inch line in subsection (a) above. Said fee is payable at the time a building permit is issued for said property. Said water capital recovery fee is payable in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other fee now existing or hereafter established by the city. The fees generated pursuant to this section shall be used by the city only for capital improvements to the city's water system. 
(2)  Apartments. 
Water capital recovery fee. The owner of any property who or which constructs apartments on said property and connects said property to the city's water system shall pay a nonrefundable capital recovery fee in an amount determined by multiplying the number of apartments by .50 by the amount set forth for a three-quarter-inch line in subsection (a) above. Said fee is payable at the time a building permit is issued for said property. Said water capital recovery fee is payable in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other fee now existing or hereafter established by the city. The fees generated pursuant to this section shall be used by the city only for capital improvements to the city's water system. 
(3)  Nursing homes/assisted living facilities. 
Water capital recovery fee. The owner of any property who or which constructs a nursing home or assisted living facility on said property and connects said property to the city's water system shall pay a nonrefundable capital recovery fee in an amount determined by multiplying the number of units by .30 by the amount set forth for a three-quarter-inch line in subsection (a) above. Said fee is payable at the time a building permit is issued for said property. Said water capital recovery fee is payable in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other fee now existing or hereafter established by the city. The fees generated pursuant to this section shall be used by the city only for capital improvements to the city's water system. 
(4)  Hospitals. 
Water capital recovery fee. The owner of any property who or which constructs a hospital on said property and connects said property to the city's water system shall pay a nonrefundable capital recovery fee in an amount determined by multiplying the number of beds in the hospital by .50 by the amount set forth for a three-quarter-inch line in subsection (a) above. Said fee is payable at the time a building permit is issued for said property. Said water capital recovery fee is payable in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other fee now existing or hereafter established by the city. The fees generated pursuant to this section shall be used by the city only for capital improvements to the city's water system. 
(d)  Water capital recovery fee to be added to Bessemer Utilities Rate Charges and Service Fees Schedule. The water capital recovery fee established by this section shall be added to Bessemer Utilities Rate Charges and Service Fees Schedule as amended from time to time. Any increase or decrease in the water capital recovery fee established by this section shall be by resolution of the City Council of the City of Bessemer, Alabama, or as otherwise provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 3476, §§ 1-4, 5-15-2012) 
Editor's note- Sections 1-4 of Ord. No. 3476, adopted May 15, 2012, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as § 110-74 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 110-75-110-89. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - ELECTRIC SERVICE 

Sec. 110-90. - Rates. 
    Rates and charges for electric service shall be set from time to time by the city council and are on file in the city clerk and treasurer's office. 
(Code 1995, § 102-76) 
Secs. 110-91-110-108. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWER SERVICE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- The Ord. No. 3232, as adopted by the city council of the City of Bessemer, Alabama on January 20, 2004 stated that Bessemer Utilities is hereby authorized to terminate the collection of sewer maintenance fees imposed by Ord. No. 2665 and that Ord. No. 2665 is rescinded. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 110-109. - Obstruction of sewers. 
    No person shall throw or deposit or cause to be thrown or deposited in any vessel or receptacle connected with the sewers, any garbage, hair, ashes, fruit, vegetables, peelings, refuse, rags, cotton, newspapers or any other substance whatever which may clog up such sewers or stop the flow of water therein. 
(Code 1973, § 20-15; Code 1995, § 102-96) 
Sec. 110-110. - Connections to sewer system; resolution declaring necessity; contents. 
(a)  If in the judgment of the city council it is deemed necessary or expedient for the protection of the public health to require the owner of any property within the city limits to install and connect with the sewer system of the city, the city council may, in addition to the present regulation in lieu thereof, adopt a resolution declaring that in the opinion of the city council it is necessary and expedient that such work be done. 
(b)  The resolution shall contain: 
(1)  The name of the owner of the lot; 
(2)  The lot and block number and the survey in which the lot is situated; 
(3)  The location at which the water closet shall be installed; 
(4)  The character of the work and quality of the water closet, including necessary water pipelines to be installed; 
(5)  The estimated cost of providing and installing the lines; and 
(6)  The date for the hearing of the property owner, which shall not be less than 20 days after the adoption of such resolution. 
(Code 1973, § 20-1; Code 1995, § 102-97) 
State Law reference- Authority to require connection to sewer, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-50-53, 11-50-54. 
Sec. 110-111. - Notice of hearing to property owner; proof of service. 
(a)  Upon the adoption of the resolution as provided in section 110-110, the city clerk and treasurer shall issue a notice to the property owner named in such resolution. The notice shall set forth the resolution so adopted and shall notify the property owner to appear, either in person or by counsel, before the city council on the day named in such resolution to show cause, if any, why he should not be peremptorily required to immediately construct the water closet at the place mentioned in such resolution at his own expense. 
(b)  The notice shall be served upon the property owner by the chief of police or by any police officer by leaving a copy of such notice with the property owner. The police officer making such service shall make return in writing upon the notice to the city clerk and treasurer. The notice shall be served at least ten days before the day fixed in such resolution for the hearing. 
(Code 1973, § 20-2; Code 1995, § 102-98) 
Sec. 110-112. - Hearing and protest; filing protest. 
(a)  Upon the day fixed in the resolution provided for in section 110-110 for hearing the property owner's objections, the city council shall proceed to hear any objections or defenses which the property owner may make in writing and to hear all evidence which the property owner may offer in support of any protest or objection so made. If the property owner fails to protest in writing, on the hearing of such resolution he shall be held to have consented to the making of the connections in the manner provided in this article. 
(b)  The protest required in subsection (a) of this section shall be filed with the city clerk and treasurer by the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 20-3; Code 1995, § 102-99) 
Sec. 110-113. - Order to make connections. 
    After the hearing provided for in section 110-110, the city council shall have the power to peremptorily order by resolution the property owner to make such connections within ten days. 
(Code 1973, § 20-4; Code 1995, § 102-100) 
Sec. 110-114. - Connection by city; lien; requirements; interest. 
(a)  In case of a failure to install or connect a water closet with the sewer system of the city within ten days after the peremptory resolution ordering the installation has been adopted, the city shall install on the premises of the property owner a proper water closet with necessary water supply line and connect it with the sewer system of the city at the expense of the owner. The cost shall be a lien upon the property in favor of the city to be collected as other debts are collected or liens enforced. 
(b)  The sewage discharge line installed shall be of the kind designated in the original resolution, provided for in section 110-110 and the cost of such installation shall not exceed the sum estimated in the original resolution. 
(c)  The amount of the cost shall bear interest at the rate of eight percent from the date of the completion and installation as certified by the mayor. 
(Code 1973, § 20-5; Code 1995, § 102-101) 
Sec. 110-115. - Statement of connection by city; filing. 
(a)  Upon the completion of the installation and connection of a sewage discharge line, the mayor shall prepare, or cause to be prepared, a statement in writing setting forth the name of the owner of such property and a description of the property on which such improvement has been made, together with the cost of such sanitary connection and installation of such sewage discharge line. 
(b)  The statement shall be signed by the mayor in his official capacity and filed with the county probate judge for record in the mortgage records of the county. The filing of such statement shall operate as notice of the existence of the lien from the date of its filing. 
(Code 1973, § 20-6; Code 1995, § 102-102) 
Sec. 110-116. - Notice of assessment; protest; consent. 
(a)  The notice of lien provided for in section 110-115 shall not be filed for record in the office of the county probate judge until the property owner has been given notice by registered mail, addressed to his last known address, of the fact of the completion of such installation and the amount of the assessment. At any time within five days after such notice has been deposited in the post office of the city, in accordance with the provisions of this section, the property owner shall have the right to file in writing with the city clerk and treasurer any objection against the material used, the manner in which the work is constructed or the cost of such assessment. 
(b)  The city council at its next regular meeting, after the filing of such protest, shall hear such protest and any evidence which the property owner may offer. It may either confirm, modify or repeal the resolution fixing the assessment. 
(c)  If the property owner fails to protest within the time and manner stated, he shall be held to have consented to such assessment. 
(Code 1973, § 20-8; Code 1995, § 102-103) 
Sec. 110-117. - Appeal of decision; bond. 
(a)  Any property owner feeling himself aggrieved by the action of the city council in overruling any protest filed in accordance with section 110-116, either in whole or in part, may within two days after such assessment has been finally fixed, appeal to the county circuit court. 
(b)  The property owner shall give a bond in twice the amount of the assessment with two good and sufficient sureties, conditioned to prosecute such appeal to effect, and to pay to the city such judgment as the court may render upon the hearing of such appeal. 
(Code 1973, § 20-9; Code 1995, § 102-104) 
Sec. 110-118. - Transcript of proceedings; hearing. 
    Upon the appeal provided for in section 110-117 being taken, the city clerk and treasurer shall immediately send to the county circuit court to which the appeal is taken a transcript of the proceedings, including the protest and bond, and the cause shall thereupon be set down for immediate hearing by such court. The court shall hear the appeal on the merits and render judgment accordingly. 
(Code 1973, § 20-10; Code 1995, § 102-105) 
Sec. 110-119. - Filing statement in absence of protest. 
    If the property owner has not protested, as provided in section 110-116, the statement in writing provided for in section 110-115 shall immediately be filed in the office of the county probate judge. 
(Code 1973, § 20-11; Code 1995, § 102-106) 
Sec. 110-120. - Applicability of sections 110-110 to 110-119 and 110-122. 
    The provisions of sections 110-110 to 110-119 and section 110-122 shall not apply to any property unless the property is located within 500 feet of a sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1973, § 20-12; Code 1995, § 102-107) 
Sec. 110-121. - Notice of readiness of sewer for use; connection of privies, sinks and urinals within 30 days. 
(a)  If any line of sanitary sewers is laid in or along any street and is ready for use, the city clerk and treasurer shall notify the owners, their agents or the occupants of all houses, tenements or other buildings situated on lots abutting upon the street in which such sewer is laid, to connect all closets, privies, sinks, cesspools and urinals with such sewer within 30 days from the date of such notice. 
(b)  After the expiration of the time stipulated in such notice, no tenant or owner of such house or building shall keep or maintain any surface closets, sinks, cesspools, dry wells or urinals upon such lot or in any building situated thereon. 
(Code 1973, § 20-13; Code 1995, § 102-108) 
Sec. 110-122. - Payment of assessment; methods. 
(a)  Any person whose property has been assessed under the provisions of this article shall have the right to pay the assessment in cash at any time within 30 days after the amount of such assessment has been ascertained by resolution adopted by the city council. Notice of the assessment shall be given to the property owner by registered mail at his last known address. 
(b)  The property owner shall have the right in lieu of paying such assessment in cash to pay the amount in monthly installments, each installment to equal 1/20th of the principal amount of the assessment. At the time of paying such monthly installment the property owner shall also pay the interest on the unpaid balance from the date of the last preceding payment to the date upon which the monthly installment is paid. 
(c)  If such property owner fails to pay the principal in cash within 30 days after notice that such assessment has been ascertained and fixed, or fails to pay any monthly installments when due and the installment remains in default for 30 days, then, at the option of the city, the entire amount shall become due and payable.
