The city clerk and treasurer shall proceed to collect the entire amount and to enforce the payment in any court having jurisdiction, or by sale as provided by law, for foreclosing street improvement assessment liens. 
(Code 1973, § 20-7; Code 1995, § 102-109) 
Sec. 110-123. - Improperly constructed drain or closet connection. 
    No person shall permit any drain to remain connected with any sewer if the work has been improperly done. No person shall permit any water closet connected with a sewer to be used or remain connected with the sewer system without a proper supply of water connected therewith, ready at all times to flush such water closet. When any water closet is out of repair, it shall be put in good order and repair without delay. 
(Code 1973, § 20-14; Code 1995, § 102-110) 
Secs. 110-124-110-144. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SEWER IMPACT FEES 

Sec. 110-145. - Payment required-Properties served by Pine Lane Sewer Main. 
    Prior to the issuance of any building permit by the city, to any applicant for a building permit whose property will be served by the sanitary sewer line known as the Pine Lane Sewer Main shall be required to pay to the city a sewer impact fee in accordance with the rules and regulations of the county sewer impact fee in effect at the time of the application. The city sewer impact fee shall be equal to 50 percent of the impact fee paid to the county in accordance with the ordinances, rules and regulations of the county. 
(Code 1995, § 102-121; Ord. No. 2473, § 1, 4-4-1989) 
Sec. 110-146. - Same-Buildings discharging sanitary sewer wastes to Pine Lane Sewer Main. 
    Pursuant to this division, the city shall not issue a permit for any building or other improvement which will discharge sanitary sewer wastes to the Pine Lane Sewer Main, either directly or indirectly, until payment of the city impact fee has been received by the city. 
(Code 1995, § 102-122; Ord. No. 2473, § 2, 4-4-1989) 
Sec. 110-147. - Same-For all sewers constructed. 
    All sewers constructed under the provisions of this division shall be operated and maintained by the city after approval for the final construction of such sewers, and shall be subject to payment of the city impact fee described in this division. 
(Code 1995, § 102-123; Ord. No. 2473, § 3, 4-4-1989) 
Sec. 110-148. - Same-Properties served by Powder Plant Sewer Main. 
    Prior to the issuance of any building permit by the city, any applicant for such building permit whose property will be served by the sanitary sewer line known as the Powder Plant Sewer Main shall be required to pay to the city a sewer impact fee in accordance with the rules and regulations of the county sewer impact fee in effect at the time of the application. The city sewer impact fee shall be equal to 50 percent of the impact fee paid to the county in accordance with the ordinances, rules and regulations of the county. 
(Code 1995, § 102-124; Ord. No. 2491, § 1, 8-29-1989) 
Sec. 110-149. - Same-Buildings discharging sanitary sewer wastes to Powder Plant Sewer Main. 
    Pursuant to this division, the city shall not issue a permit for any building or other improvement which will discharge sanitary sewer wastes to the Powder Plant Sewer Main, either directly or indirectly, until payment of the city impact fee has been received by the city. 
(Code 1995, § 102-125; Ord. No. 2491, § 2, 8-29-1989) 
Chapter 114 - VEGETATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Abatement of nuisances generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-117; maintenance of civil actions to enjoin and abate public nuisances, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-118; powers as to health, sanitation generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-130 et seq.; authority of cities to require weeds to be cut, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-140. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 114-1-114-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WEEDS 

Sec. 114-19. - Certain weeds declared public nuisance. 
    All weeds growing upon private property within the city which bear seeds of a wingy or a downy nature, which attain such a large growth as to become a fire menace when dry or which are otherwise noxious or dangerous are hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall be abated as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1995, § 106-26; Ord. No. 2509, § 1, 4-10-1990) 
Sec. 114-20. - Declaration of nuisance to name particular property. 
    The director of public works of the city shall present to the city council a resolution declaring that the weeds on private property upon a named street, describing the property upon which or in front of which the weeds exist by giving a legal description thereof, or giving a street address or parcel number of the property, declaring the growing weeds on the property to be a public nuisance. 
(Code 1995, § 106-27; Ord. No. 2509, § 2, 4-10-1990) 
Sec. 114-21. - Determination of public nuisance by council; resolution. 
    The city council shall determine whether the weeds growing upon private property are a public nuisance and shall declare the weeds to be a public nuisance by passage of a resolution. 
(Code 1995, § 106-28; Ord. No. 2509, § 3, 4-10-1990) 
Sec. 114-22. - Notice and hearing; list of contractors; publication. 
(a)  After the passage of the resolution, notice of a public hearing on the matter shall be given by certified mail, return receipt requested, mailed 30 days prior to the date of the hearing and shall inform the owner of the date, time and place of the hearing and the reason therefor. Such notice shall be mailed to the owner of the property as the owner's name and address appears on record in the tax assessor's office in the Bessemer division of the county. 
(b)  The notice shall carry a list of names of persons and/or private contractors who perform such work and are registered with the city clerk and treasurer. Such names shall not constitute a recommendation, and the failure to include such a list shall in no way affect the operation of this article. 
(c)  Notice shall also be given by publication in a newspaper normally read by all segments of the population, published in the county once a week for two consecutive weeks. The first notice shall be published at least 14 days prior to the date of the scheduled hearing. 
(Code 1995, § 106-29; Ord. No. 2509, § 4, 4-10-1990) 
Sec. 114-23. - Posting of signs. 
(a)  The director of public works shall cause two signs to be posted on the property. The wording on the signs shall be a minimum of one inch in height and shall be in the following form: 
Notice to Destroy Weeds 
    Notice is hereby given that on the ____________ day of ____________ , 19 ____________ (a.m./p.m.) in the council chamber, the council of the City of Bessemer will consider a resolution regarding the weeds growing upon or in front of this property, a copy of the resolution which is on file in the office of the city clerk and treasurer; and at that time and place will determine whether the same constitutes a public nuisance which must be abated by the removal of the noxious or dangerous weeds; and, if so, will order the abatement and removal of the nuisances, in which case the cost of such abatement and removal shall be assessed upon the lots and lands from which such weeds are removed, and such cost will constitute a lien for weed removal upon such lots or lands until paid. 
    If no objections are filed with the city clerk and treasurer at least five days before the meeting of the city council and unless such person appears before the city council in person or through his representative to show cause, if any, why his objection should be sustained, it shall be presumed that the person accepts the notice as fact and waives any rights he may have to contest the removal of the weeds. The action of the council shall be final unless good and sufficient cause can be otherwise shown. 
    Reference is hereby made to the resolution, on file in the office of the city clerk and treasurer, for further particulars. 
    Dated this ____________ day of ____________ , 19 ____________ . 
(b)  The signs shall be posted at least seven days prior to the time of the hearing. 
(Code 1995, § 106-30; Ord. No. 2509, § 5, 4-10-1990) 
Sec. 114-24. - Hearing procedure; abatement order; abatement by city or private contractors. 
(a)  At the hearing the city council shall hear and consider all objections, evidence and protests regarding the proposed removal of weeds. The city council may continue the hearing from time to time. Upon the conclusion of the hearing, the council, by resolution, shall decide whether a public nuisance exists, and if so, shall order it to be removed or abated with respect to any property or part thereof described. The city council, by passage of the resolution, shall be deemed to have acquired jurisdiction to proceed and either to perform or have performed the work of removal or abatement with respect to such property or part thereof. The decision of the city council on the matter shall be deemed final and conclusive. 
(b)  Upon approval of the resolution finding the conditions of the property to be a public nuisance and ordering its abatement, all employees and duly authorized agents of the city are hereby expressly authorized to enter upon private property for that purpose. 
(c)  The city council may, at its option, authorize private contractors, companies, enterprises or individuals to abate and remove the nuisance. The city council, by resolution, shall designate the contractors, companies, enterprises or individuals who may perform the work. Those persons so designated are authorized to enter upon private property for purposes of abating or removing the nuisance. Compliance with the competitive bid law is not required. 
(Code 1995, § 106-31; Ord. No. 2509, § 6, 4-10-1990) 
Sec. 114-25. - Owner's right to abate. 
    Any property owner shall have the right to have such weeds removed at his own expense, providing the removal is done prior to the commencing of the work by the city, its employees, agents, contractors, enterprises or individuals employed to do the work. 
(Code 1995, § 106-32; Ord. No. 2509, § 7, 4-10-1990) 
Sec. 114-26. - Report of abatement costs to city council. 
    The director of public works shall keep an account of the costs of abating or removing nuisances on each separate lot or parcel of land where the work is being done by city employees or by a duly authorized private contractor, company, enterprise or individual and shall render an itemized report in writing to the city council showing the cost of removing the nuisance on each separate lot, provided that before the report is submitted to the city council, a copy of the report shall be posted for at least five days prior thereto on or near the chamber door of the city council together with a notice of the time when the report shall be submitted to the city council for confirmation. 
(Code 1995, § 106-33; Ord. No. 2509, § 8, 4-10-1990) 
Sec. 114-27. - Abatement charges. 
    The minimum charges for removing such nuisance on each separate lot or parcel of land if cleared by the city streets and sanitation department shall be $300.00 plus $100.00 per hour in excess of two hours plus an administrative fee of $150.00. The minimum charges for removing such nuisance on each separate lot or parcel of land if cleared by private contractor, company, enterprise or individual, shall be the cost assessed by the contractor plus an administrative fee of $150.00. 
(Code 1995, § 106-34; Ord. No. 2509, § 9, 4-10-1990; Ord. No. 3282, 4-19-2005) 
Sec. 114-28. - Weed lien. 
(a)  At the time fixed for receiving and considering the report, the city council shall hear the report with any objections which may be raised by any of the property owners liable to be assessed for the work of abating the nuisance and shall make a determination by motion or resolution confirming the report. 
(b)  Upon the adoption of the motion or resolution, the amount of cost for abating the nuisance shall be referred to as a "weed lien" and shall constitute a weed lien on the property for such amount. 
(c)  After confirmation of the report of costs, the city clerk and treasurer shall turn over to the tax collector of the county, a copy of the report, and the tax collector will collect the weed lien under the optional method of taxation, pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-51-40 through 11-51-74. The weed liens shall be added to the next regular bill of taxes levied against the parcels of land and shall be collected in the same manner as ordinary city ad valorem taxes are collected and shall be subject to the same penalties and the same procedure under foreclosure and sale in case of delinquency. 
(Code 1995, § 106-35; Ord. No. 2509, § 10, 4-10-1990) 
Chapter 118 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Renting, hiring and using motor vehicles, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-15-1 et seq.; authority to license and regulate vehicles for hire, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-51-101. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 118-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Operator means every person operating or driving or assisting in operating or driving any taxicab within the city limits or the police jurisdiction thereof. 
    Owner means and includes every person who owns any interest in any taxicab being operated within the city limits. 
(Code 1995, § 110-1) 
Sec. 118-2. - Operation of vehicles in compliance with chapter. 
    No person, either as owner or operator, shall operate or permit to be operated within the city limits any vehicle for hire unless such person complies with the provisions and requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 18-23; Code 1995, § 110-2) 
Sec. 118-3. - License required; exception. 
(a)  No person shall operate or conduct a business involving vehicles for hire without first obtaining a license from the city. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the receiving or taking up of passengers or the discharging or setting down of passengers on the streets, avenues, alleys or public places within the city limits by any transportation company at any depot or bus terminal maintained and duly licensed at a fixed place. 
(Code 1973, § 18-24; Code 1995, § 110-3) 
Sec. 118-4. - License application; contents; fees. 
(a)  Every person desiring to operate a business involving vehicles for hire shall file an application for each such business or vehicle with the city clerk and treasurer. 
(b)  The application shall be made by the owner of the business or vehicle for which the license is sought, and state the following facts: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant and owner of the business or vehicle. 
(2)  The address of the principal place of business of the applicant. 
(3)  The trade name under which the applicant does or proposes to do business. 
(4)  The address of the stand from which such vehicle for hire proposes to operate, is applicable. 
(5)  The make, model, seating capacity and engine number of the vehicle for hire for which such license is requested. 
(6)  A schedule of rates and fares to be charged in the operation of the business or vehicle. 
(c)  Every owner or operator of a vehicle for hire within the city limits and the police jurisdiction shall pay annually the license fees for the operation of the vehicle for hire as may be provided in the city license schedule. 
(Code 1973, § 18-25; Code 1995, § 110-4) 
Sec. 118-5. - Operator's permit-Required. 
(a)  Every driver of a vehicle for-hire shall be required annually to obtain an operator's permit in accordance with this chapter. 
(b)  Every operator of such vehicle licensed in accordance with this section shall be given by the city a permit or card upon which shall be placed, among other information deemed desirable by the city, the photograph of the person so licensed, which shall be carried on the person of the licensee or displayed in a prominent place upon the vehicle so operated at all times. Any person shall have the right to request the identification of the driver and inspect such permit. 
(c)  For the obtaining of the permit as described in this section, the person applying therefor shall pay, in addition to any other license required, a fee to the city clerk and treasurer. The amount of the operator's permit fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1995, § 110-5; Ord. No. 1921, §§ 1, 3, 11-4-1975; Ord. No. 1928, § 1, 1-6-1976) 
Sec. 118-6. - Same-Disqualifications. 
    No permit to drive or operate a taxicab within the city limits shall be issued to any person: 
(1)  Who is under the age of 17 years; 
(2)  Who by reason of physical or mental defects is not competent to operate or drive a taxicab; 
(3)  Who is not experienced in the operation of motor vehicles; 
(4)  Who is addicted to the use of intoxicating liquors; 
(5)  Who has been convicted of a felony; 
(6)  Who does not have a valid driving license issued by the state director of public safety; or 
(7)  Who has been convicted of any crime involving moral turpitude. 
(Code 1973, § 18-39; Code 1995, § 110-6) 
Secs. 118-7-118-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Consent of city to use streets, etc., for operation of private enterprise required, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-49-1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 118-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Taxicab means an automobile or other vehicle employed in the carriage of passengers for hire within the city limits and the police jurisdiction thereof, exclusive of a bus and other common carrier duly licensed by the city. 
(Code 1973, § 18-22; Code 1995, § 110-31) 
Sec. 118-32. - Public liability insurance required; amount; notice. 
(a)  Every licensee shall, before the operation of any taxicab within the city limits, procure a policy of public liability and property damage insurance issued by some responsible liability insurance company duly authorized to do business in the state. Such policy of insurance shall indemnify such licensee, his agents and employees, from all damages by reason of injury to or destruction of life or property arising out of the ownership, maintenance or operation of any taxicab within the city limits, including injury to or death of any person being carried as a passenger in a taxicab. 
(b)  The policy of insurance shall insure such licensee, his agents and employees on account of accidents arising out of the ownership, maintenance or use of a motor vehicle in the amount of $100,000.00, because of bodily injury to or death of one person in any one accident, and, subject to the limit for one person, in the amount of $300,000.00 because of bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one accident, and in the amount of $50,000.00 because of injury to or destruction of property of others in any one accident, resulting from the ownership, maintenance or operation of each taxicab operated by such licensee in the city. 
(c)  A true copy of the policy of insurance shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and treasurer before the licensee is permitted to operate any taxicab within the city limits. Both the insurer and the insured are required to immediately report in writing to the city clerk and treasurer the fact of any cancellation of or amendment to any such policy so filed. 
(Code 1973, § 18-26; Code 1995, § 110-32) 
Sec. 118-33. - Maintenance of taxicab required. 
    Every taxicab operated within the city limits shall be maintained in a good state of repair mechanically and shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition for the protection of the safety and health of the passengers being transported therein. 
(Code 1973, § 18-30; Code 1995, § 110-33) 
Sec. 118-34. - Service to public. 
    Each licensed taxicab within the city limits shall serve the public generally, and upon the schedule of rates and fares filed with the city clerk and treasurer and posted in the taxicab as set out in section 118-66. 
(Code 1973, § 18-32; Code 1995, § 110-34) 
Sec. 118-35. - Charging or collecting illegal rates. 
    No operator, owner or licensee of any taxicab operating within the city limits shall charge or collect any fees, rates or prices for his services other than the fees, rates and prices filed with the city clerk and treasurer at or prior to the time of the issuance of the license for such operation. 
(Code 1973, § 18-28; Code 1995, § 110-35) 
Sec. 118-36. - Advertising on taxicabs. 
    No person owning or operating or assisting in the owning or operating of any taxicab within the city limits shall permit any advertising matter to be placed or carried thereon. 
(Code 1973, § 18-33; Code 1995, § 110-36) 
Sec. 118-37. - Operation over fixed route. 
    No person operating a taxicab within the city limits shall: 
(1)  Operate the taxicab over any fixed or regular route; or 
(2)  Pass any specified point on a fixed or regular time schedule for the purpose of picking up passengers. 
(Code 1973, § 18-34; Code 1995, § 110-37) 
Sec. 118-38. - Signs on taxicabs required. 
    Every person owning or operating a taxicab within the city limits shall cause to be painted on the body of such taxicab, in a conspicuous place and in full view of the public, the word "taxi" together with the name of the owner of the taxicab, and the number which the taxicab bears upon the records of the owner's taxicab business. The printing of these words on the taxicab shall be in letters not less than 21/2 inches high. 
(Code 1973, § 18-38; Code 1995, § 110-38) 
Secs. 118-39-118-64. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES AND PERMITS 

Sec. 118-65. - License contents; transferability; violation. 
(a)  Each owner or operator of a taxicab within the city limits shall procure for each taxicab a license as provided for in section 118-32. The license shall bear upon its face: 
(1)  The name of the owner of such vehicle; 
(2)  The address of the principal place of business of the owner thereof; and 
(3)  The make, model and engine number of such vehicle. 
(b)  The license for the vehicle, when issued by the city, shall not be transferred to or used in or upon any vehicle other than the vehicle for which the license was issued. 
(c)  No person shall operate within the city limits any taxicab in violation of the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 18-29; Code 1995, § 110-51) 
Sec. 118-66. - License; operator's permit; rate schedule; display. 
    Every operator of a taxicab within the city limits shall exhibit at all times in a conspicuous place in the taxicab where the same may be readily seen by passengers and by the public: 
(1)  The license certificate issued for such taxicab by the city; 
(2)  An operator's permit including a photograph of the driver or operator of such taxicab; and 
(3)  A schedule of the rates or fares upon which such taxicab operates. 
(Code 1973, § 18-27; Code 1995, § 110-52) 
Sec. 118-67. - Possession, inspection of operator's permit. 
    Every person driving or operating a taxicab within the city limits shall carry with him at all times the operator's permit issued to him by the city. The permit shall be subject to inspection by any official or police officer of the city or by any member of the public who becomes a passenger for hire in such vehicle. 
(Code 1973, § 18-40; Code 1995, § 110-53) 
Sec. 118-68. - Licenses and permits; transferability; revocation. 
(a)  Neither the owner's taxicab license certificate nor the taxicab driver's or operator's permit shall be transferable. 
(b)  Either or both may be revoked by the city council at any time upon a showing made before the city council that the owner or operator of such taxicab: 
(1)  Has violated any of the provisions or requirements of this article; or 
(2)  Has been convicted of violating any traffic laws or regulations of the city or of the state. 
(Code 1973, § 18-37; Code 1995, § 110-54) 
Sec. 118-69. - Operation of taxicab after license or permit revocation. 
    No person shall operate or assist in the operation of any taxicab within the city limits where the license issued for the taxicab has been revoked, or where the permit of the operator has been revoked. 
(Code 1973, § 18-36; Code 1995, § 110-55) 
Secs. 118-70-118-96. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ESCORT SERVICES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 118-97. - Qualifications and dress of employees. 
(a)  All employees of the motor vehicle escort service who will operate vehicles must be certified police officers, the certification being from the state. Each employee shall be of good reputation, and be familiar with the traffic laws of the city. All employees must be familiar with the operation of motor vehicles and motorcycles. 
(b)  All employees of the licensee who operate vehicles in the motor vehicle escort service upon the streets and public ways of the city shall wear police uniforms that are approved by the chief of police. 
(c)  Reserve officers who serve the city may be certified by the chief of police when such reserve officers are complying with the rules and regulations of the city police department. 
(Code 1995, § 110-76; Ord. No. 2436, § 2, 7-5-1988) 
Secs. 118-98-118-122. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 118-123. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of operating any motor vehicle escort service in the city or its police jurisdiction unless such person holds a valid license issued by the city. 
(Code 1995, § 110-86; Ord. No. 2436, § 1, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 118-124. - Application; contents. 
(a)  Any person desiring to engage in the business of operating a motor vehicle escort service shall first make application to the chief of police so that an investigation can be performed by the chief of police as to the qualifications of the applicant to engage in such business. 
(b)  The application shall: 
(1)  Specify the street address from which he intends to carry on such business. 
(2)  Be signed by the applicant. 
(3)  Give the name of at least three citizens of good reputation who will certify to the reputation of the applicant, or if the applicant is a corporation, to the reputation of the managing officer of the corporation. 
(4)  Show the kind, make and model of the vehicles with which the applicant intends to operate the business. 
(5)  Give any other information necessary to show the chief of police that the applicant is ready, willing and able to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(6)  List the names and street address of all employees that are to be used in the motor vehicle escort business to operate vehicles on the streets and public ways of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 110-87; Ord. No. 2436, § 2, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 118-125. - Finding and recommendation. 
    Within 21 days after the application has been filed, the chief of police shall make a finding and recommendation as to the applicant's being qualified and ready, willing and able to comply with the provisions of this article and the territory proposed to be served by the operation under the license to be issued. Unless the chief of police finds that the application fulfills all of the provisions of this article, the application shall be refused. 
(Code 1995, § 110-88; Ord. No. 2436, § 3, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 118-126. - Refusal; appeal; hearing. 
    If the chief of police shall refuse to approve the application of the applicant, the applicant may file a notice of appeal with the city clerk and treasurer and ask that the city council review the decision of the chief of police. This hearing may be held at a regular meeting of the city council or at such other time and place as the council may direct. 
(Code 1995, § 110-89; Ord. No. 2436, § 3, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 118-127. - Issuance. 
    If the city council finds that the applicant meets the qualifications of this article, the city council may issue a directive to the city clerk and treasurer to issue a license to the applicant for the operation of a motor vehicle escort service. Notwithstanding the city council granting the license, the applicant must comply with all ordinances, laws and statutes of the city, county and state in the operation of the business. 
(Code 1995, § 110-90; Ord. No. 2436, § 3, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 118-128. - Transferability. 
    A license granted under the provisions of this article shall not be transferrable to any other person to operate a motor vehicle escort service upon the streets and public ways of this city. 
(Code 1995, § 110-91; Ord. No. 2436, § 4, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 118-129. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  Any license issued to any person to operate a motor vehicle escort service upon the streets and public ways of this city under the provisions of this article shall be subject to suspension or revocation upon the recommendation of the chief of police to the city council. 
(b)  Suspension or revocation can be issued by the city council for the violation by such person or his agents, servants or employees who violate any provision of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 110-92; Ord. No. 2436, § 5, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 118-130. - Fee. 
    The applicant for a motor vehicle escort service license must pay the fee provided in the city license schedule upon issuance of the license. 
(Code 1995, § 110-93; Ord. No. 2436, § 6, 7-5-1988) 
Secs. 118-131-118-158. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MOVING AND STORAGE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Alabama Motor Carrier Act, Code of Ala. 1975, § 37-3-1 et seq. 

Sec. 118-159. - Moving vehicle owner moving household goods; report. 
    All persons owning or operating within the city limits any dray, moving van, furniture car, transfer wagon, express wagon or any other vehicle, who hauls or moves or causes to be hauled or moved household goods or personal effects, other than baggage, of any person within the city limits who is changing the place of his abode, shall make a report thereof to the chief of police. The report shall be made within one day thereafter on a blank form as described in section 118-160. 
(Code 1973, § 18-1; Code 1995, § 110-116) 
Sec. 118-160. - Report form. 
    The form or blank to be filled in by the person required by section 118-159 to make a report to the chief of police shall be established by the city council, from time to time and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1973, § 18-3; Code 1995, § 110-117) 
Sec. 118-161. - Maintenance of reports; expenses. 
(a)  The chief of police shall keep in a well-bound book, open for inspection at the police station, the reports required by section 118-159, alphabetically indexed. 
(b)  The entire expense and cost of executing and carrying out the provisions of this section shall be free of cost to the city, except the expense of furnishing such book and the blank described in section 118-160. 
(Code 1973, § 18-4; Code 1995, § 110-118) 
Sec. 118-162. - Use of fictitious or false name by employer of mover. 
    No person causing the removal of any property described in section 118-159 shall give the owner or operator of any vehicle employed to haul such property a fictitious name or refuse to give the correct name of the owner or party in possession of such property, so as to willfully deceive such operator as to the correct information. 
(Code 1973, § 18-2; Code 1995, § 110-119) 
Appendix A - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS 
Adopted by the City of Bessemer Planning and Zoning Commission 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Printed herein are the subdivision regulations as adopted by the city council on June 16, 1983. Amendments to these regulations are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original regulations. Obvious misspellings and punctuation errors have been corrected without notation. For stylistic purposes, headings and catchlines have been made uniform and the same system of capitalization as appears in the Code of Ordinances has been used. Where a section has been amended or repealed by a later provision, only the current language has been printed. Additions made for purposes of clarity are indicated by brackets. 

SECTION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1.1. - Title. 
    These regulations shall hereafter be known, cited and referred to as the Subdivision Regulations of the City of Bessemer, Alabama. 
Sec. 1.2. - Authority. 
    Under the provisions of title 11, subtitle 2, chapter 52, articles 2 and 3 of the Code of Alabama, 1975 [Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-52-30-11-52-36 and 11-52-50-11-52-54], these following regulations governing the subdivision and development of land are hereby adopted by the Bessemer Planning and Zoning Commission at a meeting on September 16, 2008. 
Sec. 1.3. - Jurisdiction. 
(1)  On and after September 16, 2008, these subdivision regulations shall apply to all subdivisions and development of land, as defined herein, located within the corporate limits of the City of Bessemer. 
(2)  No land shall be subdivided within the corporate limits of the City of Bessemer until: 
(a)  The subdivider or his agent has submitted the required plats and plans to the planning and zoning commission, and 
(b)  Approval of all plats and plans, including approval of the final plat, by the planning and zoning commission, and 
(c)  The approved final plat is recorded with the office of the Judge of Probate, Jefferson County. 
(3)  No building permit or certificate of occupancy shall be issued for any lot, parcel, plot of land or building site which was created by subdivision after the effective date of, and not in conformity with the provisions of these subdivision regulations, and no excavation of land or construction of any public or private improvements shall take place or be commenced except in conformity with these regulations. 
Sec. 1.4. - Purpose. 
    The purpose and intent of these regulations is to establish objective, citywide standards for public improvements and the subdivision of land within the City of Bessemer. These regulations are based upon the following elements: 
(1)  Proper, subdivision design criteria. 
(2)  The impact of development upon adjacent property. 
(3)  The definition of public and private development responsibilities. 
(4)  Concern for the health, safety and welfare of the entire city. 
(5)  Encouragement of an orderly and efficient development pattern. 
(6)  Coordination with other applicable ordinances and plans. 
SECTION 2. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 2.1. - Enforcement, violations and penalties. 
(1)  It shall be the duty of the City of Bessemer Building Official to enforce these regulations and to enforce these regulations and to bring to the attention of the Bessemer City Attorney any violations or lack of compliance herewith. 
(2)  No owner, or agent of the owner, of any parcel of land located in a proposed subdivision shall transfer or sell any such parcel before a final plat of such subdivision has been approved by the planning and zoning commission, in accordance with the provisions of these regulations, and filed with the Judge of Probate, Jefferson County. The description of metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer shall not exempt the transaction from these penalties. 
(3)  The penalty for transferring a lot in an unapproved subdivision shall be five hundred dollars for each lot or parcel so transferred or sold. The City of Bessemer may enjoin such transfer or sale or agreement by action for injunction brought in any court or equity jurisdiction or may recover the same penalty by a civil action in any court or [of] competent jurisdiction. 
Sec. 2.2. - Conflict with other laws. 
    Whenever the provisions of these regulations impose more restrictive standards than are required in or under any other ordinance, the regulations herein contained shall prevail. Whenever the provisions of any other ordinance requires more restrictive standards than are required herein, the requirements of such regulations shall prevail. 
Sec. 2.3. - Seperability. 
    If any section, clause or portion of these regulations shall be held by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unconstitutional, such findings shall not affect any other section, clause or portion of these regulations. 
Sec. 2.4. - Variances. 
(1)  Hardship. Where the planning and zoning commission finds that unusual hardship may result from strict compliance with these regulations, it may approve variances to these regulations so that substantial justice may be done, provided that such variation shall not have the effect of nullifying the intent or purpose of these regulations. 
(2)  Conditions for variance. The planning and zoning commission shall not approve variances unless it shall make findings based upon the evidence that presented to it in each specific case that: 
(a)  The granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public safety, health or welfare or injurious to other property. 
(b)  The conditions upon which the request for a variance is based are unique to the property for which the variance is sought and are not applicable generally to other property. 
(c)  Because of the particular physical surroundings, shape or topographical conditions of the property involved, a particular hardship to the owner would result, as distinguished from a mere inconvenience, if the strict letter of these regulations are carried out. 
(3)  Petition. A petition for such variance shall be submitted in writing by the subdivider at the time when the preliminary plat is filed for the consideration by the planning and zoning commission. The petition shall state fully the grounds for the application and all of the facts relied upon by the petitioner. 
(4)  Documentation. Any variance thus authorized shall be entered in writing in the minutes of the planning and zoning commission with the reason which justified the departure to be set forth. 
Sec. 2.5. - Amendment. 
    These regulations may be amended after notice and public hearing in the same manner as prescribed by law for their original adoption. 
Sec. 2.6. - Assurance for completion of improvements. 
(1)  General[ly]. The subdivider shall be responsible for the provision of all required improvements to the subdivision. This may be accomplished by either the full installation of all required improvements by the subdivider at the time the final plat is submitted to the planning and zoning commission, or by the provision of a financial guarantee of performance. 
(2)  Financial guarantee of performance. The guarantee of performance by the subdivider shall be in the form of a subdivision improvement bond or an [a] certificate of deposit, and shall meet the following requirements: 
(a)  Bond or certificate of deposit must be approved by the city engineer, and building official. 
(b)  Bond or CD must be in an amount not less than 200 percent of the total cost to cover the installation of all required roads, paving, and utilities and fees encountered in the completion of improvements. 
(3)  Failure to complete work. If within twelve months after filing said bond the subdivider has not completed all necessary improvements, or in the opinion of the planning and zoning commission said improvements have not been satisfactorily installed, the bond shall be used by the city to complete the improvements in a satisfactory manner, or the city may take such steps as may be necessary to require performance under the bond. 
(4)  Guarantee against faulty material. The planning and zoning commission may require a maintenance bond for five years for street construction maintenance and one year for sewer lines and other facilities if there is reasonable doubt concerning the stability or proper construction of any improvement required herein. This bond shall be made in cash or by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Alabama. 
Sec. 2.7. - Vacation of plat or map. 
(1)  Any plat or map, whether or not executed and recorded as provided in these regulations, may be vacated by the owner, his executor, administrator or guardian of the lands at any time before the sale of any lot therein by a written instrument declaring the same to be vacated, executed, acknowledged and recorded in like manner as conveyances of land which declaration, being duly recorded, shall operate to destroy the force and effect of the recording of the plat or map so vacated and to divest all public rights in the streets, alleys and public grounds and all dedications laid out or described in such plat or map. 
(2)  When lots have been sold, the plat or map may be vacated, in the manner herein provided by all the owners of lots in such plat or map joining in the execution of such writing. 
SECTION 3. - DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 3.1. - Usage. 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided herein, all words shall have the customary dictionary meaning. 
(2)  The present tense includes the future tense. The singular number included [includes] the plural, and the plural includes the singular. 
(3)  The word "person" includes a firm, corporation, association, organization, trust or partnership. The word "lot" include[s] "plot" or "parcel." The word "building" includes "structure". The word "shall" is mandatory. The word "may" is permissive. 
Sec. 3.2. - Specific definitions. 
(1)  Alley. A minor public way designed to afford a secondary means of access to abutting properties. 
(2)  Arterial streets. Those which serve the major traffic movements and which provide intracommunity continuity but do not penetrate identifiable neighborhoods. 
(3)  Block. A tract of land bounded by streets, or a combination of streets and public parks, cemeteries, railroad rights-of-way, shorelines of waterways, or boundary lines of municipalities or counties. 
(4)  Building official. The duly designated building official of the City of Bessemer, Alabama. 
(5)  Building setback line. A line parallel to the property line in front of which no structure may be erected. 
(6)  City. The City of Bessemer, Alabama. 
(7)  City attorney. The licensed attorney designated by the city commission to furnish legal assistance for the administration of these regulations. 
(8)  City clerk. The duly designated clerk of the City of Bessemer, Alabama. 
(9)  City commission. The city commission of the City of Bessemer, Alabama. 
(10)  City engineer. The duly designated engineer of the City of Bessemer, Alabama. 
(11)  City specifications. All construction specifications or codes which have been adopted by the city commission or as required by the planning and zoning commission. 
(12)  Collector streets. Those which collect traffic from local streets to the arterial streets by providing both land access and traffic circulation within neighborhoods and commercial and industrial areas. 
(13)  Corner lot. A lot abutting upon two or more streets at their intersection. 
(14)  Cul-de-sac. A local street with only one outlet and designed to have one end permanently closed; the closed end terminated by a vehicular turnaround. 
(15)  Double frontage lot. A lot having frontage on two non-intersecting streets as distinguished from a corner lot. 
(16)  Easement. A grant of rights by the property owner for use of a strip of land for specific purposes. 
(17)  Final plat. A plat of a tract of land which meets the requirements of these regulations and is in form for recording in the office of Probate Judge, Jefferson County. 
(18)  Fire chief. The duly designated fire chief of the City of Bessemer, Alabama. 
(19)  Group development. A development comprising two or more structures, built on a single lot, tract or parcel of land, and designed for occupancy by separate families, firms or other enterprises. 
(20)  Half-street. A street which does not meet the minimum right-of-way widths set forth in these regulations. 
(21)  Health department. The Jefferson County Department of Health. 
(22)  Local street. Those intended to provide access to abutting properties and to other streets. 
(23)  Lot. A parcel of land having its principal frontage on a public street and intended for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership or for building development. 
(23A)  Lot, interior. A parcel of commercial or industrial property not having its principal frontage on a public street. Any subdivision or resubdivision having an interior lot shall be considered by the planning and zoning commission for approval on a case by case basis. Minimum access, lot sizes, and dimensions requirements shall be met for all interior lots in accordance with land parcel zoning. 
(24)  Open space. Any land either publicly or privately owned which is designated as being permanently undeveloped and used for recreation, conservation or preservation. 
(25)  Owner's engineer. The engineer or land surveyor registered and in good standing with the State Board of Registration of Alabama who is the agent in his professional capacity of the owner of land which is proposed to be subdivided or which is in the process of being subdivided. 
(26)  Planning and zoning commission. The planning and zoning commission of the City of Bessemer, Alabama. 
(27)  Preliminary plat. The preliminary drawing(s), described in these regulations, indicating the proposed layout of the subdivision. 
(28)  Right-of-way. A strip of land separate and distinct from the lots adjoining such right-of-way and not included within the dimensions or areas of such lots, which is occupied or intended to be occupied by a street, crosswalk, railroad, road, electric transmission line, oil or gas pipeline, water main, sanitary or storm sewer main, or for another special use. 
(29)  Subdivider. The person(s), firms(s), or corporation(s) engaged in the process of creating a subdivision or having completed a subdivision. 
(30)  Subdivision. The division of a lot, tract or parcel or land into two or more lots, plats, sites, or other divisions of land for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of subdividing or re-subdividing. Also, when appropriate, this term includes changing of lot size, alteration or relocation of private or public streets and alleys, and extension of major locations. 
(31)  Zoning ordinance. The official zoning ordinance, as amended, of the City of Bessemer, Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 3526, § I, 10-21-2014) 
SECTION 4. - SUBDIVISION APPLICATION PROCEDURE AND APPROVAL PROCESS 

Sec. 4.1. - Applicability. 
    The following may be exempted within the definition of subdivision or be subject to the requirements thereof: the city engineer and zoning administrator may exempt the following parcel divisions if divisions shall not have negative effects on traffic, drainage, utility service or public safety. 
(1)  The original parcel being divided into no more than two tracts with no street construction, utility installation or other public improvements involved. Any further division of this original tract will require a recording of a subdivision plat. 
(2)  The division of land into parcels greater than ten acres where no street construction, utility installation, or other public improvements involved. Any further division will require a recording of a subdivision plat. 
(3)  Where property is divided by probated family estates. 
Sec. 4.2. - General procedure. 
    Whenever any subdivision of land is proposed, before any contract is made for the sale of any part thereof, and before any permit for the erection of a structure in such proposed subdivision shall be granted, the subdivider shall apply for and secure approval of such proposed subdivision in accordance with the following procedure: 
(1)  The preparation and submission to the planning and zoning commission of a preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision. 
(2)  The preparation and submission to the planning and zoning commission of a final plat, with required certificates. This final plat becomes the document to be recorded in the office of Judge of Probate, Jefferson County, when duly signed by the chairman of the planning and zoning commission and by the city clerk. 
Sec. 4.3. - Preliminary plat. 
(1)  Application procedure. 
(a)  Before preparing the preliminary plat for a subdivision, the subdivider should discuss with the building official the procedure for adoption of a subdivision plat and the design requirements. The building inspector shall also advise the subdivider to discuss the proposed subdivision with the city engineer. 
(b)  The application for approval of a preliminary plat shall be made on a form available from the building inspector (see appendix [1A]). 
(c)  The application, including five prints of the subdivision plan, shall be submitted to the building official at least 22 days prior to the planning and zoning commission's regularly scheduled meeting. A fee of $100.00 is due at the time [of] submission. 
(2)  Contents. The preliminary plat, which shall meet the minimum standards of design and the general requirements for the construction of public improvements set forth in these regulations, shall contain the following information: 
(a)  [Vicinity sketch map.] Vicinity sketch map, at a scale of one inch equal 2,000 feet showing the following: 
1.  Name of subdivision. 
2.  Names, addresses and telephone numbers of owner(s) and person(s) responsible for subdivision design. 
3.  Description of property location by section, township, range, 1/4, 1/4 graphic scale, north arrow and date. 
4.  Location of streets and other general development of the surrounding area. 
5.  Boundaries and approximate dimensions. 
6.  Amount of acreage to be subdivided. 
7.  Major arterial streets, utilities and community facilities (shopping areas, schools, parks, hospitals, churches, etc.). 
(b)  [Preliminary sketch plan.] Preliminary sketch plan of subdivision at a scale of not more than one inch equals 100 feet showing the following: 
1.  Name of subdivision. 
2.  Names, addresses and telephone numbers of owner(s) and person(s) responsible for subdivision design. 
3.  Description of property location by section, township and range; graphic scale; north arrow; and date. 
4.  Amount of acreage to be subdivided. 
5.  Topography at two-foot contour intervals. 
6.  The approximate location, dimensions and areas in square feet of all existing and proposed lots. 
7.  Names and location of all existing and proposed streets within the subdivision and adjacent to it. 
8.  Location of and widths of all existing and proposed street rights-of-way within the subdivision. 
9.  Plans and profiles showing the locations and typical cross-section of street pavements including curbs and gutters, sidewalks, easements, rights-of-way, manholes and catch basins. 
10.  Profiles showing existing and proposed elevations along center lines of all streets. Where a proposed street intersects an existing road, the elevation along the center line of the existing road within 100 feet of the intersection shall be shown. 
11.  Profiles showing approximate radii of all curves, lengths of tangents and central angles on all streets. 
12.  The location and dimensions of all building setback lines along each street. 
13.  Preliminary proposals for utilities showing connections to existing water supply and sanitary sewage systems. When such connections are not practical, all proposed individual water supply and sewage systems shall have the approval of the Jefferson County Department of Health. 
14.  The location and sizes of all proposed culverts, storm sewers, inlets and drainage facilities. 
15.  The location, width and purpose of all easements. 
16.  The approximate location, dimensions and area of all parcels of land proposed to be dedicated or reserved for parks, schools, open space or other public use; and conditions, if any, of the dedication or reservation. 
17.  The existing zoning classification of the subdivision and adjacent land. 
18.  A fire protection plan showing the location and size of all existing and proposed water lines and fire hydrants. 
19.  Assurances that the provisions of the latest Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways will be adhered to during construction. Detail plan may be required by city engineer. 
20.  Provide information as shown on city engineer's checklist. 
(3)  Review process. 
(a)  At least 15 days prior to the regularly scheduled planning and zoning commission meeting and public hearing, the building official shall transmit copies of the preliminary plat to the city engineer, fire chief, and any other applicable city or county official for review and recommendations. 
(b)  A public hearing shall be held at the regularly scheduled planning and zoning commission meeting. Such hearing shall be advertised in the manner as the provisions of section 11-52-77 of the Code of Alabama, 1975 [Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-77]. 
(4)  Approval. 
(a)  The planning and zoning commission shall approve, approve subject to modifications, or disapprove the preliminary plat within 30 days after the date of its regularly scheduled meeting at which time the public hearing was held. 
(b)  The recommendations of the city engineer, fire chief, and any other applicable city or county official concerning the preliminary plat shall be reviewed by the planning and zoning commission before action is taken. 
(c)  One copy of the preliminary plat shall be retained by the building inspector for the official planning and zoning commission files and one copy shall be returned to the subdivider with the date of approval, approval with modifications, or disapproval and the reasons therefore accompanying the plat. 
(d)  The approval of a preliminary plat shall be effective for a period of one year at the end of which time final approval on the subdivision must have been obtained from the planning and zoning commission. Any plat not receiving final approval within the period of time set forth herein shall be null and void, and the subdivider shall be required to resubmit a new plat for preliminary approval subject to all new zoning restrictions and subdivision regulations. 
Sec. 4.4. - Final plat. 
(1)  Application procedure. 
(a)  The application for approval of a final plat shall be made on a form available from the building inspector (see appendix [1B]). 
(b)  The application, including five copies of the original plat done on Mylar and in black ink, shall be submitted to the building official at least 22 days prior to the planning and zoning commission's regularly scheduled meeting. 
(c)  The final plat shall be drawn to a scale of not more than one inch equals 100 feet, on sheets not larger than 42 inches wide. When more than one sheet is required, an index sheet of the same size shall be filed as a key, showing the entire subdivision. 
(2)  Contents. The final plat shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat as approved, and shall contain the following information: 
(a)  [Vicinity sketch map.] Vicinity sketch map, at a scale of one inch equals 2,000 feet showing the same information as the preliminary plat, with modified date, may be used. 
(b)  [Final plat.] Final plat of subdivision at a scale of not more than one inch equals 100 feet showing the following: 
1.  Name of subdivision. 
2.  Names, addresses and telephone numbers of owner(s) and person(s) responsible for subdivision design. 
3.  Description of property location by 1/4, 1/4 section, township and range; graphic scale; north arrow; and date. 
4.  Names and location of all streets within the subdivision and adjacent to it. 
5.  Names, location and width of all streets and other rights-of-way within the subdivision. 
6.  Lot numbers in numerical order for all lots. 
7.  House numbers for all lots. 
8.  Dimensions to the nearest one tenth of one foot, bearings of all angles to the nearest one minute, and location which can be reproduced on the ground for the following information: 
a.  Lot lines; 
b.  Boundary lines; 
c.  Block lines; 
d.  Building setback lines; 
e.  Street lines. 
9.  Location, width and purpose of all utility and other easements. 
10.  Location and description of all monuments for lot and right-of-way boundaries. 
11.  Double land tie to government survey. 
(c)  [Certifications.] Certifications regarding the following: 
1.  Certification that the subdivider is the legal owner of the land. 
2.  Certification of formal irrevocable offer of formal dedication of streets, rights-of-way and other sites for public use. 
3.  Certification by the owner's engineer of the accuracy of the plat. 
4.  Certification of approval by health department or environmental services for sewage disposal. 
5.  Certification by the city engineer and building official complied with one of the following: 
a.  Installed all improvements according to these regulations. 
b.  Posted a surety bond or certificate of deposit, in an amount sufficient to assure the completion of all required improvements. 
(d)  [Restrictive covenants.] Restrictive covenants that apply to the subdivision shall be submitted with the final plat. 
(3)  Review process. 
(a)  At least 15 days prior to the regularly scheduled meeting of the planning and zoning commission, the building official shall transmit copies of the final plat to the city engineer and any other applicable city or county official for review and recommendations. 
(b)  The recommendations of the city engineer and any other applicable city or county official concerning the final plat shall be reviewed by the planning and zoning commission before action is taken. 
(4)  Approval. 
(a)  The planning and zoning commission shall approve or disapprove the final plat within 30 days after the date of its regularly scheduled meeting at which the final plat is introduced. 
(b)  If the final plat is disapproved, the reasons therefor shall be stated in the official minutes of the planning and zoning commission. 
(c)  If the final plat is approved, a certificate of planning and zoning commission approval shall be executed (see appendix [1B]), and one copy of the certificate and final plat filed by the building inspector with the Judge of Probate, Jefferson County, within 30 days after acceptance by the city council of the various dedications, including subdivision streets, as public property. 
(d)  The original of the final plat with the planning and zoning commission resolution shall be returned to the subdivider while one copy shall be maintained in the files of the planning and zoning commission and the city engineer. 
Sec. 4.5. - Acceptance of streets and other public ways. 
    Approval of the final plat by the planning and zoning commission shall not constitute acceptance by the public of the dedication of any street or other public way or ground. After approval of the final plat and the construction of streets shown thereon, the city engineer may recommend to the city council that it accept these streets as public roads and other ways or grounds as public facilities and take over their perpetual maintenance. 
SECTION 5. - DESIGN STANDARDS FOR STREETS 

Sec. 5.1. - Inspection. 
(1)  The city engineer shall approve the proposed grades, type of paving, size of drainage structures, and any or all other engineering problems involved therein before a subdivider commences to grade or pave streets within a subdivision. 
(2)  Before construction of streets, the city engineer shall be notified no less than 24 hours in advance of any phase of operation to be started. 
(3)  The base shall be inspected and installed under the direction of the city engineer. 
(4)  No paving shall be installed until the base is approved. 
(5)  No paving shall be installed until approval is given as to type of paving and materials used. 
(6)  In cases in which the city engineer has reasonable doubt concerning the stability or proper construction of any streets, he may require that after installation of the binder course that the seal course of bituminous pavement be delayed for a period of minimum of six months. 
Sec. 5.2. - Topography and arrangement. 
(1)  All streets shall be designed along contour elevations which will result in minimum grades and greatest visibility whenever practicable with consideration given to the anticipated use of the land. Grades of streets shall conform as closely as possible to the original topography. 
(2)  The proposed street layout shall be made according to sound land planning principles for the type of development proposed. 
(3)  Local and collector streets shall be laid out to discourage use by through traffic, to permit efficient drainage and utility systems, and to require the minimum number of streets necessary to provide convenient and safe access to property. 
(4)  Existing streets and right-of-way which are proposed to be retained shall be incorporated into the street system so as not to cause hazardous conditions. 
(5)  Proposed streets shall be extended to the boundary lines of the tract to be subdivided, unless prevented by topography of other physical conditions, or unless in the opinion of the city engineer and planning and zoning commission such extension is not necessary or desirable for the coordination of the layout of the subdivision with the existing layout or the most advantageous future development of adjacent tracts. 
(6)  Where a proposed subdivision has no frontage on an existing public road or public right-of-way, the subdivider must provide and dedicate to the city a suitable right-of-way for ingress and egress. This connecting road becomes part of the street system of the proposed subdivision and is subject to all regulations regarding streets. 
(7)  The arrangement of streets shall provide for the continuation of principal streets between adjacent properties when such continuation is necessary for convenient movement of traffic, effective fire protection, or for efficient provision of utilities. If the adjacent property is undeveloped and the street must be a dead-end street temporarily, the right-of-way shall be extended to the property line. A temporary cul-de-sac turnabout shall be provided on all temporary dead-end streets, with the notation on the subdivision plat that land outside the normal street right-of-way shall revert to abuttors whenever the street is continued. The planning and zoning commission may limit the length of temporary dead-end streets in accordance with the design standards of these regulations. 
(8)  Where a road does not extend to the boundary of the subdivision and its continuation is not required by the planning and zoning commission for access to adjoining property, its terminus shall normally not be nearer to such boundary than 50 feet. However, the planning and zoning commission may require the reservation of an appropriate easement to accommodate drainage facilities, pedestrian traffic or utilities. A cul-de-sac turnaround shall be provided at the end of a permanent dead-end street in accordance with the design standards of these regulations. For convenience to traffic and more effective police and fire protection, permanent dead-end streets shall, in general, be limited to 750 in length. 
Sec. 5.3. - Intersections. 
(1)  Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at right angles and in no case at an angle of less than 75 degrees. An easement radius may be required by the city engineer for intersections having an interior angle of less than 90 degrees. 
(2)  Intersections involving more than four basic street legs or approaches shall be prohibited. Merging lanes, deceleration lanes, "Y" intersections, and traffic circles are not included in this prohibition but are considered as being parts of one street leg or approach. 
(3)  Opposing intersections shall be placed opposite each other where practical or placed at a minimum of 150 feet apart, except where the intersected street has separated dual drives without median breaks at either intersection. 
(4)  Minimum curb radius at all intersections shall be at least 15 feet unless a different figure is expressly approved by the city engineer because of special topographical considerations or sound engineering practices. 
(5)  Intersections should be planned and located to provide as much sight distance as possible. In achieving a safe highway design, as a minimum, there should be sufficient sight distance for the driver on the local or collector street to cross an arterial without requiring approaching traffic to reduce speed. 
(6)  The vertical alignment in the intersection area should be as flat as possible. Where the grade of any street at the approach to an intersection exceeds three percent, a leveling area shall be provided, having not greater than a three percent grade for a distance of fifty feet from the intersection of the street centerline. 
Sec. 5.4. - Street right-of-way widths. 
(1)  The planning and zoning commission shall determine the classification of city streets. 
(2)  Minimum widths of right-of-way are as follows: 
Street Classification Minimum 
Right-of-Way 
Width 
(in feet) Alley 20 Local 50 Collector 50 Arterial or commercial/industrial 80 Cul-de-sac 50  
(3)  Subdivisions that adjoin existing streets shall dedicate additional right-of-way to meet the minimum right-of-way width requirements. 
(a)  The entire right-of-way shall be provided where any part of the subdivision is located on both sides of the existing streets. 
(b)  When the subdivision is located on only one side of an existing street, a sufficient amount of right-of-way shall be provided by the applicant in order to meet the right-of-way requirements. 
Sec. 5.5. - Street pavement widths. 
    Minimum pavement widths are as follows: 
Street Classification Minimum 
Pavement Width 
(Lane) Alley 10 feet Local 24 feet Collector 24 feet Arterial or commercial/industrial 24 feet Cul-de-sac 40 feet 
(radius)  
Sec. 5.6. - Street grades and vertical alignment. 
(1)  The grades for all streets shall not exceed 15 percent or be less than one percent. 
(2)  The maximum street grade is as follows: 
Street Classification Minimum 
Right-of-Way 
Width Alley 8% Local 15% Collector 12% Arterial or commercial/industrial 8%  
(3)  Grades approaching intersections shall not exceed three percent for a distance of 50 feet from the intersection of the street centerline. 
(4)  Vertical curves shall be used at all changes of grade exceeding one percent and shall be designed with equal tangents in order to avoid hazardous profiles. 
(5)  Proper drainage shall be provided at the low point in vertical curves. 
Sec. 5.7. - Cross slope. 
(1)  On streets in tangent alignment the high point of the road shall be at the center of the pavement. 
(2)  On typical asphalt treated seal coats, the cross slope from the center line shall be 1/4" per foot. On other types of surfacing, the cross slope shall be determined by the city engineer. 
Sec. 5.8. - Horizontal curvature for streets. 
(1)  All streets shall have a minimum radius of curvature of 250 feet. 
Sec. 5.9. - Super elevation. 
(1)  Super elevation shall normally be used on curves to aid the vehicle in negotiating the curve. 
(2)  The maximum rate of super elevation cross slope shall not exceed 8 percent. The centerline of the street shall normally be used for the axis of rotation. 
(3)  Care shall be taken to avoid drainage pockets in the low points of the super elevation. 
(4)  The transition from a crown slope to super elevation shall be determined by standard engineering practice. 
Sec. 5.10. - Sight distance. 
(1)  Stopping. 
(a)  The minimum stopping sight distance is the distance required by the driver of the vehicle to a complete stop after an object in the street ahead becomes visible. Stopping sight distance is measured from the driver's eye's, which are assumed to be 3.75 feet above the street surface, to an object 6 inches high on the street surface ahead. 
(b)  The minimum stopping sight distances for design of all two-lane streets shall be determined by the city engineer. 
Design Speed 
(MPH) Minimum Stopping 
Sight Distance 
(feet) 25 175 30 200 35 230 40 275 45 310 50 350 55 415  
(2)  Passing. 
(a)  Passing sight distance is the minimum sight distance that enables a driver to safely pass another vehicle without interfering with oncoming traffic traveling at the designed speed. The sight distance available for passing is the longest distance at which a driver whose eyes are 3.75 feet above the street can see the top of an object 4.5 feet above the street surface ahead. 
(b)  The minimum passing sight distance shall be determined by the city engineer. 
Design Speed 
(MPH) Minimum Stopping 

Sight Distance 

(feet) 25 900 30 1,100 35 1,300 40 1,500 50 1,800 55 1,900  
Sec. 5.11. - Alleys. 
(1)  Alleys may be required in commercial and industrial districts to facilitate access to parking, loading, and service points. 
(2)  Alleys are not permitted in residential districts, except when the planning and zoning commission determines that special conditions warrant a secondary means of access. 
Sec. 5.12. - Road surfacing. 
(1)  Applicability. A permanent type paving shall be applied to all streets in a proposed subdivision. 
(2)  Subgrade. 
(a)  The subgrade shall be thoroughly compacted and shaped prior to application of the base. 
(b)  The subgrade where Portland cement paving is to be used shall be brought to a firm and unyielding condition with a uniform density of 95 percent proctor. 
(c)  The city engineer shall have the subgrade roll tested at the developers cost and approved prior to base placement. 
(3)  Base. 
(a)  The city engineer shall determine if a special base is required for Portland cement concrete surfaced streets. 
(b)  The base materials for asphalt surfaced roads shall be approved, as to mixture and durability, by the city engineer. 
(c)  The base material shall be spread without segregation in a loose maximum eight-inch lift and shall be compacted by vibratory, steel wheel rollers or other approved rollers to a maximum density of 95 percent proctor. Additional depth of base material may be required because of anticipated traffic. 
(d)  The base shall be inspected and installed under the direction of the city engineer and no surfacing shall be installed until the base has been approved by the city engineer. 
(4)  Asphalt surfacing. 
(a)  A minimum of a two inch hot bituminous plant mixed binder layer shall be placed on the approved base. 
(b)  A minimum of a (11/2) hot bituminous wearing surface shall be placed on the approved binder layer after approval of the city engineer. 
(c)  A triple surface treatment type paving (bituminous surface treatment) may be used in lieu of plant mix binder and seal when approved by the city engineer. The type and rate of application for the prime, seal and aggregate shall be approved by the city engineer and shall conform to the latest edition of Alabama State Highway Department Regulations and Specifications. 
(5)  Portland cement concrete paving. 
(a)  A minimum of six-inch Portland cement concrete pavement without reinforcement shall be constructed in one course on a prepared sub grade (and base if required) after approval by the city engineer. 
(b)  Installation shall meet the requirements for strength, surface finish and joints as determined by the city engineer. 
Sec. 5.13. - Curb and gutter, valley gutter, sidewalks. 
(1)  The city engineer shall approve the location of curb and gutter, valley gutter, and sidewalks. 
(2)  Curb and gutter, and valley gutter shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete constructed on a prepared sub grade and shall conform to the cross-sections depicted in appendix [1C]. 
(3)  Sidewalks, when required, shall be a minimum of four feet wide in residential and eight feet wide in commercial areas. The cross-section for a sidewalk is located in appendix [1C]. 
(4)  Installation of curb and gutter, valley gutter and sidewalks shall meet the requirements for strength, surface finish and joints as determined by the city engineer. 
(5)  Sidewalks shall meet the requirements of the latest ADA Laws. 
Sec. 5.14. - Driveway access. 
(1)  Applications for all new accesses to streets within the city shall be made to the city engineer. The proposed location, width, drainage structure, traffic condition, site distance and surfacing shall be included in the access application. 
(2)  Entrances shall be located at points affording maximum sight distances and minimum grades. Entrances shall not be less than 10 feet no more than 20 feet width, measured at the right-of-way line. Entrances shall be located so that the curb openings are a minimum of five feet from the nearest edge of a street drainage inlet and 50 feet from the corner radius. More restrictive requirements may be required by the city engineer for commercial and industrial entrances. The cross-section for a standard driveway turnout is included in appendix [1C]. 
(3)  Commercial and industrial entrances shall not be more than 35 feet or less than 24 feet in width measured at the right-of-way line. The radius to increase the opening shall not be less than 15 but not more than 25 feet. Larger radius to accommodate truck traffic may be required by the city engineer. The distance between openings shall be a minimum of 150 feet and the distance opening from corner radius shall be 50 feet. 
Sec. 5.15. - Street names and signs. 
(1)  Street names, subdivision names and apartment project names shall be sufficiently different I sound and in spelling from other street names in the city so as not to cause confusion. The building official shall consult the postmaster before approval is given by the planning and zoning commission. 
(2)  The subdivider shall deposit with the city at the time of final plat approval the cost of traffic control devices, and street signs as determined by city engineer and street department director. 
(3)  The city shall install all street signs before issuance of certificates of occupancy for any residences on the streets approved. 
Sec. 5.16. - Streetlights. 
    Streetlights may be required by the planning and zoning commission and shall be installed in accordance with design and specification standards approved by the city engineer and electric service manager. 
SECTION 6. - DESIGN STANDARDS FOR BLOCKS 

Sec. 6.1. - General. 
    The general length, width and shape of blocks shall be determined with due regard to the followings: 
(1)  Provision of adequate building sited suitable to the special needs of the type of use planned. 
(2)  Zoning ordinance and health department requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions. 
(3)  Need for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street traffic. 
(4)  Limitations and opportunities of the topography and other physical features. 
Sec. 6.2. - Block width. 
    Blocks shall have sufficient width to provide for two tiers of lots of appropriate depths. Exceptions to this prescribed block width shall be permitted in blocks adjacent to major streets, railroads, or waterways. 
Sec. 6.3. - Block length. 
    Block lengths shall not be less than 400 feet nor more than 1,600 feet in length. 
Sec. 6.4. - Pedestrian crosswalks. 
    Crosswalks, not less than 10 feet wide, may be required by the planning and zoning commission through the center of blocks more than 800 feet long where deemed essential to provide circulation or access to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers, transportation or other community facilities. All crossings shall meet the requirements of the latest version of the MUTCD. 
SECTION 7. - DESIGN STANDARDS FOR LOTS 

Sec. 7.1. - Lot dimensions. 
(1)  Lot dimensions shall conform to the requirements of the zoning ordinance and the health department. In cases where the requirements conflict, the more strict requirement shall be followed. 
(2)  Where lots are more than double the minimum required area for the zoning district, the planning and zoning commission may require that such lots be arranged so as to allow further subdivision and the opening of future streets where they would be necessary to serve such potential lots, all in compliance with the zoning ordinance and these regulations. 
(3)  Side lot lines shall normally be at right angles to streets, except on curves where they shall be redial. 
(4)  Additional depth may be required on lots which back up to railroads, major streets, or other conflicting land uses. 
Sec. 7.2. - Double and reverse frontage lots. 
    Double frontage and reverse frontage lots shall be avoided, except where essential to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries, or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. 
Sec. 7.3. - Access. 
(1)  All lots for detached houses shall abut a public street. 
(2)  Where driveway access from an arterial street may be necessary for several adjoining lots, the planning and zoning commission may require that such lots be served by a combined access drive in order to limit the possible traffic hazard on such street. 
(3)  Where possible, driveways should be designed and arranged so as to avoid requiring vehicles to back into traffic on arterial streets. 
(4)  In special circumstances, a private access easement may be necessary to provide access to a parcel of commercial or industrial property that does not abut a public right-of-way (an "interior lot"). Access to commercial or industrial lots by private easement shall be approved only by specific action of the planning and zoning commission. In these special private access easement cases the following conditions shall apply: 
(A)  A single private access easement shall provide access for no more than eight lots. 
(B)  The property owner seeking access shall provide the planning and zoning commission a valid legal instrument, recorded in the office of the judge of probate, indicating ownership of the access easement a minimum of 20 feet in width or as required by the fire marshall and city engineer in cases where easement width may exceed the 20-foot minimum. 
(C)  The property owner shall provide a title insurance binder or commitment for title insurance from an insuring company within the State of Alabama for the property as described in the easement. 
(D)  The private access easement must be in a suitable form as approved by the city attorney. 
(E)  A statement on the filed record plat shall state the recorded access easement recording numbers, that the City of Bessemer has no obligation to repair or maintain the access in a suitable condition and that the City of Bessemer or agents shall not be liable for injuries to person or damage to property resulting from the site's lack of direct access to a public road. 
(Ord. No. 3526, § II, 10-21-2014) 
Sec. 7.4. - Property markers.
